content:
Posted: August 2, 2014
Oh dear!I played all of the Arkham series' games so far, knew this wasn't made by Rocksteady, came in with low expectations and really didn't intend to review like "Oh, this is the reason, why Rocksteady made it all better..." - but sadly, it turns out to be like this. And you cannot only blame the time limit or tight budgets: Someone really didn't get it at all and I am really shocked one is capable of ♥♥♥♥ing up such a wonderful game so badly.in shortThe main criticism and a heavy one is, that besides an absolutely lame patch work of a story (which is forgiveable), you are forced to do anything the way the game designers want you to. Choice is completely gone and to top that up, the game mechanics are horribly messed up. The first game ever, I vote down - not that it is the worst game ever, but starting from Arkham City it is the worst bootleg, I have ever had to play. Don't buy it and play another round of Batman AC instead!in detailstoryWhen reps of Warner were questioned about the lack of new stuff in the game, they responded by "Oh, but the story - so amazing twists!" Now, we know for sure, this was a standard marketing phrase and nothing else: The story is non-existent and the "twist" doesn't matter at all and it just shows that someone had no clue about story-telling whatsoever. AC had a carefully crafted story there the twist was shocking and turned the story upside down and up again. Here, it just loosely connects the Combat and Predator maps. The introduction of some of the side missions is especially bad: Either it is a glitch and just some audio missing or it goes like: "Oh, I have to do X and Y now, in order to achieve Z!" - completely out of the blue, by just passing areas, w/o logical connection to it. The same goes for the (very short) main story.side questsThis was the only downside to Arkham City, because most of them were really forgettable and in this respect AO is stronger (by sacrificing the main story for it). They are not as "cinematique" as the Cold Call Killer or Tea Party in Wonderland, but they are far superior over the rest of the AC's ones and I like the way the Anarky mission combines gliding and combat skills. gameplayThis is the most important, but also the worst part of this game and the reason why it is so unenjoyable. I would forgive everything else, but this is the main reason for voting it down:The combat mechanics are awful; especially concerning enemy AI's strikes: Sometimes (unlike both AA and AC), they withdraw a strike and you end up loosing the combo because of countering thin air. Also, it seems like you can (hardly) evade over red and yellow strike alert flashes: In AC I could strike an enemy even while he flashes yellow or evade a red one (unless armed, which you can strike), this doesn't work here.The special combo moves "trigger" only in a far smaller area around the enemy and hence you have to be far more precise. In addition to that, if you choose the wrong special combo, there is no automatic replacement (unlike AC, where a Disarm & Destroy turned into a Special Combo Takedown, etc., if the opponent was unarmed).On Predator, enemies are more sound aware than before, some of the chambers have an interesting design. Generally, there is a greater quantity of enemies in the Single Player campaign. In the Challenge maps, it is like in AA and AC.Deathstroke plays like a combination of Robin and Nightwing and is horribly underpowered in Predator as well as in Combat Challenges - not a nice experience.The Shock Glove is the game's combat novelty. Due to its non-permanent nature, it is rather a plus than a minus to the game and one doesn't have to use them, if you wanna play "old school".The new kid on the Predator block is the Remote Batclaw: Well, we didn't really need it, but I guess more useful than  Nightwing's Escrima sticks.What makes this claw so bad, is the navigational aspect to it: It replaces the Line Launcher and the Tight Rope completely and thus forces the player to use the intended path and no other! I could line-launch anywhere I wanted to - no more! As well, if there was a ladder and a grappling spot in AA or AC, I could use both options. In AO again, the game forces you to  use the predescribed method. You cannot grapple freely at all and sometimes for absolutely no reason and w/o explanation, the level design changes. Particulary, I am thinking about a mini campaign styled side quest, where Predator comes first and Combat therafter and from one second to the other, after the cut scene, the gargoyles are gone!Why, why the hack don't you let it be the players's choice, whether he wants to engage a small combat map in a Predator like style or vice versa? - This made AA and more so AC so enjoyable: That I had so many chocies.And Firefly! How can you turn away the opportunity to having the ultimate Predator challenge with a boss capable of using high ground and turning sneaking into a nightmare? Instead, it's just a Poison Ivy and Joker AA type of fight combined with cut scenes. The other assassins aren't much better: Either, a Harley Quinn's Revenge/Catwoman & Twoface type of Predator challenge or a non-existent fight by simply using Quickfire Gadgets (2 assassins). One fight was more or less completely scripted, but ok since it just happened once. In AC, I could play the game "the hard" or the relaxed way, however I wanted it to. Here, they are desperately trying to make the game harder than AC by not permitting certain options or putting more enemies out there.Another aspect of this is the completely messed up XP progress tree, which seems not to understand the subtle mechanics of AC: What's the point in unlocking basic upgrades only after half way/two thirds into the game? Isn't that again my own choice - or not?The new type of enemies aren't bad, though too much of the same. I like the Martial Artists; nice evolution of the Female Assassin of AC. The Enforcer is like an AC lieutenant and more combo breaking than that.  Preferred the Roman Abramovic Twin's gameplay mechanics.The lovely Riddler questions are gone (too complicated and love to detail would be needed) and are replaced by Anarky Tag's, which is another mere Collectible.graphics/designCheapish compared to AC. More ain't always better and this counts especially for AO: AC was carefully crafted and you could see the love and detail. Especially the colour scheme was amazing and left you marvelling in a bright phantasy world. AO drowned now in an uninspired shade of grey. Like playing AC on lowest settings w/o any special effects to it. The special flair to each district is gone and grappling points aren't clear at all (i.e. some water towers work, some don't).One area around the electricity company with a non-grapple zone was nice though.The tab menu is horribly complicated now and stuffed with cryptical icons lacking any explanation (mouse hovering/clicking not possible) - again, for no reason.bugs/techmany minor bugs and glitches as in premature triggering of events (Case File A's second task triggered before the first one), some keys don't work properly (i.e. turning off the Cryptographic Sequencer). There are also some critical bugs which freeze the game completely (not sure, whether game or Steam overlay related). final verdictBuy only on a at least 75% off sale, if you really wanna play this game. You don't miss anything.

												I wouldn't believe the reviews that said this game was mediocre, so I bought it. I'm sorry to report that most reviews were pretty accurate. Most of the technical problems reported were fixed by the developer, but there are a few kinks here and there (that weren't in the last two games).

Posted: September 15, 2014
												This game is great!I have played both previous versions and enjoy everyone of them.  Arkham Origins is far bigger than its predecessors, and plays pretty much the same.  I found the story mode a lot better than Arkham City, and a lot longer than Arkham Asylum. The mission path is easier to fulfill and i never really strayed.   Completing the game was easier to do than leaving untouched missions as i did in City.  However one thing that got on my nerves was the combat sequence.  The mechanics are great, but begun to get repetitive and became quite a chore.   Even so the rest of the gameplay was great and collecting all the collectables seems to be a lot better to seek out than Arkham City.   One new feature that wasn't in the previous installments is the crime scene investigations.  This feature is great, and like the whole sequences it plays out.  Unfortunately there wasn't many of them to do, more of these and less combat would of been great.I have given the challenges a go but find this crazy repetitive when going from one challenge to another.  Nothing really keeps me wanting more in this mode.  Just get more frustrated when you miss the counter and the combo counter resets, gggrrrrrr!Anyhow i recommend anybody who has played Batman Arkham City or Asylum to give this a go, its got all the goodness from previous installments and graphically is really good.7.5/10

content:
Posted: June 20, 2014
												Arkham Origins is, unfortunately, sort of the black sheep of the Arkham Games. What with it not being made by Rocksteady while they worked on Arkham Knight, Origins was put out by Splash Damage Studios instead. And it is, to some degree, underrated. While Arkham Asylum was excellent and Arkham City was good, Origins falls further behind and winds up in the realm of "Better than average", but it is still decent. Everything you liked about Arkham Asylum or Arkham City is still here, mostly. The problem is that Origins somewhat coasts off the success of the Asylum and City, and suffers from a lack of any new cards to throw down.On the gameplay front, combat has been improved once again, but it's gotten around to where it has inevitably become repetitive. And the entire map does feel somewhat lazily designed, as no less than half of it is copied over from Arkham City, right down to the Steel Mill section. Side missions are also making their return, although not quite as much of a spectacle. What is new is the crime scene missions, which are a welcome addition using Batman's crime reconstruction technology, although the number of them makes them go on a bit too long and a bit too short each to be truly entertaining. Boss fights haven't been copied, but as a result they're worse than City or Asylum and fail to do anything as impressive as the Mr. Freeze fight from City. Hunting down Deadshot and Riddler are also almost exactly the same from the previous games. Really, on the gameplay side, there isn't much to talk up. It's basically an expansion for Arkham City.The story is where Arkham Origins finds a good place. Asylum played much more like a comic book and did quite well in its niche, but City tried to take a darker turn without changing Asylum's formula of "Villain X is doing Y. Go to location Z and beat them up", and therefore suffered for anyone who tried to take it seriously. While Origins doesn't do much to shake that up that formula, it actually explores the relationships of both Batman and one of his biggest enemies, which both its predecessors failed to do. The character arcs affect the plot much more than they did in the previous games, and so with that, Origins takes that successful dark step up that City tried to take but misstepped somewhat. The main plot thread does hop back and forth between side stories a bit too much, but it's not that noticable, and its enjoyable while it lasts. The voice actors also do a very good job filling the shoes of their predecessors, and one villain's VA who I won't mention did such a fantastic job that I didn't realize until halfway through the game that the character's actor had changed.If you liked the previous Arkham games, you'll find pretty much everything you liked here, and maybe something you haven't seen before as well. That being said, while Origins doesn't do anything that made me want to punch the developers in the face, it didn't make me want to sing their praises either. There's nothing really new it can bring to the table, although it does make better developments in the story department by making characters more three-dimensional and making them more important to the plot. I'd pick it up on a sale if you aren't 100% convinced, but Origins isn't not worth your time, and it does no dishonor to the name of the Arkham franchise.

number of helpful: 14 of 20 people (70%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: May 16, 2016
"Nice of you to drop in Bats!"This is the 1st Arkham Game in the series. (Chronological Order) Released in October 2013. Being the first game, it  serves as the Action-packed Origin Story where (A Fresh from Training.) Bruce learns many new skills and meets many vital characters in the Arkham Storyline! (Note that this is Rocksteady's adaptation so it will be different to any origins or sagas from the comics! This is a Videogame Dammit!)Also i wont Spoil anything from the story here because im reviewing overall content and mechanics, not specific parts of the plot. You can find a neat summary on the games page for this. ;)


Time to Return to the Darkness, we are not Appreciated here.. 
A Screenshot of Batman™: Arkham Origins
By: Jaeger




Without further ado, lets get to the Black and the White, the Strengths and the Reserved Judgement that is the...Pros and Cons.PROS:+Pointy Bat-ears Strike Fear into Dumb thugs! xD+The Plot is done in such a way that its almost episodic and gives each character a balanced time in the spotight! (Before being beaten up by Batman.) Lots of new enemies are introduced especially, their origins are also given an arkham game spin. This is the origins game of the series and revelas lots and lots about the people of gotham! No spoilers here but there are many plot twists and interesting turns for the story, though they  could take a while to be revealed.+Graphics are good for the time, couldnt ask for more here. Its what you would expect from 2013, nothing more, nothing less. Lots of little effects like snowfall and chilled breaths give gotham a true Christmas feel.+His Cowl+Snowflakes=<3+Bigger Map Size which is surprisingly dense with activities. It expands on Arkham Cities map and adds south gotham to The North, connected by the gotham pioneer bridge. Gliding across the snow capped rooftops of The Major Areas of Gotham is a really unique feeling. Especially for a Batman game.+Collectibles will keep any gamer busy for at least a few days! (Maybe too many...)+The Boss battles are Balanced and shouldnt take too long to complete. Although many of them use repeating sequences, they will be beaten quickly so its not too much of a problem!+The Origins of the Characters are generally really well done! If you cant see this game as a big new entry to the series, you can at least view it as a backstory to other games in the series. (As it is the First.) Bruce's story about developing into a more solid and refined figure of justice is given to us in an immpressive way. The Pacing of the plot is done well, but you are reminded often that this is far from a cinematic experience. I wouldnt imagine seein this as a film at all (Which is probably for the better.)+Many new Features to gameplay include: Enhanced Detective Mode with the ability to "rewind" scenarios, new gadgets and interface additions. (Keep in mind that he gets all of these NEW features before Arkham Asylum!!)+It has Added Multiplayer for the first time! I've tried it only a few times so i cant say much but it does have some good modes and progression. But im betting people will buy this for the story, combat and thrill of being Brucey boy!+Story is about 12-16 hours without touching on any of the other fun Activities! This is definetely long enough for gamers and it is the average length for the Arkham games too, so thats good!+Once again, the combat system is done so well, its just so smooth! It seems like Batman is just dancing at some points, he feels in the zone at some times! Although, saying that, the targetting can get a bit off a completely ruin a huge combo..The Combat system is simple enough to understand quickly but complex enough to put major effort into strining together some Badass combos! The Mechanics of Hand to Hand (To Gadget too!) Combat in the Arkham Games are a true marvel of third person Action games, and many games (Of the same genre) have tried to dupicate aspects that stood out. Watch some gameplay of challenge maps if you still arent convinced. (I do wish there was a mode where a comic balloon would pop out and say Kapow! or Wack! with every few punches and kicks. ;D)Cons:-Its Riddled (See what i did there) with bugs and even some crashes at times. Although the main offender is frame drops in graphically busy sequences. These are minor issues but people have been known to have much worse. Obviously on Launch there was some Large problems that arose, but they were quickly patched by Rocksteady. (Every game will have issues on launch! just depends how much coverage they get really!)-A Gloomy Gotham leads to Brightness issues and an annoying fog thats makes it hard to see long distances.-Mission objectives often include much Backtracking, Many Dull Dialogue scenes and timed sequences that seem far to easy to the average gamer.-Linear Environment around the City. Like Doors that you cant open at all, Blank and boring walls, Slow Animations and No Miscellaneous Interactive objects to find!-Repetitive boss battles! The Deathstroke one is the worst offender!its really only3 different Counters and then a simple beatdown for one of the best mercenaries in DC!? A Skillful Meta-human gets given this disgraceful Repeat of actions? Quite sad really. Boss battles actually have variation between each major VIllain, taking a new apporach to defeat them really uses all of Batmans Skill and Gadgets. However i felt that they were generally better in the other Arkham Games.-The New detective mode has difficult controls and slows down the story a bit too much at times. You know  exactly where B is but you havent found the right Clues  to find A beforehand... The Hiding of Evidence is a bit too easy as well.Give us a bigger Challenge Rocksteady!-The Pacing was a bit strange as well! After a huge boss battle, it would be nice to follow up and see how alfred is doing (And join him for a cuppa!) and fix up your suit right? Instead you will get a call from Enigma and will have to deactivate some bombs straight away! Ignore the fact that Batman is a human being and even he has a bedtime! He must have adrenaline built into the suit...-The Plot would have been better with some emotional scenes or bonds built with certain figures even!A Sequence about Bruces life, A flashback to when he is training on a mountain. This comes back to pacing and where the story is going...It does have Lots of Plot twists!-Among others, Bane is a very different Character, same as many villains. Although this can be excused due to origins and all that. Some Personalities or even costumes for Batman's Foes were a bit of a strange choice. But then again, i read the old school comics so i keep comparing their personalities, etc.-Some Gadgets you will hardly use outside of missions and thir uses were too specific to stand out as a true Batman Toy. The Electrical Charge or disrupter (Although useful for armed thugs!) will never match the various functions of the Grapple hook or the Remote-Batarang.-The Colour theme seems dull compared to the other games i the series, this is obviously due to the season and the industrial design. But interiors should be more plentiful and have more Variety too!


Meta-Human Revealed! 
A Screenshot of Batman™: Arkham Origins
By: Jaeger




Final ThoughtsOverall I give this Plot-Packed Arkam experience a 7/10!Light on the New Features and Colours, but heavy on the Origin stories and Combat (Once again) this is a must-by for Batman lovers, just to see Rocksteady's take on the Caped-Crusader's rough side...and the familiar line up of Villains that we all know and love. Athough it does have numerous technical Issues and repetitve missions that will be noticeable.Don your Cowl and Gadget Belt, and Glide into this Super-hero Experience Today!Dont forget to Leave a comment if i missed anything important in this game! Now if you'll excuse me, some Thugs are clipping through walls...-Kyle

												8.5/10Better than Asylum, not as good as City.As an origins story, the plot does justice to the Batman universe and as a prequel to Arkham Asylum. The fight mechanism is  similar to all games in the franchise but the boss fights are taken up a notch and are made as unique to each super villain as possible. The detective sequences wherein Batman has to find clues and understand what happened at a crime scene are also much more fun than in the previous games, this time making it slightly more engaging. The plot thins a bit when entering the killing all the assassins part just because they were paid to kill Batman. Bit repetitive but the fights are really cool, so this can slide. All in all, a pretty damn good game. Although Troy Baker did a pretty good job as the voice actor for the Joker, many sequences will show you why Mark Hamill is undeniable the best man for the job.

Posted: March 23, 2014
												If you're a fan of the Batman video games, you will still enjoy this. It's not really a bad game, it just has a bunch of bugs and issues, and I'd like to say there are less than there were on release day, but I think I've actually encountered more on my 2nd playthrough which was just recently. The story in this game isn't bad, and actually a few times it has great writing and dialogue. Other times, it really doesn't seem right, it's sort of a mixed bag, in my opinion. Some of it didn't feel right to me, but overall it was decent. Out of the 3 Batman games out right now, this was my least favorite, but that doesn't mean it's a bad game. The whole 8 assassins part is what was misleading about this game. You would expect to fight all 8 in the campaign, which isn't the case. Some are side missions, and even as side missions, they're very short and unsatisfying. This could have been much better, much better indeed. I could probably say a few more things, but overall, you get the idea at this point. If you enjoy Batman, pick this up, though I'd recommend waiting for a sale. If you're new to the series, definitely start with Arkham Asylum, followed by Arkham City, and save this one for last.

content:
Posted: January 23, 2014
												How do I put this in the most easy form of review possible... It's a batman game. If you haven't played any newly released batman games, they're glorified QTE simulators. Don't get me wrong, that's not a bad thing. But with AI like I've seen, this "Triple A Game" has so many errors it's incredible. It's unoptimized to the point of Geforce Experience's "Optimized Setting" lagging the hell out of my 780Ti, to start out. The flying (gliding?) mechanics are glitch-prone, and overused. If you don't activate the fast-travel stations around the map, you're stuck grappling to rooftops and gliding slowly over gotham, spending 3+ hours just traveling to the various spots on the map. The AI are hyper-sensitive to everything around them, and if they even  glimpse a pixel of your cape across the room, they'll automatically start shooting. The fighting mechanics, while unique, are also quite broken. You're able to counter attacks from across the room, and the AI are apparently able to attack you no matter where you are in the room, as long as it shows that they're about to hit you. I spent hours on the first QTE boss, and lost several times just due to him zooming to my point on the map, no matter how I dodged. It's a fun game, edgy and batman-y, no matter it's flaws. I come back to it after playing other games, but I got it for free with my graphics card. Please, for the love of god, don't buy this game.

content:
Posted: July 25, 2015
												I think we've all seen that 7/10 Game of the OK cover for Arkham Oranges before, right? It basically summarizes how I feel.  We all know what we're getting with the combat, and gadgets and such, so that leaves the story and characters to try and stand out from Rocksteady's offerings. First, some pro's:Some of the predator sections really stood out as having great level "flow" and the minions eventually learn to shoot down your perches after a while, forcing you to take the fight to the ground.The sections in Blackgate really reminded me of Asylum in the best way possible. Troy Baker's Joker (despite the reliance in the character in general), I thought was great, and Roger Craig Smith was good as a younger Bruce. The standout portion of the game to me was Bane's section. They played up his intellect which creats a real dichotomy with his venom addiction, and made it that much better when Bruce realizes how smart he is and the danger he poses We even get a scene fairly reminiscent of the Knightfall comic, though he does get dumbed down in the end. I think the game was smart to have him take a more central role to the overall plot, but I think it could have been pushed even more.Even moreso, the hotel section of the game, when Bats jumps to save the Joker from falling to his death, was the high point of the game for me story and character-wise. Joker's realization of his relationship with Bats as he talks to Harley reminded me of the short comic Batman: The Deal[moonheadpress.blogspot.ca], which is one of my favorite comics about the two, and I think they really could have had something if they dug into the character like that more.And some things I didn't like as much: The last "boss fight" is an anti-climactic joke, and while the psycho Bane fight before it was somewhat unique, it made me feel less like Batman and more like Newt from Aliens.Gordon's speech at the end was laughable, and most of the writing was all around underwhelming at best. Save for one standout section I'll talk about near the end.Outside of Bane, the other assassins are all pretty bunk. Deadshot is a chump with no personality whatsoeverShiva is just a lighter shade of Talia from City, and both her and Deadshot are reduced to side quest chains(even less important than Anarky, even) with no fanfare or pizazz. Croc goes down in the tutorialElectrocutioner is essentially this game's Johnny SasakiThe Slade fight was very well coregraphed, but essentially boils down to a QTE fight. Bane gets multiple fights, with varying strategiesCopperhead is pretty much introduced and defeated in the same scene, but at least the fight was ememies-filling-the-screen fun (the painfully slow stumbling around while poisoned, not so much). Firefly, believe it or not, I think has the best showing aside from Bane. He seems like a real threat to the city and not just Mercenary # 7, and his whole section on the bridge was super fun and diverse, with lots of puzzles, interesting level design, and a pretty spacious predator room. The Suicide Squad tease at the end piques my interest for WB Montreal's whack at a different style of game, and hopefully they can pick some inspired choices for the cast. Overall, a middling Arkham game: 7/10.

It was just a disappointment to me and I consider it to be not worth what it costs at the moment.________________________________________________I really really really don't know how to feel about Batman Arkham Origins. First of all I was stoked when I heard about it and preordered it as soon as possible. When I got it I locked myself in my room for the entire weekend and played. That at least was my plan, until a couple of bugs appeared that made it impossible to continue playing. But by now I've finished it thankfully they quickly came up with patches for the PC version and storywise it was a great game. Unfortunately the story couldn't unfold it's entre potential because the game-play just straight away sucked. Batman no longer moves as fluidly, which is especially annoying when having to deal with larger groups of enemies. The freeflow everyone loved in Arkham Asylum and Arkham City has become no more than a painful itch between your buttcheeks. And do I even have to mention the Electrocutioner?Furthermore it felt A LOT like Arkham City. Even the sidemissions were the same. All they really did was to exchange the graphics so it would at least look slightly differentThis game held so many great possibilities, but it's rather poorly made, and I kinda regret having paid 45€ for it. Anyways, playing it was fun, there's a lot about it fans of the franchise will love.

content:
Posted: August 6, 2015
												Batman has a long history of escaping from some of the deadliest, most elaborate traps a brilliant criminal mind can devise. In his bat-utility belt is a gadget to get him out of nearly any predicament. But in Batman: Arkham Origins, there's one trap Batman can't escape from: the trap of expectations. By now, there are two things that define action in the Arkham series: rhythmic, free-flow combat and stealthy predator rooms. Arkham Origins has those elements in spades. But it doles them out in a straightforward, predictable fashion that lacks the inspiration of the earlier Arkham games.The most noteworthy difference between Arkham Origins and its predecessors is a significantly larger open world. But that larger world has little meaning when the things you're doing in it are the same things the smaller world of the previous game accommodated perfectly well. Grappling up to rooftops and gliding through the air still feel great, but they don't feel any better here just because you have more rooftops to leap from. And there are side quests that have you doing things like racing to and fro to disarm bombs set by Anarky, which is much like racing to answer Zsasz's ringing phones in Arkham City. The city is bigger just for the sake of being bigger, and while these side quests make interesting use of characters--Anarky's willingness to go to any length to liberate the downtrodden from the oppression of the rich and powerful makes him a fascinating figure, for instance, and the game gives him his due--the things you're doing are exactly the same as the things the previous game had you doing in its open world. Even the crimes in progress, events you can choose to respond to or ignore that come up on the police radio, aren't a chance to protect hapless citizens of Gotham from criminal elements, but just to fight more groups of thugs, something you do plenty of anyway.Free-flow combat is unchanged from earlier Arkham games, aside from the fact that there are a few new enemy types in the mix, most notably a martial artist who has an attack you need to counter twice rather than once. The animations are still excellent, and getting into a rhythm where you're dishing out punishment while perfectly countering every enemy attack still feels good, but it also feels exactly the same as ever. At a certain point in the game, you acquire shock gloves that make your punches more powerful, but this doesn't prevent punching dudes in the face from feeling routine.Predator rooms are also what you'd expect them to be, no less and no more. Of course it's still satisfying to sneak up on a goon and take him down silently, or to be perched on a gargoyle, waiting for a clueless criminal to walk right under you so you can do an inverted takedown. But it's also starting to feel rote. By this point, the mechanics governing these systems have become apparent, the process of sneaking up on enemies or of countering attacks overly familiar. You and Batman and the game he's in are all just going through the motions.8/10

												If you were a fan of the previous two games (Arkham Asylum/Arkham City) then this is a fitting exploration into a prequel of those two titles. The gameplay and mechanics will be very familiar and picked up easily (and the AR gliding tests are much simpler!).If you haven't played the previous two titles, you can still proceed with this and only miss a few of the nods to the earlier releases. Being a prequel it obviously occurs before the events of Arkham Asylum. I personally recommend playing the games in release order due to the tighter controls and graphics each new title brings.There are only a few bugs and glitches still present this long after release. I had to restart the game on multiple occasions to clear up various glitches (ie stuck game/mission progression). Apparenly WB do not see these as fairly substaintial problems, since they are still present even after most were reported around release back in 2013. So some mild frustration is to be expected.Overall this is an excellent step up in the series with some fresh(ish) ideas to reboot the franchise.

content:
Posted: April 20, 2014
												Whilst buggy, this game is seriously underated. Most of the hate comes from the large amount of game breaking bugs, which were not removed quickly enough, though at this stage I managed to complete the game only having to restart twice, both of which were not during the story, and I only need to "restart from last checkpoint", and not the entire game. [SPOILER ALERT]  The other reason that this game is so hated is because the marketing hinted at a plot that wasn't based around the Joker, and included some smaller members of the rogue gallery as the main characters. Now whilst its not true that some less famous villians are included in this game, its just that the Joker is actually the main villian, along with Bane.  Apart from that, the 'lack of innovation' in this game is the another reason that this game is hated. Whilst in comparison to the other two Arkham Games, that is true, this game has one huge area of innovation: The Multiplayer. Unfourtunately, this was not the audience wanted, so it was largely disregarded. But in fact, the multiplayer is quite fun, and at the time of writing has an active multiplayer community. This is really what I would have wanted from an Arkham multiplayer mode. Stealth against real people. Whilst I will admit playing Batman or Robin is alot more fun than the thugs, there is an equaliser. The fact that at one point in the game, one player will be able to play as the Joker or Bane. This actually can be really challenging for Batman or Robin, especially if the player of the Joker or Bane is good at the game. Of course there is one bug that *still* hasn't been fixed is multiplayer data being wiped. Though by launching the game from singleplayer mode this will prevent this bug, no matter what (from my experience). Some may also have to launch singleplayer again one they are finished, but I haven't experienced this. Now my favourite bit from this game is the Story. Now, obviously some will be dissapointed (see the spoiler) by the plot, but I still think that the story was gold. It was really the first Arkham Game to try to show the flaws in Batman's actions, as he seriously hurts people to stop them hurting others. Some of the corrupt police or common thugs are in desperate positions, and don't have much hope elsewhere, yet Batman will still knock them out cold. Still angered by his parent's death, Batman is demanding, somewhat ungrateful and unable to listen an opinion other than his own, I cringed with every conversation Batman and Alfred had, until the *incident*. Not a single thank you, shouting because Alfred opposed his views, Alfred's relationship with Batman is one of the most heart-breaking of all. The ending was uplifting, and somewhat smart. One pointer is how ubsurd it is how much happens in one night. I'd rate it 7/10, based on the fact Arkham Assylum is a 10/10 for me.

content:
Posted: March 30, 2016
IntroductionBatman: Arkham Origins is the third game in an amazing series which combines fun and proactive combat with a massive city full of secrets. If you have already played Arkham City or Asylum then you're getting more of the same, though there are many elements of the game (mainly story and characters) that are different because Origins is a prequel to the series. Plot DetailsYou are The Batman, a highly trained combat expert with an arsenal full of gadgets at your disposal. However, Gotham City doesn't really know about you at this point in time. You go from just a rumor to a full-fledged night vigilante in the space of (what should be) a night. I find it a bit ridiculous to be honest, but hey, that's just my opinion. Basically you become 'wanted' by this guy called Black Mask who puts a pretty impressive bounty on your head and hires assassins to kill you, 10 of them in fact. At first this premise really got me interested, but I didn't feel like the story was carried as well as it could be. Nevertheless, you get to meet some of the most infamous criminals of Gotham in a younger version. It was weird seeing Penguin a little younger than usual. All of this happens on Christmas eve by the way. As you traverse the city, you'll see a lot of snow, christmas trees and assorted lights everywhere. Let's talk more about Gotham shall we?GameplayGotham City is pretty much the same from Arkham City. It's large with various major areas you can travel to. You can decide to grapple and glide everywhere, or you can now fast travel via the batplane. I do appreciate the choice between them both, however the Batplane travel is just a combination of three cutscenes that never vary. I prefer physically going through the city, finding cool grappling spots and just enjoying the game that way. BUt when I simply wanted to get somewhere quickly, the fast travel system helped a lot. The problem I have with the city is that aside from enemies, it is completely empty. Remember the plot? Well it just so happens that there is a supposed curfew in effect for the entire night and so you'll never see a single regular human being anywhere. This is something I had hoped Arkham Origins would have fixed from City, but alas, we have to deal with another lifeless city. Almost any person you see is automatically an enemy because the cops aren't even on your side. The exception to this rule are the people you end up rescuing in various situations. They may thank you and leave, but otherwise they pretty much don't exist.There are quite a few things to do in the city itself. From beating up baddies to finding collectibles, this game will eat away time like acid. Combat is quite satisfying and will involve a lot of countering, utilizing gadgets and changing your strategy to deal with various enemies. Stealth gameplay is quite fun and it's highly entertaining to listen to the voice chatter of terrified enemies. Gadgets give you so many creative ways of taking out, or immobilizing enemies, so no two encounters are ever the same.Now, I dislike doing repetitive things, however there are two things that kept me interested in getting collectibles. Firstly, most of these collectibles are tied to some very creative puzzles. Each one kept me guessing and some of them absolutely blew my mind. However I never once had to pull up a guide to tell me how to solve any of them so most people should be able to get them all with enough time. Secondly, I enjoyed reading the new bits of information I got from each collectible I got. It put more life into the characters and was pretty worth it.There are many other gameplay elements which are worth mentioning but it would make this review too long. VisualsAbsolutely stunning. If your PC can max this out then that's perfect. However this game is very well optimized for even potato PCs.AudioThere are a few new voice actors in this game and while I thought they did their roles just fine, I'd still prefer the originals. Other sounds and music are top quality stuff. Highly enjoyable.SummaryWhile Arkham Origins is a great game in its own right, it feels like the developers missed multiple opportunities to expand the game past the original despite the plot. Arkham City felt a bit lifeless and this game would have done well with some expansion in that regard. Instead, it felt the same, if not worse in that category. However, Arkham Origins is overall more of the same from Arkham City, so if you liked that game, or you're new to the franchise, you'll love it.Newcomers: 9/10 - Worth a buyPrevious players: 7/10 - More of the sameIf you found this review helpful, please consider giving it a thumbs up. You can also find more reviews over at http://www.completingthebackloggroup.com/Please also check out Completing the Backlog's Curator page here - follow for regular updates on reviews for other games!

content:
Posted: March 28, 2014
												Batman: Arkham OriginsI've decided to wait, and review Batman: Arkham Origins now, rather than had reviewed it back when it was released in October, last year. Why? Because the hype. I was so excited for this game to come out. I had changed every digital wallpaper I owned to it. Bought posters, digitally made a shirt, hell, the release date was even my phone's passcode. I thought it wise to just wait, and review it when my excitement had died down. And here we are, 5 months later, and I still love this game. Sure, it has it's flooks. But what game doesn't? The gameplay is what you EXPECT, and that's okay! What the Arkham series provides is an unreal superhero experience that makes you feel like YOU are Batman. Arkham Origins still captures that and displays it in a different style and showing of the character. Arkham Origins somewhat takes the old gothic art style of Asylum and City, and sort of hides it away. You know it's there, but it's smothered underneath all the gritty realism. A harsh mix between the Nolan films and Batman: The Animated Series. The art style is also accented by the crisp visuals. and particularly to the PC version, the PhysX. (I love you Pepe) The graphics are unique, and not overly realistic, but at the same time, have that crisp Arkham feel. It knows what it is, and it tries to maintain it. The story is absolutely FANTASTIC, and is really what carries the game... Seriously... Batman fan, or non-Batman fan, you will like the story, ESPECIALLY if you have played Arkham Asylum and Arkham City.I guess the main gripe most people had with Origins was that it was "more of the same." But I have to ask, is that a bad thing? We got a new art style, amazing story, gadgets, refined predator mechanics and new abilities, a expansion to Gotham, and new playable characters. To me, Arkham Origins is a solid installment to the Arkham series.Gameplay 9/10Visuals 8/10Story 10/10Replay factor 7/10Overall: 8.5/10

content:
Posted: April 5, 2014
												It's not good enough to be considered a Batman Arkham game. Buggy, short and poorly designed.The story is good and the locations are great (albeit Gotham City doesn't have any pedestrians because of a convenient blizzard storm, and most of what's playable of it is what will become Arkham City in the future).I've experienced tons of bugs, something that never happened to me in the other Arkham games. For example, one time an entire Crime In Progress scene spawned right in front of me and I got locked inside the model of a truck which spawned on me. Another time I got killed by a bug in the first Bane fight, repeatedly. It took me more than three hours to beat that and I had to let Bane punch me because if I tried to avoid his hits I would get crushed by the floor for some reason, getting bugged inside the floor. Another time I used the Bat Wing to fast travel and my model didn't appear so I had to restart the game.Fighting sucks because of the camera angle, it's very very difficult to aim when blocking or when jumping from one thug to another because the camera twists too fast (and there's no control to turn it off since the only one there is just changes what it does with the camera when you jump out of combat).The animations are clumsy and laggy, but the game itself runs smoothly, so I wonder what happened there?Some of the boss fights are uninspired repetitions of other boss fights from the other games and some even copy some of this very game.I still recommend it because overall it's still a Batman Arkham game but it's way worse than the others. Buy it on sale and keep in mind Splash Damage hasn't fixed anything yet even though it's been months.A shame really.

												THIS GAME IS A SHAME AND A DISRESPECT WITH US AND WITH ROCKSTEADY'S WORK WITH THIS FRANCHISEDon't get me wrong: "Batman: Arkham Origins" is a very cool and fun game. It even has some improvements over the two past games, like some remarkable boss battles that are even better than most of the AA and AC ones, and some improved investigation missions with elements that reminds Capcom's "Remember Me".  But, unfortunately, all of these good things became a little blurry because Arkham Origins is one of the worst polished games from this past generation(PS360)...Arkham Origins have one of the biggest collection of bugs of the series, contrasting with the previous games, that are so well made by Rocksteady. And not only this, but Warner Montreal simply spat in our(consumers)face, when they said they're not fixing anything anymore because none of the bugs and issues the game have right now are "game breaking" and we can still finish the game. It's a shame and a disrespect with us and with all the excelent job Rocksteady had been doing with the series. From the games that a played recently, Arkham Origins was my biggest disappointment. I had fun with it, but, at the same time, I was always mourning with myself about how the game is so broken and with no polishment. I'm even kind of sad of writing this review, because I really like Batman Arkham series. But these bad developers must know that we are not happy with their work. I know it's unlikely they'll read this or even fix the game because of my review, but at least I'm spreading the word and warning some other players on what they will get into when buying this game...

												Batman: Arkham Orgins brings together two of my favorite types of gameplay. At times you are a hunter in the shadows, timing takedowns and picking apart your prey one by one while remaining invisble. Most of the time you dive into the middle of a gang to rely on quick reflixes and situational awareness to beat the absolute turd out of them. While being very fun and simple Arkham Orgins is basically Arkham City with a lower budget. All but two gadgets are the same, but even then one of the "new" gadgets is really just a reskin. The main story mode is extremely linear, which isn't bad just means less time explorin' more time kickin' booty patooty. It's also unsatisfyingly short. I have no clue what I paid for but with the main story mode complete, every collectable on the lower half of the map safe, and all the sidequests but one completed I only have 35% of the game done. Nothing left but grinding that most people will find boring.So final verdict is, if you want to buy it but don't have Arkham City, get Arkham City instead. If you've played Arkham City and crave a bit more go crazy.P.S. Don't buy the skins. They're poopy. The original skin is bad butt anyways, it tears up as the story progesses (kind of to the point where you wonder how he flipping flys with so many holes in his cape but still awesome.) content:
Posted: July 19, 2014
												Arkham Origins is an addicting game, but that doesn't mean it's good. As someone who has put over a hundred hours into Arkham City and has 100% Arkham City and Asylum, I'm not afraid to say that Arkham Origins is an inferior follow-up. Don't get me wrong, the game is fun; the combat is better than ever with the addition of new enemy types and the ability to stack up to 2 special moves. But besides that there isn't really that much the game has going for it. The predator rooms feel uninspered and generic compared to the ones in City, and can be breezed through with the use of Deathstokes grappel gun which basicly allows you to pick off up to three enemies with no challenge to it: it's basicly a ranged Inverse takedown. This eliminates the diffliculty of predator rooms. Then there's the city, the game's hub world. While it is larger than the one in Arkham City, if I remember correctly I've been told it's atleast 3 times as big as the one in AC, it feels empty. There isn't much to do apart from stopping the same general street crimes that pop-up in the city districts (whether it's fighting mobs or beating up gangs it all ends up becoming the same repitative task after a while). The are no riddler trophies or riddles that unlock bonuses and give winks and nods to the batman lore. I understand Edward Nigma hasn't transformed into the Riddler yet, but the replecement collectibles they have in the game just feel inferior compared to the collectibles of past games. There are side-missions you can do, but half of them are straight up copies of the ones present in AC; Instead of blowing up titan containers you're blowing up drug containers, there's the one where you get sucked into Mad Hatters Wonderland, there's the one where you have to track down Deadshot just like you did in AC. Speaking of Deadshot, one of the biggest flaws in this game is character development. For a game whose whole premise is based around Batman having to defeat eight assassins, the assassins themselves have barely any impact in this game. Assassins like Deathstroke have little to no screen time, they just show-up, you beat them, and you about never see them again. I'm not talking about B or C list characters here, this is Deathstroke, a major player in the DC Universe, a man who has fought the Teen Titans and had multiple comic series. Instead more emphasis is placed on characters like Bane, who has already had screen time in the previous two games. For the most part it just feels like most of the assassins where just there as fan-service instead of actually having a purpose; it's like how people always joke that the Batman story-arc "Hush" was just an excuse for Jim Lee to draw and include major stars of DC universe, with them having little to add to the overall plot.    But while there's a lot I can criticize about Origins, there are some things it gets right. Like I said earlier the combat is better than ever, not to mention the boss fights, which for the most part, are an improvement over the ones in City and especially Asylum. The voice acting is surprinsgly better than I expected; Troy Baker sounds great as the Joker and overtime Roger Craig Smith starts to grow into the role of Batman, even at some points sounding like a young Kevin Conroy. And while I do think the assassins where underplayed, I'n my opinion James Gordon and Alfred were certainly given the time in the spotlight they rightfully deserve, more so then they were in the past games. But besides that there isn't much I can say good about it. Like I said from the beginning, Origins is addicting. The comabt is satisfying, I'd dare say even more than City, but it lacks the things AC has that made me 100% it and start on my 5th playthough of it. It might just be me, I'll admit that. From what I've read in other reviews people have enjoyed this game, and that's good. But in my opinion, as an honest-to-god Batman/Arkham series fanboy, I just can't recommend this game. I wish I could put it into words that would fully convey my dislike towards this game in a way that would allow you to see it the way I do, but I can't. And when I try the only word that comes to mind is the same one I've repeated over and aver again in my review, and that word is "inferior". This game is just inferior. But I'll say again, that's just the way "I" see it. If you think you'll like it, and it comes on sale, you can buy it and make your own opinion. But if you had to ask me, I would not recommend it. P.S. I couldn't think of anyplace else add this so I just decided to talk about it here, this has to deal with game's New Game Plus mode. Following in AC's footsteps WB Montrel added a New Game Plus mode that allowed you experience the game a second time with an upgraded Batman. But here's the thing, in AC when you started New Game Plus you had all your gadgets unlocked from the start. This was cool because it allowed you an edge with the harder enemies. But in Origins you don't have your gadgets, you have to unlock them all over again. So I have to ask, what's the point of New Game Plus mode if I don't have my unlockables? That was a just a small nitpick I had with the game that I just needed to talk about.

content:
Posted: February 11, 2014
												Arkham Asylum came as a breath of fresh air in a genre combination that had left a long trail of mediocre at best games, even when coupled with some of the biggest licenses in the world. Arkham City expanded on that with an open world and a ton more things to do. Can Arkham Origins, the third game in the series, a prequel made by a different developer, keep the same high quality and still make the franchise feel fresh?The answer is, thankfully, yes. Though Rocksteady didn't work on this entry in one of the best new franchises in years, WB Montreal has hit it out of the park and convinced me that even if Rocksteady has moved on, WBM's hands are more than capable.The game starts out long before the events of Arkham Asylum, and you play as a Batman who's nowhere near as confident. He has no allies aside from Alfred, the criminals of Gotham City still aren't quite sure he's more than a myth or urban legend, and the police force will stop at nothing to take him down. On Christmas Eve, Batman discovers that someone has hired eight assassins to kill him, with a $50 million reward to the one who manages to take him down.The story takes place across Christmas Eve night and a couple hours into the very early morning of Christmas, and it's wonderfully well told, which is good because the story was the most worrying thing to me, since I figured the gameplay looked nearly identical to the past two games. The gameplay isn't just a cut and paste of the prior entries, though, with a handful of new gadgets, takedowns, and combat moves thrown in to keep things fresh. Obviously there are some gameplay continuity quirks, since why would Batman have lost some gadgets between now and then, but for the most part you'll forget about those kinds of things as you fight quite a few new enemy types, the best bosses in the series, and use your detective skills to solve crimes with some cool new crime-rewind/fast-forward stuff. It's all very fun and I have no real gameplay complaints, though those expecting radical departures from the series' formulas will be disappointed.The non-story stuff is at its best in this entry as well, with cases to solve, criminals to catch, and an enjoyable random crime system to mix things up. The only real downsides to AO are negligible. The multiplayer mode is both dead and somewhat pointless, though it could be fun if you could find some games and play with friends. The other issue is that the game, unlike Asylum and City, could use a couple more passes of polish. There are quite a few bugs in this entry, mostly with mission triggers not occurring or enemies becoming unable to be interrogated. Sometimes while rewinding a crime you will become stuck in the ground until it finishes,  things like that. I didn't run into any of the gamebreaking bugs some people have, but I guess your mileage may vary.All in all I had a blast with B:AO and I look forward to what both Batman developers have up their sleeves.9.5/10

content:
Posted: January 5, 2014
												Now, before all of you simply glance over my words simply because I don't recommend this game to everyone, allow me to explain in detail why that is so.Have in mind that I have not completed this game 100%, nor do I intend to; I am not a completionist, and even if I were, this game does not deserve it. I've also played both Arkham Asylum, and Arkham City, followed by Origins, all in quick succession and in proper order, over the course of about 3 weeks. I was also (un)lucky to pre-order this game with a decent discount; it cost me about 30€ or so, a good dip from the 50€ that the game retails for.Also have in mind that I will not be talking about the online multiplayer of this game; I feel it is an unnecessary add-on to the game that does not benefit a previously exclusively single-player experience, and a great one at that.Now, I usually don't tend to compare different games because it takes away the focus of the game at hand, but since this is a sequel (or a prequel, to be precise); a game in a series of games, I shall compare it to its predecessors simply because it makes sense. This goes more so for the quality of the previous games, and to see if this game is up to the same standard. And unfortunately, it is not.This game, like many other in their respective franchises, such as God of War and Assassin's Creed just to name a few, suffers from a very common AAA game problem; over-iteration. Companies become greedy due to the success of previous entries, and simply start cashing in on the loyalty of players with a passion for games like this. It should also be noted that this game, unlike Arkham Asylum and City, wasn't even made by the same studio; the first two games were made by Rocksteady, whereas Origins was made by WB Studio Montreal; meaning that the entire cast was changed.Now, before I can state why I don't recommend this game, I'll take a look at the two previous entries in the series.Back when I started Asylum, I expected nothing of the game. It is the only game of the three that I have not done any reading on, or have not seen any video material beforehand; I explored as I went.A week later, having finished it, and on a side note, it is the only game of the three that I have played on the Easy difficulty (and it still remains the most difficult game in the series), I came out more than pleasantly surprised. Everything, from the game's level design, to its closed, dark, gritty, and almost paranoid atmosphere, not to mention amazing characterization, was spot on. I won't even start talking about the voice acting, which was second to none. The game felt fresh. It felt new. It felt like a really high-quality piece of work.Afterwards, I almost immediately started Arkham City. With this one, I'd done some previous reading and watched some short videos. The game received almost universal praise, and I read reviews filled with nothing but good word of it. And given the quality of Asylum, I went into the game with high expectations.Another week later, I finished the game, but with mixed feelings. For one, the story seemed out of place, and was kind of messy all around. Other aspects of the game received no change whatsoever; it was basically Asylum with a different story. Luckily, voice acting remained on the same quality level as with Asylum; Hamill really shined with the Joker. Lastly, the game did improve in one aspect. That was the environment. It provided me with a more or less open world, shedding the closed atmosphere of Asylum, and providing me with the constant feeling of being on the move. The design of Arkham City was great, and it was a good change from the closed corridors of the Asylum, and this required a different approach from the player.Yet, despite all this, I still prefer Asylum. It just felt better.Lastly, I started playing Origins. I had hopes for the game. I wanted to see it correct the things City got wrong; a more coherent story, a larger world to explore, more stuff to do.And after a while, I saw that the game failed spectacularly at all of these. Now, since I'd harbored nice feelings for the previous games, I could look over the various issues that the game has. However, by the end of the game, I realized that this game was indeed a failure. It is a failure because it takes everything enjoyable from the previous games, and then limits it.For starters, the level design is a step back from Asylum, let alone City. The game basically tricks you into thinking you've been given this large open world, when it fact it is more limited than the closed levels of Asylum, for most of the game. There are only a handful of ways to progress, and the game is not flexible in this aspect. Adding a quick travel feature detracts from the game's supposed exploration-based nature, and you're left to realize that, despite this game having a (slightly) larger map than City, it is barren. The entire city is almost empty, and to make things worse, this is obviously artificial, and on purpose. The game feels poor in content. It even has loading times between areas if you quick travel. It is simply pathetic.And all of this is made worse by the fact that the game doesn't try to innovate in the slightest. It sticks to the formula of 'if it ain't broke, don't fix it', and it pays for it dearly. Nothing has changed gameplay-wise, and some things are even performed worse than in previous games. The entire system, like City, is simply copy+pasted from Asylum.Last but not least when it comes to gameplay, the game has a multitude of bugs. From what I heard and read, I actually got off easy; I only encountered two or three game-breaking bugs over the course of my playthrough. Gameplay aside, there are even more issues with the game. And that would be the story.SPOILER warning; mild story spoilers ahead.Now, it might be just me, but the story of Origins feels even more out of place than City. It is cluttered, and makes no time to explain itself, while at the same time letting down my expectations. For one, I expected the Joker's presence in the game to be minimal, even more so than in City. But no. They just went and had to make him the main villain. Again. For the third damn time. Now, all of this would be ok if he was up to par. But even that doesn't occur, as the change in voice actors is visible; while I have nothing against Troy Baker, by trying to be as good as Hamill just doesn't work, and makes the game feel cheap. It is something you'll notice if you played the previous games.Second, the game disappoints in its choice of villains; because the Joker is the main man behind the scenes, this de-values all the other villains, and makes them effectively the Joker's underlings, which is terrible. None of the other villains are given proper screen time, nor are they challenging in fights. This is evident as the game has the worst boss fights in the series. It is a step down from the outright amazing boss fights with Scarecrow and Mr. Freeze, as well as the Penguin in Asylum and City respectively.And as far as the story goes, the name of the game is misleading. This is no origins story. It is just a half-as*** attempt to cash in on the amazing work of Rocksteady. The story does not feature the true Origins of the Batman, and provides no backstory to his motivation, like Asylum does. It just takes a great character and gives him more stuff to do.TL;DR - If you simply have to have more of Batman, play the game. However, this game works best if you haven't played any of the previous two games. If you have, and think the series was great so far, for the love of God, don't play this game. If you were a fan of Asylum, stick to it. It is by far the best game in the series, and playing this will only make you dislike the franchise.As a side note, this review was longer, but it seems there's a character limit, so I had to shorten it. Oh well.

												This is the last game of the Arkham franchise I played. I tried to play it shortly after I played Arkham City, but felt it was too much of the same. I gave it time and wanted to give it a solid shot.I ran into a few bugs with riddler trophy locations. It would say a trophy was there, but I couldn't find it. This game also suffers from some optimization issues. I have a pretty beefy computer, but it would still have stutter issues while I flew through the city.Plot Spoilers: I was disappointed with the overuse of the Bane boss fight. I personally can't stand that bosses' mechanic, and felt disappointed that it was used so heavily. Though I did like the sneaking when you fought "super bane."I did like the introduction of Harley and the sequence where Joker recounts his bad day as Red Hood that turned him into the Joker. But I was ultimately disappointedd that Joker turned out to be the main villain again. Though he was somewhat more ancillary, having him popping up as a memorable side villain ala scarecrow in Asylum would have felt a little better. Overal I only recommend this game to someone who wants to complete the Arkham lineup. It feels very similar to Arkham City with a story that's only "okay."

content:
Posted: October 25, 2014
												If you've played the previous Batman games, it will be easy to get frustrated with Arkham Origins. The real center of these games is hand-to-hand combat with large groups of thugs. That's what you'll be spending a large portion of the game doing, and it's never been more frustrating.In past games, you were able to cancel out of any long animation Batman might be in the middle of in order to counter an attack coming from a thug behind you. In this game, not only do your animations have priority over your commands, but enemies can slide from a good distance away right up next to you to lay a sudden smack-down on the Bat, the whole while you are helpless to defend yourself. This makes the "Bat sense" warning signals above enemies' heads useless at least half of the time, since it will be impossible for you to counter them.This is more or less emblematic of the problems with Arkham Origins: changes were made that make little sense and do a lot to detract from the experience. There's some fun to be had here for anyone desperate for more Batman after Arkham Asylum and Arkham City, but if you can hold out, you'd be better off waiting for Arkham Knight next year.

number of helpful: 5 of 5 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 17, 2015
												Arkham Origins is the third game in the Batman Arkham series, though it is a prequel. It is obvious when playing through the game that the developer of this game is different than the previous two installments, Arkham Asylum and Arkham City. The game feels clunkier and is not as well optimized but the game still has a sort of charm that drives through, which makes it a unique, though flawed, addition to the series.The story in this game caught me by surprise because of how honestly interesting it was. The game takes place on Christmas Eve and features the first night Batman encounters The Joker. There is a twist that happens during the beginning of the game, but do not expect anything of Arkham City caliber. The character interactions are fantastic and honestly my favorite part of the game, especially the relationship portrayed between Bruce and Alfred. To see the beginnings of many characters and their involvement with The Dark Knight is interesting as well, including Officer Gordon and Barbara Gordon. Many parts of the story actually portrays Batman as a ture detective, which is very well done and satisfying.The voice acting in this game is pretty solid, even thought the actors Batman and The Joker have both been replaced. Troy Baker must be commended for his outstanding job as The Joker and filling in the big shoes left by the much talented Mark Hamill. A huge negative for me though is how awful the lipsyncing in real time is in this game. It looks extremely clunky, unfinished, and just plain bad, especially by 2013 video game standards. The cutscenes, on the other hand, are a big plus because they are extremely stylized and are a huge factor that sets this game apart from the previous installments in the series. The graphics in this game are nothing special and even when they are maxed out, they do not look as good as Arkham City does. That said, it is definitely not a bad looking game (though the fire effects are absolutely atrocious). The funny thing is even though the game came out two years after Arkham City and does not look as good, it also does not run as well. I have a pretty solid PC which can run games such as Battlefield 4 on high smoothly and at a constant framerate but for this game, it manages to lag (though not frequently) at random locations throughout the game, and especially prominent during the last couple portions, The gameplay in this game consists of what you have already been accustomed to in the series, except it just seems to be a bit clunkier. Though the flow of the combat is fluid, sometimes the takedown controls did not seem to work which got quite annoying in specific portions of the game. Also, the combat in this game is much easier than the other games because once you get a flow going, which is easy enough, you can attack enemies that are stunned and already on the ground which somewhat removes one of the only challenges in the beat-em-up combat this series did so well. There is a return of stealth portions within the game but it plays quite differently because of the very different level design compared to the previous installments. In this game, the stealth portions really just seemed easier and if you are caught sneaking around, it was also simple enough to dodge the enemies' bullets and take them down non-stealthily, which honestly should not be the case. So one of the biggest gripes about this game is the fact that it is really a lot easier than Arkham Asylum and Arkham City. There are also many new weapons introduced in this game, which does not make sense since Batman could have used them in the other installments, which take place later on the timeline. Though when making a prequel videogame, it is inevitable to run into problems like that. One of my favorite additions though is the grapple accelerator, which allows Batman to increase his speed when grappling on to any surface, which happens a lot in these games. This is one feature I definitely want to see carried over into Arkham Knight. The map in this game is slightly bigger than that of Arkham City, though it may feel emptier because of the lack of interesting and engaging sidequests. The game takes place in Gotham this time around and it does not make a whole lot of sense since the only people we see roaming the streets or the rooftops are criminals. It made sense in Arkham City, since that is an entire area infested with criminals, but the same cannot be said about this game. One great addition though is the fast-travel using the Batwing. There are multiple fast-travel spots that can be unlocked throughout the map and this idea works very well and I hope it is implemented into Arkham Knight. Though the game is still pretty fun, even compared to the first two installments, it is lacking something huge. A variety of Batman villains. We get some interesting bosses in this game but we also get some fairly unenjoyable ones with villains I don't really care about. Arkham City had an assortment of crazy and fun villains, but this game takes a slump in that department. Bane returns for a total of three different boss battles here and though they are fairly fun, it would have been more interesting to change up the formula. There is a boss battle with Deathstroke early in the game and it is very well executed, and one of the highlights in this game for me. One thing to note is that one of the boss battles is very annoying to play with a mouse and keyboard, so using a controller for this game may be a good idea.Overall, Batman: Arkham Origins is a solid game muddled by being unpolished and some poor design. However, it is still a good game in my opinion and one that is worthy to be in the series. WB Montreal did a good job at portraying these characters in a new light and I really appreciate that. 7.5/10

number of helpful: 5 of 5 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 30, 2014
												Let me clarify two things before moving forward with this review:1) I have not encountered one single bug / glitch throughout the game during my playthrough. Perhaps one thing could be mentioned: Batman occasionally does some strange movements once in the air whilst gliding. But when you stop it and do the gliding again it is fine. So, I have to assume that by the time I played this game WB had patched it properly eliminating all (or most) of the annoying issues.2) I have not tried multiplayer out, at all. I just didn't care. This franchise is all about the single player experience for me and after completing the story I moved on to other games simply skipping the multiplayer component. So, whether good or bad, I do not know and my review is based on the single player experience.Additional criticism towards Arkham Origins (beside the handful of glitches) was its incremental nature. So, while Arkham City offered a couple of new things Origins does not do so. Media cited it should have been a more transformative sequel. But why? It prepares Arkham Knight for that - Rocksteady will do that (we already know vehicles have more involvement in the new Batman game), in the meantime, Splash Damage simply picked a working formula and created a game with that.With that in mind Arkham Origins has one new thing: its story. This is now a prequel so Batman is just after his disappearance (the journey during which he honed his skills) and just started apprehending the bad guys of Gotham. Police, at this point, do not trust him (meanly because they fear him and another reason for that is them being corrupt). Of course, we have Gordon as the outstanding, good, by-the-book guy who can accept Batman (albeit he is making this decision reluctantly). So, it's interesting to be there from the "beginning" and see - for instance - how difficult it is for Batman to cope with Joker (he's quite worked up after their first encounter). I liked the story and I liked the new villains - Black Mask, for instance, or the assassins he hired to kill Batman.So, in essence, the game offers the same thing, but instead of Arkham we are in Gotham City. This is quite huge (perhaps even bigger than Arkham); there's the usual riddle trophies we can collect and many side missions. Also, there are a lot of cutscenes and one thing I found very interesting: Both Batman's and Joker's voice actor changed, but they do a very good job indeed! You can barely hear the difference (yes, even Mark Hamill's replacement is that good).I found the game a bit more difficult. You need to act much faster and there's a new enemy type who can counter Barman moves so you need to counter the counter (it makes sense, right?). Some predator challenges can be annoying as if you mess with the bad guys one by one there's always one who grabs a hostage and if he sees you he simply eliminates the victim resulting in a game over. So, even these encounters require a bit more focus.I do not know about the DLCs (I understand there's one with titled Cold, Cold Heart and it is with Freeze) but the core story is really good and the game offers a long-lasting experience just like its predecessors. Perhaps Origins sticks out a bit; this will be even more alarming probably once Arkham Knight is released; in the meantime, let's just enjoy this installment which I believe is an important part of the franchise and true fans of the series should not skip this one.UPDATE:Cold, Cold Heart DLC - The downloadable content pits Batman against Mr Freeze. We have an extra 4-5 hour long single player content that is to be launched separately from the main menu. After completing the introduction section we find ourselves in Gotham once more with "all gadgets available". I guess all gadgets means all you have obtained in the main game. There is no levelling up and only a relatively small section of the city is available as a playable are.Still, the DLC content offers a new enemy, a new boss battle and exciting cutscenes. I like how Batman faces a frozen Gotham - the snow / ice effect on his cape is brilliant. And of course completing the story still allows us to go back and pick-up the remaining collectibles. This is a good DLC - while for 10 bucks it may be a bit expensive if discounted true Batman fans must get it!

number of helpful: 6 of 7 people (86%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 21, 2014
												It's more of the same with more bugs.tl;dr: I paid $30, it’s worth $10.Now you might think more of the same would be a good thing, but sadly it's just stale.I was all aboard the hype train for this, I had faith that WB could put together a decent game, I mean how could they mess it up?1) It's incredibly short.  That being said I didn't run around getting all the Riddler boxes to beat him up for a third time.  But the main story is considerably shorter than that of Arkham City, and it ends sort of abruptly.  (Yes, yes you can continue playing after you finish the story to get the Riddler stuff.)2) The writing seems half♥♥♥♥♥♥♥  The assassins that were hired to kill Batman, which I might add were the main marketing point for the game made up less than an hour of the game.  The concept of surviving the assassins in one night sounded appealing, the actual execution was boring and short.  It's almost the same issues the Batman films ran into all those years ago, when you have too many interesting characters there just isn't time for everyone.3) The game is Riddled (heh, pun) with bugs.  From the buggy controls to the performance issues, all the way to that inescapable Riddler room that you actually had to fast-travel your way out of.  I played for 3/4 of this game on the highest settings with a decently high-end rig (i7, 16GB, HD 7970).  I had performance hits here and there, but as soon as I got to Blackgate the game became unplayable, and for no reason in particular.  Looking at performance monitors, my card was itting at 80% usage, my i7 was barely being touched and yet I was struggling to get 14 fps.   I had to look online for community fixes.  Though these are known issues, they have yet to be fixed.4) Yes the map is roughly "double" the size of Arkham city, but there were sections of the map that I barely explored because there wasn't a need.  It was big just for the sake of being big.5) While the boss-fights in the Batman series have never been anything special (with the exception of Mr. Freeze) the fights in this game are spectacularly vanilla.  I was looking forward to the Deathstroke fight, and it was over in seconds, more of a chore than a challenge.6) The gadgets are a joke.  The “glue grenade” is a clone of Arkham City’s “freeze grenade” with a new name but all the exact same functionality.  For some reason there is stun grenade… thing that you’ll probably forget that you have because it’s less effective than any of your other gadgets.There is more, but you get the idea.  With as little actual story was in this game it could have done as an expansion to Arkham City or been incorporated into whatever the next Batman game that Rocksteady is working on all hush-hush. **I must say though that this game as a whole was disappointing the one part I was surprised by was the voice acting.  I wasn't sure of their decision to swap in new voice actors for that "younger" sound.  While neither of the main characters sounded particularly younger they did do a damn fine job of bringing the characters to life.
