												I love the original Rocksteady trilogy and always wanted to give this one a try and in all honesty it was not as bad as I thought it would be!It’s definitely the weakest of all the Arkham games for a number of reasons.I found this the most glitchy/buggy of all the Arkham games.The city is very dull and lifeless. But just flakes off towards the end. A highlight would be the hints at 'The Killing Joke' I loved the red hood Joker flash back in the chemical plant showing his origin, very nicely done. Troy Baker does a fantastic job as the joker and sounds very Mark Hamill at some points which I like, all the other voices are forgettable.I would still recommend this to anyone that enjoys the other Arkham games, just don't expect anything new or exciting. But for anyone who has not played any of them, this is the one to play first as they will just get better and better!

number of helpful: 8 of 11 people (73%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 26, 2014
												SINGLE PLAYER CAMPAIGN REVIEW ONLY.Let's cut to the chase and face it - Batman: Arkham Origins is "more of the same", for the most part. It's basically more Batman: Arkham Asylum + Arkham City. If you were a fan of the two previous Arkham games and wanted basically more Batman: Arkham, then Origins certainly delivers just that. If that sounds good to you, great - you'll probably feel right at home with this title. If you wanted and expected more - well, prepare to be disappointed.Arkham Origins' voice-acting is still pretty good, even with some of the changes in some of its cast members. Regardless - the cast delivers and does a great job on their performances. While the story does take a little bit for it to get rolling, once it does - it finally decide to get good. Eight assassins are basically coming for Batman's head, as there's a bounty of $50 million on Batman's head from Black Mask. That's just the start of things, to say the least. There's certainly more to it than that. Because of such a huge cast of characters and some twists + turns in the plot and storyline, some characters - like some of the lesser known Batman villains to most non-fans of the series - never really get the time to get explored and shine here, which feels like a missed opportunity.  Some of Origins' story fills in the blanks of what happened to certain characters, how they become the character they become, or talk about some of their past - explaining some things that happened before events of the previous Arkham games. B/c this is an Origins story, it feels like some of this should've been explored a bit more.If you loved the combat of Arkham Asylum + City, it's not really changed much here - and this definitely has always been one of the strengths of this series. Some of the combat feels tweaked, here and there. Plus, there are some new weapons and gadgets here. One of the best things here are the boss fights - which are always excellent here. There certainly are plenty of side missions and collect-a-thon's here, for fans to dive into - if they are digging the game. And if that isn't enough, there's a New Game Plus Mode, among other things to dive into.After 23 hours approximately, Batman: Arkham Origins' single player campaign deliver basically more Batman: Arkham. Fans of the series wanting more Batman: Arkham, that's exactly what you receive here. If you were expecting more, innovations, and major improvements - don't! Origins is not that title. If you want more Batman: Arkham, you'll come away happy with this title. It's certainly a solid game and delivers such an experience. Origins certainly does not touch the greatness and freshness that came from the previous two titles developed by Rocksteady. Though, it can't be denied that WB Montreal has put forth a solid Batman: Arkham game.Final Grade = C+.

number of helpful: 9 of 13 people (69%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 3, 2013
												Similar Games:The previous Arkham games, Assassin’s Creed games, and every game which hasattempted to rip either of those two series off.The Good:Fantastic setting for a Batman game. Gotham City on Christmas Eve just screams “Batman Returns” and is iconic in its own right. The character design and graphics are top notch, from the major (and minor) villains to the skyscrapers of Gotham. Character animations are fluid and natural, especially in cutscenes. Copperhead, one of the eight assassins gunning for Batman, is the real standout in this aspect. The gameplay is a rehash of the previous Arkham games, with the now standard attack/counter/stun/gadget methodology in place. The combat has always been a strength of the series, and Arkham Origins is no different, except to make Batman’s combat seem less refined and more brutal. That they managed to convey Batman’s inexperience to crime fighting through his fighting technique alone is fantastic. Detective mode is now more involved, requires more evidence gathering, and *GASP* actually involves Batman having Alfred send the evidence to the GCPD for prosecution! It’s almost like the real world! #SARCASM The plot twist, while obvious to anyone who was vaguely familiar with a Batman plot past his Detective Comics days, was a welcome change of pace. The voice acting, despite having changed actors from the previous Arkham games, was still solid and believable. The “Red Hood” section. I won’t spoil it more than that, but as a fan of the comic series, this made me very happy.The Bad:This game was shipped by WB Montreal one week prior to Assassin’s Creed IV: Black Flag. What this means in layman’s terms was that WB Montreal had NO wiggle room in their release date, since Assassin’s Creed (also being a stealth action/combat game with an enhanced vision mode) would almost certainly have cannibalized their sales. In business terms, they had to ship before Assassin’s Creed no matter what state the game was in – AND IT SHOWS. A number of game breaking bugs were present in both the single player and multiplayer portions of the game, including: NOTE: MINOR SPOILERS BELOWMultiple instances where ledges that appeared to be climbable were not. One instance occurred in Burnley Tower, after the Riddler closes off the only other exit, leaving your trapped inside the Tower FOREVER… or until you fast-travel out or reset the game. If you have time and appreciate nerd rage, just Google “Burnley Tower”. An instance where pulling a raft in a dream-like sequence lead to being unable to drop the rope or reach the other shore. Infinite falling in certain places in the map, which really broke the immersion of the game somehow. If Batman ever runs into an enemy which can actually do this, he’s screwed. No level or stat saving in multiplayer, which is a non-starter for obvious reasons. Funky physics. More than once, I threw a baddie against a wall at just the right angle to make him go spirally hundreds of feet into the air. But even worse, once he landed, he got back up! Which is JUST impossible. Occasionally, you are detected by criminals from whom you have both cover and distance. Conversely, you can fly just overhead of others and go completely unnoticed. Batman sometimes drops combos for no reason, particularly during counters. There was a lack of emphasis on stealth for most of the game, and often going into stealth areas, Batman enters the room through the front door. Perhaps the enemies were expecting the vents, so the door was the most stealthy option? MINOR SPOILERS: In what is probably the worst tragedy of storytelling in this series, Barbara Gordon is portrayed as an enthusiastic teenager who somehow is allowed to access confidential police files and evidence because her daddy works for the police. Brushing aside the lack of realism there, Barbara Gordan, who became Batgirl and then, after the Joker shot her in the spine, assumed the role of Oracle, was NOT the airhead from this game. I almost stopped playing for this reason alone. The method of unlocking certain gadgets and techniques is dependent on performing certain feats. Normally that is fine, except that these feats are very specific and must be performed in the exact order that the skill tree describes. And some of these feats are nightmarishly impossible and require specific areas and circumstances to complete… just leave it at XP, WB Montreal. Come on. The Grapnel Accelerator, described as “experimental” in Arkham City, is mysteriously present years before in Arkham Origins. I understand why they decided to include it, but it represents an obvious break in the timeline of the games. The multiplayer… oh the multiplayer. It requires eight people to play, real people. NOT BOTS. NO BOTS. Good luck finding eight people on the servers a month from now. Make some friends on Steam, get a group together, and it might be feasible. Otherwise, it’s a waste of install space. Also, the shooting is really hit-and-miss, but that makes sense in an engine designed for hand-to-hand combat.Can you play it while the children are awake?:Of course not. Corpses with rictus smiles, tons of on-screen violence, multiple murder scene investigations, psychopathic villains… I could go on. Then again, if you are looking for a creative way to punish them…  While I’m picking nits…Rocksteady better be working on something damned important… like freelance work onHalf-Life 3, or (dare I wish it?) a good Superman game. I know that sounds impossible,but before Arkham Asylum, there wasn’t a good Batman game, either. I would onlyrecommend this game if you haven’t played Arkham Asylum or Arkham City, and thuscan’t compare the quality. Or if you have enemies, you could recommend this game onits multiplayer strengths.Did I make time to complete it?:I put 26 hours into it, primarily into the single player. I know that’s incongruous withmy criticisms above, but I was a big fan on the franchise going into Arkham Origins.This also represents the smallest amount of time I have put into an Arkham game, andnone of the others had multiplayer. I should also mention that a number of the bugsmentioned above have been fixed… but not all.Recommended Purchase Price:$19.99 (so, maybe Steam Summer Sale 2014?)or40% of current retail value of $49.99Reviewer:Rod Kimblehttp://www.gamerglance.com

number of helpful: 21 of 36 people (58%) found this review helpful6 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 22, 2015
												Batman: Arkham Origins is a prequel to the Arkham Asylum and Arkham City games. The story takes place in a pre-Arkham Gotham city, staring a young and inexperienced Batman. The police force of Gotham is corrupt and mostly not better than the mobsters and criminals that run Gotham. The game takes place on Christmas eve, where Black Mask has hired 8 of the worlds greatest assassins to kill Batman.The gameplay is smooth most of the time as it was in the previous Arkham games. Moving around is easier than ever with the new fast travel. The city is about the same size as Arkham City but is divided between old and new Gotham.The combat system from the previous games returns. It is all based around timing and the rhythm of the fight. The stealth is a lot like Arkham City. You have the same structure of the last two games. New type of enemies and gadgets are introduced to add new elements to the game. There is a new addition to the detective mode. There are parts of the game where you use it to analyze a crime scene and piece together the crime. It is no longer just find something to trace and follow it to from point A to B.The boss fights are improved and feel more serious but are repetitive. The story felt weaker compared to the other games. The main story could also last longer. There are also again side missions, again you have to collect the Riddler trophies. The challenge mode also returns in Arkham Origins.Arkham Origins comes with a multiplayer mode. In my opinion it was not really necessary to implement a multiplayer.Batman: Arkham Origins does enhance the visuals of the Arkham City engine and it is a very great looking game on max settings. The visuals are not a massive step above the already great looking previous game.There is not much music to listen to but the overall theme sounds nice and fits with the whole story. All the characters do sound great. You have plenty of younger versions of characters seen in previous games. The new voice of the Joker sounds really a lot like the Mark Hamil voice.Overall, this game is fun. I enjoyed it almost as much as the other two games. Sounds 10/10Graphics 10/10Gameplay 8/10Atmosphere 8/10If you liked my review, please feel free to follow me and/or my curator group:http://steamcommunity.com/id/Ov3RT4K3R/myworkshopfiles/?section=guideshttp://steamcommunity.com/groups/orcollective#curationAlso feel free to check out my YouTube Channel: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UC83DYCmrWfl9ttrhX54jmWA

content:
Posted: December 9, 2016
PROS:+ Batman+ cool story+ cheesy batman one-liners+ casefile investigations+ many unlockable gadgets+ great visuals+ some of the boss fightsCONS:- some glitches in graphics, audio and AI- crashes to desktop happen occasionally- multiplayer part is shutdown since 4th of December 2016- keyboard controls are terrible in some places- some other boss fightsComment:My first Batman game from the Arkham series. As such I cannot compare it to the others, yet. But this also works because it is first on the Arkham game story timeline. The combat is okay but gets a bit more clunky as new enemy types appear. This is coupled with keyboard controls that are not as responsive or well configured. I actually had to swap to a gamepad for the Deathstroke fight (and a couple of more times later in the game). There are lots of collectibles available (Anarky tags, Enigma data packs) and a TON of side missions. Plus 4 challenge ranks you can attempt while playing. But this all contributes to easily missable (and sometimes bugged) content, including some main assassins. Boss fights/levels are hit or miss. While some are great and engaging others become annoying really quick. Some examples - terrible fixed-camera Mad Hatter level and Deadshot hostage level end. A lot of people do not like Deathstroke, but once I switched to gamepad, the fight was actually good. Predator rooms give you options to either stealth or go in with a bang. Although this freedom is crippled by the challenges in Worst Nightmare rank. Because there is a limited amount of predator rooms you will want to do them according to what is in the challenge rank. After you finish up all of the content there is still challenge mode for some trophies but this mode became really annoying/boring fairly quick. Story is what drives this game and, while it is cheesy sometimes, I loved it. However, if you only go for the story the game is rather short. Even so it has glitches and crashed a couple of times. So get it for that nice Batman story or just to roam around Gotham ... but get it on a sale.

number of helpful: 12 of 19 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 26, 2015
												As a young studio best known for porting Batman: Arkham City to Wii U, WB Montreal must have been desperate to prove that it belongs in the same conversation as series creator Rocksteady Games. To its credit, it's hard to tell that Batman: Arkham Origins isn't one of its sister studio's earlier releases. That's some achievement, but it's also a mixed blessing.To begin with, the set-up is as economical as Arkham Asylum or Arkham City. Batman is thrust into Gotham on Christmas Eve after Black Mask puts a $50 million bounty on his head and invites eight super-villains to town to compete for the spoils. As with previous Arkham games, that simple set-up then evolves as Batman races to keep up with events.Arkham Origins doesn't leave the strongest first impression though. After a CG cutscene and a short playable prologue in Blackgate Prison, Batman is dumped into a sparsely occupied Gotham that looks tiny on his Batcomputer map compared to some of the open-world playgrounds we've run around in lately. You're free to travel across it all from the start, but players used to maps dripping with icons may be surprised at its cold emptiness.This isn't a game that lacks depth, though - it's just a game with rare patience. Story missions take place away from the streets in carefully knotted set-piece levels built around single locations - like Penguin's hidden casino♥♥♥♥♥arms-bazaar or Gotham City Police headquarters - and as you make progress the open world gradually fills up with distractions.The initial slow burn is welcome, anyway, because it's an opportunity to luxuriate in the wonderful systems and mechanics that Arkham Origins inherits from its forebears. Batman glides through levels even when he's just walking around, those famous bat ears erect with authority, and he moves fluidly in a crouched run, too, barrel-like thighs pumping him from shadow to vent. But when you start actually gliding, it's a minor revelation, opening his wings to the wind and using the grapple to grasp the edge of a distant chimney, reeling it in and launching him over the crest to continue his flight.Watch me play through the first level of Arkham Origins and provide an overview of some of the systems.We had all this before, of course, but you forget how good it was. The same goes for Batman's many gadgets. You start off with quite a few - batarangs, smoke pellets and explosive gel for blowing holes in walls - and of course you have detective vision, the sonar view mode that maps Batman's surroundings so he can track enemies as they move nervously through the darkness around him. You gain other toys at intervals, including the remote batclaw for setting up tightropes between particular grapple points.Batman remains handy in a fight, too. In hand-to-hand combat, a single attack button allows him to flow between targets, ducking and diving through dense matrices of incoming blows, repelling those that threaten to land by reaching for the counter button. It's still quick to build combos, and the final blow, which the game always puts into slow motion and frames up nicely, often has a satisfying crack to it.The one thing Batman still lacks is a gun or grenade to deal with unsuspecting groups of enemies from afar - he can either wade in with his fists and gizmos or try to isolate and pick them off using stealth - but of course that's the point of the character. There is still a slight frustration though that the game often forces you into direct confrontation rather than letting you choose your own approach, especially as tougher enemies arrive with riot shields, knives and body armour to inject complexity into each fight.Still, that is what Arkham Asylum and Arkham City did, so at least it's canon. As is the way the city starts to fill up with intriguing diversions. The Riddler is back, of course, custodian of unlockable fast-travel points that can only be activated when you break into them. This often involves hopping around adjacent buildings examining the exterior of your prize, like a high-tech octopus feeling around the outside of a bottle to reach the fish inside. Enigma has left his mark in other areas of Gotham, too, and you'll be on his various trails all night.He is probably the highlight of the side missions - again, as usual - although he's far from alone in the dark night. Anarky is fed up with Gotham's corrupt rulers and plans to deal with them somewhat more explosively than Batman, so that's a thing, and there are various other threads to follow once secondary characters - friends and foes - present themselves.2Manoeuvring around enemies to set up stealth takedowns is still fun, although you can autopilot a lot of it with two games' experience under your utility belt.So it's fun crawling over Gotham. It can still feel slightly empty at times - you'll never see a pedestrian who isn't a cheesy thug or a trigger-happy SWAT team member - but among the dark rooftops, smokestacks, red brick facades and Ace Chemicals billboards there emerges plenty to do, and I am loath to scold a game for rebelling against the fad of instant gratification. Besides, some of it is there from the start should you be paying attention. There are a host of character-building challenges to complete, for example, by doing things like performing certain combinations in combat or gliding through rings dotted around the city. These tasks are just sitting there quietly listed in one of the pause menus.The one area where Arkham Origins truly distinguishes itself from Rocksteady's work, of course, is the part of the game that UK studio Splash Damage developed: multiplayer.In Arkham Origins' online mode, three of Bane's mercenaries face off against three of Joker's gang across four maps, fighting over capture points and trying to kill the opposition until they no longer have any Battlefield-style respawn tickets left and can be wiped out.As well as limited-use knockoff versions of Batman's see-through-walls detective vision, and loadouts that can be customised with unlockable weapons and abilities such as an explosive RC blimp, each team can also call on their master when they hit a certain threshold. Bane has powerful melee attacks, while Joker has a pair of pistols good for one-shot kills and spamming explosives.The biggest twist, though, is that two other players control a third team of heroes. Yes! Someone gets to play as Batman! (And Robin.) The heroes have a suite of predatory tools including grapple hooks and various batarangs and can stalk their prey from underground passages as well. They are rewarded for performing a variety of takedowns.Despite the competing objectives, matches are simple to understand and often draw to a nervous conclusion, as Bane and Joker's teams run out of respawn tickets and try to pick each other off while the heroes circle. If a player takes out a hero at this stage, their downed team-mates retake the field, while heroes who die in this endgame lose much of their score.Things can yo-yo very quickly, and while this can mean that the preceding drama feels as though it's more for show than anything, it's tense and exciting every time, and really does result in gang members waving their guns around at the shadows in terror, just as it should.It's a fair amount of fun, then, but it's also the kind of mode you will enjoy for an evening rather than a lifetime. Taken on those terms, it's a welcome inclusion.They also feed into Batman's tech tree, although this is one of the weaker areas of Arkham Origins. Batman is already well outfitted and his most useful additions - like the shock gloves, which allow him to power up electrical items and rain fizzly blows down in combat - are rewarded for making progress in the story, so I generally just invested my XP in tougher armour, which is a bit boring. Tech trees where you find yourself rooting around for the least uninspiring upgrade are always disappointing,

content:
Posted: July 19, 2014
												Arkham Origins is a great game that doesn't deserve the flak it receives from most reviewers. Arkham Origins takes the gameplay mechanics from Arkham City - the responsive freeflow fighting mechanic demonstrating just how badass Batman is and the tightly coordinated predator rooms that allow multiple approaches - and combines it with a great storyline. If you enjoyed Arkham City, you'll enjoy this game. The gameplay isn’t much different from Arkham City. You’ll have some new/replaced items, some new enemy types are introduced, the city has been expanded and they added a new detective mini-game. Ultimately, these are only minor changes from the solid base that Arkham City created. The game doesn’t offer the revolutionary changes that Arkham City did compared to Arkham Asylum, but rather expands on it.The story features both well-known (Joker, Penguin, Bane) as lesser-known characters (Firefly, Shiva, Deadshot). Not every character is part of the main story, so it is advised to try and play the Most Wanted side missions for the full experience. The well-crafted Mad Hatter stage deserves a playthrough.At the time of writing, it appears WB patched most of the bugs. During my three playthroughs (new game, new game+ and I am the night mode, 100%, roughly 70 hours), as well as during the Cold Cold Heart DLC, I experienced only a single non-game breaking bug. This is coming from an inherently more bug-prone Crossfire system. You’ll see most negative reviews because of bugs are pre January 2014.Traditional rating: 8/10

												Oh my, tough one!I loved Arkham City, but this game... I would suggest to get it if only you truly loved Arkham City.This game feels like DLC to Arkham City, nothing is really new (except few gadgeds, but some of them are pretty trivial - glue grenade that does exactly the same as freeze grenade in AC...), it is a prequel to AC therefore every piece of history that you have found in AC will be here (Blackmask, Mr Freeze (paid DLC!), Calendar Man, Croc etc.).Stories are interesting, I will not deny that. But it feels repetetive - there is no element of suprise cause most of the stuff you have already seen in AC. Fight system is the same, there are some new enemies but very few (like 1? or 2?).Map is bigger, it has a bridge to new part of Gotham, which was unavailable in AC. There is also fast travel (which was lacking in AC) which is "a must be" in recent games.To sum up, I feel dissatisfied. I thought I will get a game that will blow me away but instead I get game that feels like AC DLC. There was a huge gap (positive one) between Arkham Asylum and Arkham City. Comparing 2 last productions I would say AO is worse :(. Buy this game only if love Batman universe or if you have loved Arkham City or if it's dirt cheap during sales (was -75% already). I really, really hope that Arkham Knight will be much better and will not give me♥♥♥♥♥♥aftertaste after completing it.

content:
Posted: February 27
												There's definitely some re-tread going on with Batman: Arkham Origins, but the combat, the relatively good story (B-list villain aside), the powerful feeling of being Batman in video game form has only muted my enthusiasm for the franchise by the smallest of marginsBatman’s always made the shadows his ally, but in Batman: Arkham Origins, he finds the shadow of his own previous games impossible to escape from. It’s as good as Batman: Arkham City in most ways, having inherited an outstanding combat system, but it lacks interesting ideas of its own, and it’s missing the polish and attention to detail that makes Arkham City and Arkham Asylum great action gamesIts name, “Arkham Origins,” is a flagrant misnomer - it may be a prequel, but this story is neither about Arkham, nor is it an origin story in any significant way. It’s more of a traditional Batman plot that retreads some of The Dark Knight’s most familiar themes over its roughly eight hours of main story content: a self-destructive insistence on working alone, and how far he’ll go to avoid taking a life - a concept the final battle cleverly toys with. It’s a respectable plot that even concocts a plausible reason for Batman to face so many villains all in one night – a $50 million bounty on his head. But it’s the kind of prequel that screams “What were we thinking when we killed off that incredibly popular character? Undo! Undo!”The actors standing in for long-time Batman and Joker voices Kevin Conroy and Mark Hamill do a good job in emulating their predecessors - Troy Baker’s Joker, in particular, is close enough that I might not have noticed immediately if I weren’t listening for it. Conroy will always be Batman for me, but his understudy does well enough.This younger Batman already has all his signature moves and gear, flies a fancy plane, and is on a first-name basis with pretty much every villain but The Joker. So at the cost of really selling the idea that these events happen prior to the other two games, Origins keeps the foundation of Arkham Asylum and Arkham City’s amazing combat intact, including every gadget in one form or another. (Mr. Freeze’s absence from the rogue’s gallery means the cryo-grenades are now concussion or glue grenades.)Two new enemy types add a little extra variety, notably the martial artists who can counter your attacks. But the only substantial change is one of those things that’s awesome for the first time you use it, but quickly reveals itself as a bad idea. The Shock Gauntlets are among the last gear you unlock, which is good, because once charged (by hitting a few guys in regular combat) and activated, they let you completely ignore everything that makes combat interesting. Riot shields, stun batons, armored thugs – Batman just punches ‘em. They’re basically a win button, and the kind of thing that doesn’t work in a prequel because why would Batman ever get rid of them?Meanwhile, in the stealth fights where Batman picks off armed thugs one by one, there’s another somewhat dirty-feeling win button: a remote grapple that strings up thugs without them even having to walk under a gargoyle. I found myself deliberately avoiding either of those gadgets, because I’m not in this to not fight criminals.Batman games are like pizza: even when they’re not very good, they’re still pretty good. Next to Arkham City, Arkham Origins is a bit of a disappointment in its lack of new ideas and use of win buttons, making it the least interesting of the trilogy. But as excuses to dive back into the excellent free-flowing combat and predator takedowns go, this story isn’t bad.

content:
Posted: March 29, 2014
												It's Arkham, It's Batman. Need I say more? Just don't expect the improvements like Asylum to City, since it isn't Rocksteady. I wish WB had been more daring with it, it's like they were too scared to alienate fans instead of trying out new things. Don't expect anything terribly fresh. It's largely a copy and paste of Arkham City, which, don't get me wrong, isn't a bad thing. Unfortunately the few changes they did make frustrate the heck out of me. I'll update if I find anything else, but I think I've explored most of the games mechanics by now.Pros: Boss fights: Bossfights are fantastic, infinitely better than rocksteady's to be honest, well, a few of them. (poison ivy anyone?) I've had a few so far, but the Deathstroke and Shiva fights were fantastic. Copperhead as well, can't wait to see what comes next. I loved the challenge, and getting the perfect completion trophies was a great was to test my skills. Few generic fights that every game has, but overall they've been great.Open world: lots of enemies, plenty to explore. Alot of the side missions are unlocked by story progression, so expect to be locked into that. If you liked the design of City, it carries into here.Crimes in Progress: I love these. Usually a tough group of enemies, nice difficulty, just don't expect to wrack up good combos without mashing dodge 24/7 (see below)Cons: (so far)Combat: I wish they had copy and pasted it. I wish. Enemies are extremely aggressive, and youll often find yourself being punched in the face while trying to perform a simple strike, and since batman moves in slow mo you cant hit and counter in time. If you played Arkham City to death like I did, youll notice. It's not obvious, but any veteran of those series will feel the slight change. Its ridiculously frustrating how hard it is to maintain any sort of combo without mashing dodge and striking once. The thugs will teleport punch to you, so even if you use freeflow to move 10 feet away, he'll somehow still hit you. I cant even batclaw slam without being punched in the middle of the slam and they weren't anywhere nearby. Really? EDIT: i tried out the combat challenge mode, and the combat feels totally different. Very quick and responsive, felt even faster than it was in previous Arkham iterations. (Deathstroke is so fast i can barely follow how fast he strikes in focus flow) Not sure why its so different.Collectibles: Scan tags, collect data packs, batarang network relays, interrogate informers. All a copy of different systems used in Arkham City and Harley Quinn DLC. I wouldnt mind but its all so mindless, I've yet to encounter a single challenging puzzle like I did in City. Got all the collectibles in City and had a blast. Here it feels like a chore.Flying: I often find it really difficult to simply shoot to the top of a building and boost past. It likes to select the fire escape on the side of the building and makes it incredibly frustrating to get anywhere quickly. And expect alot of flying around, since you cant unlock all the fast travel points from the get go and the drop points can be rather far from the edge of district.Upgrade Trees: I hate these. I hate these with a passion. I get it, its Batman starting out, he has to learn. Anyone who has experience with poorly designed upgrade trees knows what I'm talking about. Oh yeah, by the way, you HAVE to complete challenges in game to get some of the gagdets. They aren't too hard, but it took too long to get my damn sonic batarang.It's a great game, if you loved Asylum and City you'll enjoy it, just don't expect anything too amazing. Hopefully Knight will remedy all the mistakes here.

content:
Posted: March 24, 2016
												Batman: Arkham Origins is the Prequel-Sequel to the previous 2 Arkham games. Developed and published by WB Montreal instead of Rocksteady, one might be turned off to the idea of this game and would be unwilling to give the game a try. I disagree. Here's why:Arkham Origins takes place a few years before Arkham Asylum, 2 years after Bruce Wayne donned the cowl of Batman. One of the leading criminals, Black Mask, is tired of Batman ruining his plans and sends 10 elite mercenaries (some more elite than others) to kill Batman in one night, Christmas Eve, for 50 million dollars. The story mainly follows Batman evading and defeating the mercs, as well as chasing down the Black Mask. As with Arkham City, there are a few twists and turns along the way, bringing a good time to the game.The "Origins" part of the game is very interesting, as it explores the origins of the Joker as the Red Hood (canon in the comics), if not only breifly. It also explores the stuggle Batman is having with himself and how he feels the need to protect gotham from itself and all the super-criminals.Although the voice actors for Batman and the Joker are not the regular that we all know and love (Mark Hamill and Kevin Conroy), the replacements that WB Montreal found are absolutely a great substitute. While not the actors that made the characters what they are, the performances were far from sub-par, and should not be the factor that keeps you from playing the game. You can tell that the actors tried very hard to keep the roles what they were, in order to preserve the legacy. The actor who plays the Joker does a phenomenal job, and I did not even realize that the actor was not Mark Hamill until I heard his monologue around half-way through the game. The Batman actor is a bit more noticeable but nothing to complain about.The map is bigger than Arkham City's, and feels as such. There are plenty of side activities to do when you are tired of (or done with) the main story. The most fun of all of these is definitely the Crime Scenes that you can come across, and pretty much "solve" murders and thefts. There are also radio towers that Enigma (The Riddler) has hacked. These can be restored through fighting through enemies and using your cryptographic sequencer. This is recommended to do as each tower you restore unlocks the district for fast travel, which signifigantly increases the speed of play. The combat and gameplay is not very different from Arkham City or Asylum's, but this isn't a problem to me, as the combat does not need to be changed too much. There are 2 new enemies to fight, the martial arts expert, and Bane's super enforcers. While adding some diversity to the combat, it can feel repetitive at times, and I found myself avoiding combat situations and crime calls during the free roam parts of the game. Overall, this game is a great addition to the Arkham series, even if not near close to the best game in the franchise, and if you plan to play through all of the games, do not forget Arkham Origins. Though nowhere near a perfect game, I personally find it a better game than Arkham City.8.4/10

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 24, 2015
												I'm conflicted about this game.  On the one hand its a very solid title.  Despite it being an obvious cash in on the Arkham series because WB couldn't wait for Knight to reach store shelves it still offers a lot of Batman kicking♥♥♥♥♥enjoyment.  The thing is people are very divisive about this game.  Either its the best in the series or its the worst.  Its just City with a new paint job don't kid yourselves.  City perfected the formula and Origins just came in and said why fix what ain't broke?The gameplay is so similar to City that you wouldn't even know a difference if it was an expansion pack.  The gadgets feel more gimmicky when in previous games they had a practical application.  The remote claw replaces the line launcher and while its amusing it also makes predator sections even more brainlessly easy when they were already easy.  Who needs to actually stealthily take down baddies with guns when you can hook them to things and each other and take out 5/6 of the room without even moving?  On the flipside combat seems to have gotten harder with counters being a little different in timing and its a lot harder to hold up bigger combos when more variety in enemy types like venom brutes and martial arts experts.  The shock gloves feel like just evening things out at this point.The story is probably this game's strongest part.  Without spoiling much this is Batman early in his career.  He's more stubborn and hot headed.  One of my favorite parts is Gordon and how his character progresses through the story and how he distrusts Batman and thats a really cool dynamic.  Young Barbara already got the inkling to become oracle here as well.  They do a really cool plot twist that is just as disapointing and I wont spoil it here.  I will say that Bane is the strongest part IMO.  As someone who has been waiting for a proper bane in something I am so happy with how they treated him here.  It also kinda helps explain why is the way he is in previous games.  Read the Knightfall comic storyline and see why not even Dark Knight Rises got Bane right IMO.I'm just rambling at this point.  I'm a big Batman nerd if you couldn't tell lol.Also shout out to the awesome voice acting across the board.Finally the last thing I want to talk about is the open world.  This worked so well in City beacause it was all interesting.  It was densly packed and felt bigger than it actually was.  In this case its feels empty.   It feels like a city built around a video game instead of a video game built around the city.  Sense of scope is all scewed.  Parked cars all look like they were designed for midgets.  It doesn't look like a city at all.  It looks like a close up of a model city.  People complained about the riddler trophies in City and how many they were and how they got "annoying getting them all" but at least those were interesting to get.  In this there is literally no challenge to getting any of them.  Errr I mean Enigma data packs :/.  You come across one and 5 seconds in you either have the gadget capable of getting it or you don't and move on.  This is actually its saving grace because prepare yourself for this game's biggest let down.  There is no reason to getting these.  Some XP and a little throwback to previous games.  Catching Riddler in City had a point.  He had hostages.  He needed to be dealt with.  He was a real threat and there was more to it than just collecting♥♥♥♥♥♥like an old 90s platformer.....  In this he's  blackmailing criminals and Batman has to stop that because.........  thats worse than beating them up?  Ok then well the completionist in me hated this.  There was no fun in getting them and absolutely no pay off because you don't even catch him.  Save the time and ignore this part of the game and it will be much more enjoyable I promise you.So TL:DR gameplay is almost exactly the same as Arkham City.  Story is cool.  Game map and side missions are lame and boring.  The good outweigh the bad.  If you like Batman you'll enjoy this.

content:
Posted: March 31, 2015
												Have you played the previous Arkham games? No? Then do yourself a favor and don't start with Arkham Origins.If you played the others and liked it then you'll likely enjoy this one as well. It is inferior in many ways though, and I'll try to make a comparison of the most pertinent aspects below.Did you enjoy the story hinted on the trailers? If so, I'm  sorry to say this but you'll be disappointed. I won't spoil the surprise (even though I find it hard to believe it's a surprise to anyone by now) but there's a very obvious twist that simply negates the whole story advertised in the trailers. After the disappointment with the story passed I actually quite enjoyed it though! there are some interesting moments and characters. Nothing fantastic but it does its job competently.  Considering this is a prequel they certainly made some strange decisions reagarding the story. We know the villains, we know Alfred never dies, we know Batman doesn't die etc. These things can't really be used as tension effectively, but they certainly tried. They should have used the opportunity to introduce some new characters and put some real tension in there, but that's my opinion.But the true problem with this game is the obvious lack of polish. Bugs, glitches, freezes,crashes, performance drops... you name it, Arkham Origins has it. The lack of polish also shows on most of the gameplay features. A few examples: when in combat mode, the camera will be your worst enemy, showing the wall, hiding behind light posts, losing sight of batman or, when not being completely against you, just sitting the least helpful orientation possible with every enemy on the wrong side of the camera. Other example of lack of polish in gameplay is when gliding accross the city. You'll find yourself frustrated by the grapple's edge detection system. It has the habit of not detecting obvious edges you can see right in front of you, sometimes detecting edges you have no intention of grappling to etc. It's a less satisfying experience to say the least. These examples just illustrate the way the game was rushed to the shelves. It lacks polish, the kind of things solved by tweaking of parameters until everything feels right.My last complaint is the zipline feature. This was one of the fun things in other games, all you needed was a wall behind and in front of you to zip accross it! Fun and a gameplay element that opens up so many possibilities. In this game they ditched that for a zip line you can attach to nodes that are put on the map by the level designer. It's so boring. It's essentially a door/key system in disguise. A very similar dumb move was made by Thief developers when ditching the freedom of rope arrows in favor of predetermined nodes where you can put your rope. It's just a fancy key to a door.It's hard to find something they did better than previous games. I like the graphics a lot! but it's not exactly better, it's just different, more realistic style. But I do welcome the different approach, it looks very nice.If we weren't comparing with previous Batmans (which admittedly is a difficult position for any game to be in) I would say the bugs are the main problem with it. Some of them are absolutely game breaking! but if you can endure that this is a great game. It has my recommendation.

content:
Posted: November 30, 2013
												*Contains minor spoilers*I’ve been a fan of the Arkham games since Asylum, and they never fail to impress. That being said, Origins feels like a step backwards from its predecessor, Arkham City.Based during the early years of Batman’s career, the game focuses on a plot by the infamous crime lord, the Black Mask. I’m not familiar with the comics, so I was very happy to see a new primary antagonist replacing the Joker. The only problem was that Black Mask wasn’t the primary antagonist; it was surprise surprise, the Joker AGAIN. It was during the unveiling of this revelation that I became upset with Origins. I understand that he’s Batman’s arch enemy, but he had such a large role in the previous two games that I just wanted a break from his jokes. It became so much easier to compare the game to Arkham City, which was not a good idea.The previous game, Arkham City, had a very deep and original setting. A prison city that was filled with Gotham’s worst criminals was very interesting. In contrast, Origins features a Gotham city roughly twice the size, but only half as interesting. Random criminals prowl the streets and no sign of other life can be found. I wanted cars, pedestrians, and so much more. I expected a living city.There were parts of the game that impressed me though. I really liked the upgrade system. It’s still quite basic, but a definite step up from previous games that pretty much unlocked half of the upgrades from the get go. They added some cool new gadgets that I used quite often. As for the bad guys, I felt they didn’t have enough screen time. One by one they showed up, you fought with them for 15 minutes, and that was the end of them. In particular, the fight against Deathstroke was one of the greatest boss battles I’ve ever played, but after beating it, he never made a return. What’s more disappointing was that his character was only available to play as in the boring and mostly generic challenge maps, rather than the actual campaign. Some of the other villains came and went without me really remembering them at all cough cough Electrocutioner. It kind of felt like Warner Brothers sold the game on the premise that there would be plenty of bad guys to go around, but delivered a mediocre performance from them. Quality is always better than quantity in my opinion.The multiplayer is a new addition to the franchise and I don’t really know how to describe it. I feel as though the game didn’t need it and it was an attempt to get people to continue to play the game. There are times when it’s quite enjoyable, but I always felt as though it needed to be re-worked based on certain over-powered features such as the criminals detective vision.Despite the uninspiring plot twist, the often annoying multiplayer, and the incredibly familiar gameplay, the game wasn’t that bad. I wasn’t too upset, but wasn’t too impressed either. I can safely say it felt like a 6/10 experience on the whole. Worth playing if you like the Joker, not so much if you wanted more.

content:
Posted: September 19, 2016
												Oneday maybe they'll make a game called "Batman in Atlantis."  Or "Batman on Krypton."  Or "Batman in Metropolis."  But everyone knows Batman spends his nights in Gotham.When Rocksteady made "Arkham Asylum," it was the best Batman game ever.  It was the closest thing to "being Batman." The only downside was that you were being Batman somewhere other than Gotham.  Can you imagine a Batman game on the moon?  It wouldn't be the same, would it?  Batman walks the rooftops and swoops down on dark alleys.  He doesn't spend 365 nights a year in prison corridors.He guards Gotham City."Arkham City" took that into account.  But the aesthetic of an abandoned city district turned into a live-in prison is not the glass mountains of the financial district.It's not Gotham."Arkham Knight" finally brought us the giant metropolis of Gotham City, rooftop by rooftop, high-rise by high-rise.  With the Batmobile itself to fling around corners in fiery abandon.  Batman: Check.  Batmobile: Check.  Gotham: Check.  Everything was finally in place.  It's a masterpiece.  The summation of decades of Batman stories and runs.  But between "City" and "Knight" lies "Origins.""Origins" was the game that first left Arkham behind, with it's crazed lunatics and asylum setting.  It's prison decor and cockroaches.  There was good stuff there.  But it was a Batman story on the edge of canon.  With "Titan Joker" it simply walked up to that edge and jumped off.  And it's that very plot point that is integral to the entire Arkhamverse."Origins" left behind the ever more insane antics of villians from "Asylum" and "City," and boiled Batman down to his essence.  A crimefighter.  A detective.  You know, DC, "Detective Comics."  It's got more "police procedural" in it than any of the others.  Rocksteady made games about Batman losing his sanity.  "Origins" is about keeping a cool head and following the clues.  All while the mob has a contract out on your head."Origins" left the asylum behind.  It paved the way for "Arkham Knight."It brought us Gotham City.

content:
Posted: September 14, 2014
												A decent title that stands in the shadow of the two games in the same vein that appeared before it, Batman Arkham Origins is a hard title to recommend even to fans of the other two games. The gameplay copies the other two titles to a T, with no originality thrown in. This is made worse since the combat in the other games flowed much better and this game generally has a small list of bugs. The story is very run of the mill, I found myself extremely disappointed as it started running over old villans for the third time now instead of using the newer villans to greater effect. The game does so little to make itself different from the others, and is so sloppy in execution that the game drags on towards the end.6/10 If you're a fan you can consider getting it on sale, but as a large fan of the past two games I honestly regret the time I spent playing this. Still a great game for completionists with too much free time, and it's not entirely half bad. However Bam Ham Origins would be better to rest in the grave while we wait for the new title from the original team.

content:
Posted: June 14, 2015
												Ehh... it's okay.This one isn't made by the same people that did Arkham Asylum/City, but it plays pretty much exactly the same. And since that was already good gameplay there's little more I can say about it. The story takes place when Batman is still relatively new at his work apparently, but the only real way you see it is in how other characters act towards you. Otherwise, all the skills and gadgets are there for you to use. So it all feels kind of disingenous when everyone acts like you are this new vigilante who might not actually be real, but you have the full skillset of the Batman that everyone later knows. Not exactly what this game said its Batman was like.One highlight of sorts is the voice acting: Batman and the Joker got new VA's for this, and yet I couldn't really tell the difference. They both sound close enough to Kevin Conroy and Mark Hamill that, had I not known in advance that the latter wasn't the Joker anymore, I wouldn't have forced myself to look it up to check for sure. So I guess that's something. Oh, and our new Joker is the same guy who voiced Booker Dewitt from Bioshock Infinite. I thought that was neat.I can't call this a bad game, but I wasn't really into it either. I'll give this a "yes" because there is nothing fundamentally wrong with this game, but it is, without a doubt, the weakest entry in the "Arkham" series thus far.Maybe i'm just annoyed I won't 100% this game because it has multiplayer achievements. XD

content:
Posted: April 27, 2014
												Batman: Arkham Origins manages to be the worst Arkham game that, disappointingly, barely does enough to justify its asking price of £30, especially if you have played Arkham City. Lets start with the good things. - The story in Origins is very good, possibly the best out of the current trilogy. While there are pacing problems, the overall plot is deep, thought out and even manages to surprise in a few areas. - Sound design and the soundtrack are superb; feeling like they had a real production value and weren't just simply overlooked. (unlike some other things) - The voice acting is incredible, for the most part, with Troy Baker as The Joker stealing the show. (though Roger Craig Smith as Batman does a pretty good job at emulating Kevin Conroy from previous games) I must admit it's jarring to hear Batman's voice at first, (being so used to Conroy's work) but it doesn't take long to get acclimatised, with halfway through the game, barely noticing the difference.- The game manages a decent length of around 10-12 hours for the main story.Now on to the negatives.- The game world, while being of a decent size, is too cumbersome to travel round. Most of your time in the open world will be spent travelling from A to B by grappling rooftops. The fast travel does alleviate this, but you have to unlock the various points by overtaking radio towers as side missions, making the whole thing feeling a bit like too much work.  - Most of the side missions are now completely seperated from the main plot, they are now mostly unintresting and uninspiring filler.- The combat is only slightly improved from City, and with the inclusion of the new shock gloves, makes it far too easy to beat enemies.- Most of the little refrences and in-jokes to other DC comics which made the previous games that little bit more awesome are gone, it feels like most of the devs aren't as passionate as Rocksteady and it would have be nice for a couple of easter eggs here and there. - The first part of the plot (about the assassins) doesn't quite gel with the rest of the story and feels like an excuse to shoe horn some D-list DC villans. - The Penguin's 'assistants' are some of the worst characters I have ever seen in a Batman game. Plus the thick (what I assume is meant to be cockney) accent of one of them is so horrible, it's on par with Bolo Santosi in Just Cause 2.  - While I haven't played much of the multiplayer and while it was fun, it lacks depth to keep my interest, making it only passable at best.- The biggest flaw of Arkham Origins, however, is its MOUNTAIN OF BUGS. While most of the game breaking bugs have been reportedly fixed, there are still a plethora of visual bugs, such as the skybox having circular clouds covering it, textures spazzing out and not unlocking certain areas of the game. Fortunately, in my personal experience, all it needs it a checkpoint restart. Others haven't been so lucky. As WB Montreal aren't fixing the game anymore a minority will most likely never finish the game, buy at your own risk.This game is nowhere near worth its full asking price, and some of it is really good and well done, which only makes it more painful to say that if you have never played the Arkham games NEVER EVER PLAY THIS. If you have played the previous two then wait for a sale, only then it will be worth at least a vague look.4/10

content:
Posted: July 8, 2014
												Batman : Arkham Origins is yet another installment in the popular Arkham series, but it doesn't fall in line with the other 2 games seeing as developement was handled by WB Montreal. Right off the bat I'd like to say that WB did a great job with this game considering how new they are as a studio. Yes, when you start playing, you'll see a different, slightly more cartoonish batman, you'll eventually get over it. The first few hours will feel very empty and pretty much dissapointing, if you have played the other 2 games of this series. The overworld feels empty, geometry detail is very simplified even with DX11 effects enabled. Overall the mood was pretty badly executed as far as the city itself goes. You will only see impressive visual and level design once you go indoors, where lights are elaborate, cinematic and colorful. Colour is much more abundant this time. The combat system, both predator (stealth) and close up combat, remain pretty much identical to previous versions, aside from a few superficial changes like sounds. There is however a new mechanic that increases your damage output towards the second half of the story, but I don't want to spoil that for you. I found that close up combat felt more satisfying than stealth, simply because the stealth rooms were not designed for you to be creative, really. Rocksteady made extremely enjoyable stealth challenges, and WB basically was not capable of getting anywheres near that level of intricate design. All you really have to do in these sections is grapple around, wait for an enemy to seclude himself from the others, and take him down by gliding behind him and performing a silent takedown, rinse and repeat. So basically, this time close up completely trumps stealth, where as I found in City and Assylum, the stealth was more enjoyable than close up. Gadgets remain from the previous games, some replaced by something similar, essentially reskinning previous ideas. The main thing that WB really did right this time, is the storytelling, and the way you progress through the game. Arkham City's progression was fairly short, focused and let's face it, not very complex. Origins obviously tells the story of Batman's beginning, when he was considered a criminal just like the Joker, or Black Mask. Although Batman remains fairly emotionally flat, he lets out a lot of steam, and even interrogates many enemies through semi-torture, something that was rarely adressed before. Batman seems weaker in this game, he is actually a real, relatable person, in some ways. There is a sense of character progression that was completely absent in the other games. Hell, you even finally see some sort of relation between Batman and Joker that actually makes some sense, and let me tell you that relation becomes extremely interesting, and at times it almost seemed that Joker admired Batman, or even loved him. TL:DR: Origins is a narrative experience, lacking the immersion of the previous 2 games but replacing that with a cohesive, understandable story with much more variety. Is it better than the others? No. but is it worse? I can't really say that, either.It is definitely worth the price that I got it at, during the summer sale.

number of helpful: 6 of 8 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 25, 2013
												Being an Arkham "ORIGINS" game: it's a prequel! And it both sucks and rules at the same time. The success of the prequel comes from the story aspect where WB Montreal explains how "wuvable B-Man" met around 10-12 of the Batman franchise characters! This will include Deadshot, Jim Gordon, Barbara Gordon (and her secret identity ^^), and some bosses I was really looking forward to, as seen in the trailers: Copperhead and DeathStroke!The prequel nature of this title debacles in the gameplay aspect since at the start you have more twice the♥♥♥♥♥♥you had in the beginning of Arkham City! This includes the Grappnel Accelerator, among other useful gadgets.The gameplay is the same as AC (some small tweaks and combat gadgets have been added) which is great! Now animations feel a bit more fluid but Batman feels slightly slower overall. You see, in Arkham City, you could punch a guy so fast he couldn't punch/counter. In Origins combat, while very familiar, feels harder and requires more skill from the player.You should also be happy to know that the game works perfectly with mouse and keyboard and the PC port is really good!The graphics are an overall improvement over Arkham City, snow effects are f*cking extraordinary: easily the best I've ever seen! Particle effects are also really fantastic and the punch sounds are beefy and powerful and you feel like a badass!Like said above, sound design is solid! The enemy's guns sound like guns, specially the freaking snipers which are really annoying since they take around 40% of your health per-shot! Every time you punch a guy you feel like you are going to get your whole arms through the thug's face! Moving to the story: It's the best of the Arkham franchise! It's well done, it has enough twists and "Holy-sh*t! Awesome!" moments to keep you pumped until the very end, which is satisfying enough (since it's a prequel, the previous 2 games follow the events of this game, so this game's ending isn't a conclusion to the batman games by any stretch of the imagination!).This game also has cool enough side missions to give you a few more gameplay hours without outright boring you from the beginning! I must highlight the 2 assassin/boss side quests!Another thing this game pulls off really well are the boss fights! They all feel different, varied and try to put the various gadgets you have to good use!Origins is also the first Batman Arkham game to have a Multiplayer mode! Is it good? Yeah! The concept is genious and a nice variation over the standard Multiplayer modes. The are 3 teams, 2 of them are standard thugs with guns (the 3rd-person view and handling is surprisingly good! Guns also feel good, surprisingly enough!), the other team is of 2 players (where one is robin and another is batman, and they play nicely, just like in the single player (well, batman that is, you can't play as robin...but he plays exactly like batman but with a bullet shield. He plays just like Batman Arkham City (both the Robin DLC and the Harley Quinn DLC) which is nice!).The Multiplayer customization is vast and extremely deep, it has packs that you get by completing stuff in the SP campaign and MP challenges and stuff like that. There are many guns and level ups in the thugs! As for Batman and Robin it's isn't as varied and deep, but that was kind of expected...My biggest problem with the multiplayer is definately the matchmaking system: it's console ported and it doesn't work very well...it never does, anyways...You will have lag throughout your gameplay sessions but nothing gameplay-breaking! It's perfectly servicable and compared to other bullsh*tty matchmaking games like Aliens: Colonial Marines, Arkham Origins works amazingly well!Overall the game seems kinda perfect, doesn't it? Yeah, almost: It's launch was a disaster (I've seen worse trainwrecks though!) and right now, it has like a bug or two very far in-between and sometimes enemies will get stuck on the terrain causing you to sometimes break your whole combo chain. But since I'm not a combo-chain junky, I didn't mind that. I was more worried about the questionable geometry overall: sometimes there are very small places where you can be and right at the side, you can't. You can't crouch and pass under a pipe when in some other, narrower places, you can, among other annoying stuff. But this is really far in-between and don't break the experience at all. I never got stuck in terrain or anything like that, which is swell! :DOverall, what's wrong with this game is: rare but annoyingly low res textures! Mediocre matchmaking system! Anti-climactic bossfights: (Shiva and Deadshot come to mind) and Bane's is repeated like 3 ♥♥♥♥ing times!Nothing that stops me from recommending it at full retail price of 49,99€ or regional equivalent (I bet Australian pricing is absolute ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t so there you have it..)-It's easily a 9/10, one of my GOTY nomenees and overall I'd say it beats Arkham City in terms of gameplay, gadgets, boss fights, etc. (well, except the fact that AC was 100% fluid bug-free gameplay and it was highly detailed. Origins is more unpolished than it's predecessor, sadly...)-So that is it, my review of Origins, I think I'll do Dishonored after this, I've already been vastly asked to so a review on it.EDITED FOR TYPOS

The voice acting of Roger Craig Smith (Batman) and Troy Baker (The Joker) works well, albeit Kevin Conroy & Mark Hamill will be missed going forward. Thumbs up!

content:
Posted: October 6, 2016
												PROS: It has an interesting plot. The predator sections work pretty well.CONS: Where do I begin?The combat is buggy and does not work well. It often seems like the game is designed to make you break your combo. Counters don't always work. In fact on the harder difficulty you have less time to counter, but the counter indicators stay up – meaning you can think you can counter when you can't. Or Batman will just refuse to counter. Or your combo will just drop for no good reason. I've run into other glitches as well, where quickfire gadgets will just not work, causing the combo to drop. The camera also tends to be too close to Batman, meaning characters can hit you from off-camera and give you no opportunity to counter or even know they were there. Brutes do unblockable attacks and can't be taken down with special combo moves, and you'll often be fighting them in a narrow space with barely any room to dodge.The combat locations are also frequently badly designed, as fights occur in closed-in spaces that give you little space to maneuver and plenty of space for the camera to get stuck. In one case I think I was fighting five guys, one with a shield, in a space the size of an elevator.The abilities tree is also annoying. Many of the most useful special abilities are locked off until later sections of the game and require the completion of entire separate sidequests. For example, disarm and destroy – one of the best ways to deal with shields, guns, and stun batons – cannot be obtained until completing a sidequest that does not appear until the game is three-fourths completed. The grapnel disarm is also locked off until at least halfway through the game.The 'challenges' are also extremely annoying because they, too, are tiered. And worse they don't 'stack' and several special abilities are easily lost forever because they require grinding out challenges that can ONLY be completed in a few areas that do not respawn. If you want the sonic shock batarang, better get Worst Nightmare Rank 6 completed in the bank during the first time you are there or you'll have to do it during the Deadshot mission. You get two chances. Enjoy. If you want to unlock the Dark Knight skin you will spend a lot of the game grinding out challenges.The checkpoints are also badly located. If you need to restart a predator room, for example, it won't save when you begin, so you will often have to spend a minute or two to get back to the room and probably go through an unskippable cutscene, which can be annoying when you need to redo a room to try and complete something very specific and easy to mess up (like knock three people down with one propane tank).I should discuss the boss battles as well. Many people seem to enjoy them but I did not. The Deathstroke battle was really a glorified QTE in terms of how it worked. The Firefly fight was a mixture of QTE, dodging and using the same quickfire gadgets over and over. And the Bane fight was a more annoying and less-good version of the fight from Arkham Asylum. I felt the Mr Freeze fight in Arkham City was by far the best Arkham boss battle and nothing here is close.I find this game immensely frustrating. I've played the other Arkham games – Asylum, City and Knight – and I just cannot like this game. The plot is interesting. But the actual gameplay is so irritating I find myself screaming in rage. Play the other games. Skip this one.

content:
Posted: December 31, 2013
												The most important question you have to ask yourself, when considering whether or not to purchase Batman Arkham Origins, is "what do I want from a sequel?". If you want innovation, you will be disappointed. If you want the same content that you've previously enjoyed, you will be satisfied.I personally fall into the second category. I could name several games whose sequels have alienated their existing fanbase by changing too much, so I won't criticise Origins for sticking with a successful formula.Origins is almost identical to City, in terms of gameplay mechanics and mission structure. We still have the small scale open world of Gotham, which allows us to take on secondary missions against the lower profile villains in any order. We still have the story missions, which are more linear, require the use of gadgets to bypass obstacles, contain a mixture of direct and stealth combat, and finish with a boss fight against one of the more high profile villains. And we still have the mild puzzle element provided by the Riddler trophies.Combat is as fluid and tactical as always, combining attacks, counters, dodges, gadgets and takedowns, along with a variety of enemy types, some of which require specific moves to penetrate their defences. There are a few new gadgets/abilities, but nothing really revolutionary. I quite like the shock gloves though, which charge up as you hit people, and when activated will add electricity damage to Batman's punches.The story is okay, but it suffers from the same problem that every prequel will in my eyes. I already know what happens later, so I know certain events cannot possibly happen. For example, when certain characters are in life or death situations, but I know they are alive in Asylum or City, I know they cannot possibly die in Origins, which makes those scenes lack the tension they should have. However, I did like that a few different villains were worked in, which allowed me to expand my knowledge of the Batman universe.Origins is very good from a technical point of view. The graphics are fantastic, although maybe there's more of a wow factor for me because I played the previous two games on my Xbox 360. The level of detail in the backgrounds, such as shop signs and wall posters, really brings Gotham to life. However I did have to turn off some PhysX smoke effects to get a consistent framerate. Voice acting is pretty good. I was worried about the changes to key roles, especially losing Kevin Conroy and Mark Hamill, but this wasn't a problem and their replacements did a good job.I played with a 360 pad because that's what I'm familiar with for this series, and it worked perfectly on this PC version. I didn't notice any bugs at all. Length depends on how interested you are in hunting down all the Riddler stuff, but I've gone over 20 hours and still have things to do, so value for money is great.

content:
Posted: October 27, 2013
												Arkham Origins exceeds on a technical level, having some really good looking character models and good looking environments. As mentioned it doesn't feel as alive as it could be, but it's not a bad looking game by any means. The soundtrack is one of the biggest rewards here. It's a really good one. About what you'd expect from an Arkham game. The only thing that keeps Arkham Origins down is that so much of it feels like a retread of familiar territory. There's nothing here that really tries to build on the foundation of what was already established in the game before it. Arkham City did a good job of building up on what was established in Asylum despite having a lot of familiar gameplay. It feels like the developers here were playing it safe. The good news is that Origins isn't a step back. It's just not a big step forward. It does have it where it counts, though. A strong story and a good narrative to accompany it. If you liked the previous Arkham games then Origins is worth your time.

content:
Posted: January 2, 2014
												Batman: Arkham Origins should have been a standalone expansion to the Arkham series.A quick note about glitches: from the 20 hours of gameplay, I encountered some animation bugs but sadly, one major bug that would not let me finish the game with keyboard and mouse at the climax of the game in the chapel.While everybody is talking about the game being riddled with bugs, I cannot help but feel that Arkham Origins was made to cash in on the popularity of the Arkham series. While the story that is set on Christmas Eve is neat, the writing is sloppy, and the assassins are making a lot of dumb and contradicting decisions. Even though I played Arkham City two years ago, I can tell that some of the assets were re-used in this game. Moreover, the gameplay has not changed much, except for some additions to your equipment. So just take what made the Arkham games great, then rinse, repeat.Fans of the Arkham games sooner or later will ask the following questions:- Why does Batman start out with all of his equipment from Arkham City at the beginning of the game?- Where are all the people in Arkham? I guess they are all locked inside, right...- Why is the writing so forced in some areas, especially with the Joker?Do not get me wrong: Arkham Origins is a very enjoyable game and there are some nice moments in it, but this whole origin story could have been dealt with much, much better.If you played Arkham Asylum and Arkham City, you should not buy the game at full price.

content:
Posted: November 19, 2014
												I am writing this review for people that have played Batman : Arkham City (AC) and wonder if they should get Batman : Arkham Origins (AO).If you are looking to get your mind blown by a massive improvement between the two games (say new mechanics, new engine, new gameplay features, new playable characters, maybe vehicles, etc.), then you will be disappointed : AO is basically a glorified AC. It does not bring much more than AC already did. In certain area (playable character), it actually brings less.But if you are looking to extend the AC experience, on a new town with a new campaign, then AO is definitely the game to go for and it will not disappoint you.Let me put some Arkham Origins in your Arkham City :AO is indeed "only" a second version of AC, but this is a very good second version of AC. You will get a few new gadgets, a lot of new combat perks, a new "in game integrated" achievement system (that you must fulfill to unlock a specific serie of combat perks), among other things.There is now a system which rewards you for your performance after every encounter, with an XP multiplier : the better you do, the more XP you get. This is a very good addition in that it forces you to play well and try different things (do not lose combo, do not get hit, use different takedowns, etc.)They made something different with the boss fights, which are sort of based on quick time events (QTE). While I'm not a fan of QTE, to say the least, it does make up for more cinematic fights and the game is quite forgiving in that if you die, you'll get to retry at the last "stage" of the boss fight you died in. The "amount" of QTE depends on the boss, so not all the fights play the same. "I've read everywhere that this game is GLITCHED to the bone!"On that matter, my quick recap as of november 2014 :- the main campaign does not suffer any bug or glitch ;- I did not encounter any problem in the side-missions.Yet, there are two things. First, the game can sometimes "bug out" when you need to interrogate a thug. The "Y" icon does not appear when you get close to him. It can be fixed by restarting the fight. Since this bug is quite rare, the fights are quite cool and the restart option quite forgiving (you respawn close), it's ok.Second, and this one is not ok, is a glitch with the Enigma datapack. Now, this is particularly annoying because in this game, they made it way more appealing to collect the Enigma datapacks than it was in AC. In Arkham City, I did not really want to look for and solve all 400ish (!!) datapacks. Simply did not want to. In AO, the datapacks are fewer, and they have a much better integration in the game. You get to interrogate thugs which reveal the locations of a few datapacks, which then appear on your map. This is great. But at least one puzzle (extortion file 3, datapack 6) is glitched : you cannot complete it. Which defeats the purpose of collecting any of them, since you can't complete the collection in the end. Really bad.Also, there is a grapple situation. You will not be able to move as freely as you were in AC. Many roofs will not accept your grapple, while they would have in AC. Even if you somewhat get used to it, it remains annoying during all the campaign because you always try to "grapple up" and can see many places where it "should work", but no, it will not. Mildly annoying. Final impression :So all in all : if you really enjoyed AC and are looking for some additionnal content, definitely grab AO. Despite its flaws, I actually had a better time in AO due to the very satisfying combat system, meaningful achievement system, map interface, decent story, good predator maps, etc. For me, it has a been a better AC.

content:
Posted: August 8, 2014
												Batman: Arkham Origins is definitely a game. But I bet the one person on my friends list who reads these wants more. So in this Batman game you play as Batman. Big surprise there; and I was waiting so eagerly in line for this game so I could play as bloody Catwoman again. The difference is that this time you’re beating up thugs in all of Gotham city instead of just a part of it. Don’t know why because the map is the same size anyway. Obviously the people in charge of Gotham are true visionaries to double the city limits and then section it off. The character list was actually different this time though. Instead of fighting Two Face, Penguin, Bane and the Joker you will be fighting Deathstroke, Penguin, Bane and the Joker. Well I didn’t say it was a big difference. Apparently every villain is supposed to reflect something of Batman; the Joker is his opposite and Deathstroke is his equal in combat. So hell if I know what Penguin reflects. Perhaps it’s Batman’s insecurities or perhaps I’m just trying to make this segment longer. I should remember to cross out the last sentence later.There are two things to do in Gotham city; king-hit pedestrians and label them as thugs or collect Riddler trophies, but let’s be honest, you won’t do the latter. You can finally traverse the Batcave; a privilege I never collected upon because there was nothing in the Batcave with the exception of clutter. Maybe there was a secret, but bugger if I could be bothered to find it. I now see this series taking the Halo methodology in the sense that the developers said Origins was going to be the final game, but now the Arkham series has been taken back by Warner Bros. who have already announced the next game. So I guess I’ll see you back here when that bolt from the blue arrives. And for the record, this game has the twisted oddity of not having Nolan North voice acting a superhero/villain.
