content:
Posted: July 3, 2014
												As much as it would shorten things to say that if you liked or are at least familiar with previous arkham games, you won't find much new here. You have virtually the same gadgets, same fighting system, same UI, similar city, the only thing that really changed was the voice actors and storyline and for the most part, that’s totally fine if all you wanted was more batman and the DLC for arkham city just wasn't enough, and for the most part, that was me. As of writing, I haven't actually completed the game, but I feel like I got a pretty good impression as to where everything is headed. Because this is a prequel to the other arkham games, it can't really throw too much at you in terms of story as to not mess with the canon, and this kind of permeates the entire game. Everything feels like its playing it safe, and no real effort has been put in to expanding on the previous games in any light, though again, this isn't really a bad thing, it's just something that will constantly be nagging at you in the back of your head as you play.The gameplay mechanics are virtually untouched except for a few minor things relating to the upgrade path. And again, not really bad, because the previous mechanics it uses, are probably some of the best brawler mechanics in recent time. One thing I can do without though is the often clunky PC controls, half of my deaths could be attributed to the weird key presses required to dodge and preform special moves. This was a problem in the previous titles, and I feel like there really isn't anything that can be done about it, so I feel like some sort of "360 pad required" tag would be nice.The story isn't really anything special so far, and I’m not sure whether it really will be either, since again, it can't really do a whole lot due to its prequel nature. The thing that stood out to me the most though was the replacement of two of the main characters, Batman and The Joker. In the previous arkham games, they were voiced by their cartoon counterparts. The joker epically was made by Mark Hamill, who is absent in this game. The Joker replacement isn't bad, but Batman, instead of sounding level headed yet very, what’s the word I’m looking for, stern? Now sounds like he is constantly angry and thinks half yelling makes him sound scary. It’s just something that got on my nerves slowly over time. This could have been explained by Batman not being as controlled or weathered by the years, but it’s never brought up and Batman is just as, or oddly if not more capable in this game that in the future games, it just made less sense the more I pondered it. Another thing is the city, while it seems to be bigger, it has less nooks and crannies, and is missing the hidden riddler riddles of previous games to seem "better" in any sense, and it just feels like arkham city all over again since its still all cordoned off and populated only by thugs, I don't ever recall seeing one civilian in the game outside of a few scripted cutscenes and segments. Again, this is sort of explained by there being a storm on Christmas Eve, but I really just found it odd.Now, as much as I griped, I still find the game very enjoyable, and would definitely recommend it to anyone looking for more batman, or even just getting into the series, since playing them out of order probably doesn't help.

The other fights, while neat to watch, are pretty quick time event heavy.-Only one new gadget is cool, Glue Grenades. Everything else feels like a gimmick or has been in a previous game in the series.-Collectibles feel worthless. You get XP by getting them, but since you only upgrade the gadgets you like, it feels like a waste.Pick this up if it's cheap and you're bored, everyone else should replay the others.

content:
Posted: July 1, 2015
												This was a damn great game. Comparing this game to most other games just seems unfair. The story is amazing, the graphics are amazing, the sound is amazing and it all runs and looks very good on my slightly outdated rig. Nothing was done poorly save for the fact that the game has quite a few more bugs in it than would be desirable. If you have never played a game in the Arkham series than you will very much enjoy this game, although I would personally recommend going in order of release (Asylum, City then Origins). That all being said this game is both a prequel and a fairly stand alone story so you can play it out of order if you want.Now, after all that being said let's get some context of where I think this game stands in the series by first stating what I think of the first two games. I consider Batman: Arkham Asylum to be one of the few perfect games ever made. That being said I didn't care for Arkham City all that much. I did still quite like it but I felt that Asylum did everything better. The downsides are that for one the combat feels slightly slower and easier, not by a whole lot but it is noticeable. Being that Asylum felt like it had a perfect difficulty I see this as a downside. Another is that the open world design of City felt unnecessary as you were still locked in an asylum like before but this time it essentially just had a large outdoor room connecting everything. In short it may have been technically open world but it wasn't very open and it wasn't very world either. Asylum however was spooky and claustrophobic and it just worked. Another issue with City was the story. City was all over the place in a way. In Asylum we mainly had the Joker and few other villains on the way and that was fine but with City it just couldn't keep its focus on who the main villain was. Also Asylum had one silly moment in regards to the last part of the game but City felt like it had many silly moments through out.That all being said I would place this game just slightly under Asylum but above City. The combat is back to actually being somewhat difficult as it is sped up from City's slower combat. This kind of all goes out the window once you get a certain upgrade halfway through the game but even then I would hold Origin's combat above City's. Another thing done better is the city itself. For once in the series you actually get to be outside of an asylum's walls and actually stop crimes in progress and solve crimes and such. It actually feels like you are inside of a city which is further helped by about doubling the size of the map from City. Lastly is the story. My god, Origin's story just might be the best. We see a younger Batman who doesn't have much experience and is essentially going through his first significant night of crime fighting. There actually some character progression as opposed to Asylum or City where Batman was already experienced and is who he is. That all being said I would like to repeat as I said above, Origin's only real failing is that this game seems to be quite a bit more buggy than a game should be. I heard at launch it was even worse but even as it stands now I have enemies get stuck in walls making sections temporarily impassible. Nothing has happened that can't be fixed by reloading a checkpoint however so it doesn't detrack too much.To sum everything up here:Asylum: 100/100City: 95/100Origins: 99/100P.S. Oh yeah, there is also a multiplayer but I never bothered to try it. It's designed by Splash Damage so chances are it's quite good but I bet no one plays it anymore.

content:
Posted: July 5, 2015
 Some glitches/bugs solutions - on the bottom of the review Storyline  On Christmas Eve, Black Mask has put a bounty on Batman's head and 8 asssassins are trying to kill him - Deathstroke (veteran assasssin), Copperhead (a poisonous contortionist), Firefly (a pyromancer), Electrocutioner (a guy who uses high voltage), Shiva (a  martial artist), Deadshot (expert marksman), Killer Croc (a killer who is crocodile) and Bane (Oh, this will hurt) . And on batman's way the police is trying to capture him . I enjoyed every part of it honestly . It was interesting how you deafeat everyone of them successively .  Gameplay Batman Arkham Origins is an open world stealth game . You play as Batman as well . You have many gadgets which really makes you feel like Batman .When you free roam you use your batclaw to attach to buildings and you can also glide in the air . You also use your other gadgets like cryptographic sequencer which hacks security consoles by guessing the password (which I find really annoying as it was in the previous games), batarang which you throw at enemies (also you can choose remote controlled batarang which you controll), explosive gel - destroying weak walls and lots more gadgets which you also get by deafiting the assassins . When you free roam there are side missions like crime in progress where you help the police from the gangs . There are also Most Wanted missions where you do the side missions of a villian such as Anarky who plants bombs around or Enigma who has data files hidden around (also in levels) . When you stop these side missions you earn points which can be used to upgrade your gadges and etc. The combat is great but really easy (you pretty much do the same - just pressing some buttons) . The whole game didn't have a lot new stuff from Arkham City except one - the world . Its double the size of Arkham City . The boss fights are amazing . The first one which was Deathstroke showed me what Arkham Origins offers with its boss fights. Issues I honestly enjoyed the game a lot, but then the holy experience of glitches began . I even made a countdown for how many glitches/bugs I found and they were 11-12 . I had a glitch/bug in almost every level . I found solutions for them in the internet (well some of them still persist) . Wb Games doesnt give a♥♥♥♥♥♥about the game after they realised it .There are missing data handlers, glitches while you glide, some glitches that you just fall and when you get up everything is white and you have unlimited gliding, beatdown glitches (I thought the game was on ubisoft), corrupted save files (mostly on xbox), game-breaking glitches, crashes and a lot more . Verdict After all these issues I do recommend the game for its awesome storyline, amazing boss fights, great world and all these gadgets that makes you feel like Batman. Issues fixes Here are some fixes which MIGHT help you.Corrupted Save Files - Reinstall the game  .Startup Crash - Go to BatmanArkhamOrigins > SinglePlayer > BMGames > Config and delete BmEngine Elevator Glitch - immediately after you press SPACE (elevator button) press Z (first person view) and you shouldn't fall from the elevator Glide bug - Press Ctrl while gliding and then space Joker Beatdown glitch - Low your graphics and turn your wi-fi off Missing Enigma data handler on the pioneer bridge - Restart the last checkpoint and then fast travel to the BatCave and then go back to the enigma data handler and he should be there

content:
Posted: March 15, 2014
												Personally, I've played all of the Arkham games and loved them so much that I went to 100% complete each one with the exception of Asylum. This one is the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ child of the lot. The world is much larger than the previous game (Arkham City) which is a plus, however that being said, they recycled half of the map from Arkham City as well. The buildings are taller, so you're able to glide from point a to point b with no issues but it's kinda pointless to do so. The fast travel feels very repetitive. The Bat Cave is a neat little addition to the game. The story felt very generic, with a very forseeable twist. It has some really neat easter eggs, like towards the very end of the game you got to meet Harleen Quinzel the intern. The Gadgets... oh my god the gadgets. You start out with the Grapnel Booster for one, secondly they're almost identical to the gadgets from Arkham City. Baterangs, Bat Claw, Explosive Gel, all of that good stuff makes a return. The Freeze Grenade was replaced with a Glue Grenade and it (not kidding) is EXACTLY the same as the Freeze Grenade. The remote claw is neat, but it's comparable to the line launcher. You can even hold a button to ride down it just like the line launcher. Lastly, the Riddler (Now known as Enigma) side objective. It was a joke. What I always do is clear the game, beat all the bosses and start to go for all the thugs that work for The Riddler. After I got all the information where the riddler items are, I go out and find them all. This whole process in Arkham City took me about 40 hours to complete on top of all the other things, so probably about a combined total of 55 hours or so (not including game+). In this game, Arkham Origins, it took about 8 hours to gather all of the riddler items.All in all, this is an okay game. However if you compared to the previous two in the series, it's terrible. If you're thinking of purchasing this game just wait til the Game of the Year edition is released, and goes below $29.99.

content:
Posted: August 8, 2014
												Batman: Arkham Origins is definitely a game. But I bet the one person on my friends list who reads these wants more. So in this Batman game you play as Batman. Big surprise there; and I was waiting so eagerly in line for this game so I could play as bloody Catwoman again. The difference is that this time you’re beating up thugs in all of Gotham city instead of just a part of it. Don’t know why because the map is the same size anyway. Obviously the people in charge of Gotham are true visionaries to double the city limits and then section it off. The character list was actually different this time though. Instead of fighting Two Face, Penguin, Bane and the Joker you will be fighting Deathstroke, Penguin, Bane and the Joker. Well I didn’t say it was a big difference. Apparently every villain is supposed to reflect something of Batman; the Joker is his opposite and Deathstroke is his equal in combat. So hell if I know what Penguin reflects. Perhaps it’s Batman’s insecurities or perhaps I’m just trying to make this segment longer. I should remember to cross out the last sentence later.There are two things to do in Gotham city; king-hit pedestrians and label them as thugs or collect Riddler trophies, but let’s be honest, you won’t do the latter. You can finally traverse the Batcave; a privilege I never collected upon because there was nothing in the Batcave with the exception of clutter. Maybe there was a secret, but bugger if I could be bothered to find it. I now see this series taking the Halo methodology in the sense that the developers said Origins was going to be the final game, but now the Arkham series has been taken back by Warner Bros. who have already announced the next game. So I guess I’ll see you back here when that bolt from the blue arrives. And for the record, this game has the twisted oddity of not having Nolan North voice acting a superhero/villain.

content:
Posted: November 19, 2014
												I am writing this review for people that have played Batman : Arkham City (AC) and wonder if they should get Batman : Arkham Origins (AO).If you are looking to get your mind blown by a massive improvement between the two games (say new mechanics, new engine, new gameplay features, new playable characters, maybe vehicles, etc.), then you will be disappointed : AO is basically a glorified AC. It does not bring much more than AC already did. In certain area (playable character), it actually brings less.But if you are looking to extend the AC experience, on a new town with a new campaign, then AO is definitely the game to go for and it will not disappoint you.Let me put some Arkham Origins in your Arkham City :AO is indeed "only" a second version of AC, but this is a very good second version of AC. You will get a few new gadgets, a lot of new combat perks, a new "in game integrated" achievement system (that you must fulfill to unlock a specific serie of combat perks), among other things.There is now a system which rewards you for your performance after every encounter, with an XP multiplier : the better you do, the more XP you get. This is a very good addition in that it forces you to play well and try different things (do not lose combo, do not get hit, use different takedowns, etc.)They made something different with the boss fights, which are sort of based on quick time events (QTE). While I'm not a fan of QTE, to say the least, it does make up for more cinematic fights and the game is quite forgiving in that if you die, you'll get to retry at the last "stage" of the boss fight you died in. The "amount" of QTE depends on the boss, so not all the fights play the same. "I've read everywhere that this game is GLITCHED to the bone!"On that matter, my quick recap as of november 2014 :- the main campaign does not suffer any bug or glitch ;- I did not encounter any problem in the side-missions.Yet, there are two things. First, the game can sometimes "bug out" when you need to interrogate a thug. The "Y" icon does not appear when you get close to him. It can be fixed by restarting the fight. Since this bug is quite rare, the fights are quite cool and the restart option quite forgiving (you respawn close), it's ok.Second, and this one is not ok, is a glitch with the Enigma datapack. Now, this is particularly annoying because in this game, they made it way more appealing to collect the Enigma datapacks than it was in AC. In Arkham City, I did not really want to look for and solve all 400ish (!!) datapacks. Simply did not want to. In AO, the datapacks are fewer, and they have a much better integration in the game. You get to interrogate thugs which reveal the locations of a few datapacks, which then appear on your map. This is great. But at least one puzzle (extortion file 3, datapack 6) is glitched : you cannot complete it. Which defeats the purpose of collecting any of them, since you can't complete the collection in the end. Really bad.Also, there is a grapple situation. You will not be able to move as freely as you were in AC. Many roofs will not accept your grapple, while they would have in AC. Even if you somewhat get used to it, it remains annoying during all the campaign because you always try to "grapple up" and can see many places where it "should work", but no, it will not. Mildly annoying. Final impression :So all in all : if you really enjoyed AC and are looking for some additionnal content, definitely grab AO. Despite its flaws, I actually had a better time in AO due to the very satisfying combat system, meaningful achievement system, map interface, decent story, good predator maps, etc. For me, it has a been a better AC.

content:
Posted: January 9, 2016
												I only slightly recommend this game for people who want to continue the game series, for others I DONT recommend it. Play the previous ones. I am a fan of the previous games and of batman but this series keeps getting worse, at least for PC.1. The Story is fine. Nothing major. Just fine. You have a lot of side quests to do if you are bored. They are pretty boring after a while because repeating the same bust over and over again seems pointless. Especially the extortion files (riddler things) are boring as they repeat themselves for every territory. No idea who thinks that kind of grinding is fun.Some cutscenes are skipable some are not, just telling you that its loading but it probably isnt.It is a mystery to why it is not possible to listen to tapes while gliding through gotham. Worked in previous game but not here. That means you have to stay in the audio file and wait for it to play till the end. That breaks with the flow of the game.2. The graphics are good considering when it was made, the faces are mediocre though.This game is out for years and there are still so many repeating bugs in there.FIrst bossfight against croc pretty much always glitches and croc himself is dissapearing out of the world and reappearing (flickering) and the sound cuts off at the later stages.If you glide of places you sometimes have a bug where you kinda flap your wings like a bird.The games sometimes even crashes if you enter a ingame cutscene, happend to me at least once, other times it just hang for a short time.3. Controls are as bad as always. You just do sometimes things you dont want to do or sometimes counters do not work even though you pressed.This makes the boss fights so much more annoying. Most of them are stupid gimmick fights. The fight agains Bane just takes forever because of the controls and the limited options of how to take him down.The fight against Deathstroke is probably the stupidest of all with those counters. This is barely a fight and more a game of counter. Who counters better. Considering how early you fight him this is a good spot to just stop playing if you cant defeat him in normal or high difficulty because at first you dont really get the fight after a few tries.The world is essentially a bigger Akrham City I guess. It looks very similar of course. Thats good as you have spots that you remember.4. I have played 2 games of multiplayer. Playing as one of the thugs is horrible if you know how a shooter is supposed to be played. The camera control and controls are so♥♥♥♥♥♥ Dont even try it, believe me. 5. Cold Cold Heart is the only addon that makes sense so dont buy the season pass.I am not gonna say that this game is bad but it has a lot of issues and thats why its AVERAGE at most. After playing this game I am not surprised how broken Arkham Knight is supposed to be on PC.

content:
Posted: May 10, 2014
												Arkham Asylum was a revolutionary game. Arkham City was as well. By contrast, Arkham Origins is viewed as an evolutionary game, and between that and the fact that the principal actors and development studio have been replaced a lot of people figured "eh, I don't need to play this for a year." Technically speaking, Arkham Origins does feature revolutionary additions over the previous games, but it's in an area that nobody particularly asked for in the first place: online competitive multiplayer. I myself have yet to even launch it, but given that it's developed by Splash Damage I'm sure it's not slapped together. They did after all make the Return to Castle Wolfenstein multiplayer (which got carried over into Enemy Territory, and then Quake Wars, etc).The thing about the single-player is that while it's good, you literally cannot help but compare it against Arkham City the entire time. The combat system and animations are completely carried over, with some additions. You have some new gadgets (one is allegedly "new" but in reality is functionally identical to something else from Arkham City) and face a few new common foes. Luckily, one of the gadgets is straight out of Super Inframan and makes combat even more satisfying since you trounce everyone with it, and the others give you more options during the Predator encounters. The enemy AI is altered since the rate at which you counter rather than strike has gone way, way up. Boss battles are VASTLY improved over the previous games, as each one emphasizes that you do different things. At no point do you feel "well, this is the same thing I did for the last boss."But even with that said, at most points you DO feel "well, I've done this before." Aside from the combat, the sidequests have you doing the same gameplay mechanic as 2 years ago (and 4 years ago) albeit for a different cosmetic reason. Example: in Arkham City you have to quickly travel across the city to answer phones in time to stop a killer. Here, you have to do the same to defuse bombs. It's the same map as Arkham City, albeit with some new zones. It helps a little that you can now fast travel. But there must be fewer grapple points because getting from place to place is a little trickier than it used to be. You'll be fighting and fighting, and with the random "crimes in progress" that spawn, you'll fight more. You're rarely going to be scanning the environment unless you're prompted to do so. Crime scene investigations are a new addition, but much like the show CSI you aren't really doing anything yourself. The computer is magically reconstructing a series of events based on your having scanned a body and a spot of blood (which they can't show as red). Then you go beat up a guy. You can't inadvertently defeat the person you meant to interrogate either, so there's no "save this guy for last" aspect to combat. But you are now given grades for each encounter, such that higher grades yield XP bonuses. Winning is largely a foregone conclusion given that you're Batman, but winning with an A or S rank is the tough part. In fact, I still haven't gotten the last one because it doesn't always play the *wham* sound effect to denote you KO'ed someone with a hit (I call this the "BATMAAAAAN!" since if I could mod this game I would replace that sound with the screaming pug). The game offers various challenges for additional bonuses and upgrades, but it's buggy about deciding whether or not some of them "count." I busted my ♥♥♥ doing the "do 4 exotic takedowns in a Predator section" and then it didn't count it. And then it turned out there were no more Predator sections in the game. AND it won't let you complete those challenges on the challenge maps, so if you don't do it during the story you're screwed...unless you replay it on the much harder New Game+ mode...The reduced architecture grapples and increased enemy attack rates are somewhat minor, but if there's a major "step backwards" here it's one of atmosphere. This Gotham City isn't yet overrun with supervillains who've marked their territory and themed their gangs. The incentive to see the world isn't really as strong. The Riddler's challenges were designed to direct you to all the cool little references, but at this point there is no "Riddler" etc so you're basically completing the challenges for the sake of hearing the "extortion data that's going to harm innocent people" recordings. Except pretty much all of them pertain to supervillains and corrupt civil servants whom you take down anyway. It feels more like a task since there's less "reward" for doing it. Why oppose this so strongly? That's the REAL enigma.The strong negative online backlash to Arkham City's criminal dialogue means that EVERYTHING pertaining to threats or abusive language is long gone (that already got walked back since the Arkham City DLC) so pat yourselves on the back, Team Social Justice. Between that and the fact that Batman is less infallible at this stage of his career, the writing has gotten a lot more praise compared to Arkham City. But for me, it feels less satisfying to beat people up because I overheard them saying they're cold and hungry, or that they're resorting to crime because they lost their job and now they have to not be home on Christmas Eve. This definitely plays into the "Batman as fascist authoritarian conservative" reading of the character. I kind of wonder if the writers just hate Batman as a concept, since the villains all expose the flaws in his approach and morality and Batman has no answer because he can't admit "the reason I can't kill you is because you're all too profitable as IP."Also, the game takes place over a few hours on Christmas Eve into Christmas Day, yet the amount that happens is absurd. True, a lot happened during Arkham City, but there was planning leading up to it. How can these locations be THIS devastated and re-renovated in just a few hours? And it's not even accidental; the game points out "yeah, it's been 3 hours." On the other hand, James Gordon isn't Commissioner yet, so the cops are pretty much all dirty. In this game you get to beat up SWAT team guys, which is the part of "Year One" that is the most important. The Assassin's Creed guy as Batman has his highs and mids since he's mostly forced to imitate Kevin Conroy, but with a name like "Roger Smith" you'd think he was BORN to impersonate Kevin Conroy's Batman! Troy Baker (who already nailed his Richard Moll Two-Face impersonation in Arkham City) is about as dead-on a mimicry of Mark Hamill's Joker as one could hope, given that Mark can no longer really do that voice anymore. Richard Epcar (voice of the Joker in the fighting games) has a few background lines that jump out to me, but I guess he also directed a lot of the secondary dialogue recordings.I enjoyed Arkham Origins, but I'd still say to hold off on getting it. Not so much because of the issues described above so much as the fact that there's a ton of DLC and all of it's spread out across platforms and retailers due to exclusivity (Challenge maps where you're Bruce Wayne in training, etc). There's a Season Pass which includes that stuff, but it costs another $20 and for now is almost entirely cosmetic. They say there'll be at least one story DLC, but what'll it be about? Maybe something inspired by The Long Halloween? I don't know, so I don't know if that, a few challenge maps, and some cosmetic skins are really worth the money. For now I'd say to pick this up once a "complete edition" is available unless you happen to buy a new video card that bundles it.

												Batman arkham origins is the first game in batman arkham games that was developed by Warner Bros. Games Montréal not rocksteady and the story is set 2 years before the story in b man arkham asylum. Okay first thing im going to talk about is the story:The story is set on cristmas eve and black mask has hired 8 assassins to kill the Bat. In this game black mask will be important in the story. Batman is trying to save his head by takingdown every assassin my opinion is that the story in arkham asylum and arkham city are a lot better.the second thing is gameplay:the gameplay is the same as the previous games.One thing is realy good and that is the boss battles there are alot more boss battles than in the previous games and thats realy cool.the third thing are the graphics and enviroment The grapchics are the same as the previous games the system requiremens are the same but the problem is that the city is realy lifeles  and not well designet as arkham city so...The multiplayer Batman arkham origins is the first batman arkham game that has multiplayer. The multiplayer is realy fun there is 3 control points that you have to capture all three. When you capture all three you eliminate the gangs reinforcments to win that is invisible predator online mode but there is hunter hunted mode that you have only one life. The rest of the multiplayer you can check on the internet its realy realy fun and you can play as bane or joker or the heroes.The final verdict:The final verdict for batman arkham origins is:story: 7.5gameplay:9.4graphics:7.8multiplayer:10.0 So batman arkham origins is a good game but nothing like batman arkham asylum and arkham city. Thats what i expected when the other company developed a batman game and not rocksteady but the multiplayer rocks for me its the best multiplayer in the history of gaming, but most people would disagree. Well a new batman arkham game is coming out in october batman arkham knight and rocksteady will be developing it so i think it will be epic.

Posted: July 1, 2015
												So, after many people asked me about it, here it is. Batman: Arkham Origins feels like a game from the Arkham Franchise. But also, it feels completely different.. The story, the music, the sounds, the gameplay, everything seems to be completely different in comparison with Batman: Arkham City, Batman; Arkham Asylum and Batman; Arkham Knight, but at the same time, you can feel that it belongs to them, on the one or other wise. It is indeed not as good as the other parts, but it deserves to be called "Arkham" nevertheless. If you should buy it? Definetely, if you already have the other games of the Arkham Franchise and like them. But if you dont know the others, i would advise to buy another Batman game, like my all-time favourites Batman: Arkham City and Batman: Arkham Knight.

content:
Posted: April 5, 2014
												According to many critics a flawed mess, I find it rather enjoyable. Yes, it has a number of weird glitches, but up until now I have not run into anything game breaking. The combat remains pretty much the same from AC, the combos look better, the story is fine, and more detective work is interesting. The side quests are awesome, you will meet old and new adversaries, some of them you already met in the previous games (well, previous games, but in continuity, AO is a prequel). As someone who spent more than 30 hours in both AA and AC I can recommend this game mostly to fans of both games, while new players should really start with Arkham Asylum. 8.5/10, would be 9 if not for the minor glitches which are annoying.Edit: There is hope for some bug fixes in the upcoming DLC Cold Cold Heart, even though they denied they are making anything. At least I find it rather stupid not to fix the common issues with bugged Enigma stuff.Edit n.2: After finishing the story I have to say, AO has the best story of all the Arkham games.Edit n.3: The DLC Cold, Cold Heart is fine. Nothing spectacular, the crash was fixed pretty fast, minor glitches still exist (weird camera angles and the weird movement of the camera). But it was better than the DLC in AC, so a few (literally 2-4 hours depends on your clear time) and it has the well known Freeze backstory. 7/10 for the DLC

												Arkham Oranges is a lovely game, that sadly only got mixed reviews due to its buggy launch and similaritys to Arkham City. Arkham Oranges feels like Arkham City 2.5, however, in my opinion this is not a bad thing for a game made simply to tide fans over until Arkham Knight. The game builds upon the great systems that City introduced, in my opinion Oranges offered a better story, however, this is for you to decide on your own. The multiplayer was a good edition but one I don't think the game required. In short Oranges Arkham is a good game it improved a already great game series, but did not innovate all that much.

content:
Posted: April 22, 2014
												My personal favorite Batman game to date. It's darker, grittier, and more sinister than both Arkham Asylum, and Arkham Origins. It may not be Kevin Conroy as the Caped Crusader, but Roger Craig Smith does a decent job at a younger, inexperienced Batman. Troy Baker also takes over the mantle as The Joker, the unstable, unshakeable, villain we know and love; and he pulls it off well! While combat hasn't changed drastically from the previous games, Arkham Origins still delivers that Batman feeling we know and love. I don't recommend the multiplayer, however.

content:
Posted: March 30, 2015
												WB may have patched the bugs that everyone is complaining about (or maybe I'm just lucky) but I just finished the rather short campaign and never hit any bugs that affected gameplay. The occasional FPS drop and unresponsive counter attack, yes. There felt to be a lot of loose ends with the main story that aren't addressed by the end of the game. Without giving too much away, there are certain villains that take a back seat as the story goes on and the game never revisits them, instead pushing the Bat towards one or two of them until you start to forget about the others. Overall, it's your basic Arkham game: smooth combat, strong storyline (except for the previously mentioned issues) and lots of bonus objectives after the completion of the story. Overall rating: 8/10

content:
Posted: April 13, 2015
												Arkham Origins is a pretty fun game with some exceptionally well done boss fights. The combat is the same free flowing wonder from the previous games. Its nice to see the early days of Batman shown in a video game. The vigilante/criminal uncertainty feels nice. The Batman-Joker dynamic is handled really well in this game. One area in which the game lets you down is in the inconsistent world traversal, especially with grappling. When you are gliding around Gotham, it feels as if the developers decided to put in grapple points at random. So you lose the momentum and land when you dont want to. The usual tropes in Arkham games also are present. Mash A to open grates is extremely annoying.All said, Arkham origins tries hard to be as good as the Rocksteady games before it. For the most part it is, but sadly it only comes close.

content:
Posted: April 5, 2014
												According to many critics a flawed mess, I find it rather enjoyable. Yes, it has a number of weird glitches, but up until now I have not run into anything game breaking. The combat remains pretty much the same from AC, the combos look better, the story is fine, and more detective work is interesting. The side quests are awesome, you will meet old and new adversaries, some of them you already met in the previous games (well, previous games, but in continuity, AO is a prequel). As someone who spent more than 30 hours in both AA and AC I can recommend this game mostly to fans of both games, while new players should really start with Arkham Asylum. 8.5/10, would be 9 if not for the minor glitches which are annoying.Edit: There is hope for some bug fixes in the upcoming DLC Cold Cold Heart, even though they denied they are making anything. At least I find it rather stupid not to fix the common issues with bugged Enigma stuff.Edit n.2: After finishing the story I have to say, AO has the best story of all the Arkham games.Edit n.3: The DLC Cold, Cold Heart is fine. Nothing spectacular, the crash was fixed pretty fast, minor glitches still exist (weird camera angles and the weird movement of the camera). But it was better than the DLC in AC, so a few (literally 2-4 hours depends on your clear time) and it has the well known Freeze backstory. 7/10 for the DLC

content:
Posted: July 18, 2014
												Arkham Asylum and Arkham City are tough acts to follow, but I think Arkham Origins manages it okay. The gameplay is more or less identical to previous games. You are Batman and it's your job to leave a trail of bruised faces and broken bones through Gotham. One gets the impression as you float over the city that maybe this place isn't worth saving, considering that every single citizen of Gotham is some sort of thug or hoodlum that's plotting to rob the local jewelry store. The game tries to sort of justify this by saying there's martial law, but it's a tad ridiculous. Sometimes Batman even comes across as being the bad guy. A bunch of times I was floating around the city, saw some guys on a street corner and jumped in on them to start punching. Doing that a few times reminded me of Scott Kurtz's "My Parents Are Dead", which I don't think is what the devs were going for. So for future installments, having some actual civilians in the city (maybe even areas of the city where people don't try to come punch you on sight!) would perhaps be a good idea. Though I think Arkham Knight starts with Gotham being evacuated so I can't imagine that improving. Overall though, there are some great character moments in here, particularly with the Joker (who completely steals the show from these c-list assassins they have around). And the sneakysneaky/punchypunchy gameplay is just as great as it always is. So grabbing this title is not such a bad idea. I won't be doing the post-story collectibles though.

It's defnitely not so bad as some people say it is..SPOILERS AHEAD!-The story, too much Joker, though this isn't really their fault, Joker has been the main bad guy in the previous titles, and i was awaiting a "fresh" villain, and got excited because of black mask. Just a bad timing because of the last two games.- The city is pretty empty yes, and they could have used different thugs than just a few models. Gotham is beatifully done, but it's not really fun to explore it, like it was on Asylum and City.Most of the boss battles are great! I loved the Deathrstoke one, it was visually great, Firefly's boss battle is one of my favorite boss battles ever as well, there was some great visuals and felt like a good action movie scene.All in all, i like this game, very much. It's not as good as the "originals", but great game nonetheless. Hope WB games does more Batman games.

content:
Posted: November 26, 2013
												The best batman game so far. It improves many aspects of Arkham City. The campaign is more engaging. The narration is fluid and full of plot-twists. Some scenes are epic, really! The combat system is the same as Arkham City, perhaps a bit harder, and the upgrades are almost the same. That's a bit disappointing, but it's not a huge problem since the previous game hade already a very good gameplay. The map is double the size of AC: old gotham ( arkham city before the earthquake) and new gotham (more verticality). There are a lot of sidequests but not all of them are good... The voice acting is just great! I initially had some doubts about batman's new voice actor, but he surprised me. In my opinion he's even better than Kevin Conroy. Also Joker's voice acting is great! Then there are challenge maps as in the previous games and...the multiplayer, which I haven't tried yet due to some bugs (which they have solved now). good job wb montreal.  9/10

												The third installment of the Batman franchise is imo the best and most refined. But is that enough to warrant a recommendation in late 2014, when it really only is an incremental improvement on the five year old  first game?I think it is, but it really depends on whether you own one or both of the other titles, and how much you liked them. There are some new gadgets, enemies, moves, refined crime scene mode with timeline control and much more. The villian roster unfortunately still has the main focus on the same old characters.As usual there's a ton of things to do besides the main story, but I didn't deviate much from it, and completed the game in 15 hours.There were a couple of bugs, which I don't remember from any of the previous games, including enemies gettings stuck out of your reach forcing you to reload a checkpoint. If you haven't played any of previous games, and know you're only gonna buy one of them - it should be this one. 75%

content:
Posted: July 5, 2016
												The short of it is that this game is a lot like sitting down to eat seconds of a good meal. You've tasted it all before (City, Asylum, etc.), but seconds are filling. The food does the job. You're able to walk away from the table without feeling hungry. Chiefly, I recommend Arkham Origins for the story. It has a numerous plot threads but the primary story concerns the nature of the relationship between Batman and The Joker. Batman and The Joker are cut from the same cloth. They are two sides of the same coin, and their material base is Gotham City. This alone isn't too relevatory if you've seen any of the movies or Batman:TAS. The interesting twist this game supplies is that once having established Batman and Joker as twinsies, so to speak, it digs a little deeper into their respective obsessions for one another. The Joker, of course, plays horribly contrived games but in playing these games he attempts  to carry them to a logical end in a way that will fundamentally reveal the true character of the players. In Batman's case, Batman with little push, violia, might show that underneath his cowl is a clown with very green hair.Fun! Right? It's okay. Batman and the Joker essentially have different answers to the same question, and since I referenced food at the start of this review, I may as well reference it again (and I think this line is used in one of the movies): how loyal do you expect a good dog to be when hungry? The one bad day can turn someone onto many different roads. In the Joker's case, it made him into a crazy. In Batman's, the bad day riddled his being with guilt. The real question is about whether the bad day is an indicator of fate or free will. My leaning is the Joker, at bottom, believes no hungry dog is a loyal dog. It's nature. It's chaos. It's whatever you want to call it. We are all animals destined for a brutal, disappointing life. We just need a little push to reveal our true face. Batman would likely disagree. Life may be one vile task after another, but we have the choice to let it affect us in such and so a way.Anyway, there's a lot more to say here. I jotted down some of the thoughts I had (whether they be right or wrong) after initially completeting the story of the game. There's plenty to think about and for that I give this game thumbs up.

content:
Posted: December 25, 2014
												Batman: Arkham Origins is said to be the weakest game in the Arkham series, and yes it is gameplaywise. Storywise this game isn't really outstanding and you can see the major plot twist coming from miles away. But the characters is what makes this game standout from the other two, especially the Joker. The Joker in this game is the most horrofying version I've met, the developers. We also get an insight in his messed up mind which kinda helps to not only portray him as a monster. Which I like, in the previous Arkham games the Joker is the main villain and only placed there to be a anarchistic lunatic who murders everyone who comes in his way.I've read some reviews saying that this game got performance issues. I for one have not experienced any other than a few small FPS drops when flying through the air which is to be expected. It's a big good looking world where it snows all the time, there is snow on the ground aswell as people even though I have been able to pretty much max this game(except enhanced shadows) on my R9 280x.The game is overall great and is a nice addition to the Arkham series. I would recommend playing this one before Asylum even though it's the third in the series it a nice introduction to it.

content:
Posted: December 5, 2014
												This game, Does not work as a sequel. If you own Arkham city, don't even think of buying this game. It is almost exactly a reskin of Arkham City, with a larger map and less memorable levels and boss fights. The map is a slightly modified version of the one from arkham city, with a very large bridge and a equally sized island. The story is okay, but the boss fights are absolutely terrible. Even on the easiest difficulty, I almost broke my monitor on the Deathstroke and Copperhead boss fights, which try to be like the Arkham city boss fights, but fail miserablely. All of them are 0/10 apart from the last Bane battle, which is fantastic like the Mr Freeze fight, exept you cannot hide or run ANYWHERE because of the small size of the room you are in, and Bane is charging everywhere. The combat is great as normal, but the developers could not hold themselves back from adding the Joker. Over all, this game is the same price as the Arkham city GOTY edition, but is worse. Just buy the Arkham City GOTY version. It is better, Funner and far more replayable.

content:
Posted: September 15, 2016
Product received for free
Cheap Sale ReviewI'm thinking of doing this whenever the game I had is on sale. Maybe push someone who's on the edge on whether or not to fork out that little dollar they have or make them have a second thought of buying it. Mild spoiler ahead.Batman Arkham Origins(2013) is a spin-off prequel to the Batman Arkham Series developed by WB Games Montreal and Splash Games. Preceded by Arkham City(2011). The other trilogy is developed by Rocksteady.Just like other Arkham games, the combat is enjoyable and can be addicting. It's like playing rythm games but with violence and bone-breaking.You need to push the right button at the right time. With variety of enemy, you'll need to adapt to their different patterns. The additional ranking system, where your combo is judged and marked is a nice additional feature for me.There is also more buildings you can get into compared to Arkham City which I think makes the game feels a bit fresh and new rather than feeling you play Arkham City all over again.The predator challenge where you have to take out enemies one by one is challenging enough. Throughout the game, enemies are more adapt to your techniques. If you keep taking them out from above, they'll mine the gargoyles or ledge. Take them down from below too often, they'll throw bombs. Taking your time to knock them all out , they'll put mine traps.You can also explore the Batcave. You can gain XP by having cheek-in-tongue conversations with Alfred who complains about bats in the Batcave. You can also have virtual combat challenges and training in it.Though debatable, Origins might have the best story compared to other series. It has more emotional side to it. It explores Bruce Wayne as a man full of rage rather than just as his inexperience as Batman and learn what it takes to be Gotham's Knight. He learns he can't challenge Gotham alone. The villains feel really fleshed out. Great rouge galleries. Especially Bane with his ability to outsmart Batman. The story alone is enough reason to play this game. It really felt different out of all the entry in the series.Buuut, Arkham Origins come with it's many flaws.If Arkham Knight suffers from bad port, this game suffers from questionable game design. I'll nitpick the little ridiculous bit first. Why Batman, master of combat can't break thin wooden plank. That's like the first thing you break if you learn martial arts. In the game, you have to explode it with the explosive gel. The map design to say controversially, is lazy. A big part of it is literally a revised copy of Arkham City. They do make it bigger by adding additional area but that only make travel through the city feels more like a chore. This has to do with Batman's navigation ability. Batman can grapple boost to a building to travel faster. Problem is the speed of his glide and grapple boost is the same in Arkham City. Batman's navigation mechanics and the speed may work in moderately sized, condensed map as in Arkham City but not when it's big as in Origins. I think it needs to be faster.To be fair, they had relatively little development time. And the publisher, the infamous WB more or less wants this game to be made just to keep the hype for the franchise alive as Arkham Knight took 4 years to complete.The nygma challenges and collectibles is such a drag as you have to backtrack anything you missed in the huge empty buildings with nothing to do as you had cleared the enemies earlier in the game.The story is great. IMO, the strongest out of all the series but I can't help but feel it was just a retold of separate stories that had been written in the comics which was tailored together perfecly. The man who laughs, The Killing Joke, it's all there. Tailored together and was changed here and there. The other two series Asylum&City, though inspired by the events in comics, their story stands on their own.Was this game worth your time? Yes, definitely but I suggest you play Arkham City first. I think it will give you a feeling of an expansion from the previous game. Deathstroke's fight is great, Anarky's a great philosophical fight and the DLC is the best out of all Arkham series's DLC. The cold,cold heart and Bruce Wayne's training in Korea/Japan(I don't know. I think there's a cultural mix-up in the dlc).

number of helpful: 6 of 9 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 26, 2013
												I really really love this game.  Before I say anything I will say there are some bugs. Nothing that has been game breaking for me but others will tell you that there are some nasty bugs and glitches. They have done some 'tweeking' with Arkham Origins that has changed the timing of counters or critical hits. That will have you swinging at air a bit more than in AC. There have been times where I think to myself, "that was cheap" but I have been playing AC lately too (I'm on a Batman junk out) and find there are things in that that also kinda irk me. I think they have done something with the flying/gliding that seem to make it more responsive or just plain easier. Either way I am better at gliding in Origins. As far as the gadgets go it's pretty much a wash.  Except for the remote claw which is overpowered but still hilarious just to sling two foes into each other. Instead of a freeze grenade you have a glue grenade. They do exactly the same things, literally.As far as multiplayer goes I can't comment on that. I'm not a big fan of online multiplayer.Overall, I like Origins a little bit more than City. Whether it's because it's newer and the graphics are nicer (that DX11 snow is wicked), the city seems more fleshed out and brighter, the story having more villains, less Nolan North or the fact that Batman isn't wearing his underwear on the outside (yet). At the end of the day I would give this game a 8.5/10. Without really bringing anything completely new to the table I can't give it a much higher score. It's still definitely a must play for comic and Batman fans.

number of helpful: 7 of 11 people (64%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 3, 2014
												I enjoyed Batman: Arkham Asylum and while I was disappointed by it's sequel, Batman:Arkham City, I also enjoyed and completed it. That is where my enjoyment of the trilogy ends, however. I should mention that I played Arkham City with maximum graphical settings and benchmarked at an average of 30 FPS, so the fact that I had graphical issues and slowdown was interesting to me.Within minutes of beginning the game I began to notice graphical issues. During the first boss-encounter with "Killer Croc" was a memorable one, since while I'm lead to believe that Croc's special abilities include making him extremely large and strong - the file negates to mention that apparently he has the ability to flicker in and out of visibility. This left Batman looking like he'd made a wrong turn on the way to ninja school and had taken up the art of mime instead.More graphical errors started when I got into a more open world environment, as less than 5 minutes later I was treated to a display of Batman's amazing aerodynamic prowess - gliding gently through the air while symultaneously forward flipping in a fashion resembling a hamster in a washing machine. It was quite entertaining actually.I also have to report that the combat system is what you would expect from this latest generation of Batman:Arkham games - because it's copy&pasted from Batman:Arkham Asylum. From what I can see there have been no changes to the combat engine, Batmans animations or the AI of the... AI. Almost all simple fights can be won by spamming the "punch, punch, punch, counter, punch, counter, punch, takedown" sequence and when faced with tougher opponents with knives, body armour or guns, it becomes "Punch, punch, punch, cape sweep, rapid punches, counter, cape sweep, rapid punches, counter, repeat as necessary until victory." The aiming system is still rather ham-fisted, in that when there are multiple enemies attacking in close proximity to each other it can be very difficult to judge which of them will be struck. This is especially irritating when one of said enemies is charging their attack (when you would want to counter, if you wouldn't strike them before their blow landed) and hit his buddy instead - losing your combat multiplier in the process. In addition, a ground takedown still can't be interupted in order to counter a standing attack - maybe that's by design but it doesn't feel right to me.I'd also love to know why that "bat effect" which occurs on the last punch of every combat decides that my FPS should drop from my average 30 down to 1 or 2 for around 5 seconds? It's been like that since Arkham Asylum and it baffles me as to why it happens.The RPG aspects also feel out of place to me, as they did in Arkham City. It really feels like the whole leveling up system is shoe-horned into the game in order to add play-time to it. Since I have yet to encounter any true "time limits" in the game, I see no reason why Batman wouldn't fly around the beginning area, beating up random thugs until he reached maximum level before going out to tackle Gothams meanest and ugliest. I was under the impression that was what his pre-game training was for, but oh well.All in all, if you thought that Batman:Arkham City was a great game, you'll think that Batman:Arkham Origins is also a great game. But if you were, like I was, underwhelmed by the sequel to Batman:Arkham Asylum, then you will be left disappointed by this title.Oh, one last note for the developers: Batman, being the superhero who refuses to kill, would not drop a thug from the top of a building, even if there were a christmas tree to potentially break his fall. It's very out of character and completely broke my immersion in the part - I was from that point onwards playing as Wayce Brune - the cheap Batman knockoff from China, whom evaded customs on the back of a banana shipment.

												I AM THE NIGHT..........................................Batman Arkham Origins cannot be called a game. It would be insulting to call it a game. Rather it is a expereince. Batman Arkham Origins is the vision of beauty, the perfect Batman simulator. It has detective work, Batman beating up thugs and the Joker. Each boss adds variety and menace.Thus I concude by saying that this game is pure awesomesauce and you SHOULD buy it. ♥♥♥♥ IGN. You cant spell ignorant without IGN. Seriously ♥♥♥♥ them.

content:
Posted: May 25, 2014
												Before I provide my opinion, please do remember this is all respective of my own experience, as I do not think anyone else will have the exact experience I did. As for the purchase, got this for $10 off of humble bundle and bought the dlcs through steam.I do not suggest this game due to several issues and qualms I had right off the bat (no pun intended), and after a few hours, I stand by my suggestion. The game is poorly ported over, as several major aspects of PC play are completely disregarded and difficult. I personally play on a wide screen monitor, so the fact this game has no ingame FOV or graphical setting to adjust quality to my choosing is deplorable. Furthermore, if you have dual or more monitors running, the game essentially overrides any resolution on these extra monitors despite resolution limitation (i.e. the rest of your screens will be blacked out, kind of pointless dont you think?). The initial graphical settings just consist of Normal and High, not much customization there. Additionally, for those playing on high res monitors, mouse smoothing and the sensitivity options make it extrememly difficult to play as you must manually adjust them through the ini files. This comes to my next problem, as adjusting any of these ini files shoot up the ctd and glitch frequencies beyond the normal buggy gameplay. Of course, I have played the previous games as well, and can shed light on the experience to the plot and mechanics. The mechanics have relatively stayed the same, but imo, have been simplified right off the bat. The executions are far more limited than in previous games and I think the responsiveness of the movement suffers as a result of the above optimization issues. That being said, its pretty much the same thing as the previous game. Some new gadgets and detective methods have been added, but the balancing efforts disrupted much of the combat. I still say play the first two over this one as they were much better imo.With the lack of optimization and subpar experience, save yourself the trouble and dont buy this, but if you must persist, get it during a sale. The skins are unavailable during the initial playthrough which is again a bummer as most of the dlc consists of skin packs, and replay is not an experience I wished to partake in. My advice for dlc's, get the campaign addons, avoid the season pass, you'll save cash.

												Arkham Origins is not an origin story for Batman, but rather for how Batman comes across some of his greatest enemies in later years. That being said, Arkham Origins has a dark and impacting story that shapes his character within only one explosive christmas night. Though the game is handled by new developers, combat, stealthing, and other game elements are kept intact are extremely addicting. Though all of Gotham is exposed, the side content doesn't feel as immersive as one would want it to be, despite the fact it's most often fun. There are a few new gadgets, but nothing game changing. A few short conveniences also provide nothing too notable. It may have not stepped up the bar, but it's stil an Arkham Game. 8/10

content:
Posted: December 16, 2013
												Finally, I finished yet another wonderful game. And thankfulIy this game has everything it's previous Arkham games had. The "Hero moment". To my surprise it's pretty much Arkam city, however, a tad bigger. I mean why wouldn't it be right? Previously "Arkham City" had everything except for the feel of an actual city. Rather than just another large prison which was half of the city of gothem itself. Arkahm Origins,The story is pertty stirght forward you are the batman. A myth amongs the good people living in gothem. As well as to the scumbages, and the hardend crminals. You are either a story that's good enough to just pass the time. Or you a force to be reckoned with. To the officals and press, you are nothing more than a deranged person in a costume playing vigalante. To them you are needed to be put down.  On the dawn of chrismas eve a bounty was placed on his head. 50 million dollars in cash, to whomever can kills  this supposedly the Dark protector. Moments later, the worlds deadlyest assassin's come out of the shadows, to come and collect there reward. Cold cold heart,A dlc for Arkam origins that tells the story of Victor fres aka "Mr, Freez". Here we would know, how or why did he became the iconic vilian as we all know him to this day. Did he turn out this way becuase of the lush for fortune, fame and power. Or was there a more to his stroy? Let's find out. The combat is solid. Just as it's pervious Arkham games. A stedy beatem up. From the well timed counter attacks to utalizing every single technological, and physical tool at your disposal. Scaring the living daylight out of cold hearted criminals.  On the plus side they got to introduce a few new bad guys to beat up. As well as a few new upgrades. Some of which are just referbished items the older ones. But still interseting. Also you get to have new fast travling system the bat plaine.  Which makes this game an interesting begining to the epic story of the caped crusader. I was one of the lucky few that didn't get to see the deadly bugs that cuased such a headache from launch day. That just ruined the game's overall experience for so many. And I am glad that they even worked harder to fix if. So that gives them a few points in my book.Overall, it's a good game to experiance the: "I am Batman!!!" moment . Which makes this still worthy of it's name "Arkham".

content:
Posted: August 20, 2014
												This was a big dissapointment unfortunately.Arkham Asylum and City were both epic games that were both strong on story and on character. Here all of those elements are stripped away and you're left with the bare bones fighting parts of the game without much purpose.The story is so thin. A bounty has been put out on Batman. Rather than just sit in his cave or spend the night as Bruce Wayne, he heads out into the city for everyone to take pot shots at him. This story is set back when Batman had only just begun apparently. This idea had real potential as we saw in the recent Batman movies but other than a brief mention of it at the beginning there's very little attention paid to this element in the game. And he has the Batwing! Which he never had in the earlier games... so he starts out his career with a freaking jet that he somehow looses later on? Comon!!All the gadgets from the earlier games are also present which doesn't make any sense chronologically either.I've no idea where the Origins element came from but I get the feeling its just a marketing ploy.After ten mins of playing the game you realise you've been here before. City didn't feel like it was just more of the same. It expanded on both the gameplay and story of Asylum's more focussed efforts. This really feels like a mission pack.i would only recommend this to the most die hard fans who won't mind that there's nothing new here.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 26, 2015
												[PROS]- Tweaks the Arkham Combat System to be slightly faster, more "crunchier".- Boss fights are some of the BEST in the series, which includes Arkham Knight (almost non-existent) as well.- Deathstroke is fully playable in Combat and Predator Maps.- Many hours of replay value in order to complete the Dark Knight Challenges, New Game+, and I Am The Night.- Multiplayer mode adds a welcoming distraction to the main game and has its own progression system and Achievements.- Overall plot is a more FOCUSED and easily the most digestible story of the Arkham games.[CONS]- Does not innovate as much as Arkham City; very FEW new game mechanics are introduced.- Many hours of FRUSTRATION to complete MISSIBLE Achievements, Dark Knight Challenges, and "cheap" deaths in I Am The Night.- Deathstroke and Bruce Wayne Challenge Maps provide NO Achievements and may be SKIPPED entirely if uninterested.- Features Multiplayer Achievements, some of which may be EXTREMELY FRUSTRATING to achieve due to LACK of players online throughout the day or poor matchups.- Adept players of the Arkham Series may find the main story to be quite SHORT and Predator Rooms can be easily solved by ABUSING the Batclaw."Batman: Arkham Origins features a large open cityscape with few changes to the core game mechanics already established by Rocksteady. Playing as Batman feels very similar as in Arkham City which makes for a easy transition into this installment. Visuals are much improved in this sequel and the voice work is noticeably top notch.Players can expect an additional 20+ hours of gameplay to hunt achievements and complete side quests. Both Batman's upgrades and Dark Knight Challenge progress carry over into New Game+, allowing players to complete tasks they weren't able to accomplish the first time around. New Predator and Combat challenge maps add variety to the entire experience, especially for those who enjoy the gameplay of the Arkham series. Obtaining all 3 medals in every challenge map feels rewarding and justly earned.Multiplayer is a welcoming distraction to the game, but only features two game modes and some very tedious/frustrating multiplayer-specific achievements. Some players may experience PC performance issues that probably won't be solved due to WB Montreal no longer supporting the game.Overall, this game satisfies most Arkham fans, bringing together iconic villains such as Black Mask, Bane, and of course, the Joker, in one compelling story."

												I, hand on heart, can't recommend this game.Don't get me wrong, I do enjoy playing it. The storylines good, the challenges have a great learning curve. They managed to keep the same kind of gameplay as Arkham City plus add more scope to the detective cases. This they should be proud of. I'm not going to stop playing it until I've finished Cold, Cold Heart.The bugs are the issue here. When you walk into a room and end up falling through the floor, you know that this game was rushed and hastily put together. The amount of times you see something that should have been flagged straight away by bug testers is amazing.WB Montreal made a statement saying "We're only going to fix the game breaking bugs". I gotta tell you guys, you failed. Royally.I'm probably going to dodge anything by WB Montreal and Splash Damage for the forseeable future. I certainly won't be pre-ordering any new titles from either Studio.If you are kind of interested in this, Wait to see if they fix the bugs, then wait until its in the Steam Sale.

content:
Posted: December 28, 2013
													I don’t understand how this game received a 7.8 on IGN. This isn’t necessarily bad, however, Call of Doge received a score of 8.8, which irritates me endlessly.This isn’t the best of the series, but it still is a lot of fun. The plot is a major improvement to Arkham City’s and the cinematic cut scenes are excellent. I’m not sure why people are upset about The Joker being the main antagonist. This is a PREQUEL! Of course he’s going to be the main baddy because this is technically the first time we are introduced to him! This doesn’t take place right after city, folks; this is before Asylum and the plot clearly indicates that. The free-flow combat is still beautiful, but could have been improved more such as adding more combat moves. IGN deducted points because there’s ‘too many win buttons’, someone please explain that to me. WHY is that a bad thing?The environment of this game is okay, but is not as lively as City; of course because of the thick snow. IGN also says there isn’t enough Easter Eggs… I’m not sure what game they played. Enigma has his challenges all over the map. IGN also said the city was ‘lifeless’. Again, not sure what game the played. You run into crimes in progresses and baddies roam around the streets.IGN was completely unfair reviewing this game. They complain about it not having many changes compared to it predecessor, but YET they gave CoD of Doge an 8.8… Clearly IGN is being paid off here, either that or they got someone who is a big CoD fan to review the game. At least the community votes reveal the truth, as the community gave Origins an 8.9 and CoD of Doge a 3.2.

content:
Posted: November 1, 2014
												It may not have the gripping, egdy story of Arkham Asylum, or the pulsepounding gameplay everyone loved from Arkham City but this game still holds a place among some of the greatest Batman games. Simply because the overall formula in terms of combat and manuerverability around the now expansive city of Gotham, it has been given low marks. Personally, I feel that the storyline presented in this iteration of the Batman: Arkham franchise is one of their most unique and intriguing yet. It has shown a much more human side to The Dark Knight than has been seen since the end of Akrham City. Throughout the games, we simply know he is the Batman but here where learn WHY he is the Batman. That should be more than enough to grant this game a playthrough.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 2, 2014
												Really nice game: Great atmosphere, rewarding gameplay; a very nice prequelAlthough it has its pros and cons, they neither feels to pull it in a direction of complete crap or wonderful masterpiece. This game is very hardware exstensive so you better be prepared to drop some settings and quality if your computer is not the best. Gameplay wise, it is very difficult and rewarding in its own regards. If you have not played the other Batman games, I suggest it just for the sole purpose of learning the controls and feel of the other games, as this one is a step forward rather than a step back for the series. If you have terrible reaction speed just be prepared to play the same section over and over and over again, and also be prepared to be lost, as this puppy rarely holds your hand through some of the levels. Overall, it is a pretty nice game, but then again, I only paid $2 for it, so I can't complain

												i would recommend batman to those who love a good story, a gripping edge game with lots of great mechanics and story, both the single player and the multiplayer are great,Here are some pro's and con's about the multiplayer.Pros:*The game is really fun to play with friends*The hero/villian is simmilar to the star wars battlefront 2 game making the game really fun to play.*Being batman and robin with a friend can make the game really fun systimatically trying to take down all the villians.*Being able to run around and hide as batman and robin makes it good because there are many ways to take out opponents.*The games Mechanics are quite like Gears Of War, making the game a easy game to understand the mechanics off and just pick up a keyboard/controller and get to it.Cons:*in loading scenes if you hear your friends are on before you, that almost always means, you aint joining that game.*there is no grouping system, so you all have to quickly try and get into the lobby while there is space.*Nobody plays the other game mode, unless then cant find a game on the other one.*at the start of a game you can join with a team of just you, even though the game must have 8 players at the start, meaning it kicks them off, which can make one sided games.*Players cant join midgame.

												Don't make my mistake. Don't buy Origins. The battle with Deathstroke is a glorified qte (I mean come on! This is Deathstoke we're talking about), the controls are unresponsive and sluggish (I played with an Xbox one controller, the official pc drivers let it act the same as a 360 controller), the game is glitchy (with npc's often clipping into the ground being a particularly annoying problem for me), and you can't even use the costume dlc until you finish the stinkin' game. number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 8, 2014
												This installment is definately half-baked and underdone. While the first two game were quite silly, they were still fun.This one doesn't feel fun, the side-quests quests feel more like chores and the main quests are uninspired and repetitions of the earlier games that add very little to the series. Graphically the game feels like it was made BEFORE the others. The levels lack detail and look primitive. A very big step backwards from CITY which had amazimg detail and still looks great. Origins feels like I'm playing a fan-made mod for CITY. The game is BUGGY and glitchy. Stupid little bugs that didn't exist in any of the previous games. Batman sometimes has real trouble figuring out if he's gliding or falling and other times whether he's grabbing a ledge or falling past it. So even the engine is a step backwards. Lastly the storyline....this game does not feel like an "origin" story. I think whoever decide to go with "origin" was not connected to the rest of the development team. Batman is already well kitted out at the start of the game and there is little-to-no development into how he becomes later Batman. Character-wise and technology-wise he already is (Grapnel-Boost?). It seems the "origin" aspect was just a clumsy way to bring back characters that had already died in the previous games.DISCLAIMER: I haven't finished the game, but the way it going I don't know if I will.

												Profoundly frustrating experience.  They took something that was near perfect and made it passable.  There are so many annoying little bugs everywhere, the story is forgettable, and the collectibles aren't even hard.  That being said, I still played almost 100% of the content, excluding New Game + and other harder difficulties.  I can only imagine that those modes simply make a frustrating game into a near-impossible one.  Everyone knows these were crumbs Warner Bros. fed us to keep our mouths watering for Arkham Knight.  I'm ashamed to say they did their job very well.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 28, 2014
												This game was pretty cool, about an 6.5 out of 10.  The game play was very similar to Batman Arkham City.  It pretty much consisted of the same main missions and side missions as Arkham City except with different bad Superheros.  Gadgets pretty much performed the same  actions as the ones in Arkham City except these "new" ones had different names and minor tweaks (i.e. new glue gernade instead of the old ice gernade.)  The old Riddler Trophies are now Enigma data packs but they involve almost identical puzzles as to Arkham City.  I could go on about this forever but you pretty much get the point.However, if you are able to play the game on the ultra settings, it is a sight to behold.  I played Arkham City on PS3 but my visual expierence on my new self built computer was a lot better.  The character and city textures and shadows are amazing.  I couldn't believe how the snow on top of buildies realistically reacted to enemies and my footprints when sneeking and fighting.  Knocked down enemies leave body shaped dents in fresh snow cover and each foot print looks like real as if someone was walking through 4-6 inches of snow.  When inside buildings, debris and trash reacts realistically to the enemies that walk through it like ive never seen in a video game.  The texture details really made the game a more enjoyable than the similar one I played on the consul.However, stunning graphics and texture detials comes the need for a powerful unit to process them.  I do not know the exact specificaitons of the game but I tried playing the game on the lowest settings on my middle market laptop and it absolutely sucked.  Now I know that only specific laptops are made for gaming and mine was not made for it but even dumbing down the graphics and reslolution to its minimum wouldnt even get me past the first character interaction.  I then decided to play it on the computer i just built (Intel I5-4430 Quad core, 8GB DDR3 RAM, Sapphire Radeon R9 280 3GB GDDR5 Grahpics Card) and it was able to process everything just find on all Ultra settings.All in all I would not reccomend this game if you previously played Batman Arkham City.  The story lines between the two games are almost identical along with the gadgets and side missions.  Even though the Ultra graphics settings and the texture detials are quite impressive, it is not worth picking up unless you know 100% that you have the hardware required to play the game on Ultra.  Also, I would not buy this game at all for its original price, the only way I would MAYBE get this game was if it goes on sale for very cheap.Go ♥♥♥♥ yourselves,Cory
