												[PROS]- Tweaks the Arkham Combat System to be slightly faster, more "crunchier".- Boss fights are some of the BEST in the series, which includes Arkham Knight (almost non-existent) as well.- Deathstroke is fully playable in Combat and Predator Maps.- Many hours of replay value in order to complete the Dark Knight Challenges, New Game+, and I Am The Night.- Multiplayer mode adds a welcoming distraction to the main game and has its own progression system and Achievements.- Overall plot is a more FOCUSED and easily the most digestible story of the Arkham games.[CONS]- Does not innovate as much as Arkham City; very FEW new game mechanics are introduced.- Many hours of FRUSTRATION to complete MISSIBLE Achievements, Dark Knight Challenges, and "cheap" deaths in I Am The Night.- Deathstroke and Bruce Wayne Challenge Maps provide NO Achievements and may be SKIPPED entirely if uninterested.- Features Multiplayer Achievements, some of which may be EXTREMELY FRUSTRATING to achieve due to LACK of players online throughout the day or poor matchups.- Adept players of the Arkham Series may find the main story to be quite SHORT and Predator Rooms can be easily solved by ABUSING the Batclaw."Batman: Arkham Origins features a large open cityscape with few changes to the core game mechanics already established by Rocksteady. Playing as Batman feels very similar as in Arkham City which makes for a easy transition into this installment. Visuals are much improved in this sequel and the voice work is noticeably top notch.Players can expect an additional 20+ hours of gameplay to hunt achievements and complete side quests. Both Batman's upgrades and Dark Knight Challenge progress carry over into New Game+, allowing players to complete tasks they weren't able to accomplish the first time around. New Predator and Combat challenge maps add variety to the entire experience, especially for those who enjoy the gameplay of the Arkham series. Obtaining all 3 medals in every challenge map feels rewarding and justly earned.Multiplayer is a welcoming distraction to the game, but only features two game modes and some very tedious/frustrating multiplayer-specific achievements. Some players may experience PC performance issues that probably won't be solved due to WB Montreal no longer supporting the game.Overall, this game satisfies most Arkham fans, bringing together iconic villains such as Black Mask, Bane, and of course, the Joker, in one compelling story."

content:
Posted: December 16, 2013
												Finally, I finished yet another wonderful game. And thankfulIy this game has everything it's previous Arkham games had. The "Hero moment". To my surprise it's pretty much Arkam city, however, a tad bigger. I mean why wouldn't it be right? Previously "Arkham City" had everything except for the feel of an actual city. Rather than just another large prison which was half of the city of gothem itself. Arkahm Origins,The story is pertty stirght forward you are the batman. A myth amongs the good people living in gothem. As well as to the scumbages, and the hardend crminals. You are either a story that's good enough to just pass the time. Or you a force to be reckoned with. To the officals and press, you are nothing more than a deranged person in a costume playing vigalante. To them you are needed to be put down.  On the dawn of chrismas eve a bounty was placed on his head. 50 million dollars in cash, to whomever can kills  this supposedly the Dark protector. Moments later, the worlds deadlyest assassin's come out of the shadows, to come and collect there reward. Cold cold heart,A dlc for Arkam origins that tells the story of Victor fres aka "Mr, Freez". Here we would know, how or why did he became the iconic vilian as we all know him to this day. Did he turn out this way becuase of the lush for fortune, fame and power. Or was there a more to his stroy? Let's find out. The combat is solid. Just as it's pervious Arkham games. A stedy beatem up. From the well timed counter attacks to utalizing every single technological, and physical tool at your disposal. Scaring the living daylight out of cold hearted criminals.  On the plus side they got to introduce a few new bad guys to beat up. As well as a few new upgrades. Some of which are just referbished items the older ones. But still interseting. Also you get to have new fast travling system the bat plaine.  Which makes this game an interesting begining to the epic story of the caped crusader. I was one of the lucky few that didn't get to see the deadly bugs that cuased such a headache from launch day. That just ruined the game's overall experience for so many. And I am glad that they even worked harder to fix if. So that gives them a few points in my book.Overall, it's a good game to experiance the: "I am Batman!!!" moment . Which makes this still worthy of it's name "Arkham".

												The events in Arkham Origins take place about five years before Batman: Arkham Asylum, in midwinter Gotham City. This is batmans 2nd year for fighting crime.  The entire game is trying to catch/stop black mask and trying to get rid of the assassins which black mask has placed on you whose names are "Deathstroke,firefly, copperhead, deadshot, Electrocutioner, Shiva, bane, killer croc. You do get to see Mr.Freeze, Riddler,  joker, and penguin. The game does have a nice way in introducing how Harley Quinn and the joker met.Pros-Steam trading cards & achievements-Fast Traveling-Boss fights are some of the BEST in the series-Story-Riddler puzzles-Many locations previously unseen: Gotham City proper, the Batcave, Wayne Manor, Blackgate Prison, "Arkham City" BEFORE it's urban decay, the GCPD-Very own batcave -biggier mapConsNo real serious improvements in regards to gadgets, enemy types, or other basic gameplay elements

content:
Posted: March 6, 2015
												The latest in the Arkham Origins series though fun leaves much to be desired. Dont get me wrong I enjoyed the game, but it is the weakest of the 3 out so far. The lag issues are HORRENDOUS could not even complete the first boss fight. Had to go and edit the congif files to get it to run properly. My computer has 2 7770 Radeons which should run this game smoothly. Any time I leveled up and upgraded I would have to leave that area of the map due to lag this was 20-30 FPS or less. Next is the glitching, during the first Bane fight if you are too close to the wall you are thrown through it and fall off the map completely. Enemies can become stuck in guard rails and just stay there. Sometimes when you are flying Batman would have a spasim flipping around mid air for no reason. Combat is horrid as well you can not counter an enemy as you are throwing a punch. Then there are the combo breakers you'll just throw a punch at no one and lose your score. The camera does not always show where your enemies are they can be off screen and sucker punch you.This could be due to Batman doing this for only 2 years but still. Batman can also get stuck if he grapples improperly leaving you with a view of what ever you were standing on and no way out but to just fall for an auto-reset. This game is riddled with bad game mechanics and enviromental issues. There are also continuity issues that plague this game that I won't even get into due to spoilers, but those eat at me so much more than they should. They range from Bat Tech to your enemies. Boss fights were not to par as the other games' were. Pretty much 3-4 stages follow pattern rinse repeat watch cutscene.The game also requires you to fully be aware of your challenges and achievements many of which are missable. Once the story is complete you are out of luck and have to restart to get the challenges and achieves. The environment just feels like Arkham City, in reality is really just is that only cleaned up. I give it a 5.8/10 only for the most die hard fans of the series.  So all in all fun game but the issues it has are too many to overlook in the review. This game came out Oct 2013 and I started in Feb 2015 AND STILL had to find fixes for these issues.Fingers crossed for Arkham Knight learning from these issues and being a great way to end the series.

They are now so simple we can hardly call them puzzles. Everything is so simplified, we lose a real challenge here.Also : bugs and bugs everywhere but it's so common now, why should they bother?It could really have been better but Aside from that i enjoyed that game, we can feel that it's the beginning of the cape crusader in all that is falling on him. Of course playing that in 3D is also a true experience!I recommend this game for the amazing experience in 3D and the story but i won't say it's a fabulous game, clearly if this repetitive business goes on in the future of the Arkham Series i'll gladly stop buying those

content:
Posted: November 14, 2014
Introduction : The game, played from a third-person perspective, focuses on Batman's combat and stealth abilities, detective skills, and gadgets for combat and exploration. Aside from the main story, Batman can help the police deal with crimes, and confront other supervillains terrorizing the city. Arkham Origins introduces the ability for Batman to virtually recreate crimes, allowing him to investigate the scene and identify the culprit. The game is the first in the series with multiplayer capability.(+)Graphics : Graphics have been improved comparing to Arkham City . The game looks even more realistic now .(+)Music :  The melodies don't try to go too far and are consistently coated in adrenaline-pumping elements. You're gonna love it .(+)Cutscenes :  Absolutely FANTASTIC. Can't really tell much witout spoiling everything but cutscenes just wants to make you play more and more !(+)Story :  Arkham origins' main storyline is set five years before that of 2009's Batman: Arkham Asylum and follows a younger, less-refined Batman. So you have the oppurtunity to witness Batman become a legend from a simple .. rumour .(+)Content :  The content is wide and full of possibilities . You can either keep on following the main storyline , or go after the most wanted targets , glide around the city and help cops in need , or you can just simply run around and deal with the Riddler's crazy puzzles .(-)PVP :  Completely unnecessary . When i first heard about Origins multiplayer option i was very excited , but after actually having a chance to test it out myself i found out that it's nothing like the Singleplayer . In singleplayer you can bash in through your enemies and knock them out witout breaking a sweat . But in multiplayer , batman fights like he is drunk . Not recommended if you're buying for the multiplayer .(+)Gameplay :  The gameplay is pretty much like any other Arkham games . Same tools , same counter design , a bunch of different takedowns , but still not boring .My opinion on this game is that it's definitely worth every dollar . If you liked the other Arkham games you'll probably get hooked up on this too .8/10 -   Triskelion Turbella Reviews

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 1, 2015
												Batman Arkham Origins is the third installment of the Batman Arkham series and the pre-quel story of Batman Arkham Asylum, and was developed by a different team than the first two games. Although I must say that Batman AO is inferior compared to its predecessors gameplay-wise but still pretty good story-wise. I recommend you to play Batman AO if you are a fan of the Batman Arkham series, and I FULLY recommend you to get the Cold - Cold Heart DLC since its got a really good and interesting story, as well as the bad*** new suit  THE XE SUIT ,TL,DR; I still quite enjoyed playing Batman AO, but I don't feel the solid gameplay that I got when I played the previous installments.Pros:+ GOOD gameplay, but somehow I felt that AO has an awkward feel and controls compared to its predecessor. + GOOD story. + GOOD fighting system. Free Flow Combat with this new feature ( Shock Gloves ) is a huge fun.+ GOOD array of gadgets, allowing you to takedown enemies with your own style. + GOOD sound. + GOOD atmosphere. + GOOD graphics, better than the previous games. + GREAT characters and voice acting, the characters really felt like they are coming right out of the comics. + Detective Mode Case Reconstruction is a fun new feature, but could be done better.+ Dark Knight System is a good addition as well, but is implemented poorly, especially the Predator System.+ Batwing drop system, allowing us to Fast Travel to certain points in Gotham City.Cons:- The controls feel a bit awkward and clunky.- Most areas are just copied from Batman Arkham City maps.- More collectibles, but less Riddles.- Gotham City is a huge city, but the lack of any civilians feels weird to me. All I see are thugs. Is this Gotham City? or Arkham City, where all its inhabitants are criminals?- Dark Knight System Challenges should be able to be done in ANY ORDER, to avoid any missable challenge(s).- Missable predator challenge, because some of them can only be done in certain maps of the STORY mode. This is seriously annoying, especially because this game uses autosave system. Imagine if you forgot to do a 1 predator challenge, progress through the story, autosaving and BAM you just missed the opportunity because its the only area where you can do the challenge.- Less polished, Batman AO still has many bugs, such as: -> gliding achievement sometimes not triggered, it takes a few tries. -> sometimes after the Riddler Informant was interrogated, NO new collectibles are marked on the map, and then you must run around to find ANOTHER Riddler Informant.-> sometimes predator challenges are not counted when the conditions are met, but sometimes counted when the conditions are not met. I know, I am confused as well...Overall: 80/100

content:
Posted: June 12, 2014
												The Bat has existed for a while, the legend is known to roam the night, pulling thugs from the light into the dark.Gotham is changing.. slowly but steady, even though the law is not with him, it's still in him, he knows true justice and knows the gray balance between the black and white that right and wrong is.However the city changes to terror for one night, Black Mask puts up a bounty on hes head and the night ends up nothing like The Bat might expect.. even though he expects the worst.This Batman game is the third to be a part of the Arkham series, known infamously to be the worst, which in all honesty is untrue, the game is (after a lot of updating) finally fairly polished and provides well over 20+ hours of entertainment with a slick and fresh Batman. Fighting mechanics has been fixed the Batwing provides the well needed transport and the villains provides the drama, action and fireworks that these comic heroes needs.The Best Arkham game in my HUMBLE opinion.9/10

content:
Posted: January 15, 2015
												Hands down the best in the series; you will not be dissapointed. This is the best looking, most badass batman out of all the series. The boss fights are absolutely amazing with astonishing cutscenes. I cannot stress enough how great this game is, and how "more badass" it is.  I have not run into any bugs , and I am currently on my 6th playthrough. Most of the negative reviews came from the bugs, but I guess they are all fixed now. The city looks flawless. The sandbox environment is very good and really makes you feel immersed. Arkham Asylum and Arkham City are really great games, but this one tops it all off. And ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ you feel really jacked when you fight Deathstroke and Firefly. V: 10/10A: 10/10Story: 10/10 Realism: F--- you, I'm Batman.P.S. I actually have over double (almost triple) the hours you see above.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 22
												The pacing of the story is slow and a little underwhelming at the begining of the game but, makes up for it by the end. For the gameplay is very much touch and go all the time. Half the time batman does what you tell him to do and, other times he jumps in front of a guy with a shotgun and causes you to die. This problem in terms of the gameplay doesn't seem to stop at this game but, continues throughout the series. It's one of the most annoying aspects of the game but, could just be the PC port I'm not sure seeing as I only own a PC. The story in the begining like I said is slow and underwhelming with a lot of bits sprinkled about and having you piece them together by the middle of the game. By the half way mark the game really starts to pick up big time at least the depth of the story. Most of my time during the game actually took place doing the side repeatitive side missions. Granted the side missions will take up most of your time if you choose to do them. The world just like other batman games is vibrant and full of life everything from the steam shooting out from the vents to the interactive snowfall. The skill upgrades are lacking to a degree and, my first and probably only play through I did on Hard and by only upgrading the melee side of the tree. This made it extremely easy by mid game once you start mastering the flows of a fight getting easily 40x hit combos. This part of the game is only made easier by the electric gloves you pick up during the game downing twenty enemies fairly easily. The boss fights however were fun and hair pulling. Every boss fight you go through on hard difficulty will take you more than five times to complete and, you end up knowing all the moves of the boss by the end of the fight. One other part of the batman games I don't care for is the fact they seem to hand everything to the character as they go holding their hand all the way through. Overall I'm glad I stuck in and played the last half of the game for me it's a 6/10

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 1, 2016
												If you're anything like me and you've played the other Arkham games but overlooked this game as it wasn't made by Rocksteady and got mediocre reviews, but are still itching for some more Batman fun then this game is worth a try.I can't really say too much bad about this game, it's alright really. Nothing special, but worth a play through. It's very similar to Arkham City and even reuses a lot of the same assets, but it differentiates itself enough for it to feel like it has its own thing going on.The story is a bit routine and mundane but it does have its fun moments, and it does a decent job of providing the Arkham series with a starting point in its narrative, not that I necessarily feel like that was actually needed. I particularly liked the boss battles. I won't spoil it by naming names, but there is one boss battle in particular which makes this game worth playing.There is some slight oddness with the free-flow combos for me, like they just don't quite work nicely, and I often dropped out of a combo when I feel like I shouldn't have. It's like the timing on pressing the buttons at the right time is a little too slow. I had a few slight glitches and I had one hard crash towards the start, but generally speaking the game works quite well. I got a pretty consistent framerate and the graphics are fairly pleasing if unremarkable.I would say this game is better than a lot of the initial reviews may have made it seem. That being said I understand the game was reported to have had a lot of bugs and issues at release, but I didn't play it until recently. I got the game for free with all the DLC from WB after the whole Arkham Knight debacle. I'm not so sure I would have been too impressed with the game had I paid full price, but I would say it's definitely worth buying if you can get it on sale for a decent price.

content:
Posted: December 19, 2015
												Main game: fun, but too many ideas borrowed from Arkham City.  The final boss fight is literally a rehash of the ingenius Mr. Freeze fight from B:AC.  The story is decent & Troy Baker's performance as the Joker is excellent.  Bane is closer to Nolan's version of an intelligent villain rather than the cartoon versions of a stupid brute, so that's good.  I loved Arkham City & while I'd say this game was fun, I understand that they had no original ideas and used Arkham City to tell another Batman story.Final verdict: 7.5/10DLC: How long was it Angry Joe?  3.5-4 hours, including getting all of the achievements.  The story was okay.  Where as the main story had an original take on the Joker and other's origin stories, this was Mr. Freeze's origin story and was pretty much an exact retelling without much deviation from other versions.  At least it felt somewhat different with the new ice moves and stuff, but that's not really enough to recommend at anything over $2.  Oh, and the other DLC in the season pass was some garbage challenge maps and different suits for Batman which you can only use once you've beaten the main game and go for new game plus or plus plus (aka: I Am The Night mode).Final verdict there: 6/10 and don't get the season pass

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 16, 2014
												Another great entry to a great series. Batman: Arkham Origins deserves none of the hate it gets from fans of the Batman games. I'll tell you one thing, though, WB did not innovate too much on the gameplay from the previous Arkham games. But, I ask you a question: is this really a bad thing? WB was wise to do this instead of taking the risk to change the game in a series that doesn't belong to them. So, what we get is another Batman game that lets us explore Gotham City once again and relive the beginning of the Dark Knight. The story, by the way, is a great excuse to throw in some SICK boss battles. The boss battles are each so different and challenging, I'll tell ya. And while I hear this game has major bugs at launch, all seem to be entirely fixed at this point in time, more than a year after launch. Speaking of fixes, this PC port is AMAZING! It runs beautifully, all settings maxed out, getting 40 fps (which is good enough for me for a 3rd person game) on my GT755M, a laptop graphics card, mind you. And with all of the nvidia-specific features, you'll be happy you're a PC gamer. And going back to the game content itself, Batman: Arkham Origins has the usual massive amount of side quests and things to do outside of story missions. Now, I've, for the most part, only played the story missions, but I plan on going back soon enough to do more side quests. One string of side quests I saw a bit of on youtube has you finding the Most Wanted Criminals of Gotham, letting you fight more boss battles, and ultimately squeezing as much as you can out of this worthy entry. While Origins doesn't add too much to the gameplay aspect (which is already simply perfect), there is no reason you shouldn't pass up the chance to enjoy it again in addition to a surpringly good story.9/10--Origins is a game which follows the rule: "If it ain't broke, don't fix it".... and I appreciate that.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 9, 2014
												-> MINOR SPOILERS AHEAD <-Batman Arkham Origins when it was initially released had too many bugs to count, that frankly not only ruined the overallexperience but in some cases made the game literally unplayable. Having played the previous Arkham games and seeing the Trailer for the game I got really hyped, it looked promising. So how does the game fare?-Intro:To start off - the setting is great, playing the role of an unrefined Batman struggling to survive on Christmas Eve being targeted by 8 hired killers of Black Mask and the one and only - Joker whilst getting to know himself, what he wants, his ambitions and goals in life and who he is or will become, how to world views him. Meeting familiar faces and forging the friendships and rivalries we know and love from DC characters.-StoryThe Story is mediocre and it throws its trump-card, the big reveal WAY TO EARLY!I don't want to spoil anything so I won't continue with this section.-The WorldThe game starts at the Blackgate Prison Facility, being overrun by criminals, and the beloved "super-criminals". Batman has to investigate who is behind the prison break and put an end to their deeds. While the prison segment is great, the intro fantastic, and later being introduced to all the assassin that you will face later on, with amazing backstories and cinematics, through that little segment the goals are set and you have a purpose as a player and as Batman!<->And it pretty much goes downhill from here except one or two points in the game.<->Getting to explore all of Gotham sounded great! (on paper) The game features the same places as Arkham City, adding in the rest of Gotham (an island south of the Arkham part) Two equally large places for you to travel and explore! The game introduces a fast travel option which makes the whole exploration thing a lot faster getting from place to place. One of the biggest drawbacks of this game is that freeroaming Gotham isn't as fulfilling or satisfying as the previous game. The world is really bland (going as far as to say the city feels dead at some parts). The snow that is covering ALL of Gotham is there so they can hide the fact that they are unable to create a lust and immersive city for the player to explore and interact.You will feel like you are making circles around the place or just seeing the same places over and over again, because you can't tell where you are going or making progress, forcing you to open and close the map every 5 seconds to get your bearings. Both upper and southern Gotham, are 99% most of the part boring, they don't offer any interesting places to explore and the places that are rehashed are more interesting that the new places (solely for the fact that you want to find how much bland the Arkham City part is).In contrast-> Arkham City felt alive, every detail there made the gameworld so much more vivid and much more interesting to explore, it gave the motivation to learn more about this place and its habitats/prisoners/criminals. Listening to prisoners talking to each other, badmouthing their bosses, witnessing prisoners bullying other prisoners, other random events, from the carefully placed billboards featuring known places to people who read the comics or seen the movies. Everything was placed with care and Rocksteady with respect to the Batman/DC lore. Getting to know the villains from their interesting and long side-missions, sympathize with them and pity them at the same time. [That brilliant writing from Rocksteady isn't here to no-ones surprise]-The Side-mission CharactersWhile great in the comics, here they are pushed aside for no reason, the missions are rushed and the payoff isn't at all great or fulfilling and you will end up wanting more of these characters, without recordings, no other interactions, all but one or two missions are very anti-climactic and feel half-arsed. The other new addition is the "extensive" (in quotations) detective mode, which would have made you feel more like Batman, while the concept seems promising it isn't executed well. The game will hold your hand throughout all of the investigation scenes, telling you exactly where the interaction points are, while looking cool and impressive your involvement in this as a player is minimal at best.-The Gameplay Its pretty much the same as City, but slightly changed so that is more forgiving with the addition of some charged fists weapon. The combat might seem the same to a lot of people but from my experience with it, it is more cheap that City, when a enemy swings his fist, sometimes it connects when it shouldn't and feels more clunky and unnatural,                          (Like the Batman vs Bane fight in the Dark Knight Rises, HEYO!)I came to that conclusion because having finished every Riddle combat challenge with every character in Arkham City, (which is a lot) I have a near perfect understanding of the combat system and can safely say that they ruined the combat formula by changing little things here and there.The last things that needs to be addressed are the -Boss Fightsand-Voice ActingBatman is not voiced by Mr. Conroy anymore and Joker not by Mark Hamill. Which turned many people off, it was little discouraging I'll be honest, the fact that THE definite voices for these two characters are getting replaced is off-putting. Batman's new voice is surprisingly very fitting and suits the character and timeline VERY well, the actor portrays him faithfully and is a welcome addition and worthy (If you may) to play the Batman role.On the other hand we have Troy Baker taking the role of the Joker. Honestly I was in shock when I heard his voice in the game, the laugh was SPOT ON and portrayed the character to a T. I'll go on a whim and say that he is ON PAR with Mark Hamill, In my humble and honest opinion no-one could have voice this Young Joker more *perfectly* that Baker. I was honestly scared when he made a threat (Like the Nolan Joker) always laughing even when beaten to a pulp.They can't replace them but where a welcome and great addition to the franchise.The thing that is bar none, no questions asked, no argument here: are the boss fights (most of them a least)The payoff is fulfilling and deserving to call itself an Arkham game based on how it handled the boss fights.For the most part they are diverse and unique. The most hyped battle in the game with Deathstroke, delivers ALL it promises: (Black-Bar Short Description about the fight )---Very Minor Spoilers--- Fluid combat, different stances/phases, gadget integration, PRECISE counter-presses, satisfying and INTENSE fight sequence. The fight will be most enjoyed with Hard mode ON, NO COUNTER-ICON indication.It is one of the best boss fights ever and the most difficult in the series yet.Losing 4-5 times before nailing Slade. The downside is that you will never see Slade again, only in some ending cut-sceneFINAL PART (PROS)1)Fantastic Voice Acting2)Great looking visuals/textures3)Great Boss FightsFINAL PART (CONS)1)Uninteresting Game World2)Mediocre Plot3)Bugs/Glitches (Gamebreaking ones, official patches/support ended)4)Unbalanced Gadgets5)Not fleshed out side-characters6)Multiplayer still unbalanced and may never be fixed7)Rehashed assets not put to good use.I wouldn't recommend this game despite its pros. They are way, way outnumbered, I would recommend buying Arkham Asylum and Arkham City, they are VASTLY superior to this title, its just not up to par. I could recommend it only to the hardcore die-hard fans of the Bat and the series and only after a huge price drop.---EDITOR NOTES---Thank you for reading my first game review, I want to do more of these so if you feel so inclined, PM me your thoughts, positive/negative, criticism is much appreciated :) +English is not my native language sorry for any syntax or grammatical error/mistakes.

content:
Posted: June 27, 2014
												I don't usually bother writing reviews for games I've played, but I felt this game warranted one. As far as I can tell, there hasn't been any attempt to improve/innovate upon the previous Arkham games. Nearly evey single gadget/ability/upgrade has been copied and pasted from previous Arkham games into this one. Gotham City feels completely lifeless. I have yet to encounter anyone that isn't either a cop or a criminal. There a way too many buildings that can't be grappled onto which makes getting around a hassle at times. However, the new voice actors do an OK job as Batman and the Joker (not great but alright). And if you enjoyed the previous Arkham games most of what you liked about those games can be found in this game. All in all though, this will probably be the first Arkham game that I don't 100% and I would not reccommend buying it if you're on the fence about it even if you did enjoy the previous installments in the series.

content:
Posted: June 28, 2014
												DO NOT BUY THIS GAME AT FULL PRICE!!The reason i say that is not because the campaign is bad or the multiplayer is plain and boring, it's purely due to the sheer amount of bugs and glitches that currently exist in this game. If it wasn't for the bugs that liter this game, then this game would be a full fledged complete package that would be well worth your time and money. The single player is very good overall. the graphics are great, the pc port is managable, the game mechanics without a rebind of keys is reasonably good and can be used easily when put in comparison to a controller. the multiplayer admittedly being rather sparse in terms of it's game modes and amount of maps, is fun, enjoyable and can get very tense especially in the hunter, hunted game mode which plays like search and destroy in call of duty in the sense that you have one lifeand one only, die and thats it, very emersive indeed. But the bugs in this game seriously hamper the amount of enjoyment you will be able to extract out of this title. in addition to the bugs, the developers of this title have no current plans to fix and improve the game which is bad and near insulting to hardcore batman fans and fans of the previous arkham titles. therefore i cannot recommend buying this game to anyone unless you are willing to encounter and ignore the near game breaking bugs that currently exist in the game then by all means play and enjoy but for the rest of us, i suggest staying away from this game.

												This game gets a lot of hate and I don't know why.  I can understand people being upset by game breaking bugs, I had one such bug when the game initially released, but it was patched within a day or two.  I can even understand people being upset by annoying bugs that happen frequently, in which I had that as well.  But none of that matters when you're able to be sucked into such a beautiful world of beating the crap out of bad guys looking like a bat.  If you love anything about Batman, you need to play this game.10/10

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 9, 2014
												-> MINOR SPOILERS AHEAD <-Batman Arkham Origins when it was initially released had too many bugs to count, that frankly not only ruined the overallexperience but in some cases made the game literally unplayable. Having played the previous Arkham games and seeing the Trailer for the game I got really hyped, it looked promising. So how does the game fare?-Intro:To start off - the setting is great, playing the role of an unrefined Batman struggling to survive on Christmas Eve being targeted by 8 hired killers of Black Mask and the one and only - Joker whilst getting to know himself, what he wants, his ambitions and goals in life and who he is or will become, how to world views him. Meeting familiar faces and forging the friendships and rivalries we know and love from DC characters.-StoryThe Story is mediocre and it throws its trump-card, the big reveal WAY TO EARLY!I don't want to spoil anything so I won't continue with this section.-The WorldThe game starts at the Blackgate Prison Facility, being overrun by criminals, and the beloved "super-criminals". Batman has to investigate who is behind the prison break and put an end to their deeds. While the prison segment is great, the intro fantastic, and later being introduced to all the assassin that you will face later on, with amazing backstories and cinematics, through that little segment the goals are set and you have a purpose as a player and as Batman!<->And it pretty much goes downhill from here except one or two points in the game.<->Getting to explore all of Gotham sounded great! (on paper) The game features the same places as Arkham City, adding in the rest of Gotham (an island south of the Arkham part) Two equally large places for you to travel and explore! The game introduces a fast travel option which makes the whole exploration thing a lot faster getting from place to place. One of the biggest drawbacks of this game is that freeroaming Gotham isn't as fulfilling or satisfying as the previous game. The world is really bland (going as far as to say the city feels dead at some parts). The snow that is covering ALL of Gotham is there so they can hide the fact that they are unable to create a lust and immersive city for the player to explore and interact.You will feel like you are making circles around the place or just seeing the same places over and over again, because you can't tell where you are going or making progress, forcing you to open and close the map every 5 seconds to get your bearings. Both upper and southern Gotham, are 99% most of the part boring, they don't offer any interesting places to explore and the places that are rehashed are more interesting that the new places (solely for the fact that you want to find how much bland the Arkham City part is).In contrast-> Arkham City felt alive, every detail there made the gameworld so much more vivid and much more interesting to explore, it gave the motivation to learn more about this place and its habitats/prisoners/criminals. Listening to prisoners talking to each other, badmouthing their bosses, witnessing prisoners bullying other prisoners, other random events, from the carefully placed billboards featuring known places to people who read the comics or seen the movies. Everything was placed with care and Rocksteady with respect to the Batman/DC lore. Getting to know the villains from their interesting and long side-missions, sympathize with them and pity them at the same time. [That brilliant writing from Rocksteady isn't here to no-ones surprise]-The Side-mission CharactersWhile great in the comics, here they are pushed aside for no reason, the missions are rushed and the payoff isn't at all great or fulfilling and you will end up wanting more of these characters, without recordings, no other interactions, all but one or two missions are very anti-climactic and feel half-arsed. The other new addition is the "extensive" (in quotations) detective mode, which would have made you feel more like Batman, while the concept seems promising it isn't executed well. The game will hold your hand throughout all of the investigation scenes, telling you exactly where the interaction points are, while looking cool and impressive your involvement in this as a player is minimal at best.-The Gameplay Its pretty much the same as City, but slightly changed so that is more forgiving with the addition of some charged fists weapon. The combat might seem the same to a lot of people but from my experience with it, it is more cheap that City, when a enemy swings his fist, sometimes it connects when it shouldn't and feels more clunky and unnatural,                          (Like the Batman vs Bane fight in the Dark Knight Rises, HEYO!)I came to that conclusion because having finished every Riddle combat challenge with every character in Arkham City, (which is a lot) I have a near perfect understanding of the combat system and can safely say that they ruined the combat formula by changing little things here and there.The last things that needs to be addressed are the -Boss Fightsand-Voice ActingBatman is not voiced by Mr. Conroy anymore and Joker not by Mark Hamill. Which turned many people off, it was little discouraging I'll be honest, the fact that THE definite voices for these two characters are getting replaced is off-putting. Batman's new voice is surprisingly very fitting and suits the character and timeline VERY well, the actor portrays him faithfully and is a welcome addition and worthy (If you may) to play the Batman role.On the other hand we have Troy Baker taking the role of the Joker. Honestly I was in shock when I heard his voice in the game, the laugh was SPOT ON and portrayed the character to a T. I'll go on a whim and say that he is ON PAR with Mark Hamill, In my humble and honest opinion no-one could have voice this Young Joker more *perfectly* that Baker. I was honestly scared when he made a threat (Like the Nolan Joker) always laughing even when beaten to a pulp.They can't replace them but where a welcome and great addition to the franchise.The thing that is bar none, no questions asked, no argument here: are the boss fights (most of them a least)The payoff is fulfilling and deserving to call itself an Arkham game based on how it handled the boss fights.For the most part they are diverse and unique. The most hyped battle in the game with Deathstroke, delivers ALL it promises: (Black-Bar Short Description about the fight )---Very Minor Spoilers--- Fluid combat, different stances/phases, gadget integration, PRECISE counter-presses, satisfying and INTENSE fight sequence. The fight will be most enjoyed with Hard mode ON, NO COUNTER-ICON indication.It is one of the best boss fights ever and the most difficult in the series yet.Losing 4-5 times before nailing Slade. The downside is that you will never see Slade again, only in some ending cut-sceneFINAL PART (PROS)1)Fantastic Voice Acting2)Great looking visuals/textures3)Great Boss FightsFINAL PART (CONS)1)Uninteresting Game World2)Mediocre Plot3)Bugs/Glitches (Gamebreaking ones, official patches/support ended)4)Unbalanced Gadgets5)Not fleshed out side-characters6)Multiplayer still unbalanced and may never be fixed7)Rehashed assets not put to good use.I wouldn't recommend this game despite its pros. They are way, way outnumbered, I would recommend buying Arkham Asylum and Arkham City, they are VASTLY superior to this title, its just not up to par. I could recommend it only to the hardcore die-hard fans of the Bat and the series and only after a huge price drop.---EDITOR NOTES---Thank you for reading my first game review, I want to do more of these so if you feel so inclined, PM me your thoughts, positive/negative, criticism is much appreciated :) +English is not my native language sorry for any syntax or grammatical error/mistakes.

												Игра выполненна на ура, новые анимации, новая графика, новый сюжет, новый открытый мир, новые гаджеты, новый режим и новые более крутые приёмы бэтмена ну и конечно же новый злодей "Чёрная маска", почти все кто не читал комиксы не знают кто он такой,однако кроме него есть ещё немного малоизвестных злодеев такие как электрошокер и т.п..У игры реально много плюсов и я эту игру считаю офигительной как и в плане графики так и в плане геймплея, в игре присутствует открытый мир что даёт целый симулятор бэтмена но и всех игр есть минусы потому что в этой игре есть небольшие баги в мультиплеере.Моя оценка 9.5 из 10.Если вы задумались над покупкой этой игры то я вам советую пройти предыдущие части игры потому что это ОДНА ИЗ САМЫХ ЛУЧШИХ ИГР в жанре экшен от 3-его лица.

Posted: September 18, 2014
												After suffering through a horrible first impression, I waited for the devs to fix it. Unfortunatly they didn't. I have a mid range game rig so was not expecting the game to look good, so I set the game at my benchmark given to me by nVidia, annnnnd, 10 fps max. I set the settings lower and I got even LOWER fps. This was after the sopposed "fix". Note to everyone out there my specs fit the requirements. I waited 3 months and reinstalled the game and nothing was fixed. So I did some browsing and found a unofitial patch that took out something in the graphics but the game ran "fine". The game was not even that good. The combat was the same we've seen, not even any new moves/animations. Also the story was entertaining but had little logic and some of the villan side missions (like Anarchy's bombs) felt forced. Overrall if your computor can get passed the obviously false system requirements. Then you can suffer through a game that has nothing importent to show you. Overrall statement 5/10.

Posted: March 28, 2014
												I'm a massive Batman fan. I know a lot of people claim that, but I challenge anyone to find a Batfan as big as me. I loved Asylum and City, and when I saw Origins was being delivered by a different studio, I swore never to play it.And then it went on sale.Figuring 'hey, what's ten bucks?', I bought it. I now have no idea what people are/were complaining about. Yes, there are some shortcomings when compared to the previous games, but that comes with any franchise. I mean, what if nobody played another Zelda game after Ocarina of Time? People talked crap about Windwaker, but it's one of my favourite games.Arkham Origins is a superb game. It's Batman all over. Does it hold up to its preceeding titles? Not 100%. But you can't let two near perfect games ruin a wonderful one. Is it worth $50? That's up to you. But if it goes on sale again, I thoroughly recommend picking it up. As long as you go in with an open mind you won't be disappointed.

content:
Posted: April 6, 2014
												Batman: Arkham Origins is the third installment in the Batman: Arkham series of video games; it serves as a prequel to both Arkham Asylum and Arkham City and provides an insight into the early days of Batman's career. This is the first game in the series I have played extensively, despite owning the other two titles.This game follows Batman/Bruce Wayne on Christmas Eve in Gotham City; the villain Black Mask places a significant bounty on your head, meaning the best and brightest villains flock to Gotham on Christmas Eve to take down Batman. I thought this was a great way to provide diversity in the villains you'll encounter, each with their own characteristics and different fighting styles; Bane, Copperhead, the Joker, Deadshot, Mad Hatter, Deathstroke, Electrocutioner and the Penguin are all villains that Batman will encounter in one way or another. The voice acting and motion capture of these characters is absolutely brilliant, and it was very enjoyable to face off against them.This game is a sprawling open world brawler; Batman has a number of tools and gadgets to navigate the vast environments such as grappling hooks, glue grenades, smoke grenades and batarangs, all of which come in useful in a variety of ways. You can glide across the cityscape uninterrupted; this is one of the best features of the game, as the player is allowed to navigate the world as you choose without limitation.Gameplay in Arkham Origins consists of engaging in fist fights with goons, sneaking around areas, solving puzzles and gliding around Gotham. Like previous entries in the series, Arkham Origins uses the freeflow combat system; as Batman, you can fly around a punch up whilst delivering hits and countering attacks. Different enemies require different fighting styles and techniques, and the enemy diversity as well as the range of tools means the fights are always entertaining and challenging. The stealth sections are equally entertaining, as you can use your tools and the environment to eliminate enemies undetected. You'll also come across challenging puzzles within the game, such as bypassing traps and blocked areas as well as solving puzzles left by Enigma.Video and sound design in this game is also very good. Excellent attention to detail in combination with a highly appealing graphics engine, this game looks absolutely stunning on high settings. Voice acting and sound design is also fantastic, and feels like a highly authentic Batman experience.This game was very enjoyable due to its highly polished gameplay and compelling story. Without spoilers, the scenes concerning the Joker and his early meetings with Batman provide a unique take on the story that I found extremely interesting and riveting for the game. If you enjoy action packed brawlers in an open world setting, I highly recommend this game. Loads of replay value and excellent value for money, Batman: Arkham Origins is an epic game for fans of Batman and action games in general. 9 / 10

content:
Posted: November 7, 2013
												A functional but uninspired addition to the Arkham series, and arguably my biggest disappointment of 2013.Takes the great framework left by Arkham City, but doesn't really do anything to improve upon it (with the exception of the new crime scene missions), and new combat tools such as the shock-gloves remove a lot of the challenge that came from planning your approach to each fight.Coupled with a completely throw-away multiplayer componant, its a somewhat enjoyable, but totally unnecessary entry in the series.Bottom line: Asylum and City are two of the greatest games of this past generation. Origins isn't.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 25, 2014
												First of all, this game appears to have built entirely from recycled Arkham City maps... and before I get on to the rest of my complaints, I'll point out that this, more than anything, contributes to feeling that Arkham Origins is just an extremely half-baked expansion pack for it's vastly superior predecessor.The narrative, if you can call it that, is held together by a single fraying thread... and you feel like you stumble from one uninspired set piece to another with nothing logically or emotionally tying any of it together. That alone wouldn't be too horrible (this is an action-based videogame, after all) except...Ye gods, what did they do to the combat!? The loosy-goosy combat has gotten so simple that you barely need to participate to make progress, that is, until you reach one the game's absurdly annoying QTE-laced boss fights. We're not talking the occassional QTE either, but full-blown, unavoidable, QTE-centric battles.Look, this game isn't fun. Or good. There are better games out there and this contributes nothing to the Arkham franchise. It's not just not worth your money, it's not worth your time. Spend both on something more rewarding.

												I would really like to say that I enjoyed this game.  I want to say that I enjoyed the combat system, the exploration, the visuals, maybe even the story line.  I want to say that I <was> looking forward to DLC.  I did purchase a season pass after all.But now, I am going through major buyer's remorse after the unethical business practice, that is literally refusing to fix the game any further, and instead focus on the story DLC coming out.Well, unless I can get a refund, I am in it for the long run, so I may as well find out.  And if you haven't bought the DLC already, DON'T.  If you haven't bought the game yet, DON'T!  Just read this article: http://www.gamespot.com/articles/batman-arkham-origins-has-no-plans-to-fix-several-game-breaking-bugs/1100-6417619/And I want you to tell me if you'd still want to buy the game otherwise.I loved this game.  But now, I wish I could break it into dust and blow it into the developers eyes in annoyance just for them to understand how we fans feel when this news came to light.

content:
Posted: December 19, 2015
												Main game: fun, but too many ideas borrowed from Arkham City.  The final boss fight is literally a rehash of the ingenius Mr. Freeze fight from B:AC.  The story is decent & Troy Baker's performance as the Joker is excellent.  Bane is closer to Nolan's version of an intelligent villain rather than the cartoon versions of a stupid brute, so that's good.  I loved Arkham City & while I'd say this game was fun, I understand that they had no original ideas and used Arkham City to tell another Batman story.Final verdict: 7.5/10DLC: How long was it Angry Joe?  3.5-4 hours, including getting all of the achievements.  The story was okay.  Where as the main story had an original take on the Joker and other's origin stories, this was Mr. Freeze's origin story and was pretty much an exact retelling without much deviation from other versions.  At least it felt somewhat different with the new ice moves and stuff, but that's not really enough to recommend at anything over $2.  Oh, and the other DLC in the season pass was some garbage challenge maps and different suits for Batman which you can only use once you've beaten the main game and go for new game plus or plus plus (aka: I Am The Night mode).Final verdict there: 6/10 and don't get the season pass

Posted: February 11, 2014
												It's like they took everything bad about Arkham City and made an even larger game about all the bad parts.  Everyone and their sister has guns now so you can't just get into fights without getting wtfpwnd, and the game is terribly unclear about what your objective is.  It's just, "lol u need to do this, but idk how loloololololl" and last game you at least had the detective vision but now they added these jammers that ♥♥♥♥ that up so you can't see how you're supposed to progress, which I guess appeals to people who enjoy dark souls.  Then there's that they made the city 3 times larger, then cut your flight speed in half, and you can't go faster by swooping down, oh no, cuz you see the human body travels just as fast going at a 5 degree angle as it does at a 90 degree angle.  Just ♥♥♥♥ing terrible, the boss battles have been reduced to nothing more then press RMB and LMB to win.All in all 1/10.

This game is terribly underrated.For the past few months I've been struggling with whether or not to get the game and play it, since all I've heard was harsh criticism. I got through the game and I can't understand WHY this game got 74/100 on steam. It has everything we could have asked for! Story is remarkable and I don't see absolutely anything wrong with it. In fact, I would say some parts are even better and more mind blowing than in Arkham City. This is so far the darkest and most interesting Batmans IMO, since it tells us so many stories that shine the light on things some players were wondering about (those who didn't read the comics, of course). Glitches? Bugs? They happen! Throughout the game I had some here and there, but they didn't even frustrate me to the point where I would even bring it up if others didn't. I absolutely love this game.The only bad side is the graphics. It looks downgraded compare to Arkham City. My personal rating for this game is 9.5/10

content:
Posted: February 10, 2015
												This review can be wrapped up in a single sentence. Not as bad as many people will say, but not good enough to carry the Arkham series name. This game is utterly passable. The controls, looks and overall execution are just fine (as they should be, since it's primarily just borrowed from the previous titles), but the scale of the game falls significantly short of Arkham City. I don't think purists will be the only people irritated by the anacronystic, and fairly schizophrenic, way that this origins Batman has advanced, and regressed, from his Arkham predecessors... wait... successors... well, you see my point. Anyway, overall, not actually a bad game, but when compared to the excellent games from which it was spawned, you must wonder if it's existance was necessary as it seems to do nothing to advance the franchise. That said, if cheap enough, and you just want more Arkham, pick up this game... just set those expectations down a level or two, and you won't be disappointed.

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 27, 2014
												Topping Arkham City would be hard to do, but they have succeeded. Arkham Origins is a masterpiece. The new voice actors were spot on, and they kept the game play the way we all came to love and enjoy. The story was fantastic, it was beyond flawless. Making a prequel to the events in Asylum and City and mastering it is not an easy feat. It was laid out perfectly and I loved the way they portrayed each faction and the way they reacted. Perfect 10 out of 10.Multiplayer was actually a lot of fun and definitely a great added addition to an amazing series. (After you got over the random crashes that randomly occured). I hope to see them fine tone it, if they decide to do it again. When I completed the achievements only one mode was unlocked,, however I know now they added another mode, but it would be nice to see that happen during the initial release.Most DLC is mainly silly skins and a couple challenges(not needed for achievements), but the one DLC that is actually worth something was the Cold Cold Heart DLC.~ It adds as much as the Harley Quinn DLC in Arkham City did, and it was very well done. The story was spectacular and I enjoyed the way they developed it and how it connects all the puzzle pieces. Also the new batsuit was badass and needs to make a reappearance.

												Ah Batman Arkham Origins the game I waited for sense febuary when they gave clues for it. The game that I played right after preloading it. The game I completed 100% in less than a month after the games release. I am going to say I was in love yet also dissapointed with this game. First of all the game is very alike to arkham city with I am completely fine with. But the changes I found in the free-flow combat and predator missions were bad. With predator moving to gargoyle to gargoyle is not as smooth as the previous games and silent takedowns sort of glich out with their knockout smash's. In free-flow, the game has lost it's rythm with going from enemy to enemy. With that a side let's talk about the story. While not written by Paul Dini (the writer of asylum and city) instead it is written by Corey May and Dooma Wendschuh, which is fine because the story is great, but leads to a lot of screwed up continuity with Dini's work. Now let's talk about something new: the multiplayer. The multiplayer is created by splash damage not WB games Montreal. I found it very enjoyable to play with batman in predator maps with real players. There are two modes from the time of making this review: Invisible Predator Online and Hunter, Hunted. These are both extremely enjoyable and kept me playing. So the final verdict of this review though it is very alike to Arkham City it is still a fun Arkham game and with the addition of multiplayer I recommend this game but, with the bugs, glitches and other problems it detracts for the experience noticeably. So if you like batman and that is what you want more of, buy Arkham Origins. 8.6/10

content:
Posted: December 20, 2014
												Although Arkham Origins is not as high-quality or polished as Asylum and City, it has some surprisingly fun elements that make it worth it. You get to play as Deathstroke during the challenge maps, which are pretty well-made (but glitchy), and I actually found the multiplayer quite fun. For new Arkham players, get this and do not run away from the series if you think this is glitchy. For those who have played the previous two, this one is slightly disappointing but is still fun and often awesome nonetheless.

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 27, 2014
												Topping Arkham City would be hard to do, but they have succeeded. Arkham Origins is a masterpiece. The new voice actors were spot on, and they kept the game play the way we all came to love and enjoy. The story was fantastic, it was beyond flawless. Making a prequel to the events in Asylum and City and mastering it is not an easy feat. It was laid out perfectly and I loved the way they portrayed each faction and the way they reacted. Perfect 10 out of 10.Multiplayer was actually a lot of fun and definitely a great added addition to an amazing series. (After you got over the random crashes that randomly occured). I hope to see them fine tone it, if they decide to do it again. When I completed the achievements only one mode was unlocked,, however I know now they added another mode, but it would be nice to see that happen during the initial release.Most DLC is mainly silly skins and a couple challenges(not needed for achievements), but the one DLC that is actually worth something was the Cold Cold Heart DLC.~ It adds as much as the Harley Quinn DLC in Arkham City did, and it was very well done. The story was spectacular and I enjoyed the way they developed it and how it connects all the puzzle pieces. Also the new batsuit was badass and needs to make a reappearance.

content:
Posted: May 24, 2015
												Considering that this game is very similar to Arkham City in this review i'll simply point out the differences between the two. If you didn't played Arkham City (or Asylum) I strongly advise to play those before this one. The Good General (slight) graphical improvementsThe new snow effect is very nice and add to the atmosphereAtmospheric boss fights, different from each other (Deathstroke and Copperhead being my favourite, but be advised most of them make a heavy use of QTE)The area of the city you can navigate is doubled in extensionBatman got an armor The Bad The gamebreaking bugs have been fixed, but you may still encounter some occasional glitch. The story is decent, good at the start, while it suffers from being extremely predictable later on, it's anyway worse than AC one. The city environment is lacking character and atmosphere if compared with ACPoor level design, moving through the city with the grappling hook is not as enjoyable as in AC. The Wasted Multiplayer mode that is actually quite fun, but it was not supported by the dev, you WILL experience crashes and the infamous "lost connection to steam" bug that will prevent you from playing most of the times.Massive improvements on the Ivestigation Mode where you can re-enact what happened on the scene based on the evidence you collect, but it's all wasted due to the red arrow that point you to the evidence you need, taking away any kind of "detective feeling" or sense of accomplishment, incredible wasted opportunity.This game is in my opinion still inferior to Arkham City but if you enjoyed AC and want more of the same this game is worth your time and money.

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 27, 2013
Don't fix what isn't broken, one of the few cliches that still work.I bet if people didn't know this wasn't Rocksteady studios they wouldn't even know the difference. It's like asking people to tell the difference between drinking bottled water and municipal water and then asking which one tastes better.I'll rate this game high, I don't care. There is absolutely nothing wrong with Origins. If Arkham City were the third installment and this were the first one, then people would be making same complaints. I'll settle for the Uncharted 3 argument/syndrome but there is little to no reason to downgrade this game because it more or less features same core gameplay. And WHAT IS that "same"? Refined fighting system, satisfying action, old and new upgrades (that you have to actually work for this time around by completing challenges), expanded itnel/database, enigma's games, superb voice acting, crime investigations, top notch cinematics, joker's side of the story (a clock work orange), a plethora of new and old characters each of whom require a different takedown approach, the perma-death mode, among many other things, the horror!There's little to no innovation? Well, for starters you can't innovate much when it comes to something that happened in the past. But there are small changes there and there. You can now slide into the grates and open them. You can daze your foes with smoke and they will swing their arms at each other and punch it each by accident. Many fights are no cakewalk. Many enemies become armed towards the middle of the game, the ninjas, the martial arts experts and Bane's brawlers can make fights quite tough. The environments are also more varied. There is still no blood splatter anywhere, however. Many fights requires preparation in advance - disable guns, check; disable gun crates check; mark the ones you want to bump together, check; throw the smoke pellet in the middle of the crowd, check; swoop in and start kicking♥♥♥♥♥The game is considerably longer than the other two. It took me 30 straight hours to beat it and I have only completed around 60% of the game. The game literally goes on and on.The game is much more Tim Burton-y this time around. There are more highrise buildings so there is greater satisfaction of gliding and plunging down. The city is filled with gangs and crimes that you can prevent. The streets are wide so there is more maneuverability. There is more approach to targets. The old Arkham City area is filled with somewhat disturbing Christmas decorations. The art design is off the charts. I also like the fact that you are kind of on your own in a sense that cops and criminals don't really know what to make of you. The graphics are also somewhat expanded, noticably the lens flare, the smoke that adjusts to your movement and changes its shape (nonexistent on the consoles), and physx (ah, those snowflakes dancing around when you fight 10 people at the same time - the consolites are missing out), AND LET'S NOT FORGET THERE IS NO GAMES FOR WINDOWS LIVE.Each boss fights requires a level of investigation, psychological build up and later on skill and patience - something that Arkham City wasn't too famous for later in the game (which was one of GS's gripes by the way). The ultimate bane fight was as close to the Mr. Freeze fight as it got. The uneasy alliance with Gordon was also played out pretty well.I can only wish this was the first installment. Arkham City was pretty much a perfect game but it doesn't preclude Origins from being a great game.P.S. Don't skip the credits scene.

content:
Posted: November 21, 2014
												Batman: Arkham Origins is a great, very fun, immersive, and visually stunning game! Most people prefer Asylum and City, since they were developed by Rocksteady instead of WB Montreal; while I don't necessarily prefer Origins, it didn't disappoint me either. One thing that is MUCH better about it is the visual detail and overall smoothness of gameplay. With my system (specs at the bottom) and new drivers, I play Origins in 3D Vision, rendered at 4K (using DSR), with EVERY setting maxed, except for AA being on TXAA low plenty smoothly enough for me to play very enjoyably and literally be blown away by the Nvidia Physx and rich visual detail all around! The footprints and thug impressions in the snow, the the sense I should be feeling the snowflakes hitting my face, the fun of demolishing the thugs, the joy of exploring the richly-detailed city as the Batman, along with many more great points make it great! This game has the same style and feel of the earlier games, which is AWESOME, and offers players a MUCH larger map to roam around as they wish! Great game, worth the money, and worth many hours of immersive gameplay!Can't wait for Arkham Knight (back to Rocksteady)!System Specs:Case: NZXT Phantom 001BKCPU: Intel i7 3970XMOBO: ASUS Rampage IV Extreme x79RAM: 32GB 1600 DDR3 4x8GB (Quad channel)GPU: EVGA GTX 780 Classified w/ ACX coolerSound Card: Creative Sound Blaster Recon 3D ChampionRaid 1 for OS: 2 10,000 RPM 300GB VelociRaptors1TB 7200RPM data driveMonitor: Asus VG248QE 144Hz refresh, 1ms response, 80M:1 Contrast Ratio, 3D Vision supportSurround Sound: Logitech THX-certified Z-5300e

number of helpful: 5 of 8 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 8, 2014
												I will commend this game on the premise and story. While not a particularly original plot, it is told well and at a good pace. This Batman is younger and more angry, and it was interesting seeing people react to him as a new figure in the city of Gotham. These things alone made the game worth playing. Even the item collecting seemed a bit more grounded, which made that more entertaining as well.However, one is left with the sense that the game simply did not get enough playtesting, or not enough time to react to the results of playtesting. There are minor glitches here and there, but the most glaring oversight is in the combat.Batman is no longer able to consistently interrupt his own attack animations. This most commonly manifests itself when trying to counter an attack that begins after you've already started attacking someone else. You'll find yourself getting hit a lot more. More difficulty is fine, but not allowing the player to respond to threats as they happen generally makes the combat feel unfair. This seemingly small change makes much of the gameplay less satisfying than in previous iterations, but is rendered moot about 2/3 into the game when you get a new upgrade that makes the combat fairly easy.Batman Arkham Origins is not a bad game, but given its predecessors and its potential, it is a disappointing one.

number of helpful: 5 of 8 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 19, 2013
												For a Batman: Arkham [something] game, this game was incredibly weak and full of bugs. It wasn't terrible, but they managed to make the most important part of the game frustrating and inconsistant: the combat. In the previous Arkham games, combat flow was silky smooth, and guiding the Batman around the fight was intuitive and consistent. In this game, that all goes away. It is incredibly hard to maintain freeflow, often at no fault of the player (Batman seems to randomly miss blocks and strikes, no matter how you are aiming the camera, and sometimes it is impossible to target the opponent you want, with it seeming like Batman is attacking everyone except the baddy you want him to take out). If these issues were consistent and predictable, it wouldn't be a big deal, but as they aren't, fighting goes from fun to frustrating in a hurry. Going back and playing Arkham City after playing this game was like a breath of fresh air. This game could have been a worthy addition to the Arkham games, but when it breaks the very thing that makes the Arkham games so much fun, I just can't give it a positive recommendation.

content:
Posted: August 22, 2015
												Batman: Arkham Origins is the prequel to the Arkham series, but will you want to play it ?Batman: Arkham Origins take place in the first year of Bruce Wayne becoming Batman. On Christmas Eve Black Mask hires 8 assassins to hunt down and kill Batman for 50 million dollars. So it's up to you to capture every assassin and save Gotham.Gameplay is almost identical to Arkham City. It adds new elements like shock gloves that speed up combat, but do less damage. Overall the combat is identical to Arkham City and if you played that you know what to expect.Graphics are also identical to Arkham City, but unlike AC they add snow and snowing effects and add Christmas decorations to make you feel like Christmas is just around the corner. Graphics are amazing to say the least even though they are just a re-skin.The soundtrack is awesome. When you fight some of the bosses and the music kicks in is just awesome and makes the fights even better.The game is a bit harder than the other titles. Stealth play's a bigger role in this game and the armed enemies do more damage. But the game is still really easy.Level design is mostly taken out of Arkham City, but there are new locations. Overall it's really well made but there is one location that has horrible design is the Gotham Police station. I got lost and confused multiple times. I would have liked for them for not make it that confusing.Game is pretty long. It took me 17 hours to finish the main story and complete all side quests. 2 hours more to play the Cold, Cold Heart DLC. Not to mention there's also a lot you can do after you finish the game and also there are challenge maps. The game is incredibly buggy. During a boss fight, the boss got stuck in a wall. I needed to restart for it work again. Sometimes, I couldn't interrogate people after I beat them up. The game doesn't have any game breaking bugs and restarting from a checkpoint fixes the problem. The multiplayer mode is kind of fun but now it's full of hackers and it's kind of hard to get into a game. My suggestion is to skip all MP dlc.Batman: Arkham Origins isn't as good as the previous titles. The game is buggy and it get's boring really fast, but it's still really fun. The boss battles are interesting and are fun as hell. The story is really interesting too. Overall if you are a fan of Arkham games this is a must own. But my suggestion is to get the game on sale only. I give Batman: Arkham Origins a 7/10

number of helpful: 7 of 12 people (58%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												A valiant effort by WB Montreal, but ultimately too many things wrong with it for me to recommend. Rocksteady perfected the combat with Arkham City, but for some reason WB Montreal decided it would be a good idea to tweak things that would create a "no step forward, two steps back" sort of situation. At least on the PC, interrupting attacks to counter foes has been removed. Batman's attack animations are needlessly lengthy and sluggish, creating a situation where trying to attack an attacker head-on will result in Batman being beaten to the punch, 10 times out of 10. There are two problems with this: your default attack button now becomes Counter, and Batman is reduced to lower in skill than a common street thug. The changes to the combat compared to Arkham City remove the power fantasy of being Batman. The game was incredibly buggy on release, as well. There are nitpicks, too, like the leveling design being completely linear, or the electric gauntlets basically invalidating any strategy the original two games required for dealing with special foes, but those are minor things. The real issues are in the combat, and when that's most of what this game is, you've got a problem.Play Arkham City instead, or wait for Rocksteady's next installment. I can't recommend this one.

content:
Posted: November 1, 2015
November 1st, and the sales are still running in the Halloween Sale. The morning sun'sglow seems to bounce off Summer-Rain'sface as both of you leave your house."Are you going back to class? I think I mighthave to get a doctor's note for today..."You start, rubbing the back of your head. Summer-Rain looks at you in an almostcondescending way, hands on her hips."No. No way am I going to be seen walkingto class with you. What will people think?"Your heart sinks and you try not to make itobvious to her. "Although..." She begins, and your eyes meet hers only to see thatshe grabs you by the hand and leads youto school. "Come on! I have an idea!"Both of you are in a half-run, ending upin the computer lab for media students.You question why, and she beckons youto sit as she powers on two of the PCs."Sign into your steam account and wecan play until the next class." She winks,as she opens up her own steam client."But the next class is at 4pm..." Shelooks at you with a dangerous glint inher eye. "Exactly. Since I can't be seencoming to class with you... might aswell spend some time while waiting herewith you, right?" She busies herself onher own screen and you try to ignorethe naughty thoughts that creep intoyour head.Looking at the sale, Arkham Originsis strangely discounted, with no otherof the Batman games included. Not oneto turn down a good origin story and aBatman game, you click buy and thegame is soon yours.A breakout at Blackgate Prison is shownwith Black Mask the head honcho, alongwith the brutish Killer Croc as an introductory boss fight. The action moves at a speed that is almost breakneck, and the story engaging and compelling, drawing uponthe rich mythology of Batman, the storiesof Year One, Man Who Laughs and the Long Halloween in particular.Combat is meaty, weighty, and at times,brutal. Against mobsters, ninjas, martialartists and mercenaries, Batman is neverwithout an edge, but the fighting isbalanced, fair and the controls are tight.Seven Assassins have been contracted byBlack Mask to hunt down the Bat onChristmas Eve. Gotham's bitter winter cutsyou from beyond the computer screen asmultiple side objectives with grueling andcompelling puzzles put you to the test bysome of Batman's soon-to-be regularenemies and villains.Summer-Rain realizes the amount of zealyou play with, along with the sickeningsounds of combat and gunfire. "Origins?"She exclaims, leaning in next to you asshe peers over. You exhale quickly, beingthis close to her was unexpected. "Yeah."She observes in silence as you play throughthe Arkham Origins, the story unfoldingmore and more like an actual hollywoodfilm. When the Joker makes his appearance,Summer-Rain gasps and wraps her armaround your own, almost making you jump.She looks at you expectantly, and both ofyou smile at each other, before she leanson your shoulder and continues watching."Idiot." She mumbles. "Sorry." You reply."Class starts in 10 minutes." She saysabsent-mindedly, as you fight Bane amida rooftop battle, helicopters surveying thescene. "When we get back to class..."she disengages from holding you, and youfeel all the more colder than a winter inGotham. "This never happened, loser. No one willknow, got it?" You don't know whetherto smile or feel sad, as Summer-Rain looksat you expectantly again, hands crossedabove her petticoat that flares out, drawingyou in as it accents her curves..."-Hey! Got it?!" She stammers, lookingmore adorable than angry. "Yeah. Got it."Summer-Rain perks up, and says that she'llwait for you outside as she needs to gofreshen up. As soon as Summer-Rain shutsthe lab door, her face becomes determined."Leave him alone." She says, Ms. Novocaineright next to her, looking into the computerlab window. "Or what?" She whispers. "He longs for me... I know that much."Summer-Rain's eyes narrow viciously,regarding Ms. Novocaine with cruel eyes,eyes that were once as cruel to you fromMs. Novocaine. "He doesn't even know what happened. If he did... he'll end uplike Batman. Taking it out on the wholeworld." Ms. Novocaine smiles an evil grin. "You make it seem like that's a bad thing."Summer-Rain is steadfast now. "It is." Shefiercely snaps back. "He deserves better."Ms. Novocaine flips her hair back and strutsoff, waving her hand dismissively atSummer-Rain. "Does he deserve you?"You open the door to find Summer-Rainon the verge of tears amid the emptycorridor, the afternoon sun streaming inthrough the windows. "Summer...?" Youstart, when she spins round, burying herface into your chest as she holds youfor dear life. "Shh." You reassure her."What happened? Tell me..."She hits your chest with her fist half-heartedly as she demands through hersobs that the class will not know. Yourepeat her request to reassure her."I wanna milkshake." She says, lookingup at you. "I want to skip class and havea milkshake with you at the park."Taken aback, you nod and smile slightly."Okay...! Milkshakes at the park it is!"Summer-Rain leans her head againstyour chest. "Promise me something..."She begins, a new request of hers isimminent, you think. "Yes, Summer?""Don't add me... to your burden."Your eyes widen, but she holds youtighter now. "Those were alfred'swords..." Your breathing stops only for a moment. "I promise, Summer." You whisper,holding her tenderly as you reassure her."...and I promise no one will know."Summer-Rain sniffles, looking up at you now, before an uneasy distance is suddenly re-established between the two of you. As you both reachthe doors of the school's entrance,you feel you need to say this."Summer."She is taken aback but how seriousyou made it sound. "Yes?" You faceher and offer her your hand."Whatever you're going though,Summer... I will be here. For you."She looks at your hand and then back to you, before holding your hand gingerly. "I know, my Dark Knight." She says, as the both of you push the doors open, walking into the afternoon sun and towards the park."...I've always known."
