content:
Posted: October 20, 2016
												Compared to the previous 2, this game is a buggy mess. The story isn't bad but there are things like events not triggering or enemies getting clipped into walls. Sometimes the AI gets stuck on objects, other times it doesn't read your input correctly. They just did a bad job overall.And there's no benefit to doing certain sidequests like the Riddler one. You don't even get to catch him this time around like in the other 2 games after completing all of the challenges, lots of them being highly unintuitive (you'll be looking them up online). He's just...not there, like they ran out of time to complete his story even though they force you to take over his towers to fast travel between districts. The game just feels like they ran out of ideas and decided to make you do fetch quests, beat up mobs, and backtrack excessively to make up for the lack of content.TLDR: Decent story, bad execution, not worth doing sidequests, achievements, or DLC (which is a standalone mode). You'll probably buy/play it anyway. Season Pass not worth it. Also, fast travel shows unskippable cutscenes.

content:
Posted: September 18, 2016
No Wonder this is Almost Non-Canon.Batman: Arkham Origins is a spin-off made by Warner Brothers, NOT the same devepers as the original trilogy of the Arkham games (those are made by Rocksteady) and it shows. It really does.STORY As the title suggest, this game takes place before any event of the Arkham games, precisely 2 years from the beginning of the Batman, for many just a misterious figure, with no knowledge if friend or foe. Obviously, the currupted police of Gotham sees it as an enemy, so it does his best to take him down.Anyhow, this Christmas Eeve Black Mask claims a bounty on your head of 50,000$ to anyone who manages to kill the Bat, on which 8 super hitmans, from Deathstroke to Bane, decided to give a shot to take the money and the glory. It's up to you to stop them and bring peace to Gotham.But something does not add up, since Black Mask might not actually be himself, but a new misterious figure, which- ok its the Joker, its on every advertisment, and it's an unwritten rule that you cannot have a Batman game without the Joker. If the premise sounds pretty weak, is it because it actually is. The other Arkham games always made sense, since Batman always found himself stuck in an Astylum or the city itself by a threath greater them him, but in this game the only reason he's tied to his city is because "he must do what is right", even tho is never really established that the citizen are in danger, except for the last moments where they throw in the classic underground bombs.The only really good part about the story is the  Joker's origins: it follows very closely the source, and its very well exposed. Personally, I would have prefared if the plot stick more to this, instead of showing me a  Joker who acts like a 12 years old on too much sugar.GAMEPLAYLiterally the same as Arkham City, but somehow worst. The grappling hook feels very unresponsive most of the time, and quite often during combat some moves didn't do as I wanted.But in the moments where I couldn't realize what was happening, the game was either trying to hold my hand way too much, or just flushing himself down the toilet with his billion bugs and glitches.when I say that this game is incredibly unpolished, trust me, it really is, and I'm not talking about performance issues. I never really had framerate drops or crashes, it worked fine for that, but in my playtime I had:-Enemies stuck in walls that stopped my progress-Enemies coming back from being unconcious staring at me doing nothing-Enemies flying away after a takedown-Ragdolls going crazy-Batman getting stuck in places-The takedown ability randomly stopped workingThis was quite frustrating, since it made me die, or worst, forced me to boot up the game from the start, killing the whole atmosphere.COLLECTABLESThis might feel like a pointless rant for lots of people, but hear me out: this game has the worst riddler collectables possible. I played every single Arkham game 100%, doing everything possible in each game. Arkham Asylum rewarded me with some really cool insight, and recordings that are incredibly well acted. Arkham City gave me a story line, and the possibility to punch the Riddler in his stupid mouth. Arkham Knight literally gave me an intense boss fight with the Riddler, and with the whole completion, a secret ending.So what does this gave gives you for discovering and completing everything? Absolutely nothing. Sure, you get some recordings in here aswell, but they're not as fun as Asylum, and they didn't even bother to give you and enounter face to face with the Riddler, or even him aknowledging the fact that you ruined his plans. There was no reward whatsoever, which really felt underwelming, and kinda made me feel ripped off. I do not suggest to even bother trying to collect everything from this game, if you care about completion like me.GRAPHIC AND MUSICIt's the same engine as City but more detailed, not much to say. It looks great, even tho the cape often glitched around instead of being amazing like the previous games, but not much of a complain.I actually noticed the textures had some troubles loading sometimes, but after a second of pop up, it would work pretty smoothly.The music was clearly not composed by the same author of the Arkham Trilogy. Don't get me wrong, is still "all right", is just not as effective. I liked the "Nutcracker" snuck here and there, since the game takes place in a Christmas setting. Other then that, not a whole lot that was incredibly stunning.FINAL RATING: 5/10This was pretty much a cash-in on the name of the Arkham games. They tried to replicate the exact glory that Arkham City earned by copying what they did right and not even trying to spice things up. It's just a lazy attempt to breath some fresh air on something that is perfectly fine the way it is. Warner Brothers, if you really want to launch yourself in those superheroes games, just bright us a new title with a new superhero, maybe a game about Flash, or if you don't want to leave your Bat-comfort zone, give us a proper Suicide Squad title.Just try for god sake.

number of helpful: 11 of 20 people (55%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 24, 2014
												If you see people saying Origins is horribad, rest assured, they're wrong.First thing first, Origins is almost copy paste of Arkham City, the 2nd installment of Arkham series. It definitely brings many good things Arkham City (and Asylum) had. Similar gadgets, similar combat styles, familiar characters (well, of course, it's Batman after all), and it's always nice to know Batman before he became established super hero. If you've played the previous two, you wouldn't feel any awkwardness playing the game.Navigating in an open city couldn't be easier. Batman can jump from building to building, grapple with ease - much ease than on AC from my fingers' memory - and now can use 'teleport' aka fast travel with Batwing to reach other corners faster. ...well uh, after completing Tower missions against Enigma, of course.There are also many other hidden objects and sidequests you can do like in Arkham City. Enigma Datapack, destroying poison barrels etc. The template pretty much the same like previous installmentPersonal preference: I've played all three Batman installments on Steam, and I feel the smoothest combat is from this Origins.Performance wise, so far I am having zero problem with Batman Origins set up on all low settings. On Batman Arkham City, though, I've had considerable slowdown, not because of my weak graphic card, but because it was bugged game engine - thanks to PhysX.For the contents on Steam aka DLC, there's zero reason to get multiplayer DLCs. This game's intended to be played as SINGLE player. Why on earth would they be pushing MP contents into Batman I don't know. Just buy the SP DLCs and you're good to go, or wait until GOTY pops up. By that time, then, I think Arkham Knight will have been in existence. Game's on sale for 75% off quite often, so I would recommend to pick it up at that price.And don't forget, this game's best played with controller. I have no issue with both Dinput (using x360ce) and Xinput gamepads.So yeah, Arkham Origins is the game you either hate or love. It's a copy paste from previous game, and adds almost nothing except better combat and or navigation in city, perhaps. Well what can I say, don't fix what ain't broken? Isn't that the golden rule?At any rate, this game is a must have if you're Batman fans.

content:
Posted: October 26, 2016
												This feels like a game made by people with all the right tools at their disposal, but possessing insufficient ability or care to get enough out of them.The tone is set from the very beginning, with juddery intro videos, and the glitches persist from there. The game is riddled with little glitches, like unconscious enemies remaining standing, or hitting an invisible floor when cut down from gargoyles so that they float in mid-air. It also suffers from sharp framerate drops even on a 1080.Aside from consisting of a B-list of villains, the boss fights are often badly designed. The first in particular sets a poor tone by being badly unbalanced and frustrating, while later ones are ruined by the grossly overpowered shock glove weapon which renders them ridiculously simple. The detective scenes offer a glimmer of hope as an interesting new concept, but the game tells you, audibly and visually, exactly what you have to to every step of the way. There is no skill or thought required. They are glorified QTEs. Indeed, much of the game feels this way - it is constantly telling you exactly what you have to do.It has its good moments - a few strong cutscenes, some decent voice acting, generally decent graphics - but is not in the league of its two predecessors.

												If there will be another Batman game in the future i hope it won't be for another couple years as this felt like a rehash of everything. Like they took Arkham City's world, Asylum's animations and tacked on a crappy multiplayer and made the game buggy as hell.The 'origins' storyline felt like a reason to add in the ever-popular Joker and many of the other assassins hardly added anything to the game other than a checklist to complete. The villain roster was decent but none really stood out like in Asylum or City.Roger Craig Smith as Batman was ok. Too many of his lines were dry and his tone felt forced. Troy Baker's Joker is almost spot on and listening to his dialogue was one of the few immersive moments I've experienced in this title.If you want the best Batman experience, play Asylum. It may not be as open-worldy, but the gameplay is tight and focused. I'm glad I only spent $15 on Origins.6.8/10

												A perfect example of milking a franchise based on previous installment's success! This game is no where near the level of Batman Arkham Asylum and City. Both are amazing games and should be played to fully enjoy the series. This one however feels like a DLC.The good part about this 'dlc' is that it goes back to show the story before the events of Arkahm Asylum. Aside from that and few new gadgets, the entire game looks and feels like a copy-paste of previous installments. This one even comes with occasional glitches that I've never encoutered in the other twos. If you've played the first two games, play it as a "steam sale, gotta have it" style game. It will expand the story a bit.On the positive sides however, the game does introduce some amazing mechanics, most notably the detective-simulation type system to investigate a crime scene. Hopefully in the next TRUE Batman game, it will be implemented with better, improved, and complex elements. I recommend this as a good buy, but it is not to be compared to the first two games.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 7, 2014
												Batman: Arkham Origins review. It's no Arkham Asylum or Arkham City.Set just two years after Bruce Wayne becomes Batman, the game has our caped crusader still as yet unknown, a myth amongst criminals and a wanted man by Gotham City PD. Bruce is on his own, and Origins explores how Batman becomes protector of Gotham.Let's start off with the bad. There are a HUGE amount of horrific bugs and control issues that really hamper the game, including a few game breaking ones. Combat flows awkwardly and haphazardly, with serious AI issues abounding all throughout. Often the gadgets can stop working, and many times it's not always clear where to go next. However, YMMV in these areas, so take that with a grain of salt.That being said, there are flashes of pure unadulterated brilliance in Origins. The story is AMAZING, and I would put it superior to both Asylum and City, even if they played it a bit safe with the ending. Fights with Deathstroke, Deadshot (♥♥♥♥ that fight) and even Firefly are great to see and pulled off nicely. Deathstroke's fight is absolutely brilliant, requiring strategy and constant awareness to do flawlessly.The game looks very nice, even on my middle-range system. I can only imagine what a beastly rig would make this game look like. Environments however are a little bland. Would have liked to see more greenery, but the setting of the game at Christmas does explain away that omission.Overall, while not as tight mechanically as Asylum, or City, Origins is worth your time. A great imagining of a Batman not yet a recognisable hero, but still a threat to the criminals of Gotham.Rating: 3.5/5Warner Brothers has no intention of patching bugs that don't break the game, so be aware that some issues can and most likely will arise while playing.

												For the eight hours of seamless gameplay I was able to enjoy, this game was surpassing my best expectations. A really well paced game, worthy of being a game of the year. content:
Posted: February 13, 2014
												I got this game at a cazy deal and yet I still find this game to be such a let down. I was and am a HUGE Batman Arkham Series fan. I really loved the dark atmosphere and challenge (on hard) of the first game and the high replayability of the second game. With that said, this game in no way pushes the series forward. The raved about boss fights are lazy. This game completely exhausted the combat system (believe or not) and then compounds that with repetitious uninspired stun/beatdown boss fights. The story was also weak and spent way too long to show itself different or new. I found myself (a Batman fan!) getting more and more cynical as I played. I have about 25% of the main story left and I'm not even the slightest interested in how things turn out. (6/10)PS: For an inspired boss reference, I think Poison Ivy with Catwoman, Killer Croc in BAA, Mr. Freeze, Solomon Grundy, and even Bane in BAA were inspiring boss fights.UPDATE: I have now completed this game (after some reluctance) and the final fight is just about the ONLY inspird boss fight I've found in this game.

content:
Posted: December 30, 2013
												Batman: Arkham Origins is a prequel to the Arkham Asylum/Arkham City games.  Only 2 years into being Batman and helping out in Gotham, Batman has his toughest night yet since this Christmas Eve the villian Black Mask has put a bounty of 50 million dollars on his head and 8 deadly assassins are in Gotham looking to score.The game looks really great and runs well even on my older laptop with an Nvidia GeForce 310 512MB card.  Occasionally has some small bugs like batman gliding through the air and flopping up and down constantly, or even more infamous, quick time events where the buttons don't register (If you can, use a controller).  Combat is the same as the other Batman games.  Very quick and fluid combos against large groups of enemies, or Predator set pieces where you pick off enemies one by one in sneaky fashion.The story is much more fleshed out than the previous games as well. Without giving too many spoilers, It shows how Batman's relationship evolved with the police and Liutenant Gordon, why so many villains want him dead and how he earned his reputation in Gotham as a hero.If you liked the previous Batman games and want more, you will definitely like this game.

content:
Posted: April 2, 2014
												EDIT: I have been playing the online a lot lately and I have to admit that the online is actually very, very fun and creative. The same cannot be said about the Single Player.Whoever says that this game is not repititive has obviously not played the masterpiece known as Arkham City. Remember the Payphone Killer missions? Well, they are back again as bomb missions. The Bane "Blow Up TITAN" mission is replaced with Black Mask's "Blow Up Drug Containers" mission. The Freeze Blast/Cluster/Mine grenades are now replaced by the huge rip-off known as the Glue Grenade. The Line Launcher is now replaced by a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ replacement known as the "Remote Claw", which Bats literally stole from Slade the Terminator. The Remote Electric Charge gun is now replaced by the Shock Gloves. And the Beyond skin is only available in multiplayer!!! And as if it just wasn't already repititive enough, the TITAN dudes are replaced by the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t "Enforcers" Bane boss fight is another giant rip-off of the TITANs, Firefly is extremely similar to Clayface and you even use the same gadget, the Glue/Freeze grenade to defeat both of them AND you have to dodge around to avoid either charges or, in Firefly's cas, the Flamethrower. Mad Hatter's mission is a rip-off of the Scarecrow Hallucination minus it isn't that exciting, AND I HAVEN'T EVEN STARTED TALKING ABOUT THE ♥♥♥♥ING MAIN STORY YET!!! Remember the Epic Fight in the gladiator pit in Penguin's museum? Well, it's back again. The TN1 Bane fight is a rip-off of the Mr Freeze fight, it's just without the feeling of helplessness, and the feeling that it truly is a game of cat and mouse in City. Copperhead is a huge rip-off of both Ra's Al Ghul AND Scarecrow, and while I admit it is enjoyable, the Deathstroke fight is also copied from Ra's Al Ghul, remember the Beat-Down sequences and countering huge attack chains? Collecting all of these communications circuits or whatever they were is a huge rip-off of destroying Penguin's Jammer, and you do it to apprehend the same guy again! How great is that? I should also mentioned that I enjoyed the setpieces in Arkham City, but the setpieces in Origins, espicially, the Main Theme, SUCKS. And remember how it would have been nice if the plot was about Batman screwing Black Mask up? Well, it's about the Joker again! Also, while some parts of the dialogue is nice(e.g. Joker's first conversation with Harley), most of it SUCKS, espicially the Predator Inmate Conversations. P.S: They've also somehow managed to screw up the Freeflow Combat in this game. Controls are unresponsive and you cannot cancel your own blows to counter anymore, and some of the new sounds(e.g. knockout sound) are terrible

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 26, 2014
												If Arkham Asylum offered the thrill of becoming Batman, and Arkham City offered the thrill of exploring Gotham in free flight, and Arkham Knight will (supposedly) offer the thrill of piloting the Batmobile, then Arkham Origins seems to be offering the thrill of experiencing the genesis of Batman's most important relationships: Alfred, Gordon, and an array of his iconic nemises. However, Arkham Origins does not, as you might think, tell the story of how Bruce Wayne became the Batman. In fact, the circumstances of Wayne's childhood tragedy, training, and return to Gotham as reborn vigilante is already in the past, before the game begins, and he is already equipped with batarangs, grapnel, and Batwing jet. Instead, the 'Origins' referenced are the seeds planted in the story that will eventually mature into the Arkham City future. Along the way, Batman grows from a shadowy rumor to a renowned crime-fighter, having already taken bites out of local threats like Penguin and Black Mask, but also starting to attract enough attention to himself to begin to tip the established balance of power that will change Gotham forever.Unfortunately, where the previous Arkham Games have built and expanded on the fantasy of 'becoming' the Batman and living his adventure, with his gadgets, intelligence, and fortitude, Origins deviates very little from the City forumla of roaming the night, dealing justice to criminals, solving crime, and saving the city from an overarching threat. There's nothing new here, which is probably good news if you enjoyed City, but will disappoint if you're looking for the Arkham franchise to raise the ante. In a very real sense, Origins is a sort of deluxe-sized expansion pack for Arkham City that transposes that sequel's gameplay back in time.The good is that the polish and production values are as high as ever. The animation, cinematics, voice acting, and so on are extremely immersive, and Gotham looks great as a proud, post-industrial metropolis beginning to decay from the inside out. All of Batman's gadgets return, and there are now even more districts to explore, with never a shortage of thugs to beat into unconsciousness. There is a full compliment of challenge maps to medal in, side quests to complete, and obscure objects to find and collect, as in City. The main addition to the Arkham series overall is the "Crime Scene" sequences where Batman explores and reconstructs various crimes in order to solve a problem. While these are very, very simple puzzles, the actions and narrations do give the player a solid sense of being the "World's Greatest Detective", which is often neglected in Batman movies and games.The bad is that it will feel very much like playing Arkham City all over again, in a more mundane environment, and with a story campaign that feels noticably shorter when you consider it apart from all the diversions that you might explore along the way. Batman gains new abilities by completing various challenges according to the Dark Knight system, but what might have been enjoyable can easily become a frustrating grind when the challenge requirements do not properly align with the actual given opportunities within the game, forcing you to replay the game over if you want to maximize your potential. Lastly, this is clearly the least stable, most buggy iteration of the Arkham franchise. While most of the issues have been resolved by now, the game does not seem to have been coded cleanly or elegantly. Expect to experience crashes along the way.Concerning the DLC: The Initiation Pack only features Challenge Map content, which is a good value if you like that gamplay (I do). You can play pre-Batman Bruce Wayne in a weaker, stripped-down form on all the standard maps, along with a difficult, 5-map campaign simulating his training as part of the League of Shadows. Conversely, the "Cold Cold Heart" DLC is a standalone, story-only campaign, with no challenge maps, that doesn't interact with the main Origins storyline at all. If you just like the Batman story and experience without the tedium of Challenge medals, then this is perfect content for you, featuring a complete set of side quests, equipment upgrades, open-world exploring, and plotline with new enemies and characters, and a challenging new boss fight integrating stealth, combat, and gadgets together. As for the Batman costume skin packs, I didn't find them ultimately worth the value. The various suits and costumes generally did not fit well into the strong, well-established artistic design the game already possesses, and were at best comical and at worst distracting.In summary, Arkham Origins is retelling stories you have probably already heard before. If once was enough, you should probably take a pass, but if you can't just get enough, Origins is happy to offer more.

content:
Posted: April 9, 2014
												Overall the game is very very good the combat has depth and is not too complex, maling it really feeling like one of the only games that feels like it can stand on combat alone if needed but with the platfroming/ puzzle solving mechanics that give it a balance of fun that I feel that only this and the orgional price of persia series has accomplished in the 3d relm. The story is engaging and gritty while keeping the plot simple and is meant to give of a feeling of determination to stop what is going on rather than putting 50 plot twists in or going down so deep in Batman lore that you have to read years worth of Batman comics or stop the game to search in wikipedia to understand (thats is not saying there will be no charcters that people will not know before getting into the game but rather the game does a very good job explaining who they are through both the cut scenes and gameplay styles and areas that you interact with them in). Thank being said I think there is two things holding the game back. The main one is that the city in the single player just feels so....... empty you end feeling like your saving a city with nobody in it. Now, the games excuse is that everyone is staying in their homes due to a huge storm, but in reality there are still some people out and about even in snow storms (now saying that is smart or not, that is a different subject) so could had a least a couple of people out and about in the streets, something like saving a woman when those sudden crime reports come up? Even a few npcs would make it feel that your in a living city and not an apocalytic one. (and for any of those that will say that the world is more for collecting, the orgional Crackdown was a collect-a-thon in almost the same exact way and still managed to create a livelier city than this AND was released in 2007) the other promlem is that the multiplayer is boring, which I know is a very common complaint and is really not the reason people buy this game but it still dosen't change the fact that it could be done better than a generic thrid person shooter with batman combat, what makes it frustrating is that all it need to be good was a endless oneline mode with friends similar to the single player challenges or some online co-op.  Don't let the negatives deter you though this game is good just could have been better if Wb interactive wasn't trying to release a new game every year  like it is the combat version of call of duty which I am very afraid that it is becoming like that with the new game announced for this year.

content:
Posted: November 7, 2013
												This game, well everyone who loves batman arkham series, especially akrham city, would like or hate this game. Batman Arkham Origin is the prequel of the Arkham series where the Bruce Wayne just passed two years in battling criminal as the caped crusaderThe story of this game, despite not being developed by Rocksteady nor written by the previous game writer. This game has the best story in overall arkham game series. You will questioning how the moral standard of batman that he will not kill or let anyone get killed, even his most dangerous enemy. When playing this game maybe you will think, "If I were him, I would kill that ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ so there will no other victims." And this game told more about Alfred that really wanted his master just live a normal billionaire life, forgetting his night vigilante routinity. And there will be some other origin story about joker too that previously been told by "The Killing Joke" comic. Overall this game has really done a good job in his story aspect about Batman loreThe gameplay, well this is a little bit down of this game. The overall gameplay is almost identically the same with Arkham City. Even the city is almost the same with previous. Only a minor tweak to the gadget and character proggression system. In this game there will be some achievement that will rewarded you with some perk. But some of the achievement is quite hard to earn and only able to do in some specific places. So maybe for people who don't want to read any guide or such will find himself frustated because you can't do some achievement and your only hope is to do the new game plus that been harder than normal playthroughMy verdict is, 8 out of 10. Yes I heavily value a story from the game I played. And Batman Arkham Origin has done really good job in telling the story. Even it's not really told the "Origin" about Batman nor about the Asylum itself but I really love the story of this game. More emotional and more character is more lively compared to previous game. But if you value the gameplay more then you will eat a same burger, but this time the ketchup is plentier than the previous.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 11, 2014
COMPLETED 100%I got this prequel to the ever sucessful Arkham series, hoping it'd be better than what critics have made it out to be. But as it turns out, the game is more of an overall disappointment to what it could have been a signifciant improvement to Arkham City. While AC was so flawlessly free of technicalities, this game is still riddled with quite a few glitches and bugs the devs couldn't be bothered with. Nothing so game-breaking at least. Where the games shine, the combat system, AO does away by making for slightly more challenging enemies and variations. This is surely a good thing, if not for the numerous control input problems and fight inconsistencies that simply ends up screwing up the enjoyment of gameplay. Especially annoying when the game expects you to perform up to task for the stupid Dark Knight System and ranked challenge maps.Thankfully there's the very unbalanaced and overpowered Shock Gloves, to compensate for this. A new and important gadget to this game, it makes you wonder why the heck wasn't Batman using this OP weapon in Arkham Asylum and Arkham City. I mean it helped  defeat Bane and save Alfred from near-death. It's so glorious, there's no reason to abandon it.  There's only one thing AO has made the biggest improvement from the past games. The main story missions are now more noticeably fun and interesting to get through, despite the silly premise which mainly serves as a subtle excuse in order to chuck a whole bunch of notable Batman villians in this one single game. It's also slightly longer and less than straightforward, compared to AC's main campaign, which is nice.. The dark cinematics and presentation are also brilliantly well done in coveying the tone of the game. If only the actual game looked as good... Boss fights are exceptionally great fun as well but makes Batman look too darn overpowered for someone just starting on an early vigilante career. The open world of Gotham is much bigger than the Arkham City in Arkham City, many similiar buildings stand out, being bigger in size, and the layout is mostly different enough to distinguish as being unique. It's also as completely unrealistic as ever, as a city completely void of civilians. Another ridiculous excuse to prevent Batman from making "social interations" with civilians. What a bummer.Collectibles still remain the same, data packs replacing riddler trophies this time and the number of packs hidden and are spread around the city. Finding or acquiring them isn't as hard as before, with less puzzles and challenges to solve. A show of leniency to completionists, or just a lack of effort on the devs' part in rushing this game. 3.5/5 - Game presentation is great, some areas of gameplay is an improvement, others is a thumbs down. A great game regardless, nevertheless, but nothing much so noteworhy for the upcoming Arkham Knight to follow and adapt from.

												Fun, but not as polished as the previous two games. Seems to be glitchier, multiple times I've ended up bat-swinging into areas I shouldn't be able to reach (And getting stuck there), and once I managed to leave the map altogether and ended up falling into an endless abyss. The voices, unfortunately, are no longer the DCAU cast, but the new VA's do a great job at filling those rather large shoes, although the Joker's VA seems to be trying a little too hard with his Mark Hamill Joker voice and it's tenDENcy to STRRRRRRETCH out CEEEEEERtain syllables... Regardless, if like me you like batman and you liked the other two games you'll probably still really like this one. The fact that it's not made by the same team is obvious but the fun's still there.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 8, 2015
												This current entry in the Batman/Arkham series is a lot of the same for fans of the previous titles -- as Batman, you explore a large segment of Gotham, dealing with a multitude of villians and optional objectives during a particularly heated Christmas Eve, setting some groundwork and backstory for the previous Arkham titles and the upcoming Arkham Knight.The game flow follows a somewhat rigid structure of exploring the city freely for bonuses that earn you some unlockable abilities, as well as data and viewable charater models, while the main objectives require you to go into large interior areas and set peices and finishing up with a unique boss battle. I would say that for some fans fatigued with the series this could be considered a negative, but the story is well-written and paced, set during a time where Batman is still getting into his role and is considered inexperienced. That said, the voice acting is superb, and the game holds together well on its presentation.Combat is also copied verbatim from the other Arkham titles. It is a very fluid system that rewards the player for fighting large groups of enemies without getting hit and most importantly, not breaking the literal flow of combat by stopping for any reason. This one has some tougher enemies than in the other games, requiring more combinations of evasion and disarming to manage the enemies, which I assume is also trying to push the point of a Rookie Batman and making sure experienced players still stay on their toes.For the very experienced and people demanding a challenge, the game offers a permadeath mode called "I Am the Night" which adds a much greater layer of tension, and I'm happy to see it offered up.It looks like the game had gotten some heat when it was initially released due to some bugs and glitches, but in its state as of posting, I only had one isolated instance of a massive framerate drop in the Batcave that resolved itself after about thirty seconds that I believe may have been on my end. All in all, I'd say this game is a very worthy purchase for a fan of the Arkham series or people interested in jumping into the Arkham series.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 6, 2014
												TL:DR >  Watching Batman movies and reading Batman comics is great and all, but if you really want to feel like you are the Dark Knight, playing Arkham Origins is probably as close as you can get without becoming a billionaire and having your parents murdered. What makes the game so great is that it features all the elements of being Batman: Detective work, awesome gadgets, martial artistry, chasing crazy people, wearing your underpants on the outside, and so on.Long review:Graphics: Excellent, well tuned to NVIDIA GPUs, notably DX11 Tesselation and PhysX. AMD guys may have a different story to tell.Gameplay: For these new to the game, some boss fight scenes will be a considerable challenge, so prepare to die and restart the game from that point and get taunted for failing.Story: Well-developed characters and story line that explains a lot about the prequels, and dropping subtle hints that allows the Batman universe to intertwine in all the three games. This is one of the strongest points in the game; Take for instance, the origin of Mr. Freeze, Bane's breakdown, the relationship between Bruce Wayne and his butler, and the Joker's over the line insanity.Tips: Get the season pass to access the rest of the DLCs. If you don't need online play, the season pass has you covered with the rest, such as the Initiation DLC and stuff. That adds extra hours of immersive gameplay that'll keep you practising and on edge to keep up with your enemies.Length:Well balanced. On average, it is possible to pull off both the main and side missions without being sidetracked too far from the game, and also offers sweet upgrade points which reward the gamer's time spent on the side missions. Replay value: Owing to the excellent challenge mode(s) and extra game play modes, you8 cannot play this game once. Overall rating: 10/10. This game is perfect.PS: Did I mention there were Ninjas? Yes, I did. Overall: 10/10. Gameplay reminiscent of Batman Arkham City.Extra notes for AMD users: On DirectX 11 tesselation, use normal settings and avoid all NVIDIA "enhanced" settings, they can cripple the game's performance. The same aplies to people using NVIDIA GPUs priot to Kepler.

												This game i s pretty good, theres a strong combination of story and open world while at the same time having a well written story and addictive gameplay. Then i realized i didnt use the one item on my utility belt needed to pass that level, or i was in the wrong room, or i was in the right room but couldnt figure out what the dialouge was telling me. content:
Posted: November 28, 2013
												Batman: Arkham Origins is an odd one. While the gameplay itself has been tightened up, for example the combat flows a lot better and enemies are generally more aggressive than they were during previous games, the innovation is seriously lacking.The collectibles are uninspired compared to the original riddles and the main story is just downright dire, with the assassins that are supposedly after you falling more into sidequests than anything else. The copy/paste assets of Arkham City doesn't do the game any favours either, as it feels more like an expansion than anything.Graphically the game looks great and there are a few nice touches here and there such as PhysX enabled snow and it has been optimised to hell and back so it runs fantastically (game breaking bugs aside), but it still doesn't look as good as Arkham City does.It's a good game if you are a fan of the series, but I would hold off and get it a little cheaper unless you really have to have it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 27, 2014
												When I heard about this game being developed by a different company, I thought it would be a refreshing experience. I am not opposed to change, if that change is good. But then, when I played it, I immediately realized that I was wrong. This game is not a change. Let me explain why:• In terms of gameplay, Arkham Origins is identical to Arkham City. It even has the same map. The environments are different, but that difference is merely superficial. The devs made the easiest decision: don't innovate, just recycle. Even the gadgets are the same. Most of them we've already seen before, and the "new" ones are just different versions of the same thing (remote claw=line launcher, though the claw is a bit of an improved version; glue grenade=freeze cluster). The shock gloves are a very nice addition though, but because of its usefulness, every fight after you get them is a joke. Except boss fights of course, in which you will be screaming to your monitor the word "bull****" several times.• In terms of story telling, it follows their predecessors with extreme accuracy. The story itself is different, of course. It includes several villains that weren't present in previous installments, but it also includes several that were, and without the need to do so. But there are no plot holes, and the story shapes out well as a prequel to Arkham Asylum. I recommend staying through the credits (despite the fact that credits are extremely long).• In the graphical aspect, don't even get me started on the bugs. Man this game is buggy as hell, considering it's been released some time ago. Consider yourself extremely lucky if you get past your first boss fight without issues. And pray that enemies don't get stuck behind walls forcing you to start a fight all over again, and this applies to boss fights as well. I wouldn't say this feels like a beta, but it's certainly close. When it's not bugging out, it's the same as Arkham City. Don't expect anything new here.It has its epic moments, don't get me wrong, but it all feels the same to Arkham City, and that's where the game fails: originality. Still, I would recommend any fan of the franchise to get this game, but only when it's on sale, it's not worth the full price.Final score: 3.25/5

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 28, 2013
												Prior to Batman: Arkham Origins the only game Warner Bro. Monreal had worked on was the port of Arkham City to the Wii and  Lego: Legend of Chima Online.  That being said, they had the impossible task of trying to fill the shoes of Rocksteady Studios.  A company that revolutionized the superhero genre of videogames. A game that made us, possibley for the first time, feel like the superhero in question. No liceneced game, much less a superhero game, had really nailed it like Rocksteady did in the Arkham games. I'm not an Warner Bro. Montreal apologist but if Arkham Orings had been the first games to release we'd have been blown away.  It's disappointing we didn't get more interation in the third time out but what's there is solid.  Origins feels like a game that a produced by a studio that's just getting it's sealegs. Bugs abound but most of the game breaking issues have been resolved as far as I can tell. I didn't have nearly as many issues as most where having but I could chalk that up to luck.If you like Batman there just isn't a good reason not to pick this up now that some of the kinks have been work out. Batman: Arkham Orgins is wonderful game for Batman fans with enough combat and story to entertain a non-comic nerd.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 2, 2015
												Arkham Origins didn't try to be something else.It takes the combat,visual art and challenging boss fights from it's predecessors.Why fix something that ain't broken?The combat is very similar to Arkham Asylum and City but of course it looks and feels more fluid.It is improved but not so much that you'll feel a major difference.Gameplay-wise,Origins follows the same exact patterns as the previous games.You will have lots of Predator encounters where you try to take out armed enemies silently,followed by tons of skirmishes against various enemy types,and then boss fights.I don't complain,but they didn't even try to bring something new.At least the game's combat is good enough so you won't get bored to death.The boss fights are good and interactive,with good dialogue.The story-line is good.It's not fantastic,but it's good.I must say,stuff happens too fast and it might seem confusing at times but it's decently presented and delivered,with good portrayal of the characters from the comics.Arkham Origins tells the story from the begining and it brings cool personalities like Deadshot,Deathstroke,Black Mask and so on.My least favorite part are the ''side-quests''.They feel like a chore.You just run around the city doing mostly unsatisfying stuff in order to reach a goal.I know it's supposed to be for completionists,but at least try to spice it up a little.Batman Arkham Origins is a good game,alongisde two great games.It's the lesser game when compared to City and Asylum but it's still good.

												Batman: Arkham Origins is very similar to the last game, Arkham City which isn't a bad thing as the previous game was a masterpiece in it's own right.The story isn't as good as the previous two but it's still amazing, at times predictable but at other times surprises you with a plot twist that you didn't expect.The general plot of this game follows Batman on Christmas Eve as a bounty has been placed on his head that many major and minor villains will attempt to get from you.It should be said that this game was developed by Warner Brothers Montreal which is a different studio from the previous two and the upcoming Arkham Knight game which were all developed by Rocksteady Studios, it's because of this that I can forgive this title from not having too many changes from the last games.There is so much to do in this game even after you complete it, for example there is a most wanted side quest that allows you to try to stop criminals such as The Mad Hatter and The Penguin and bring them into custody. The Good - Good Story- Many interesting villains, even some you may not have heard of- Graphical improvements from previous game (not too much)- Fun side activities- Improved mechanics- Battle system is great with only a few problems- You can be Batman, who doesn't want a taste of that Batman lifestyle am I right? The Bad - Battle system is repetitive at times- Not many improvements from the previous games- A few glitches had to be sorted out, I never ran into many glitches like the fatal error or controlling flight issues however I did have to fix an issue with the cutscenes as mine lagged a lot; I ended up finding a guide on the steam community to help me.- Some tasks such as the collectables are still a chore in my opinion and I wish they were done more interestingly than they are in this game, for example Arkham Asylam had audio logs from the villains which were interesting to listen too and made me want to collect them.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 18, 2013
												An absolutely amazing game, building on the success of the previous installments, this game brings everything to the table. The story basically picks up after the Batman: Year One graphic novel, faithfully keeping the characters within "canon" boundaries and building upon their personalities with excellent voice acting, extremely articulated facial programming. The story is worthy of the Batman title, and the action is a step above the previous two games. The gadgets have been revamped slightly, and the "Dark Knight" challenges make you feel like the Bat yourself as you complete them. The visuals are drop-dead gorgeous and the art direction was well thought out. This extended and restored version of Gotham City is beautiful and keeps you exploring for hours and hours on end. With so much content, the replayability and longevity of life that this game has it tremendous. Sure the game launched with a few glitches, but they were promptly corrected by WBMontreal, and we now have a perfect game.

Posted: June 25, 2014
												I am an avid Batman fan and I truelly enjoyed the grittyness and raw ability that Batman dmeonstrates in this game.  In this game you play a Batman who is young and not as refined as the one we typically think of.  This allows for an experience unlike most Batman adventures where we do not see an unsure and angry Bruce Wayne/Batman.  The detective mode is extremely enhanced over the past two Batman games.  Most boss fights are challenging and enjoyable.  The overall story is compeling and feels like a batman movie.  Lots of gadgets, some detective work, and tons of action. Overall a very enjoyable expansion to the franchise.  I rate this game 9/10.  In the end, ask yourself if you want to be batman fighting against some of his greatest foes and some lesser known villians, than this game is definitely for you.

content:
Posted: July 6, 2014
												I had my doubts about this game after seeing a swapping of hands for developers and the metacritic scores, in comparison to the previous games (not that the metacritic was all that bad, its just lower than the previous titles.), but after picking this game up for $7.50, I can say that I got my money's worth and left satisfied. Although we saw the departure of Rockysteady on this title, presumably because Arkham Knight is quite resource consuming, WB Studios stepped in and did a fair job. They kept the good stuff (combat, open world, gadgets) and added a few nice features. Were you not aware of the change in studios, the only differences that might alert you to the fact would be the WB Studios logos and the new look interface. Otherwise, this game plays very much like the previous Arkham games. In my opinion, thats a good thing because it signals the developers knew what worked and didn't try to butcher it. For others, that is the inherit problem with this game; the fact that it is pretty much a clone of Arkham City. Were it not for a few changes, this game would be an exact clone. I really didn't have too much of a problem with this, seeing as its only the 3rd game in the installment and I'm not quite sick of doing the same thing over and over again yet. While its true that there isn't much innovation here, I'm glad that the new developers stuck with a route that worked and not one that tarnished the series. For that, we should all be proud. The story in this game is fits well in the universe and unravels the beginnings of several overarching plot points in the series, mainly the beginning of the Batman-Joker conflict and early versions of Harley Quinn before she goes evil, for example. On that note, it was interesting to see the beginnings. Sure, they could have been fleshed out a bit more, but I'm not complaining. The story was good until the end, and I really didn't have any qualms about it. Like I said, gameplay is more or less the same, save for a few reskinned gadgets with slightly different (although still true to core functionality) uses, as well as some new enemies to fight. Combat is the same, with perhaps some new moves down the line when you level-up. The world is still open, and it plays very similar to Arkham City with a myriad of things to do. One thing I really liked, however, is they definitely fleshed out the detective mode here. While its still a very minor part of the game, you can analyze the crime scenes more by reanacting the crime and investigating more clues to solve the crime. Sure it holds your hand and it doesn't feel like it should, but its a welcomed addition that was missing from Arkham City that made me happy to see. In addition, the boss fights have been improved in my opinion, and overall, were a bit more satisfying than the previous game. This game is not free of issues, however. I found that the counter key/button was only responsive 75%-80% of the time, causing large fights (10+ enemies) or counter heavy battles to be frustrating at times, as the counters would just not work at all some of the times. This also applied to ground takedowns. It just seemed like the key/button wasn't registering for me at times. There are also some combat bugs, such as enemies flying off the screen when hit or enemies clipping into buildings (still fightable even if you couldn't see them), but nothing gamebreaking here. A major issue, however, is the crashing. It shares a similar crashing issue with Arkham City. While this game crashing didn't seem to lock up my PC, it did seem to crash more often than the last game. I'd say it crashed once every 3-4 hours, and sometimes more often. If you are looking for a new Batman game that innovates the series, you'll have to look elsewhere, but if you are looking for a solid and faithful prequel to the last two games, look no further. While this game is nowhere near perfect thanks to some bugs and such, it is a game worth playing and is enjoyable from start to finish. Recommened. 8.5/10

content:
Posted: January 16, 2014
												Overall, it's a good game.  If you liked Arkham City, and you want to play it again but you're tired of the dialogue, here's your chance.  There are one or two new tweaks to the combat system and gadgets, but from all the trailer content we definitely saw that coming.  The story's not bad, but actually I liked it more before the plot twist came in.  Dialogue was excellent, and I really liked watching characters bring up why Batman is not the right answer to every problem.There's a lot more emphasis on boss fights in this entry, and some of them are cool!  But some of them are quite frustrating, especially since this game seems to be a bit buggier than the two before it.  This probably has something to do with the larger scale.  Since the only thing to do in this larger world is fight goons, and you will assuredly find more goons.  Combat is just about the same as Arkham City, so to me this more felt like padding the game's length than an actual improvement.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 30, 2013
												Batman: Arkham Origins is a prequel to the Arkham Asylum/Arkham City games.  Only 2 years into being Batman and helping out in Gotham, Batman has his toughest night yet since this Christmas Eve the villian Black Mask has put a bounty of 50 million dollars on his head and 8 deadly assassins are in Gotham looking to score.The game looks really great and runs well even on my older laptop with an Nvidia GeForce 310 512MB card.  Occasionally has some small bugs like batman gliding through the air and flopping up and down constantly, or even more infamous, quick time events where the buttons don't register (If you can, use a controller).  Combat is the same as the other Batman games.  Very quick and fluid combos against large groups of enemies, or Predator set pieces where you pick off enemies one by one in sneaky fashion.The story is much more fleshed out than the previous games as well. Without giving too many spoilers, It shows how Batman's relationship evolved with the police and Liutenant Gordon, why so many villains want him dead and how he earned his reputation in Gotham as a hero.If you liked the previous Batman games and want more, you will definitely like this game.

content:
Posted: May 19, 2014
												Excellent game! The story is just amazing. I think through out all the game it keeps you wanting more. I think more than one left the Enigma clues til last. That's the only thing that haven't changed. But still this time the clues are easier to solve. Thumbs up for that. The story is about, well, you know, Batman... He finds out at the beginning that some guy offered 50 grand to the person that killed the Bat. He finds out who and then the story goes... bla bla.The variety of weapons is a little similar to the previous Batman. Although I am satisfied with the weapons offered I might wanted to get more surprised by the weapons I could have gotten.Ok, what else? Oh. Combat engagement is ridiculously fun! It has a lot of moments like God of War where you have to press buttons to get free or fight an enemy. This thing really makes the game more appealing.Graphics are great just as the other Batman. Of course Origins has better graphics, more fluid animations and so on.The other thing that kept me going with this game is the online. Right now I have about 22 hrs played. 'bout 12 hours of singleplayer story. and 10 of multiplayer. The customization of your online character loadout is really original. Joker team is my favorite. Now here are the cons of the online:I know this is the first Batman with online multiplayer game but still is very simple. I think you should have had more guns or customization of guns given to your disposal. While being the hero is great... being the bad guys isn't as great. The developers should have been far more in to it.I recommend this game. It will give you tons of fun and variety in the Arkham saga. For the first Batman multiplayer they did a great work!

content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												I find that the game is a worthy prequel to Arkham City. It retains most of the features from Arkham City and because of that, some might say that it should have been a big DLC rather than a whole new game. However, it expanded the map, added in a whole new story and a bunch of new side activites that can bring you 16 to 20 hours of new gameplay. There are some flaws however. I felt that it was slightly easier than Arkham City and the challenge mode imo is not as enjoyable as the AC either. The game was also riddled with bugs during the first week from performance issues to being unable to complete certain missions/quests. Those should have been patched by now. You can't play stealth for many of the main story missions either so that could be a major flaw to some.tldr: Get this game if you are a big fan of Batman series or just want to have some fun. Whether on a sale or at full price, this game is a must get for 2013/2014

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 20, 2014
												*NB: Some minor spoilers in this review* I came to this game late in the day. I love Batman, but having been burned by game breaking glitches in both Asylum and City, I refused to pay top dollar for Origins. especially at launch. Add that to no Conroy and no Hamill, and I had real concerns about how Origins would stack up. So I waited, and eventually it went on sale. Well, I was partly right. Troy Baker is no Hamill as the Joker. He puts in a valiant effort, amd he should be applauded, but he is in the master's shadow. Otherwise, though, Origins is superb, perhaps even the best in the series. The combat is the most enjoyable of the games so far, and the villains - most of whom it is fair to say are in the Batman B cast  - are actually very engaging. The writing is also top notch, the highlight for me being when Joker's rhapsodizes the bat at the same time as seducing Doctor Quinzel. It's also fun to play Batman as he finding his feet. Detective vision takes on a more literal meaning for the 'world's greatest detective', actually used to solve some mysteries, as opposed to finding out where the nearest grapple point or wall to explode is (though you still use it for that). So, it's great. If you love the series, or enjoy seeing Batman done well, you should enjoy this.Edit: Some people have said this game has issues with Mouse and Keyboard controls. I used a controller, and had none.

content:
Posted: March 21, 2015
												Batman: Arkham Origins is an interesting beast, given the two excellent games that precede it. While some may cite the recycled environment from City (with the addition of South Gotham) and items (with the addition of the Shock Gloves and Remote Claw) as reasons why this game should be skipped, looking at the full package, this game is worth playing. It boasts a compelling story as a rougher, younger Batman confronts a number of assassins who attempt to kill him on Christmas Eve, some of whom have never been featured in the "Arkhamverse" before. He also must deal with Black Mask, and more importantly, a sadistic, psychopathic criminal known only as "The Joker." This "forging of key relationships" that the game sells itself on is consistent throughout the game's narrative, helped by some excellent CGI cutscenes and voice acting from Roger Craig Smith and Troy Baker. There are some bugs that might hinder one's playthrough, and the number of collectibles do have the tendency to make the side quests drag on, but Origins remains a solid game hampered by relatively minor problems. These problems don't prevent the best moments of the story from feeling like an unhinged, flaming roller coaster ride.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 26, 2013
												Batman Fans Rejoice! The Prequel for the Batman Arkhamverse is now here. Origins is set in the early days of Bruce Wayne as Batman. Although it says "Origins", it is well over two years from the beginning of his vigilante crime fighting. In this game, you will encounter a lot of "first" as you battle enemies, and established alliances.Its story may lack the intensity and direction unlike the two original arkham which was written by paul dini. However, the game still delivers quite a compelling story. The game starts off rather plain but once you get to the middle part, that's where it kicks in. Gameplay is identical to the previous games, but with some new features like gadgets, and a new class of enemies. The game is beautiful in terms of its graphical presentation. The only problem with this game is the amount of bugs and glitches it has that seem to destroy my immersion throughout the game. In addition, this game now supports multiplayer where you will be facing joker's and bane's thugs as you get to play as Batman or Robin. But to be quite frank, the multiplayer doesn't live up to its expectation and fails in giving you a good gameplay.In Conclusion: Aside from its multiplayer and a ton of glitches, this game is a solid one and I recommend playing this game especially if you are a batman fanatic.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 18, 2013
												An absolutely amazing game, building on the success of the previous installments, this game brings everything to the table. The story basically picks up after the Batman: Year One graphic novel, faithfully keeping the characters within "canon" boundaries and building upon their personalities with excellent voice acting, extremely articulated facial programming. The story is worthy of the Batman title, and the action is a step above the previous two games. The gadgets have been revamped slightly, and the "Dark Knight" challenges make you feel like the Bat yourself as you complete them. The visuals are drop-dead gorgeous and the art direction was well thought out. This extended and restored version of Gotham City is beautiful and keeps you exploring for hours and hours on end. With so much content, the replayability and longevity of life that this game has it tremendous. Sure the game launched with a few glitches, but they were promptly corrected by WBMontreal, and we now have a perfect game.

content:
Posted: August 24, 2014
												For a game that I remember receiving a lukewarm reception at its launch, I was really impressed with Arkham Origins. Whenever the reins of a franchise is handed over to another developer, there's always that worry of how the end result will turn out and in this case, I don't think you'd even notice any difference whatsoever. The game follows the formula of the previous games almost to a fault and while it doesn't come close to matching Arkham City, there's a few moments within the story that really stand out from the series that I think it should be remembered for. If you've enjoyed Asylum or City, you'll enjoy this. If this is your first Batman game, while there's nothing really wrong with this, I'd probably encourage you to play Asylum first.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 9, 2014
												Arkham Origins is a fun addition of the "Arkham" franchise.  It lacks much of the polish, and some of the charm of the Rocksteady games, but has an interesting story and nicely varied boss fights that fans of the series will be able to appreciate.  They do a decent job of keeping things in line chronologically, and there are only a few noticable anachronisms that break the illusion of a story that takes place before Arkham Asylum.  Unfortunately, there are a few bugs that persist even now, and some of them are game-breaking.  However, in my playthrough of the main story, i managed to avoid every one of them (the My Alibi Bug is easily avoided).  "Cold, Cold Heart" (the story DLC) is the only place where I ran into game-breaking and unavoidable bugs.  That said, I was able to retain the fidelity of my save file by simply quitting after the bug had triggered (not trying to save again), and everything loaded fine.  The only thing that is still in error, is that two of the Steam Achievements have not triggered appropriately for me during "Cold, Cold, Heart".At the end of the day, I strongly recommend Arkham Origins for fans of the previous two Arkham games, especially if you get it cheap (A Holiday sale would be best, since the story takes place on Christmas Eve).  It's not one of the Rocksteady games, but it's a fun way to spend a bit more time in their world, especially while we wait for Arkham Knight.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 26, 2014
												Batman: Arkham Origins is the newest title in the Batman Arkham franchise. I noticed that it got very negative review and i thought i would write my review to clear some things up.First of all Arkham Origins is not trying to do something new or redo a major part of the game and for a good reason if WB Montreal had added something new or redid something Rockstedy put in place they would have been blamed by fans for messing up what Rockstedy had created.First of all the story it's really good. The first two Arkham games had an okay story but it wasn't a story i really connected with i mostly finished the game and that was that. Arkham Origins on the other hand has a story that keeps you on your toes wondering whats going to happen next. In my opinion it's way better than the past Arkham games.One of the biggest things Origins got blamed for was the difficulty but i personally like the challenge. The first two Arkham games always felt to easy i went through them really quickly and after that it was over. Origins adds to the challenge and might have overdone it the game could be argued overly hard but once you get the hang of it it becomes pretty easy.The boss battles are much more interesting take the firefly battle for example avoiding fire while a bridge was falling apart was really enjoyable. The boss battles also gave me something new a feeling of satisfaction when you defeat a boss. This was never really in the Arkham games.My favorite part of the game was the Multiplayer it adds a whole new aspect of the game and can be pretty scary. You really feel what the criminals you encounter feel as you see something swoop past you and then take you out from behind. The bane and joker games are your average 3rd person shooter but playing as Batman or Robin is really fun.While the game may not have added much it delivers in one category making an excellent Arkham game. all in all I rate this game7/10 it had some major glitches that should have been fixed.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 21, 2015
												Batman: Arkham Origins is an interesting beast, given the two excellent games that precede it. While some may cite the recycled environment from City (with the addition of South Gotham) and items (with the addition of the Shock Gloves and Remote Claw) as reasons why this game should be skipped, looking at the full package, this game is worth playing. It boasts a compelling story as a rougher, younger Batman confronts a number of assassins who attempt to kill him on Christmas Eve, some of whom have never been featured in the "Arkhamverse" before. He also must deal with Black Mask, and more importantly, a sadistic, psychopathic criminal known only as "The Joker." This "forging of key relationships" that the game sells itself on is consistent throughout the game's narrative, helped by some excellent CGI cutscenes and voice acting from Roger Craig Smith and Troy Baker. There are some bugs that might hinder one's playthrough, and the number of collectibles do have the tendency to make the side quests drag on, but Origins remains a solid game hampered by relatively minor problems. These problems don't prevent the best moments of the story from feeling like an unhinged, flaming roller coaster ride.

content:
Posted: April 27, 2014
												Horrendously glitchy, the flight controls will mess up mid flight, data packs are still there after you grab them, gadgets will get stuck to controls and you cant switch to something different, pathing issues where you can climb things that make no sense and can't climb things you should definitely be able to, enemy units getting stuck on walls and barriers (Had a thug get stuck in a wall during a predator room to the point where i had to try and use explosives near him to blast him out of the wall so i could progress).The QA for this game was horribly done and the actual implementation is a little flawed as well. Never mentions anything about scanning items and you have to figure out for yourself it actually matters for collectibles).I don't mind that its a repeat of mostly the same mechanics with some new gadgets, i gladly accept that and would gladly play it and enjoy it. However the near constant glitches and the flawed implementation of the game prevent me from enjoying this title. I do not count it as a true Arkham game and consider it a flawed product. It is the first game i have ever played as a finished product where i wanted to start writing bug reports for the developers.

content:
Posted: December 6, 2014
												TL:DR >  Watching Batman movies and reading Batman comics is great and all, but if you really want to feel like you are the Dark Knight, playing Arkham Origins is probably as close as you can get without becoming a billionaire and having your parents murdered. What makes the game so great is that it features all the elements of being Batman: Detective work, awesome gadgets, martial artistry, chasing crazy people, wearing your underpants on the outside, and so on.Long review:Graphics: Excellent, well tuned to NVIDIA GPUs, notably DX11 Tesselation and PhysX. AMD guys may have a different story to tell.Gameplay: For these new to the game, some boss fight scenes will be a considerable challenge, so prepare to die and restart the game from that point and get taunted for failing.Story: Well-developed characters and story line that explains a lot about the prequels, and dropping subtle hints that allows the Batman universe to intertwine in all the three games. This is one of the strongest points in the game; Take for instance, the origin of Mr. Freeze, Bane's breakdown, the relationship between Bruce Wayne and his butler, and the Joker's over the line insanity.Tips: Get the season pass to access the rest of the DLCs. If you don't need online play, the season pass has you covered with the rest, such as the Initiation DLC and stuff. That adds extra hours of immersive gameplay that'll keep you practising and on edge to keep up with your enemies.Length:Well balanced. On average, it is possible to pull off both the main and side missions without being sidetracked too far from the game, and also offers sweet upgrade points which reward the gamer's time spent on the side missions. Replay value: Owing to the excellent challenge mode(s) and extra game play modes, you8 cannot play this game once. Overall rating: 10/10. This game is perfect.PS: Did I mention there were Ninjas? Yes, I did. Overall: 10/10. Gameplay reminiscent of Batman Arkham City.Extra notes for AMD users: On DirectX 11 tesselation, use normal settings and avoid all NVIDIA "enhanced" settings, they can cripple the game's performance. The same aplies to people using NVIDIA GPUs priot to Kepler.

content:
Posted: June 12, 2015
												I am Vengeance.I am the Night.I am Batman.Okay, don't let my playtime discourage you from reading my review. I have completed the game on my PS3.If I were to describe this game in one word it would either be great or underrated.This game is great, IMHO the free roam is better than City. In City there weren't as many enemies to fight and the map could be traversed in minutes. In Origins there are a ton more in groups of 8 or 9ish, the map is also bigger too. Crimes also make the game a lot more fun, they're better than they were in CityThe story is just as good as City, but there are some parts I dislike in Origins, and City's ending is better. I also like the costume in Origins over City, it's more intimidating and realistic.I haven't experienced any crashes or stutters except for a micro stutter and a small FPS drop (won't drop below 58 usually) when zoning. I've heard that using DirectX11 Enhanced makes the game unstable so I don't bother with it.I have never bothered with the multiplayer but I've heard it's bad.SummaryPros:Great StoryGreat gameplayAfter game free roamThe music is as good as City'sMixed:Not the same voice actors, but this is a younger Batman so I guess...Cons:Some costumes are annoying to unlock Batman breaks his rule at one point, he kills Bane then revives him. I thought that was bad Some of the boss fights are disappointing and even frustrating compared to cityThe occasional FPS dropEnigma (Riddler) challanges are boring.9/10This review may be updated soon as I play it more.Specs:GTX 780 6GBi7-2600 @ 3.40GHz16 RamI didn't run this game at ultra but might chagne the settings.

I found it hard to get into at first attempts as it feels very similar to City before it really kicks in and the fact that Batman has practically more if not better suit and equipment and abilities takes some fathoming considering this is meant to be his humble beginnings.Aside from those thing once you get into it, the story and visiting all the key players for the first time in the humble beginnings as well as linking things canon to Arkham Asylum & City make for quite a treat making it a must for a fan of the series.This is especially true with all the issues remedied and the game looking quite sexy too. Posted: June 25, 2014
												I am an avid Batman fan and I truelly enjoyed the grittyness and raw ability that Batman dmeonstrates in this game.  In this game you play a Batman who is young and not as refined as the one we typically think of.  This allows for an experience unlike most Batman adventures where we do not see an unsure and angry Bruce Wayne/Batman.  The detective mode is extremely enhanced over the past two Batman games.  Most boss fights are challenging and enjoyable.  The overall story is compeling and feels like a batman movie.  Lots of gadgets, some detective work, and tons of action. Overall a very enjoyable expansion to the franchise.  I rate this game 9/10.  In the end, ask yourself if you want to be batman fighting against some of his greatest foes and some lesser known villians, than this game is definitely for you.

content:
Posted: June 28, 2014
												The Batman: Arkham series has swiftly become one of my favourite franchises. This one is developed by a different studio and suffers from some bugs, story issues and general feel of "same-iness" but it's still an enjoyable experience.It's in the vain of a 3D "Metroidvania": You explore a vast world, getting upgrades that allow you to reach previously inaccessible areas. Traversing through that world you encounter countless thugs that you beat up in a very satisfying free-flow combat experience, or take them out one by one using stealth, in the "predator"-style encounters. It all feels very Batman.Play Arkham Asylum and/or City first as they are better games, but this one is still really good so you should give it a try afterwards.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 30, 2013
												Batman: Arkham Origins is a prequel to the Arkham Asylum/Arkham City games.  Only 2 years into being Batman and helping out in Gotham, Batman has his toughest night yet since this Christmas Eve the villian Black Mask has put a bounty of 50 million dollars on his head and 8 deadly assassins are in Gotham looking to score.The game looks really great and runs well even on my older laptop with an Nvidia GeForce 310 512MB card.  Occasionally has some small bugs like batman gliding through the air and flopping up and down constantly, or even more infamous, quick time events where the buttons don't register (If you can, use a controller).  Combat is the same as the other Batman games.  Very quick and fluid combos against large groups of enemies, or Predator set pieces where you pick off enemies one by one in sneaky fashion.The story is much more fleshed out than the previous games as well. Without giving too many spoilers, It shows how Batman's relationship evolved with the police and Liutenant Gordon, why so many villains want him dead and how he earned his reputation in Gotham as a hero.If you liked the previous Batman games and want more, you will definitely like this game.

content:
Posted: March 21, 2015
												Batman: Arkham Origins is an interesting beast, given the two excellent games that precede it. While some may cite the recycled environment from City (with the addition of South Gotham) and items (with the addition of the Shock Gloves and Remote Claw) as reasons why this game should be skipped, looking at the full package, this game is worth playing. It boasts a compelling story as a rougher, younger Batman confronts a number of assassins who attempt to kill him on Christmas Eve, some of whom have never been featured in the "Arkhamverse" before. He also must deal with Black Mask, and more importantly, a sadistic, psychopathic criminal known only as "The Joker." This "forging of key relationships" that the game sells itself on is consistent throughout the game's narrative, helped by some excellent CGI cutscenes and voice acting from Roger Craig Smith and Troy Baker. There are some bugs that might hinder one's playthrough, and the number of collectibles do have the tendency to make the side quests drag on, but Origins remains a solid game hampered by relatively minor problems. These problems don't prevent the best moments of the story from feeling like an unhinged, flaming roller coaster ride.
