number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 8, 2015
												This current entry in the Batman/Arkham series is a lot of the same for fans of the previous titles -- as Batman, you explore a large segment of Gotham, dealing with a multitude of villians and optional objectives during a particularly heated Christmas Eve, setting some groundwork and backstory for the previous Arkham titles and the upcoming Arkham Knight.The game flow follows a somewhat rigid structure of exploring the city freely for bonuses that earn you some unlockable abilities, as well as data and viewable charater models, while the main objectives require you to go into large interior areas and set peices and finishing up with a unique boss battle. I would say that for some fans fatigued with the series this could be considered a negative, but the story is well-written and paced, set during a time where Batman is still getting into his role and is considered inexperienced. That said, the voice acting is superb, and the game holds together well on its presentation.Combat is also copied verbatim from the other Arkham titles. It is a very fluid system that rewards the player for fighting large groups of enemies without getting hit and most importantly, not breaking the literal flow of combat by stopping for any reason. This one has some tougher enemies than in the other games, requiring more combinations of evasion and disarming to manage the enemies, which I assume is also trying to push the point of a Rookie Batman and making sure experienced players still stay on their toes.For the very experienced and people demanding a challenge, the game offers a permadeath mode called "I Am the Night" which adds a much greater layer of tension, and I'm happy to see it offered up.It looks like the game had gotten some heat when it was initially released due to some bugs and glitches, but in its state as of posting, I only had one isolated instance of a massive framerate drop in the Batcave that resolved itself after about thirty seconds that I believe may have been on my end. All in all, I'd say this game is a very worthy purchase for a fan of the Arkham series or people interested in jumping into the Arkham series.

Posted: January 18, 2015
												It's a bad copy of Arkham city. The story is great, the characters are pretty good, though you don't see them that much. Combat seems harder, while Arhkam city was balanced. Filled with bugs, even after a huge patch. Bosses are really boring and annoying, basically all you do is repeat a sequence on how to hurt them, and dodge their attacks. A bonus is that they integrated achievements into the game, so you have a reason to get them. The map is a bit big, and the interiors maps aren't fun. The riddler challanges are awful. Most of them are just one gadget away from taking a collectable. The reward for finishing them was decent, but not as rewarding as in City.The online game is fun and original. It made this game as a whole, less bad for me. On the other hand, it has no real balance. Experienced players smash newer ones. Also, when super villians come out (part of the game), the game becomes super hard. Also filled with way too much bugs, connection drop outs which just has to get on your nerves.I can't say it's all bad, I did enjoy the story, and some aspect of the game. It's worth a play, at least for the story, but not remotely close to the last game.Some of the worst programming ever. I'm not blaming the developers, maybe they weren't told to fix stuff, but to focus on other tasks. I mean, man, it's so bad you even lose credits you earned, because of so many issues. content:
Posted: April 9, 2014
												Overall the game is very very good the combat has depth and is not too complex, maling it really feeling like one of the only games that feels like it can stand on combat alone if needed but with the platfroming/ puzzle solving mechanics that give it a balance of fun that I feel that only this and the orgional price of persia series has accomplished in the 3d relm. The story is engaging and gritty while keeping the plot simple and is meant to give of a feeling of determination to stop what is going on rather than putting 50 plot twists in or going down so deep in Batman lore that you have to read years worth of Batman comics or stop the game to search in wikipedia to understand (thats is not saying there will be no charcters that people will not know before getting into the game but rather the game does a very good job explaining who they are through both the cut scenes and gameplay styles and areas that you interact with them in). Thank being said I think there is two things holding the game back. The main one is that the city in the single player just feels so....... empty you end feeling like your saving a city with nobody in it. Now, the games excuse is that everyone is staying in their homes due to a huge storm, but in reality there are still some people out and about even in snow storms (now saying that is smart or not, that is a different subject) so could had a least a couple of people out and about in the streets, something like saving a woman when those sudden crime reports come up? Even a few npcs would make it feel that your in a living city and not an apocalytic one. (and for any of those that will say that the world is more for collecting, the orgional Crackdown was a collect-a-thon in almost the same exact way and still managed to create a livelier city than this AND was released in 2007) the other promlem is that the multiplayer is boring, which I know is a very common complaint and is really not the reason people buy this game but it still dosen't change the fact that it could be done better than a generic thrid person shooter with batman combat, what makes it frustrating is that all it need to be good was a endless oneline mode with friends similar to the single player challenges or some online co-op.  Don't let the negatives deter you though this game is good just could have been better if Wb interactive wasn't trying to release a new game every year  like it is the combat version of call of duty which I am very afraid that it is becoming like that with the new game announced for this year.

content:
Posted: February 23, 2015
												Arkham Origins - I love the Batman Games, but this game attracted me more than Arkham City and Asylum. I loved playing the story and the game's side missions. The story adds better boss fights (use of stealth this time in some bosses) and fun missions such as predator missions. The side missions have you foiling the plans of Edward Enigma, Bird, Penguin and other Batman villains. This time around Batman had multiplayer, which is a really good feature that I feel didn't get enough attention. This multiplayer has 2 players playing as hereos - Batman and Robin (With heaps of skins from your favourite Batman comics) and 6 other players split between either Bane or Joker thugs. These characters have firearms, traps, grenades and many other weaponry to take down the stealthy hunter (the hereos), these character are customisable aswell, changing their outfit, archytypes and accessories. I have heaps of fun playing with my friends online and think any player should expierence this. So please, do yourself a favour, and buy this game :)

content:
Posted: January 2, 2015
												I loved this game, as I loved the previous two. Everyone seems to complain about bugs and glitches but I completed the game without encountering more than 2. The two which did come up cleared by itself within 10 seconds. The story in my opinion is the best out of the series because unlike the previous ones which seemed to almost be like a montage of Batman Adventures, this one shows Batman going through some growth. It feels more like a movie because the main character does not stay static like the previous ones. I love the new voice actors and it's a great re assurance that we will still have Batman and Joker in the future since Konroy and Hamill seem to be retiring soon. The boss fights are quite good, I really don't get what everyone is saying. Although the mechanics are pretty much the same as City's it feels just as satisying to clear a room as it always had. If it ain't broke don't fix it. The cutscenes are amazing and the soundtrack complements them better than City did. Graphics of course have been improved and the added part of Gotham is great to see since it contrasts the Old Gotham so much.TL;DR, Judge this game for yourself and not join the circle jerk of "omg so many bugs" because there really aren't that many.

content:
Posted: April 18, 2014
												This is a good game, yes, but it lacks a certain something that the Rocksteady-made Arkham games have. The city feels far less memorable than Arkham City, and that bridge will never not be a pain. Furthermore, I've encountered more glitches in this game -- no game-erasing ones thankfully -- than both Asylum and City, the latter of which I also played at launch.Looks good, true. Plays decently, though combat has been changed -- there seems to be a tighter window for countering, for example. It's not a terrible game, as I said. But I'm not inclined to play it again and get all of the Enigma datapacks, not like how I went and replayed Asylum recently. Recommended, but not as strongly as the other two Arkham games.

content:
Posted: April 20, 2014
												A lot of reviewers didn't like this game and I actually disagree with them because I enjoyed this game a lot. Yes, they used the Arkham city from the last game but it was the city after all. They massively improved a game I really enjoyed and that made it better. The map was better, the enemies were way more unique and the story was really good. It did a good job starting out batman and introducing elements that would eventually carry over to asylum. My only critique is that it was very unfortunate they couldn't get Mark Hamill to voice the joker... I mean, they had a good story for starting joker out but without the right voice, it just didn't work. I'm sorry, but Mark Hamill is the living embodyment of Joker. Without him, the joker seems flat, unsadistic and kinda sad. Putting that aside, I loved this game and had tons of fun and I'd even say its better then Arkham city. City was enclosed, only had a few areas, and the side quests were uninteresting compared to this game. I can't wait for the next installment though I'll be sad to see such an amazing series come to a close.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 29, 2014
												Ever since the release of Arkham Asylum, I have been a diehard Batman video game fan. I had doubts for Asylum that were quickly disproven and from that point, I went to the midnight release of Arkham City. That being said, as soon as I saw that WB Montreal was developing a prequel game, I began to worry. Now, some of those worries were founded, others not so much.Arkham Origins is a mixed bag. It brings both good and bad things to the Arkham franchise. I'll start with the negatives.Deja-vu. You'll play this game wondering what is different about it than Arkham City. You have almost the same gadgets, combat upgrades, grappel abilities, etc. It's not bad; it's just really familiar. Mission types are similar, if not the same, and a good portion of the map is the Arkham City map covered in snow. Granted it's in greater detail with a graphical overhaul, but it's the same map. The good: Story. It's not as good as Arkham City's story with all the twists and great care and attention that were given it, but it's decent. It introduces many of Batman's familiar villains in a plotline that isn't disappointing. That's something that isn't easy to pull off.  The voice acting is good, with Troy Baker stealing the show with an excellent Joker presentation. (especially considering that he isn't Mark Hammill) The graphics can be excellent, but can also disappoint. Some areas have great details and effects, but even those aren't jaw-dropping. I run this on a 1GB GTX 650ti and get around 45FPS average, which is decent for the settings I run it at. The sound editing could use some work, as it was difficult to hear voices over SFX sometimes, even after altering the levels. I haven't tried multiplayer much yet, to be honest I probably won't do it at all. I didn't buy this game for the multiplayer and I'd be surprised if anyone did. The single player doesn't disappoint, but it really doesn't exceed any expectations either. It's a good entry in the series, but it's not as excellent as we've come to expect from an Arkham title. If you're a fan, it's worth getting, but you may want to wait for a sale to purchase this game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 30, 2013
												Batman: Arkham Origins is a prequel to the Arkham Asylum/Arkham City games.  Only 2 years into being Batman and helping out in Gotham, Batman has his toughest night yet since this Christmas Eve the villian Black Mask has put a bounty of 50 million dollars on his head and 8 deadly assassins are in Gotham looking to score.The game looks really great and runs well even on my older laptop with an Nvidia GeForce 310 512MB card.  Occasionally has some small bugs like batman gliding through the air and flopping up and down constantly, or even more infamous, quick time events where the buttons don't register (If you can, use a controller).  Combat is the same as the other Batman games.  Very quick and fluid combos against large groups of enemies, or Predator set pieces where you pick off enemies one by one in sneaky fashion.The story is much more fleshed out than the previous games as well. Without giving too many spoilers, It shows how Batman's relationship evolved with the police and Liutenant Gordon, why so many villains want him dead and how he earned his reputation in Gotham as a hero.If you liked the previous Batman games and want more, you will definitely like this game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 28, 2014
												The Batman: Arkham series has swiftly become one of my favourite franchises. This one is developed by a different studio and suffers from some bugs, story issues and general feel of "same-iness" but it's still an enjoyable experience.It's in the vain of a 3D "Metroidvania": You explore a vast world, getting upgrades that allow you to reach previously inaccessible areas. Traversing through that world you encounter countless thugs that you beat up in a very satisfying free-flow combat experience, or take them out one by one using stealth, in the "predator"-style encounters. It all feels very Batman.Play Arkham Asylum and/or City first as they are better games, but this one is still really good so you should give it a try afterwards.

content:
Posted: March 31, 2014
												Even though it says I've only played this game for five hours, I mostly played this game offline and have completed the campaign. I must say that although the game is great, it is no match to what Arkham City had. The story was great, loved the part with the refrences to the Killing Joke and Joker's origin. However, what really began to tick me off was the combat, it was much slower and not as fluid. I found myself having the slow down, which is not a good thing when facing fifteen people at once. The only way I could take down some of the later battles were the shock gloves, which were way too overpowered in my opinion. The younger Bruce Wayne does actually feel younger, he seems more arrogant and less experienced, and I loved having Alfred talk to me rather than Oracle for a change. This is not just Batman's story though, it is also a story about the Joker, whom I found intriguing. The new voice actors suprisingly fit well, but nobody can beat Kevin Conroy. Gotham City seems really like a cut and paste Arkahm City, but it has some new tricks up its sleeve. Overall, even though this game is probably the weakest in the series, it's really well done. I'm suprised it was good, as it was not Rocksteady who made this game, but WB Montreal. 8.4/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 1, 2014
												While not as good as the other Arkham games, it is still a great game. The story is interesting, and the dialogue is well written. It is very straight to the point, and the story makes it clear that this game is all about the boss fights, and in that regard, it doesn't dissapoint. The boss fights are varied, and very fun. From the hand-to-hand fight with Deathstroke, demanding split second timing and reflexes, to the surreal brawl with Copperhead, and the tactical stealth ancounter with Deadshot, this game will keep you busy with each passing boss fight.Sadly, I can not say the same for the side missions. It is the same thing we've been doing since Asylum. Scan this, collect that, go there. Not much variety at all. It doesn't help that you're doing this on the same map as Arkham City. Sure, they have added new areas, but it doesn't offer much in terms of variety. It is hard to know your way around the map, when everything looks the same. They say in the game that you have to go to the industrial district, but the entire city looks like an industrial district! In fact, like Arkham City, the entire city looks like a war zone in an industrial district. It makes sence in City, being a cut off part of the city for prisoners, but in Origins, that is not the case. Things are on fire, the bridge is covered with piles of crates, broken cars and criminal activity. And navigating it has gotten harder. I swear they have reduced the amount of grapple points in the city. Even in places where there is no logical reason why I wouldn't be able to grapple, I can't. It gets very frustrating. And there are fewer things you can climb up on. Sometimes you can clumb up on objects that are, maybe, 3 and a half meters tall. At other times, you can't even climb up on something waste high.Then there's the gadgets. You won't find much in terms of variety here either. Most of the gadgets are just altered versions of the old ones, or the exact same ones. But they do the job. If I have one major criticism of the gadgets, it is one that applies for all of the Arkham games. The gadgets are a bit far fetched. They feel out of place. It feels like they belong in a sci-fi game. They explosive gel has no reason to be a gel. In the comics and other media, Batman frequently carries explosive charges. Why does it have to be gel here? It feels a bit contrived. And why does he have to spray it in the shape of a bat symbol? Wouldn't that just take more time? And the disruptor looks like some sort of plasma rifle. I don't mind what the gadgets do, I just think they look a bit to futuristic. But that is just preference on my part.All in all, I think it is a really good game. Its charm doesn't lie in its open world, or the side activities. It lies in the boss fights,, the the different levels and the characters. If that is what you're looking for, then I wholeheartedly recommend Arkham Origins. But if you are looking for a great open world game, with a lot of things to do, I recommend waiting for Arkham Knight, or pick up Arkham city which, while not very good at side activities either, does at least offer more grapple points, and climbable ledges, making the city easier, and more enjoyable to navigate.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 23, 2015
												Batman; Arkham Origins is the third installment in the now legendary Arkham series, but it is the first chronologically. The story pits a fairly new Batman, with only a couple of years of crusading under his belt, against some of his most powerful adversaries, many of whom he will encounter for the first time. This game features a gripping story line, amazing graphics, and the revolutionary combat interface that makes this series a must have. I own this game on WiiU and PC, and I am happier with the PC version. The WiiU version had a number of glitches and problems that made it difficult to play at certain points of the story. The game is fantastic on either platform, however, and I would certainly recommend it for WiiU owners.The absence of the voice talents of Mark Hamill (Joker) and Kevin Conroy (Batman) may have diminished this title, but only slightly.  Roger Craig Smith and Troy Baker fill in for the roles respectively, and do a very nice job. I will always prefer the former couple, but the latter don't spoil the fun. I can't help but believe that this change, as well as the fact that Rocksteady didn't develop the game, is what earned this game a generally lower score from most critics. Personally I find the tighter battle elements that were introduced, particularly in some of the boss fights, has only pushed the series forward. The boss battles are varied and engaging, and the I Am The Night mode gives the title enormous replay value. There is also an online mode for PC which allows the player to conrol either a hero or a villain's cronie in a fight for control of a map. 10/10

content:
Posted: September 6, 2015
I don't know why most aren't people satisfied with this game because i sure as hell am.Single playerThis game has a good story, a slightly similar combat system of arkham city with a few new added gadgets , new enemy types, and about 9 villains you get to face off and fight. Unlike arkham knight boss battles, this installment brings back the feeling of what its like to fight actual bosses who could kill you if your not too careful for example bane, deathstroke, cooperhead and others.MultiplayerThe multiplayer in this game is also good. There are 3 teams Jokers gang, Bane's gang and batman and robin .You get to play as one of the elite henchmen who work for either the joker or bane and you get to play as batman and robin, sort of like a predator/prey system where about 6 players are henchmen(prey) and 2 players are batman and robin(hunter). I like how the mutiplayer gives you the opportunity to play as henchman and get to experience their perspective of being stalked by batman, you maybe thinking how hard can it be to spot a man in bat costume or even be scared of him but trust me after playing as a henchmen you will FEAR THE KNIGHT.The drawback to multiplayer is that its really hard to find a match when there aren't many online players, each matchmaking session takes about 10-15 minutes which is abit frustrating and things get even worse when a game starts with people who are either afk or disconnected during the match since there is no vote to kick feature and players can't join during multiplayer sessions. This game may not be as good as arkham city but its still worth buying and playing. I recommend buying when its on offer like i did, then you won't regret your decision if you dont like it.

content:
Posted: November 18, 2013
												An absolutely amazing game, building on the success of the previous installments, this game brings everything to the table. The story basically picks up after the Batman: Year One graphic novel, faithfully keeping the characters within "canon" boundaries and building upon their personalities with excellent voice acting, extremely articulated facial programming. The story is worthy of the Batman title, and the action is a step above the previous two games. The gadgets have been revamped slightly, and the "Dark Knight" challenges make you feel like the Bat yourself as you complete them. The visuals are drop-dead gorgeous and the art direction was well thought out. This extended and restored version of Gotham City is beautiful and keeps you exploring for hours and hours on end. With so much content, the replayability and longevity of life that this game has it tremendous. Sure the game launched with a few glitches, but they were promptly corrected by WBMontreal, and we now have a perfect game.

												I've enjoyed this game for the story and the fact it's Batman and the assorted characters from the Rogue Gallery. I play with mouse and keyboard, and perhaps it makes a difference using a gamepad, but I could not play comfortably using my Logitech F310.Side-missions get a bit repetitive like looking for all the Riddler's hidden data packs.The game doesn't seem as good as the first two Arkham games, possible due to being released by a different developer.I don't recommend purchasing this game if you haven't played the other two first.  I do recommend purchasing it if you are a fan of Batman, have played the previous two games, and want to experience the story.  Overall, I would give it 3 stars out of 5.

Posted: November 28, 2013
												Batman: Arkham Origins is an odd one. While the gameplay itself has been tightened up, for example the combat flows a lot better and enemies are generally more aggressive than they were during previous games, the innovation is seriously lacking.The collectibles are uninspired compared to the original riddles and the main story is just downright dire, with the assassins that are supposedly after you falling more into sidequests than anything else. The copy/paste assets of Arkham City doesn't do the game any favours either, as it feels more like an expansion than anything.Graphically the game looks great and there are a few nice touches here and there such as PhysX enabled snow and it has been optimised to hell and back so it runs fantastically (game breaking bugs aside), but it still doesn't look as good as Arkham City does.It's a good game if you are a fan of the series, but I would hold off and get it a little cheaper unless you really have to have it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 27, 2014
												When I heard about this game being developed by a different company, I thought it would be a refreshing experience. I am not opposed to change, if that change is good. But then, when I played it, I immediately realized that I was wrong. This game is not a change. Let me explain why:• In terms of gameplay, Arkham Origins is identical to Arkham City. It even has the same map. The environments are different, but that difference is merely superficial. The devs made the easiest decision: don't innovate, just recycle. Even the gadgets are the same. Most of them we've already seen before, and the "new" ones are just different versions of the same thing (remote claw=line launcher, though the claw is a bit of an improved version; glue grenade=freeze cluster). The shock gloves are a very nice addition though, but because of its usefulness, every fight after you get them is a joke. Except boss fights of course, in which you will be screaming to your monitor the word "bull****" several times.• In terms of story telling, it follows their predecessors with extreme accuracy. The story itself is different, of course. It includes several villains that weren't present in previous installments, but it also includes several that were, and without the need to do so. But there are no plot holes, and the story shapes out well as a prequel to Arkham Asylum. I recommend staying through the credits (despite the fact that credits are extremely long).• In the graphical aspect, don't even get me started on the bugs. Man this game is buggy as hell, considering it's been released some time ago. Consider yourself extremely lucky if you get past your first boss fight without issues. And pray that enemies don't get stuck behind walls forcing you to start a fight all over again, and this applies to boss fights as well. I wouldn't say this feels like a beta, but it's certainly close. When it's not bugging out, it's the same as Arkham City. Don't expect anything new here.It has its epic moments, don't get me wrong, but it all feels the same to Arkham City, and that's where the game fails: originality. Still, I would recommend any fan of the franchise to get this game, but only when it's on sale, it's not worth the full price.Final score: 3.25/5

content:
Posted: July 1, 2015
												Mechanically, this game boasts a lot of improvements from Arkham City. The fighting feels smoother and a little more challenging. Better use is made of your detective skills this time around, as piecing together the crime actually segways into larger plot elements. I also found the scavenger-hunt style skill upgrades engaging too. The problem is, that this game falls back on the previous games far too much for its plot points. The adventure  starts with a rogue's gallery of more obscure Batman's Nemisises (Nemesisi? Nemisiss? is this even a word?) but eventually circles back to all of the same antagonists the previous games used. The story isn't bad exactly, just sort of boring.Still, it's a pretty solid game, it just plays things a little too safe for its own good.

Posted: January 13, 2014
												I enjoyed the game, but there were some issues with the port. There are no mouse settings to change in-game, the default layout for keybindings show a controller first and you have to click another button to find the keyboard, and you can't navigate the map with a mouse. The mouse settings can be changed in a notepad file so it's not that big of a deal. Not being able to control the map with a mouse is irritating as all hell though and is one of my biggest gripes about the game. Not that big of a deal, but constantly irritating.Now, on to the good. The combat is just like Asylum and City, but with some changes such as the upgrade paths and some of the upgrades. There are actually more ways to counter all those things that were uncounterable in the last game so fighting is now more fluid. The absolute biggest improvement over the last games were the cinematics; they were god damn awesome.  The rest of the game was pretty much the same as the last games, but with a new story.I didn't play the multiplayer and don't much care to. I bought this game for the single player campaign and the multiplayer is pretty much a quick gimmick you play and then leave.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 20, 2014
												*NB: Some minor spoilers in this review* I came to this game late in the day. I love Batman, but having been burned by game breaking glitches in both Asylum and City, I refused to pay top dollar for Origins. especially at launch. Add that to no Conroy and no Hamill, and I had real concerns about how Origins would stack up. So I waited, and eventually it went on sale. Well, I was partly right. Troy Baker is no Hamill as the Joker. He puts in a valiant effort, amd he should be applauded, but he is in the master's shadow. Otherwise, though, Origins is superb, perhaps even the best in the series. The combat is the most enjoyable of the games so far, and the villains - most of whom it is fair to say are in the Batman B cast  - are actually very engaging. The writing is also top notch, the highlight for me being when Joker's rhapsodizes the bat at the same time as seducing Doctor Quinzel. It's also fun to play Batman as he finding his feet. Detective vision takes on a more literal meaning for the 'world's greatest detective', actually used to solve some mysteries, as opposed to finding out where the nearest grapple point or wall to explode is (though you still use it for that). So, it's great. If you love the series, or enjoy seeing Batman done well, you should enjoy this.Edit: Some people have said this game has issues with Mouse and Keyboard controls. I used a controller, and had none.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 22, 2014
												While its debatable where this ranks in the series of Arkham games, one thing's for sure...we're going to have a lot more Batman. At first I was opposed to WB throwing together a new studio to create filler Arkham games while Rocksteady tooled away on their next creation, but you know what? I don't mind so much anymore. Arkham Origins might not be the most polished title but it certainly is just as fun as the previous two installments. You have the same great gameplay you're used two, new villains from the DC universe, and some more backstory to our brooding hero (and villains). The multiplayer is flawed but I like that they took the risk of building something out because it's open for improvement (for future iterations). I'm looking forward to the Mr. Freeze DLC and hopeful (fingers crossed) that the time taken to create this new content will be worth the wait.My biggest gripe that doesn't spoil any sort of story aspect of the game are the costumes. Costumes that you can purchase or unlock but can't equip in the campaign until you've played through the game at least ONCE. That's a big gamble for WB to assume that we as gamers and consumers have the patience to play this again. Yes you can change your costume on the Challenge maps but not all of want to play that mode. If there was a cheat in the main menu (like Arkham City) that allowed to temporarily unlock costume play for that play session, I think everything would be fine (who knows, maybe this is in the pipeline).Minus my complaint about the costumes, I actually enjoyed this game quite a bit. Having had some time to think about it post completion; I'd give this a solid 7.5 with room to improve with the new DLC.

content:
Posted: February 23, 2015
												Arkham Origins - I love the Batman Games, but this game attracted me more than Arkham City and Asylum. I loved playing the story and the game's side missions. The story adds better boss fights (use of stealth this time in some bosses) and fun missions such as predator missions. The side missions have you foiling the plans of Edward Enigma, Bird, Penguin and other Batman villains. This time around Batman had multiplayer, which is a really good feature that I feel didn't get enough attention. This multiplayer has 2 players playing as hereos - Batman and Robin (With heaps of skins from your favourite Batman comics) and 6 other players split between either Bane or Joker thugs. These characters have firearms, traps, grenades and many other weaponry to take down the stealthy hunter (the hereos), these character are customisable aswell, changing their outfit, archytypes and accessories. I have heaps of fun playing with my friends online and think any player should expierence this. So please, do yourself a favour, and buy this game :)

content:
Posted: January 1, 2015
												A decent follow-up to the Arkham series, with the trademark combat that we all know and love from the Arkham series. Though it pales in comparison when compared with its predecessors, it was still an enjoyable experience to play. Authough it was developed by Warner Bros. Montreal and not by Rocksteady, who had developed the previous Arkam games, the still got many things right. First of all, the story was captivating. I won't spoil too much, but it was pretty enjoyable. Secondly, the voice work for this game was amazing. Though I would always prefer the classic portrayal of Batman and Joker by Kevin Conroy and Mark Hamill respectively, Roger Craig Smith and Troy Baker deliver an exceptional performance. Still, this game has its own fair share of cons. The world felt bleak and without much character, unlike Arkham city, where each segment of the world reflected of the personality of whichever mob was controlling it. Secondly, authough Warner Bros. Montreal tried new and innovative things, afew of them fell short, such as Electricutioner's gloves, which were too overpowered.Overall, I would give this game a 7.8 out of 10.Good game, but many flaws.

content:
Posted: January 27, 2015
												Not sure why some people find this game so offensive. It's quite good! You play as Batman (doi!) and this takes place in the early days. Batman's a little younger, a little stubborn, and yet still has all those magnificent toys.You're in an area that's roughly twice the size of Arkham City. Though you clearly cover the same area that was eventually blocked off to create Arkham City but before it was all crappy. Plus another section of Gotham. Origins also impliments a much needed fast-travel system.You'll see some fun Batman enemies like Penguin, Killer Croc, Black Mask, Bane, and a stable of other villians from the Rogue Gallery. Some you've never seen in an Arkham game prior to Origins. I've heard some people complain about the boss battles, but I had a lot of fun with them.People also complain about glitches. Perhaps this was an issue when the game released, but as of today (1/27/15) it seems to be fine. Only a couple that I noticed, and they were NOT game breaking. Such as a defeated thug clipping through the floor, and some minor animation sync problems. Otherwise I had no issues.In the end: Fan of Batman? Get it. Fan of Arkham games? Get it. Never played an Arkham game? Start with Arkham Asylum, then Arkham City, then get it. Hate Batman and/or Arkham games? What are you, some kind of joker!?8.5/10 - Will play again, will continue to try and 100% it, will BATMAN!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 27, 2013
												Arkham City sits at one of my most favorite games of recent years, it was perfectly made and well paced. How exactly could they improve it, shortly put.. They didn't. This game, after being handed over from the orginal developers, was flat out copied over. It feels generally like what I would expect in a DLC, not a full priced game. However, I do recommend this game fully. Just not at full price. I preordered this not expecting much, but what I did get was a dose of strong story telling and character development and is definitely worth playing if you can make it past the thirty year old man child that is our immature protagonist. - The map is now larger, covering portions of soon to be Arkham City and New Gotham, albeit empty due to a cop out excuses of curfew. Even with this larger area, the game feels intolerably lonely and devoid of creativity that was present in the previous titles. + The music is more fitted to the Christmas themed enviroment, my favorite being The Joker's Theme. Which is allowing of an eerie but calming feel.- The Boss battles fall flat, being a series of button mashes and repetition. Except Deadshot, it took me forever to beat him and I loved every single agonizing death with restart. This though does not make up for the failure which very well could have been a surpass to the fight with Mr Freeze in Arkham CIty. + A semi-detailed look into the canon background of The Joker, directly referencing The Red Hood. With a major plus of showing him as being what he is, the polar opposite of Batman.. being given no choice to do what he must because that is the way society has made him, just as Bruce has been made into what he is by the actions of others... mainly Joe Chill. + Well delivered characters especially Edward Nigma, whose appearance was more horned in than ever before, but welcomed. He made me question if what I was doing was the moral thing to do, yet Big Bad Bat Bruce seemed to ignore it, lost potential there. - Immature Brat Bat. I understand that this is supposed to be an origin story, ignoring that Bruce crowned the cowl two years before the start, but he is such a ♥♥♥♥♥ at times. He is even straight cruel to Alfred and even endangers him time after time because of his careless nature. +/- The newly added and changed features were some iffy choices.     - No Bruce, You cannot have gadgets seven years before the prototype was made.     + Crime Scenes show the true detective skills that make Batman the "World's Greatest Detective." (Even if they were kinda look here click, look there click.)    - Very Eh Upgrade system, feeling more like the linear choices of Arkham Asylum. I could go on for hours about this game, and no I didn't play the multiplayer and am ignoring the glitches because I didn't buy it for the multiplayer and I'm sure anyone reading this has yet to buy the game, not needing to worry about now patched glitchums. The bottom line is the game is good, but falls short of the hype and glory that Arkham City had. It's worth looking into buying to see how the story progresses, just don't look for a worthy sequel/prequel in this. If City was a strong 10/10 than this would have to be at max 6/10... Asylum 8.

												A good Arkham game. Not the best sure... But still overwhelmingly good!The backlash at this game is surely reasonable, seeing that it's done by a new developer and as such is not a Rocksteady game. But, the backlash is unjustifiable. This game is really good and a solid addition to the Arkham series. It may not be Rocksteady, and may not be too innovative. But it does innovate and does the Batman: Arkham formula right!The game's story is set on Christmas Eve when Black Mask decides to put a bounty on a very young Batman, who's still in his second year of crime fighting, which attracts the world's 8 deadliest assassins to track him down. The story is easily the best part about the game and is a very good Batman story. It does what other Arkham games dind't do, which is explore the dynamic between Batman and his allies, mainly Alfred, Barbara (AKA Batgirl) and Comissioner Gordon. The story is set 5 years before Asylum, but quite honestly, it should be 10. The characters are way, WAY younger than their Asylum counterparts and really, since Asylum depicts Tim Drake as being the current Robin, while Origins depicts Batman working alone. It just doesn't fit well... but that's a nitpick.The gameplay mechanics are pretty much the same as City. Free flow combat. Stealth gameplay. Crime scene investigations. Open world gliding and grappling. Riddler trophies. It's really similar to City, but still has some twists of its own. Some new gadgets such as the Reverse Claw and the Concussion Detonator offer some cool dynamic gameplay mechanics to both Stealth and Combat. New enemy types such as the Martial Artist are also a very welcome addition that really make combat much more interesting and less repetitive.It's easily noticeable that this isn't a Rocksteady game since the way the grappling works and the enemy AI are, really feel different... I feel like this is a nitpick, but it's just something I felt having played both other Batman games. Still, glitches and bugs were a rare occasion for me personally, yet I felt they were more than City or Asylum ever had.Multiplayer is interesting, offering a 3v3v2 scenario. Playing as a goon in Joker and Bane's gangs is acceptable. It's a very standard 3rd person shooter. Still, the feeling of having Batman or Robin on your tail really helps you understand how the goons you beat up in singleplayer feel like. Batman and Robin themselves are the same as usual, but knowing that the goons you take out are players really change the feeling of pulling off a sucessful takedown. The assymetric aspect of the multiplayer however is its downfall. Having Batman, Robin, Joker, Bane and goons all play different is not only confusing, but also frustrating since you never seem to catch a break and play with who you want.This is a Batman game however and what matters is the singleplayer. Thankfully Arkham Origins delivers a good Batman experience with some minor tweaks but innovations nonetheless. An amazing story and the solid gameplay from past Arkham games make it a very cool game. Just don't expect a Rocksteady game. Still, WB Montreal's first game is an amazing one for a first game.Buy it if you want some more Batman action before Arkham Knight. It's really good but if City was just the ammount of Batman you were craving, you can skip it without missing out on too much. But, if you haven't played the others, by all means, buy this game. It's really good!Highly recommend it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 28, 2015
												Batman: Arkham Origins is very similar to the last game, Arkham City which isn't a bad thing as the previous game was a masterpiece in it's own right.The story isn't as good as the previous two but it's still amazing, at times predictable but at other times surprises you with a plot twist that you didn't expect.The general plot of this game follows Batman on Christmas Eve as a bounty has been placed on his head that many major and minor villains will attempt to get from you.It should be said that this game was developed by Warner Brothers Montreal which is a different studio from the previous two and the upcoming Arkham Knight game which were all developed by Rocksteady Studios, it's because of this that I can forgive this title from not having too many changes from the last games.There is so much to do in this game even after you complete it, for example there is a most wanted side quest that allows you to try to stop criminals such as The Mad Hatter and The Penguin and bring them into custody. The Good - Good Story- Many interesting villains, even some you may not have heard of- Graphical improvements from previous game (not too much)- Fun side activities- Improved mechanics- Battle system is great with only a few problems- You can be Batman, who doesn't want a taste of that Batman lifestyle am I right? The Bad - Battle system is repetitive at times- Not many improvements from the previous games- A few glitches had to be sorted out, I never ran into many glitches like the fatal error or controlling flight issues however I did have to fix an issue with the cutscenes as mine lagged a lot; I ended up finding a guide on the steam community to help me.- Some tasks such as the collectables are still a chore in my opinion and I wish they were done more interestingly than they are in this game, for example Arkham Asylam had audio logs from the villains which were interesting to listen too and made me want to collect them.

content:
Posted: December 11, 2014
COMPLETED 100%I got this prequel to the ever sucessful Arkham series, hoping it'd be better than what critics have made it out to be. But as it turns out, the game is more of an overall disappointment to what it could have been a signifciant improvement to Arkham City. While AC was so flawlessly free of technicalities, this game is still riddled with quite a few glitches and bugs the devs couldn't be bothered with. Nothing so game-breaking at least. Where the games shine, the combat system, AO does away by making for slightly more challenging enemies and variations. This is surely a good thing, if not for the numerous control input problems and fight inconsistencies that simply ends up screwing up the enjoyment of gameplay. Especially annoying when the game expects you to perform up to task for the stupid Dark Knight System and ranked challenge maps.Thankfully there's the very unbalanaced and overpowered Shock Gloves, to compensate for this. A new and important gadget to this game, it makes you wonder why the heck wasn't Batman using this OP weapon in Arkham Asylum and Arkham City. I mean it helped  defeat Bane and save Alfred from near-death. It's so glorious, there's no reason to abandon it.  There's only one thing AO has made the biggest improvement from the past games. The main story missions are now more noticeably fun and interesting to get through, despite the silly premise which mainly serves as a subtle excuse in order to chuck a whole bunch of notable Batman villians in this one single game. It's also slightly longer and less than straightforward, compared to AC's main campaign, which is nice.. The dark cinematics and presentation are also brilliantly well done in coveying the tone of the game. If only the actual game looked as good... Boss fights are exceptionally great fun as well but makes Batman look too darn overpowered for someone just starting on an early vigilante career. The open world of Gotham is much bigger than the Arkham City in Arkham City, many similiar buildings stand out, being bigger in size, and the layout is mostly different enough to distinguish as being unique. It's also as completely unrealistic as ever, as a city completely void of civilians. Another ridiculous excuse to prevent Batman from making "social interations" with civilians. What a bummer.Collectibles still remain the same, data packs replacing riddler trophies this time and the number of packs hidden and are spread around the city. Finding or acquiring them isn't as hard as before, with less puzzles and challenges to solve. A show of leniency to completionists, or just a lack of effort on the devs' part in rushing this game. 3.5/5 - Game presentation is great, some areas of gameplay is an improvement, others is a thumbs down. A great game regardless, nevertheless, but nothing much so noteworhy for the upcoming Arkham Knight to follow and adapt from.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 9, 2014
												Arkham Origins is a fun addition of the "Arkham" franchise.  It lacks much of the polish, and some of the charm of the Rocksteady games, but has an interesting story and nicely varied boss fights that fans of the series will be able to appreciate.  They do a decent job of keeping things in line chronologically, and there are only a few noticable anachronisms that break the illusion of a story that takes place before Arkham Asylum.  Unfortunately, there are a few bugs that persist even now, and some of them are game-breaking.  However, in my playthrough of the main story, i managed to avoid every one of them (the My Alibi Bug is easily avoided).  "Cold, Cold Heart" (the story DLC) is the only place where I ran into game-breaking and unavoidable bugs.  That said, I was able to retain the fidelity of my save file by simply quitting after the bug had triggered (not trying to save again), and everything loaded fine.  The only thing that is still in error, is that two of the Steam Achievements have not triggered appropriately for me during "Cold, Cold, Heart".At the end of the day, I strongly recommend Arkham Origins for fans of the previous two Arkham games, especially if you get it cheap (A Holiday sale would be best, since the story takes place on Christmas Eve).  It's not one of the Rocksteady games, but it's a fun way to spend a bit more time in their world, especially while we wait for Arkham Knight.

content:
Posted: April 22, 2015
												Let's be honest: I have been a fan to the Batman franchise exploited by Rocksteady Studios (Batman: Arkham City; Batman: Asylum). Batman: Origins is very similar to these previous titles under many respects. Good points to notice:+ the pace of the game:    ... the gameplay feels rapid, smooth and comfortable; ennemies are very different from one another and the many tactics at your hand will have to be adapted accordingly (some parts require stealth and range, while others require you to go full melee);    ... the scenario is faithful without being submissive to the original comics; events happen at a pace that favours narrative tension and suspense;+ the richness of the main story and the coherence between the main story (as developed from the main quests) and the side quests:    ...  alternance between primary and secondary quests feels natural and allows you to play with a certain degree of freedom with respect to which quests you will actually pick, and with respect to the order in which you will tackle them (that can be only good given how big the "world" or "map" is);    ... the staging of the game in that the cut-scenes and the transitions between gameplay footage and cut-scenes creates a very pleasant yet coherent experience; thus you can start figthing a boss on the rooftop of a skyscraper only to have him escape by air, so that you have track him down to the sewers of a dark, high security prison.+ the richness of the environments and details; this contributes to make you immerse into the universe of the famous D.C Comics detective;+ optimization: the game runs properly even on 3-year+ old laptops (like mine).Bad point to note:- poor debugging; but I have never come across a bug I could not overcome by reloading the last checkpoint.

content:
Posted: June 25, 2014
												Very underrated game from the Arkham franchise. People usually complain about this title not coming from Rocksteady and constantly ♥♥♥♥♥ing about how bad it is when in reality it's not that bad at all. The story is actually pretty good considering Warner Bros. Montreal made it and not Rocksteady. The feel of the game and the atmosphere is good because it is an open-world Batman game and fans of the series will realize the familiarity of the map to Arkham City (because it's a prequel to Asylum). The world is beautiful but feels a bit limited in the free roam after about 15+ hours of gameplay. When you glide from building to building you there's a point when you go like, "I should be able to grapple that but I can't". The gameplay itself is well clunky compared to the Rocksteady titles if you put enough time in it. Combos and free flow combat are smooth but later you'll feel that sort of miss that refined finish Asylum and City had. Side missions are a blast in this one as they were in Arkham City but I find myself finishing them quicker and easier than in previous games. The boss battle are the usual cape-stun battles but there are a few that stand out that are amazing (Deathstroke, Shiva, Joker, etc). Overall Arkham Origins isn't a masterpiece or a real upgrade from Arkham City, but it indeeds fulfills the roll of entertaining levels and the player feeling like a BAMF when playing Batman. Fans of the series will definitely enjoy Arkham Origins and others might.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 6, 2015
												If you are looking for a game that is as revolutionary to the Batman franchise as Batman: Arkham Asylum was, then move on. In terms of gameplay, Arkham Origins doesn't really bring anything new to the table. Instead it refines a few of the issues that were present in Asylum and City (such as fighting "brute" enemies where you defeat them by piggyback. There is hardly any, if any at all, of that here), and brings to light an origin story that can can almost rival Frank Miller's Batman: Year One.Paralleling Miller's epic remastery of the Dark Knight's origins, Batman has his work cut out for him as not only does he have to fight the super villians and crime lords that have plagued Gotham for decades, but he also has to fight an overly corrupt Gotham City Police Department. James Gordon is only a Captain, and the way Commissioner Loeb runs things ol' Jimmy doesn't really know who he can trust. With a trigger happy SWAT Leader Branden to contest with, doing his job isn't easy either. Furthermore, we also get to see the Joker fall even farther into depravity as he questions what really is maximum fun. Before it was just the mob, politicians, and a whole lotta money, but with the Batman in the mix there is just no telling what life has in store for him! Even so, with cameos from 'B' grade and 'A' grade villians, there aren't as many easter eggs in this Batman, particularly because they really don't exist yet. Still, it leaves Gotham feeling a little empty. In particular I would liked to have seen Harvey Dent in the mix somewhere. He and Bruce/Batman were good friends before he became TwoFace, and having that ally in his origins (such as with Miller's adaptation) could have made for some interesting story development.All in all, as I said if you are looking for something revolutionary in terms of gameplay you should probably move on. But if you are looking for a damn good origin story, this is a great place to start.

Batman Arkham OriginsWorst Arkham game? Arguably yes. But is it a bad game? I can confidently say, NO.It's a well produced game, while it's feel more like a re-skin of Arkham City with very very small changes, but it still give a good free roam experience. The Main Story is "meh" for Arkham standart, but the whole package is good.PROSSolid action free-roam experience.Better city design than Arkham City.Some of the Boss Fights are super satisfyingFast travel system is great.CONSNot really an "origins".It just feels like Arkham city, with better graphics.Lacks of immersion compared to previous Arkham games.Side missions are shallows, just fillers to make the world feels "full".Easier combat than previous Arkham games (can e a pro too).Multiplayer is dead.Now, should you play this? If you're a hardcore Arkham series' fan, you can skip this one. Not much to find on this one.But if you just looking for a solid free-roam action game, I can say just try it especially on discount.It's a good game, just doesn't have enough magic like previous Arkham games has.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												Batman: Arkham Origins is a sequel that presents minor new tweaks and features over its predecessors. But it manages to be a good game and a worthy sequel nevertheless thanks to the still kicking Arkham formula and few good elements on its own.Regarding the gameplay, Origins focuses mostly on direct combat encounters: the few new gadgets you will get are suited for direct confrontations and the game will throw new kinds of enemies at you, the majority of which are able to either retaliate from your attacks or be downright invincible till you'll perform the right "trick" to bring them down to normal. The stealth sequences, on the other hand, didn't recive any improvement or new gimmick whatsoever.That said, two of the new gadgets tend to make the late game much easyer: the electric gloves can nullify every kind of enemy defense, effectively breaking down the main appeal of the fistfights, while the remote claw can connect an enemy to an explosive object from the environment or a vantage point for an easy takedown, without any ammo limit to prevent you from clearing up entire rooms.The new expanded map features environments you already visited in Arkham City, albeit reskinned accordingly for a prequel, along with new areas of Gotham, including a long bridge that separates the two. The level design and the attention to the original sources are as polished as usual for an Arkham game.The plot is the most praised aspect of Batman: Arkham Origins, since it feels original and makes an overall good use of the various characters. As a reader of the comic books, however, I would had handled the main antagonist a little better and crafted  the various assassins and criminals into the plot better, at the cost of reducing the importance of already enstablished Batman rogues.The multiplayer mode is a novelty for the Arkham series, and is about a capture the control point kind of experience between two weapons-wielding gangs while a third team of two people, who control Batman and Robin, try to thwart them as much as possible via stealth gameplay. While controlling the elite forces of either the Joker or Bane (and sometime the bosses themselves) in a third person shooter fashion and customize them as you see fit when it comes to weapons, gadgets and gear is a new and interesting feature, Batman and Robin are so much less effective in this mode than in the main game, making playing them sometimes more an annoyance than a blast. Beside that, the multiplayer mode as a whole is a worthy addiction, all things considered.The Initiation DLC is just another challenge campaign tided up by some unique cutscenes and an original setting, an eastern ninja training ground. While the change of scenary is surely a novelty, the various combat and predator challenges are nothing new, gameplay-wise.The Cold, Cold Heart DLC is the only story-driven pack for Arkham Origins, which basically shows the first encounter between Batman and Mr. Freeze. The DLC itself is very short, with its main story being beatable in two or three hours, and the few side quests are just recycled from the main game. There isn't anything new even on the gameplay's front. The only highlight of Cold, Cold Heart is the final battle against Mr. Freeze, a challenging predator encounter.Batman: Arkham Origins can be considered a fairly good attempted for an official prequel for the series, but really suffers from several not stellar development choices

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 6, 2015
												If you are looking for a game that is as revolutionary to the Batman franchise as Batman: Arkham Asylum was, then move on. In terms of gameplay, Arkham Origins doesn't really bring anything new to the table. Instead it refines a few of the issues that were present in Asylum and City (such as fighting "brute" enemies where you defeat them by piggyback. There is hardly any, if any at all, of that here), and brings to light an origin story that can can almost rival Frank Miller's Batman: Year One.Paralleling Miller's epic remastery of the Dark Knight's origins, Batman has his work cut out for him as not only does he have to fight the super villians and crime lords that have plagued Gotham for decades, but he also has to fight an overly corrupt Gotham City Police Department. James Gordon is only a Captain, and the way Commissioner Loeb runs things ol' Jimmy doesn't really know who he can trust. With a trigger happy SWAT Leader Branden to contest with, doing his job isn't easy either. Furthermore, we also get to see the Joker fall even farther into depravity as he questions what really is maximum fun. Before it was just the mob, politicians, and a whole lotta money, but with the Batman in the mix there is just no telling what life has in store for him! Even so, with cameos from 'B' grade and 'A' grade villians, there aren't as many easter eggs in this Batman, particularly because they really don't exist yet. Still, it leaves Gotham feeling a little empty. In particular I would liked to have seen Harvey Dent in the mix somewhere. He and Bruce/Batman were good friends before he became TwoFace, and having that ally in his origins (such as with Miller's adaptation) could have made for some interesting story development.All in all, as I said if you are looking for something revolutionary in terms of gameplay you should probably move on. But if you are looking for a damn good origin story, this is a great place to start.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 27, 2013
												Arkham Origins is an excellent installment into the franchise to the series and definately one worth buying. I played the first two Arkhams on the Xbox 360 and plugged in a 360 controller to my computer to play this game as well, so the controls for me felt very familiar. The combat is smooth and a lot better, though the better fights also mean the fights are significantly harder, but the lack of game changing elements (other than new and better gadgets) make the fights also begin to feel repetitive at times, like little things you have to do in order to get to the sweet, wonderful boss fights. However, it's not the gameplay that makes Arkham so great, but rather it's fantastic story. Every plot point ties in with eachother beautifully and, even despite this game being a pre-quel, it creates a completely fresh and new story with many unexpected moments and incredible feats of character/character development for Batman and his villains alike. The map here works better than City's, though not due to it's size, but rather it's believability. City tried too hard to make every notable building have something going on with it, whether a side mission or just snipers on the roof, while Origins leaves many buildings just building while still adding enough features on their other buildings to feel the need to travel wisely. If you enjoyed the last Arkham games then i would definately recommend this game, to the point where the story and bossfights alone are worth it.

content:

												Ok let's get this out of the way, this is the worst game in the series so far. Now you might be asking yourself: lol is dis duud on meth or sumting. Well, actually you might think that I'm gonna say some logical reason for making such a statement(not the meth thing). So le't get down to it. The fighting and stealth are both still really fun. So what is the problem? Well the problem is that they are indeed fun, but they were also fun in Arkham city(I would acually say that they were both better in Arkham city), and they have not really been changed at all since then. Overall the gameplay is nearly identical to Arkham city. Everything that worked there, also works quite well here.They did add few neat things, but I was hoping for more. And yeah, there is that multiplayer mode....that nobody really wanted to see. There are also a lot of glicthes in the game, some are small and some are serious issues. The game does also crash quite often.But anyway, what about the story? Well the joker has a big role in it...again. The joker is a great character, but could you give the spotlight to someone else please, he already had a huge role in 2 games! There is also that 8 assassin's hire by Black mask thing, which doesn't really get as much attention as I hoped. The boss fights that they were bragging on about are not even that special. Some of them are quite good, and some are the quite bad.A lot of people were♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥off because Mark Hamill and Kevin Conroiy are not in the game, but those new voice actors for Batman and the joker both do a good job, so no need to worry about that. But overall the story and characters are all quite good. I would even say that the story, might be the best in the series. The problem is that it lacks tension, because it's a prequel.Ah whatever, I think that I have said all that there is to say.Even though Arkham origins is quite clearly the weakest part of the series, I still had some fun playing it, but I was left hoping for much more. It's a solid entry in the series that still needs some major fixes. After that it might even be a pretty good game

content:
Posted: June 30, 2016
												The second Arkham game I played. Numerous glitches made this game problematic - especially for PS3 users who (much like PC users with AK) were majorly shafted with several problems that were never fully solved and remain in gameplay to this day - ranging from graphic problems with lag during glide-mode all the way to Batman becoming 'stuck' during boss fights. The 'shock gauntlets' (for lack of a better name) while an interesting gimmick for less-capable players, took away much of the challenge that City contained and lacked any option to disable them. Like Batman himself this game was much more rough-around-the-edges than what was to come; but what it did right it did well and for that it deserves appreciation. The story, the atmosphere and the young Bruce/Batman MADE this game approachable even if you weren't familiar with the series. It is an origin story without actually being one. The new 'random event/cop in danger' missions that crop up from time to time over the police band are a welcome distraction that feels like it could have been used in Knight. The much larger map of Knight with randomly generated numbers of foes and victims to save would have been quite a simple feature and is one of the reasons I still play Origins. Getting back to the story - and it isn't hard to do so - the plot in Origins moves around much more quickly than City, Asylum and Knight as well. The feel of a goal - a purpose - is much more present in Origins. Gotham - for the first time in the series history - actually FEELS like a city (or at least a town) with the much larger scope and map. Also, the origins the game gives for characters and areas that are introduced through the narrative are not only plausible, they (in many ways) are more streamlined and believable than many things DC has produced to date! The writing of this game - coupled with actors like Troy Baker - leave you wanting more even if you get stuck during that fight with firefly.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 25, 2016
												I don't know why this game didn't get more love.I have had this game in my library for over a year and after reading so many negative reviews I was afraid to play it thinking that it must be super bad and not worth playing. After reading some reviews I expected it to even barely be recognizable as a Batman game.  However, having liked Arkham Asylum and absolutely loving Arkham City I figured I had to give it a try, especially if I plan on trying Arkham Knight. I was expecting a dog. Maybe it was because my expectations were so low, but I really enjoyed it a lot.Granted, it didn't add a whole lot to the gameplay of Arkham City, but it was a great story in its own and having access to many of the gadgets and abilities right from the beginning, made it that much more enjoyable. There were a lot of varied things to do and for the first time I started playing in some of the challenge modes and I enjoyed the addition of the skill challenges during regular gameplay. I loved the Combat Challenges which helped train me as I went back into the game.It might have lacked a bit of the polish that was in Arkham City and at times combat seemed a little bit clunkier, especially when trying to do a followup attack on a downed enemy, but I really feel that if this game had come out before Arkham City, it would be getting all of the praise and Arkham City would have been looked down on. It was a solid game and it stands on its own. Some say it was more like DLC for Arkham City, but I have never gotten this much time and enjoyment out of any DLC for any game. My current hours spent on this one surpass those I spent in Arkham City.I don't consider myself a Batman fan or even a DC fan (I always liked Marvel and Spiderman). I am, however, a great fan of these Batman games and yes, that does include Arkham Origins.  If you enjoyed Arkham Origins and Arkham City, you have to play this one. If you found Arkham City repetetive and not so good, don't play this one. Please, if you did like the other Batman Arkham games, you owe it to yourself to try this one. Don't be influenced by all of the naysayers. This is a great game!!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 8, 2013
												This game got blasted in reviews for essentially being the same as Arkham City.  This is true, but I don't view it as a negative.  The game inherited a winning formula, and rather than change it unnecessarily, they kept it as-is.  As a result, Arkham Origins has a winning formula as well, rather than a broken "New Coke" design.I feel like the story is the strongest of the Arkham games so far, and the game looks visually stunning.  Playing with PhysX especially was a revelation as to how much more convincing that tech can make a game's environments, and I really hope to see it adopted in a wide range of future titles.Most of my complaints are things inherited from the past games.  I'm not a big fan of the overly muscled look for everyone in the game, sans Joker and women.  Nor the way Batman pinballs around the room during combat.  There's got to be a better way to represent rapid motion than that.Though the map is larger than Arkham Asylum (and City), because you spend so much time gliding overhead, City and Origins feel much smaller to me.  The various buildings in City and Origins are largely pointless and tend to blend together in a way that the environments of Asylum never did.The rock-paper-scissors nature of a lot of the enemies is annoying.  The game is at its best when it creates those "I'M BATMAN" moments of the player dropping into the middle of 50 guys and cleaning house - thugs that require a special gimmick to be defeated (stun the armored thug, get behind the stunner thug, etc) break that feeling.  It isn't that they're hard, but that they reduce your options in a fight down to one, and it's the same one every time.  The only complaint I have that is exclusive to Origins is that the voice actor for Batman is terrible.  I'm not a Kevin Conroy fan (I'm in the minority that prefers the Bale voice), but the new guy is terrible enough that it pulls me out of the game.  This just isn't Batman's voice coming out of Batman.But those things aside, this is still an excellent game, and may actually be my favorite of the trilogy so far.  Walking around the Batcave, for whatever reason, is particularly enjoyable to me.  If spending an hour exploring the Batcave and trying to read every blurred text-containing texture appeals to you, put this one at the top of your wishlist.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 8, 2013
												This game got blasted in reviews for essentially being the same as Arkham City.  This is true, but I don't view it as a negative.  The game inherited a winning formula, and rather than change it unnecessarily, they kept it as-is.  As a result, Arkham Origins has a winning formula as well, rather than a broken "New Coke" design.I feel like the story is the strongest of the Arkham games so far, and the game looks visually stunning.  Playing with PhysX especially was a revelation as to how much more convincing that tech can make a game's environments, and I really hope to see it adopted in a wide range of future titles.Most of my complaints are things inherited from the past games.  I'm not a big fan of the overly muscled look for everyone in the game, sans Joker and women.  Nor the way Batman pinballs around the room during combat.  There's got to be a better way to represent rapid motion than that.Though the map is larger than Arkham Asylum (and City), because you spend so much time gliding overhead, City and Origins feel much smaller to me.  The various buildings in City and Origins are largely pointless and tend to blend together in a way that the environments of Asylum never did.The rock-paper-scissors nature of a lot of the enemies is annoying.  The game is at its best when it creates those "I'M BATMAN" moments of the player dropping into the middle of 50 guys and cleaning house - thugs that require a special gimmick to be defeated (stun the armored thug, get behind the stunner thug, etc) break that feeling.  It isn't that they're hard, but that they reduce your options in a fight down to one, and it's the same one every time.  The only complaint I have that is exclusive to Origins is that the voice actor for Batman is terrible.  I'm not a Kevin Conroy fan (I'm in the minority that prefers the Bale voice), but the new guy is terrible enough that it pulls me out of the game.  This just isn't Batman's voice coming out of Batman.But those things aside, this is still an excellent game, and may actually be my favorite of the trilogy so far.  Walking around the Batcave, for whatever reason, is particularly enjoyable to me.  If spending an hour exploring the Batcave and trying to read every blurred text-containing texture appeals to you, put this one at the top of your wishlist.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 29, 2014
												Ever since the release of Arkham Asylum, I have been a diehard Batman video game fan. I had doubts for Asylum that were quickly disproven and from that point, I went to the midnight release of Arkham City. That being said, as soon as I saw that WB Montreal was developing a prequel game, I began to worry. Now, some of those worries were founded, others not so much.Arkham Origins is a mixed bag. It brings both good and bad things to the Arkham franchise. I'll start with the negatives.Deja-vu. You'll play this game wondering what is different about it than Arkham City. You have almost the same gadgets, combat upgrades, grappel abilities, etc. It's not bad; it's just really familiar. Mission types are similar, if not the same, and a good portion of the map is the Arkham City map covered in snow. Granted it's in greater detail with a graphical overhaul, but it's the same map. The good: Story. It's not as good as Arkham City's story with all the twists and great care and attention that were given it, but it's decent. It introduces many of Batman's familiar villains in a plotline that isn't disappointing. That's something that isn't easy to pull off.  The voice acting is good, with Troy Baker stealing the show with an excellent Joker presentation. (especially considering that he isn't Mark Hammill) The graphics can be excellent, but can also disappoint. Some areas have great details and effects, but even those aren't jaw-dropping. I run this on a 1GB GTX 650ti and get around 45FPS average, which is decent for the settings I run it at. The sound editing could use some work, as it was difficult to hear voices over SFX sometimes, even after altering the levels. I haven't tried multiplayer much yet, to be honest I probably won't do it at all. I didn't buy this game for the multiplayer and I'd be surprised if anyone did. The single player doesn't disappoint, but it really doesn't exceed any expectations either. It's a good entry in the series, but it's not as excellent as we've come to expect from an Arkham title. If you're a fan, it's worth getting, but you may want to wait for a sale to purchase this game.

content:
Posted: March 31, 2014
												Even though it says I've only played this game for five hours, I mostly played this game offline and have completed the campaign. I must say that although the game is great, it is no match to what Arkham City had. The story was great, loved the part with the refrences to the Killing Joke and Joker's origin. However, what really began to tick me off was the combat, it was much slower and not as fluid. I found myself having the slow down, which is not a good thing when facing fifteen people at once. The only way I could take down some of the later battles were the shock gloves, which were way too overpowered in my opinion. The younger Bruce Wayne does actually feel younger, he seems more arrogant and less experienced, and I loved having Alfred talk to me rather than Oracle for a change. This is not just Batman's story though, it is also a story about the Joker, whom I found intriguing. The new voice actors suprisingly fit well, but nobody can beat Kevin Conroy. Gotham City seems really like a cut and paste Arkahm City, but it has some new tricks up its sleeve. Overall, even though this game is probably the weakest in the series, it's really well done. I'm suprised it was good, as it was not Rocksteady who made this game, but WB Montreal. 8.4/10
