number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 1, 2014
												While not as good as the other Arkham games, it is still a great game. The story is interesting, and the dialogue is well written. It is very straight to the point, and the story makes it clear that this game is all about the boss fights, and in that regard, it doesn't dissapoint. The boss fights are varied, and very fun. From the hand-to-hand fight with Deathstroke, demanding split second timing and reflexes, to the surreal brawl with Copperhead, and the tactical stealth ancounter with Deadshot, this game will keep you busy with each passing boss fight.Sadly, I can not say the same for the side missions. It is the same thing we've been doing since Asylum. Scan this, collect that, go there. Not much variety at all. It doesn't help that you're doing this on the same map as Arkham City. Sure, they have added new areas, but it doesn't offer much in terms of variety. It is hard to know your way around the map, when everything looks the same. They say in the game that you have to go to the industrial district, but the entire city looks like an industrial district! In fact, like Arkham City, the entire city looks like a war zone in an industrial district. It makes sence in City, being a cut off part of the city for prisoners, but in Origins, that is not the case. Things are on fire, the bridge is covered with piles of crates, broken cars and criminal activity. And navigating it has gotten harder. I swear they have reduced the amount of grapple points in the city. Even in places where there is no logical reason why I wouldn't be able to grapple, I can't. It gets very frustrating. And there are fewer things you can climb up on. Sometimes you can clumb up on objects that are, maybe, 3 and a half meters tall. At other times, you can't even climb up on something waste high.Then there's the gadgets. You won't find much in terms of variety here either. Most of the gadgets are just altered versions of the old ones, or the exact same ones. But they do the job. If I have one major criticism of the gadgets, it is one that applies for all of the Arkham games. The gadgets are a bit far fetched. They feel out of place. It feels like they belong in a sci-fi game. They explosive gel has no reason to be a gel. In the comics and other media, Batman frequently carries explosive charges. Why does it have to be gel here? It feels a bit contrived. And why does he have to spray it in the shape of a bat symbol? Wouldn't that just take more time? And the disruptor looks like some sort of plasma rifle. I don't mind what the gadgets do, I just think they look a bit to futuristic. But that is just preference on my part.All in all, I think it is a really good game. Its charm doesn't lie in its open world, or the side activities. It lies in the boss fights,, the the different levels and the characters. If that is what you're looking for, then I wholeheartedly recommend Arkham Origins. But if you are looking for a great open world game, with a lot of things to do, I recommend waiting for Arkham Knight, or pick up Arkham city which, while not very good at side activities either, does at least offer more grapple points, and climbable ledges, making the city easier, and more enjoyable to navigate.

												pros: visuals & graphics options, benchmarking available, challenge modes, crime scene investigation improved from the previous arkham games, characters are well voice acted, narrative experience to batman's origin, the signature arkham-style combat as we all know it, side missions & other villains to fightcons: no fullscreen windowed mode, can't skip game launch logos, the city is visually lacking compared to arkham city, binds run & jump to one key (spacebar) - unable to bind them to separate keys, STILL makes the player mash spacebar to open vent doors (like the previous arkham games), mash spacebar to move a raft on water, immersion breaking transitions to video cut scenes, random fps drops, unable to use the mouse to navigate the map, clunky ingame menu, sometimes abilities are unresponsive (especially during combat) which is the drawback of multi-button abilities (thanks to console design), some buildings will not let you grapple on them (even though they realistically could be grappled on), deathstroke suddenly vanished from a fight (I had to re-load my last save point), deathstroke battle is a tedious trial & error fight, boss battles are hit or miss (some can be really clunky like the firefly fight) & final boss fights were tedious, the game constantly make you crisscross the center bridge in-between missions, some of batman's audio cues overlap with each other, online is a hit or miss experience, map is littered with tedious enigma "batarang this thing" data itemOverall, the game runs stable considering the game's disastrous launch (stability issues in every arkham game during launch). Although the bugs that prevented you from progressing the main story have been patched, from what ive read a lot of the game's major bugs will not be patched (post-launch support completely ceased). This game feels bare bones compared to Arkham City (more of a narrative experience in comparison), but I welcome the improvement to crime scene investigations.Batman: Arkham Origins has my recommendation if you are new to the Arkham series, hit or miss if you have played the other Arkham games. This game feels more like a half-effort extension/DLC'ish to Arkham City.

												So far I have 16 hours in Asylum(100%), 34 in City(Main Story, all Riddler bull♥♥♥♥, and DLC) And 23 in this game; "Arkham Origins", to me this is part of the franchise, it is a bit glitchy but the story, refined gameplay which is the best so far in the series(IMO) and better side missions really made it up to me. I loved the boss battles which felt intense and challenging, The DLC was also great, and the crime scene addition is impeccable. So far this is my ranking1. Arkham City2. Arkham Asylum3. Arkham OriginsPros:StoryGameplayLots of ContentCons: Glitchy Feels lazy by only re-doing the map and adding a few districts.Verdict:8.5/10Worth the money and a fun game to play. Pick it up whenever, preferably on sale like I did because it is a little bit glitchy.However I can understand something like the flying animation glitch, because that seems like it would be impossible to fix. But I had one crash, two checkpoint restart glitches(I was stuck and invincible.), and sometimes I had to get collectables a second time even though it saved afterwardss.

												First let me say I like a fair amount of things about the game. Some of the boss fights are the best in the series. The introduction of some of Batman's major villains is pretty cool. Some of the setpieces are great. It's not a bad game. What it is, is a tedious game. The Riddler puzzles feel largely uninspired and just vomited onto the map, there are 400 challenge mode medals to get, and there are two tiers of new game plus. Play it if you're itching for more Batman and have beaten the three Rocksteady games.

content:
Posted: October 29, 2015
												A great Batman game, being a fan of Rocksteady’s Arkham series, this WB title was definitely a must play. The story was impressive with plenty of great interactions, clashes with batman’s villains, side quests to level up, new and interesting characters, well-made cut scenes, fantastic voice acting and a great soundtrack. The gameplay didn’t change that much from Arkham City and Asylum aside from a few tweaks and a bit more challenging encounters. There are also a few new gadgets and ways to use them.The map itself is huge and well designed to fit Gotham’s environment, but It is lacking a bit more population aside from gang members and police officers, since this is Gotham city and not a prison city anymore, but still a good job nonetheless. I am not a big fan of the multiplayer version of the game, because a game like this should be focused more on the single player aspect, but aside from its micro transactions it is entertaining.The challenge maps and campaign maps are always a nice addition, as well as being able to play as Deathstroke, sadly they didn’t give him an expansion story, but fortunately they released the Cold Cold Heart DLC which is pretty good.I do recommend the game and it is pretty cheap in its full price, but since it still possesses a few bugs and glitches, I would advice getting it on sale

content:
Posted: April 18, 2014
												Has to be one of the best games I've played. I don't take to FPS type games easily but Batman is one of the best FPS/beat-em-ups going. The meleé combat system is relatively easy to get to grips with and progresses nicely as the story unfolds; the story is engaging and creates a great Batman-esque (dark) atmosphere; and the voice acting is spot-on.I have the game running fairly well under Windows 8.1 with a 4GHz Core i5, 8GB RAM, GTX 760 2GB graphics card, and all the graphics options maxed (except for AA on GeForce TXAA Low) - roughly 30fps or above @ full HD. The game is visually stunning, Gotham is beautifully recreated with lots of detail and a fluid system of moving around.The gameplay is split between action in the cityscape and action in buildings/enclosed areas. There are some nice alternative sections too and a little puzzle solving to obtain certain objects.I loved Gears of War on the XBox and this is just as easy to get into. I haven't completed the game yet (30%) but there has been plenty to do and there is good replay value in various challenges you can unlock and training modes.It's not perfect, mind, there are the occasional camera angles issues and the odd glitch that requires a game restart.If you like Batman and like FPS type games then this is a no-brainer, for everyone else it's close to a no brianer, and for those that hate these types of games you may be surprised at how good it is.Now, can someone make a Spiderman game with this engine and dynamics?

content:
Posted: April 20, 2014
												The game itself is fine. It plays fine, the story is not bad. There are times where the game will show glitches, such as Batman falling THROUGH THE GROUND, or landing in water when he should be landing on the ground. Those, quite frankly, shouldn't bother anyone too much as they aren't too bad. Now, I am not too familiar with all the glitches, however I can tell you: STAY AWAY FROM 'MY ALIBI'. After you fight Bane, there will be a prompt to go after someone called The Bird. There are three places you travel to in order to complete the mission. The last place is 'My Alibi.' When I played it, I did the mini-boss fight with The Bird, then I was able to walk around. I walked into an adjacent room which turned black, as if I were between layers. Then I tried to leave the building but got stuck, so I restarted the game. When I continued the game, I saw Batman stuck in limbo, completely rendering the game broken. I've checked around and I see that it is a common glitch that occurs.I have only had this game for about a month, so whatever updates occured to fix this problem never carried over to when I bought it. I'm recommending this game because as I have said, it is fine and most of the glitches aren't too bad. All you need to do though, to be safe, is to completely avoid going into 'My Alibi.'

content:
Posted: January 18, 2015
												It's a bad copy of Arkham city. The story is great, the characters are pretty good, though you don't see them that much. Combat seems harder, while Arhkam city was balanced. Filled with bugs, even after a huge patch. Bosses are really boring and annoying, basically all you do is repeat a sequence on how to hurt them, and dodge their attacks. A bonus is that they integrated achievements into the game, so you have a reason to get them. The map is a bit big, and the interiors maps aren't fun. The riddler challanges are awful. Most of them are just one gadget away from taking a collectable. The reward for finishing them was decent, but not as rewarding as in City.The online game is fun and original. It made this game as a whole, less bad for me. On the other hand, it has no real balance. Experienced players smash newer ones. Also, when super villians come out (part of the game), the game becomes super hard. Also filled with way too much bugs, connection drop outs which just has to get on your nerves.I can't say it's all bad, I did enjoy the story, and some aspect of the game. It's worth a play, at least for the story, but not remotely close to the last game.Some of the worst programming ever. I'm not blaming the developers, maybe they weren't told to fix stuff, but to focus on other tasks. I mean, man, it's so bad you even lose credits you earned, because of so many issues. Please don't♥♥♥♥♥♥of your players!!!!!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 6, 2015
I don't know why most aren't people satisfied with this game because i sure as hell am.Single playerThis game has a good story, a slightly similar combat system of arkham city with a few new added gadgets , new enemy types, and about 9 villains you get to face off and fight. Unlike arkham knight boss battles, this installment brings back the feeling of what its like to fight actual bosses who could kill you if your not too careful for example bane, deathstroke, cooperhead and others.MultiplayerThe multiplayer in this game is also good. There are 3 teams Jokers gang, Bane's gang and batman and robin .You get to play as one of the elite henchmen who work for either the joker or bane and you get to play as batman and robin, sort of like a predator/prey system where about 6 players are henchmen(prey) and 2 players are batman and robin(hunter). I like how the mutiplayer gives you the opportunity to play as henchman and get to experience their perspective of being stalked by batman, you maybe thinking how hard can it be to spot a man in bat costume or even be scared of him but trust me after playing as a henchmen you will FEAR THE KNIGHT.The drawback to multiplayer is that its really hard to find a match when there aren't many online players, each matchmaking session takes about 10-15 minutes which is abit frustrating and things get even worse when a game starts with people who are either afk or disconnected during the match since there is no vote to kick feature and players can't join during multiplayer sessions. This game may not be as good as arkham city but its still worth buying and playing. I recommend buying when its on offer like i did, then you won't regret your decision if you dont like it.

content:
Posted: February 23, 2015
												Arkham Origins - I love the Batman Games, but this game attracted me more than Arkham City and Asylum. I loved playing the story and the game's side missions. The story adds better boss fights (use of stealth this time in some bosses) and fun missions such as predator missions. The side missions have you foiling the plans of Edward Enigma, Bird, Penguin and other Batman villains. This time around Batman had multiplayer, which is a really good feature that I feel didn't get enough attention. This multiplayer has 2 players playing as hereos - Batman and Robin (With heaps of skins from your favourite Batman comics) and 6 other players split between either Bane or Joker thugs. These characters have firearms, traps, grenades and many other weaponry to take down the stealthy hunter (the hereos), these character are customisable aswell, changing their outfit, archytypes and accessories. I have heaps of fun playing with my friends online and think any player should expierence this. So please, do yourself a favour, and buy this game :)

content:
Posted: September 17, 2016
												7.5/10It's a good game, better than Asylum but worse than Arkham City. Why? Though the map is supposedly bigger and the Bat gets a couple of new gadgets, the game overall feels a bit clunky and unpolished. Even with a good rig (970 gpu), the game has crashed several times, frozen, and had game-breaking glitches. Honestly it was fun for me to exploit the games bugs, such as the one where you can enter a huge empty building in the middle of the map and just watch the animations twist Batman's durable armour. SInce the game is set in Gotham during a winter, it also feels washed out compared to Arkham City's sharp textures. Gotham in BA Origins is also a lot more spread out, but it suffers because of it. While BA City was packed and interest to explore, Gotham feels empty and lifeless if not for the occasional gang of thugs. In general graphically the game can look gorgeous, and then suddenly a texture begins glitching out and the immersion gets completely lost.Story-wise it is OK, the battle with Deathstroke being the most memorable in the series for me. However, it doesn't feel like much new or interesting; it's just the general Batman vs All story. Considering the game is for 5 bucks right now, I would say definitely buy it. However, if you don't have BA City already and can't buy both that game and this one, I would recommend the purchase of BA City.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 25, 2016
												I don't know why this game didn't get more love.I have had this game in my library for over a year and after reading so many negative reviews I was afraid to play it thinking that it must be super bad and not worth playing. After reading some reviews I expected it to even barely be recognizable as a Batman game.  However, having liked Arkham Asylum and absolutely loving Arkham City I figured I had to give it a try, especially if I plan on trying Arkham Knight. I was expecting a dog. Maybe it was because my expectations were so low, but I really enjoyed it a lot.Granted, it didn't add a whole lot to the gameplay of Arkham City, but it was a great story in its own and having access to many of the gadgets and abilities right from the beginning, made it that much more enjoyable. There were a lot of varied things to do and for the first time I started playing in some of the challenge modes and I enjoyed the addition of the skill challenges during regular gameplay. I loved the Combat Challenges which helped train me as I went back into the game.It might have lacked a bit of the polish that was in Arkham City and at times combat seemed a little bit clunkier, especially when trying to do a followup attack on a downed enemy, but I really feel that if this game had come out before Arkham City, it would be getting all of the praise and Arkham City would have been looked down on. It was a solid game and it stands on its own. Some say it was more like DLC for Arkham City, but I have never gotten this much time and enjoyment out of any DLC for any game. My current hours spent on this one surpass those I spent in Arkham City.I don't consider myself a Batman fan or even a DC fan (I always liked Marvel and Spiderman). I am, however, a great fan of these Batman games and yes, that does include Arkham Origins.  If you enjoyed Arkham Origins and Arkham City, you have to play this one. If you found Arkham City repetetive and not so good, don't play this one. Please, if you did like the other Batman Arkham games, you owe it to yourself to try this one. Don't be influenced by all of the naysayers. This is a great game!!

content:
Posted: January 12, 2015
												Now, I want you to know that Batman: Arkham Origins is the  best game I have ever played - It has very exciting and dramatic story, it has very beutifully made fights and perfect stealth and detective parts, a lot of  a lot of boss fights - there are more than 10, huge map, and extraordinarily made graphic. In this game, you can enjoy playing as Batman (of course) or a mercenary called DeathStroke (in challenge mode). There are 4 game modes (new game, new game +, I am the night - you mustn't die and challenge mode), 3 difficulties and a lot of upgrades. Story of the proloque  (spoiler warning)The story takes place in Christmas Eve, the time Batman didn't know Joker and Black Mask was still the biggest villain of Gotham. Batman found out that Black Mask made a night called "One night to kill the Bat": He invited to Gotham 8 assasins: DeathStroke, DeadShot, Copperhead (female), Firefly, Bane, Shiva (female), the Electrocutioner and Killer Croc. Their task is simple: "Kill the Batman in the Christmas Eve night, if you want to get 50 000 000 $", told Black Mask to them. Is Batman going to defeat them or is someone going to pick up the bounty? It is up to you to find out :D.Positives A very long story2 charactersPlenty of upgrades and achievementsTrading cardsExciting story4 save files4 game modesA very big mapYou can go in housesNegativesUnrealistic cape (You have holes in it and you still can fly? :))

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 5, 2015
												I am not going to lie, I thoroughly enjoyed this game, despite the fact that the gameplay mechanics were relatively unchanged. This does not even compare to Arkham City, but doesn't make it a bad game either, not at all! This prequel to the Arkham series puts you in the suit and cowl of Batman as expected, but this time years before the events of Arkham Asylum. Batman is still the experienced fighter as he is in Asylum, but does make mistakes that you don't see in Asylum or City, which I enjoyed, it shows he wasn't always the perfect interrogator and is still a human, albeit an incredibly skilled, master detective with loads of gadgets at his disposal.Now the gameplay remains almost untouched, with a few new things here and there such as the new martial artist fighters, and a new feature to the detective mode of which I'm too lazy to talk about. There you have it, those are the only additions in terms of gameplay, which isn't much at all, and if you ask me they were very unnecessary. The addition of multiplayer was also unnecessary, and rather crummy, this is a single player game, so don't try to tamper with it in that manner! If you've played Arkham City, you've basically already played Arkham Origins, in terms of gameplay at least. Other than gameplay, the story is new and worth playing through, the main reason I bought it actually... well that and it was on sale! The story was great, and that's what made it feel like a worthy addition to the series, seeing the events that came before arkham and particularly getting to have a one-on-one match with Deathstroke was awesome. I won't say much else about story as to not spoil it. Overall this game was a fun game to playthrough, but after beating it I found myself bored of the game because it didn't have a lot more to offer than the previous game Arkham City, just the same gameplay and not much joy in finding the Riddler packages, I've already done enough of that in City and the puzzles to achieve them weren't exactly new either. This was more or less a story expansion that I enoyed playing through, but didn't find it worht my time to go for 100%. If you were to choose between Arkham City and Arkham Origins, go with City, this may have been a worthy addition to the series, but you don't actually need it to understand any of the story from Arkham Aylum or City. 7/10, would still recommend, but only if you want to experience the story.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 24, 2015
												The game was made to keep fans busy until Rocksteady released the official sequel in the series, and it shows. While it seems interesting on paper, the the studio behind this game played things as safe as they possibly could. The map is largely borrowed from Arkham City, most (if not all) of the new gadgets are just the old toys with slightly different mechanics and passed off as "New", nothing new to batman's move set as far as combat goes, the missions feel like they were recycled from the first two games... This prequel never steps sets out to improve on the games before it.But at the same time, it's not bad. It just feels like a step back in quality a bit, and whatever new things this game adds their so minor that they really don't make much of a difference. Gamers label this game as glorified DLC for a reason.If you had to choose, forget this title and just play the original games. The game may be titled "Origins", but believe me when I say you're not missing anything. In a way, this game has about as much importance to the Arkham series as Harley Quinn's Revenge had to Arkham City. It's just filler. Though, despite my complaints, I can still recommend this game. Just... not for at full price. Wait for a Batman Steam sale and scoop this up for $5.00... hell, even the season pass wouldn't hurt for the Mr. Freeze side story, challenge maps, and additional costumes. For $10.00, it's worth it, but for the asking price, you're better off buying the first two or putting that cash towards Arkham Knight.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 25, 2014
												Long story short: I LOVE THIS GAME!Before starting, let's just be clear about the things I didn't like:- If you want to complete the ranks of Worst Nightmare, you MUST do it during the story line, because the Predator rooms do not respawn after you complete them during the story. This is a real pain in the butt if you completed the story line. I even had to play the I Am The Night mode (you die, you start all over again) for completing this rank.- The same condition of "finishing the ranks just during the story" make the "challenge maps" unatractive. And besides, you just get achievements if you get ALL of the medals. I mean, c'mon! at least give me an achievement for getting almost all of them!- Sometimes (not often, but it happened to me a couple of times) bugs will make you restart to the last checkpoint. As an example, I was fighting the last boss, and suddenly Batman and the boss stopped moving and just stared at each other... It was kinda funny, thou.Said this, let's go to everything I totally loved:-The whole story is something amazing! whorty of any comic book!. I would go into details, but I don't want to spoil anything. I just loved it so much that playing the normal, new game plus, and I am the night mode was a total pleasure. The only "but" is that I consider it to be too short, compared with Arkham City, but it is compensated by the many side stories that are allowed by the Most Wanted missions.- You gotta love Barbara Gordon <3- I do think this game makes the Batman to be more a detective than the previous games, which is a very fun thing to play. It's kinda easy thou, since the Batman does everything for you. - If you can, buy the DLC Cold, Cold Heart. The way they explain the origins of Mr. Freeze is stunning! - The gameplay is, as always, something intuitive. I played Arkham City like... two years ago? and now I just graved the PS3 controller (yes, **** you, Microsoft!) and it was like riding a bike... people don't forget!- Getting all the collectibles, all the upgrades, all the tags, everything, will give you lots and lots of hours of gameplay. I did reach 100 hours of gaming just with the singleplayer mode (my brother also played the game, so, I didn't actualy play that amount of time). I might have taken my time, thou, I'm sure you can do it faster.About the price, yes, 30 dollars for all the time I played is worthy, but yet, that amount of money for just one game is kinda too much for me. I got this game during the Summer Sales, and those 7.5 USD I did spend for this game are one of the best buying I have ever made. But, If you're ok about paying 30 USD for one game, I'm telling you, DO IT!! you wont regret!.I can't really talk about the multiplayer mode. I'm not too much into playing online, then I just tried it for a while. It was fun.Summary: GO FOR IT!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 29, 2014
												Ever since the release of Arkham Asylum, I have been a diehard Batman video game fan. I had doubts for Asylum that were quickly disproven and from that point, I went to the midnight release of Arkham City. That being said, as soon as I saw that WB Montreal was developing a prequel game, I began to worry. Now, some of those worries were founded, others not so much.Arkham Origins is a mixed bag. It brings both good and bad things to the Arkham franchise. I'll start with the negatives.Deja-vu. You'll play this game wondering what is different about it than Arkham City. You have almost the same gadgets, combat upgrades, grappel abilities, etc. It's not bad; it's just really familiar. Mission types are similar, if not the same, and a good portion of the map is the Arkham City map covered in snow. Granted it's in greater detail with a graphical overhaul, but it's the same map. The good: Story. It's not as good as Arkham City's story with all the twists and great care and attention that were given it, but it's decent. It introduces many of Batman's familiar villains in a plotline that isn't disappointing. That's something that isn't easy to pull off.  The voice acting is good, with Troy Baker stealing the show with an excellent Joker presentation. (especially considering that he isn't Mark Hammill) The graphics can be excellent, but can also disappoint. Some areas have great details and effects, but even those aren't jaw-dropping. I run this on a 1GB GTX 650ti and get around 45FPS average, which is decent for the settings I run it at. The sound editing could use some work, as it was difficult to hear voices over SFX sometimes, even after altering the levels. I haven't tried multiplayer much yet, to be honest I probably won't do it at all. I didn't buy this game for the multiplayer and I'd be surprised if anyone did. The single player doesn't disappoint, but it really doesn't exceed any expectations either. It's a good entry in the series, but it's not as excellent as we've come to expect from an Arkham title. If you're a fan, it's worth getting, but you may want to wait for a sale to purchase this game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 11, 2014
												The Arkham series has been setting the bar for melee combat for some years now.  So Origins has big shoes to fill.   Fans have gotten used to an unbelievable experience AND a serious evolution in gaming style each time a batman is released.  So it’s understandable why Origins has gotten poor reviews especially from fanboys.  What Origin actually turned out to be was an excellent game cut in the same mold of Arkham City, but without any evolution in gameplay. Putting the fanboyism aside the game is not a money grab by copy and pasting City.  It’s just a solid game in the series and well worth anyone’s time. To be fair however Origins has some serious problems that are odd considering their nature.  Having basic bugs still in core gameplay mechanics months after release is a huge bone for fans to pick.  Especially since we didn’t see those bugs in the two previous games and this new developer had Rocksteady’s work to build on.  The worst problem still unresolved is what I call a hitbox (I am sure it has a real name) basically when the cursor is placed over an object the command will flash and allow you to use the key.  In Origin I frequently had near game breaking problems with the hitbox.  Trying to quickly go from perch to perch was nearly impossible in this game.  I could put my cursor over the location and it just refused to allow me to go there.  Sometimes it would just be a delay of a second but other times it would never register.  This ruined a key part of a batman game and got me killed countless times. I would rate the Plot and theme done by this developer a B or B-, it’s not something I found interesting but it was enjoyable.  I think the bottom line with Origins is that you have to take it for what it is; it’s another 20 hours or so in Arkham City with some new twists that will marginally intrigue you.  Is it a true successor to the Arkahm family no, but it’s worth 50-60% of full price.   My Score  75/100

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 24, 2015
												Batman Arkham Origins is the 3rd action-adventure gamein the Arkham series where you play as Batman in Gotham. Arkham Asylum, the first, was great. Arkham City, the second, was even better, even though the story did get convoluted at times just to fit in all the content. Arkham Origins just feels like it's something to tide us over until Arkham Knight is finally released.The story is both better and worse than City. It definitely has more focus than City, which started off simple but had an incredibly convoluted build-up to the end.The gameplay is definitely worse, in both small things and bigger things. There are glitches where Batman can get stuck or enemies suddenly stop registering as enemies and just stand there looking goofy, ground takedowns seem to work only when they feel like it, and sometimes necessary encounters simply don't happen until you leave an area and come back. Mind you, this is with all the patches and fixes that are likely to ever be applied this is as good as it gets. It never gets so bad that it makes Origins unplayable, but it's just not as polished as City.Multiplayer had so much potential, it was awesomely paced, had an easy to understand objective, well balanced set of teams and skill ceilings. Servers wouldn't save data for the opening week though and no one played it again. Sucks to see such squandered potential.Pros:+ Another installment into the Batman franchise+ Good Plot+ Improved and interesting boss fights+ Great voice acting+ Incredible amount of side quests and other things to do, albeit it was poorly paced+ Incredibly fun multiplayer if you can get a group of friends to play with youCons:- Basically just Arkham City rebooted; Same combat and gadget system as Arkham City- Bigger map but somehow more boring to explore- Multiplayer that dropped the ball on launch- Plethora of bugs and glitches scattered around the gameTL;DR7/10Fun game if you like the Batman story, gameplay-wise and innovation-wise you're better off playing Batman Arkham City or Knight. I definitely got my money's worth but it wasn't as fun as the previous.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 1, 2014
												While not as good as the other Arkham games, it is still a great game. The story is interesting, and the dialogue is well written. It is very straight to the point, and the story makes it clear that this game is all about the boss fights, and in that regard, it doesn't dissapoint. The boss fights are varied, and very fun. From the hand-to-hand fight with Deathstroke, demanding split second timing and reflexes, to the surreal brawl with Copperhead, and the tactical stealth ancounter with Deadshot, this game will keep you busy with each passing boss fight.Sadly, I can not say the same for the side missions. It is the same thing we've been doing since Asylum. Scan this, collect that, go there. Not much variety at all. It doesn't help that you're doing this on the same map as Arkham City. Sure, they have added new areas, but it doesn't offer much in terms of variety. It is hard to know your way around the map, when everything looks the same. They say in the game that you have to go to the industrial district, but the entire city looks like an industrial district! In fact, like Arkham City, the entire city looks like a war zone in an industrial district. It makes sence in City, being a cut off part of the city for prisoners, but in Origins, that is not the case. Things are on fire, the bridge is covered with piles of crates, broken cars and criminal activity. And navigating it has gotten harder. I swear they have reduced the amount of grapple points in the city. Even in places where there is no logical reason why I wouldn't be able to grapple, I can't. It gets very frustrating. And there are fewer things you can climb up on. Sometimes you can clumb up on objects that are, maybe, 3 and a half meters tall. At other times, you can't even climb up on something waste high.Then there's the gadgets. You won't find much in terms of variety here either. Most of the gadgets are just altered versions of the old ones, or the exact same ones. But they do the job. If I have one major criticism of the gadgets, it is one that applies for all of the Arkham games. The gadgets are a bit far fetched. They feel out of place. It feels like they belong in a sci-fi game. They explosive gel has no reason to be a gel. In the comics and other media, Batman frequently carries explosive charges. Why does it have to be gel here? It feels a bit contrived. And why does he have to spray it in the shape of a bat symbol? Wouldn't that just take more time? And the disruptor looks like some sort of plasma rifle. I don't mind what the gadgets do, I just think they look a bit to futuristic. But that is just preference on my part.All in all, I think it is a really good game. Its charm doesn't lie in its open world, or the side activities. It lies in the boss fights,, the the different levels and the characters. If that is what you're looking for, then I wholeheartedly recommend Arkham Origins. But if you are looking for a great open world game, with a lot of things to do, I recommend waiting for Arkham Knight, or pick up Arkham city which, while not very good at side activities either, does at least offer more grapple points, and climbable ledges, making the city easier, and more enjoyable to navigate.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 28, 2014
												A misunderstood game with a bumpy start, Arkham Origins is an often-maligned yet fun and gripping prequel to Arkham Asylum and Arkham City. Visually, the game is superb. Even on low settings, the snow-covered streets of Gotham are a sight to behold. The gameplay is smooth and responsive, and taking on rooms of thugs and mercenaries by yourself is still as fun as it first was back in 2009. You actually feel like Batman at certain moments in the game, and the side-quests (which involve tracking down and stopping crimes in progress and the schemes of minor villains) are fun distractions from the main story.Multiplayer is finnicky, but it might appeal to some people. I would recommend the game for the singleplayer alone, as you're guaranteed to get a lot of time out of that. All-in-all, I would give this an 8.5 out of 10, docking points for the disappointing plot twist halfway through the game, user-unfriendly multiplayer, and occasional bugs that pop up in free roam. Buy it on sale if you're hesitant about the game or new to the series. Only buy it full-price if you're a fan of the other Arkham games or a diehard Batman fan.

content:
Posted: April 3, 2014
												Arkham Origins is a love story about two men who have an unhealthy, obsessive and mentally/physically abusive relationship. One of them enjoys wearing tight black leather, boots, ropes and various toys he hangs from his belt.The other likes to haphazardly smear on make-up, and die his hair rad colors and wear bright multi-colored clothing.The black-clad "bear" often beats his "sub" while the sub laughs manically. Just when you think it's going to go too far, "safe" phrases like "You won't kill me! HAHAHA" and "DO IT HAHAHA KILL ME! You can't can you?!" show that behind all the seething and gritted teeth, there is a mutual respect between these two love bats.Even though it made me puke, I enjoyed this game, like too much booze. Not appropriate for Australians.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 22, 2014
												While its debatable where this ranks in the series of Arkham games, one thing's for sure...we're going to have a lot more Batman. At first I was opposed to WB throwing together a new studio to create filler Arkham games while Rocksteady tooled away on their next creation, but you know what? I don't mind so much anymore. Arkham Origins might not be the most polished title but it certainly is just as fun as the previous two installments. You have the same great gameplay you're used two, new villains from the DC universe, and some more backstory to our brooding hero (and villains). The multiplayer is flawed but I like that they took the risk of building something out because it's open for improvement (for future iterations). I'm looking forward to the Mr. Freeze DLC and hopeful (fingers crossed) that the time taken to create this new content will be worth the wait.My biggest gripe that doesn't spoil any sort of story aspect of the game are the costumes. Costumes that you can purchase or unlock but can't equip in the campaign until you've played through the game at least ONCE. That's a big gamble for WB to assume that we as gamers and consumers have the patience to play this again. Yes you can change your costume on the Challenge maps but not all of want to play that mode. If there was a cheat in the main menu (like Arkham City) that allowed to temporarily unlock costume play for that play session, I think everything would be fine (who knows, maybe this is in the pipeline).Minus my complaint about the costumes, I actually enjoyed this game quite a bit. Having had some time to think about it post completion; I'd give this a solid 7.5 with room to improve with the new DLC.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 20, 2014
												The game itself is fine. It plays fine, the story is not bad. There are times where the game will show glitches, such as Batman falling THROUGH THE GROUND, or landing in water when he should be landing on the ground. Those, quite frankly, shouldn't bother anyone too much as they aren't too bad. Now, I am not too familiar with all the glitches, however I can tell you: STAY AWAY FROM 'MY ALIBI'. After you fight Bane, there will be a prompt to go after someone called The Bird. There are three places you travel to in order to complete the mission. The last place is 'My Alibi.' When I played it, I did the mini-boss fight with The Bird, then I was able to walk around. I walked into an adjacent room which turned black, as if I were between layers. Then I tried to leave the building but got stuck, so I restarted the game. When I continued the game, I saw Batman stuck in limbo, completely rendering the game broken. I've checked around and I see that it is a common glitch that occurs.I have only had this game for about a month, so whatever updates occured to fix this problem never carried over to when I bought it. I'm recommending this game because as I have said, it is fine and most of the glitches aren't too bad. All you need to do though, to be safe, is to completely avoid going into 'My Alibi.'

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 22, 2014
												While its debatable where this ranks in the series of Arkham games, one thing's for sure...we're going to have a lot more Batman. At first I was opposed to WB throwing together a new studio to create filler Arkham games while Rocksteady tooled away on their next creation, but you know what? I don't mind so much anymore. Arkham Origins might not be the most polished title but it certainly is just as fun as the previous two installments. You have the same great gameplay you're used two, new villains from the DC universe, and some more backstory to our brooding hero (and villains). The multiplayer is flawed but I like that they took the risk of building something out because it's open for improvement (for future iterations). I'm looking forward to the Mr. Freeze DLC and hopeful (fingers crossed) that the time taken to create this new content will be worth the wait.My biggest gripe that doesn't spoil any sort of story aspect of the game are the costumes. Costumes that you can purchase or unlock but can't equip in the campaign until you've played through the game at least ONCE. That's a big gamble for WB to assume that we as gamers and consumers have the patience to play this again. Yes you can change your costume on the Challenge maps but not all of want to play that mode. If there was a cheat in the main menu (like Arkham City) that allowed to temporarily unlock costume play for that play session, I think everything would be fine (who knows, maybe this is in the pipeline).Minus my complaint about the costumes, I actually enjoyed this game quite a bit. Having had some time to think about it post completion; I'd give this a solid 7.5 with room to improve with the new DLC.

If you set it down like I did, pick it back up, dust off those electrified gauntlets, and put the hurt on some baddies!

												So far I have 16 hours in Asylum(100%), 34 in City(Main Story, all Riddler bull♥♥♥♥, and DLC) And 23 in this game; "Arkham Origins", to me this is part of the franchise, it is a bit glitchy but the story, refined gameplay which is the best so far in the series(IMO) and better side missions really made it up to me. I loved the boss battles which felt intense and challenging, The DLC was also great, and the crime scene addition is impeccable. So far this is my ranking1. Arkham City2. Arkham Asylum3. Arkham OriginsPros:StoryGameplayLots of ContentCons: Glitchy Feels lazy by only re-doing the map and adding a few districts.Verdict:8.5/10Worth the money and a fun game to play. number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 11, 2013
												******REVISION*******My original opinion was that this game had major flaws that didn't let it hold up to Asylum and Arkham City. I stand by that opinion. This game STILL has some problems but a little bit of hindsight makes me realize that the other two Arkham games are phenomenal, and if I compare this to them, Origins falls short. However Arkham Origins on its own merit is a playable, enjoyable Batman game. Some of the story in the later parts of the game is acutally quite good. It's a shame that the most interesting parts of the story are at the end where a large majority of players will never get to. There is some psychological insight into the relationship of Batman and one of his major enemies that I've not seen in quite that way before. I said this in my original, brief review but I got a kick out of the early character models for penguin and some of the other rougues from the Batman gallery. If you can get to the last third of the game there are some good story beats in there. The combat is flawed but you can adjust to it. I've changed my recommendation from a no to a reserved yes. You still feel like the Bat.....and that is pretty cool.**********End Edit************************** I paid $5 for Arkham Asylum GOTY. I paid $30 for Arkham Origins. It should have been the other way around. I'm only two hours in and things may change but it feels like this third installment is a step backwards. The fighting doesn't have quite the right rythm to it. Animations often times slide just a little bit to far from one side to the other in order to make a fight sequence work. There are some issues that even early on just don't make sense. This is an origins story, so why does Batman have all the devices that he had in the later games? I will say that seeing the "younger" version of some of the characters from this version of the world is neat. I'm going to continue playing but unless you're a die hard, I don't feel like I could recommend this version without a MAJOR sale.

												Now that I've finished it and everyone sort of looks down on it might as well review it. I've enojoyed my time with Arkham Origins not only because of the differences it had from Asylum and City but because of its dark atmosphere. The boss fights (excluding Bane) weren't constanly being drawn out with "Venom" and there were less chores to do all around. Asylum didn't have this problem but with City I saw every villian as an annoyance whereas Origins' villians threatened something I cared about. The end of this game wasn't a bulky boss fight but more so an outlet for you to taste revenge and release Batman's anger. I am absolutely satisfied with this pickup that costed about 7$ on GMG.

content:
Posted: July 25, 2014
												Unlike too many open world games in recent memory, Batman: Arkham games don't fall into the trap of giving you a world packed out the ears with boring menial tasks.  If you took away the world and put Batman in a room fulll of thugs, this game could still easily stand on its own.The combat encourages timing over button mashing, improvisation over spamming, and thoughtfulness over bullheadedness.  The stealth gameplay is a rare example of one that blends in so well the action rather than taking away from it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 25, 2014
												Long story short: I LOVE THIS GAME!Before starting, let's just be clear about the things I didn't like:- If you want to complete the ranks of Worst Nightmare, you MUST do it during the story line, because the Predator rooms do not respawn after you complete them during the story. This is a real pain in the butt if you completed the story line. I even had to play the I Am The Night mode (you die, you start all over again) for completing this rank.- The same condition of "finishing the ranks just during the story" make the "challenge maps" unatractive. And besides, you just get achievements if you get ALL of the medals. I mean, c'mon! at least give me an achievement for getting almost all of them!- Sometimes (not often, but it happened to me a couple of times) bugs will make you restart to the last checkpoint. As an example, I was fighting the last boss, and suddenly Batman and the boss stopped moving and just stared at each other... It was kinda funny, thou.Said this, let's go to everything I totally loved:-The whole story is something amazing! whorty of any comic book!. I would go into details, but I don't want to spoil anything. I just loved it so much that playing the normal, new game plus, and I am the night mode was a total pleasure. The only "but" is that I consider it to be too short, compared with Arkham City, but it is compensated by the many side stories that are allowed by the Most Wanted missions.- You gotta love Barbara Gordon <3- I do think this game makes the Batman to be more a detective than the previous games, which is a very fun thing to play. It's kinda easy thou, since the Batman does everything for you. - If you can, buy the DLC Cold, Cold Heart. The way they explain the origins of Mr. Freeze is stunning! - The gameplay is, as always, something intuitive. I played Arkham City like... two years ago? and now I just graved the PS3 controller (yes, **** you, Microsoft!) and it was like riding a bike... people don't forget!- Getting all the collectibles, all the upgrades, all the tags, everything, will give you lots and lots of hours of gameplay. I did reach 100 hours of gaming just with the singleplayer mode (my brother also played the game, so, I didn't actualy play that amount of time). I might have taken my time, thou, I'm sure you can do it faster.About the price, yes, 30 dollars for all the time I played is worthy, but yet, that amount of money for just one game is kinda too much for me. I got this game during the Summer Sales, and those 7.5 USD I did spend for this game are one of the best buying I have ever made. But, If you're ok about paying 30 USD for one game, I'm telling you, DO IT!! you wont regret!.I can't really talk about the multiplayer mode. I'm not too much into playing online, then I just tried it for a while. It was fun.Summary: GO FOR IT!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 6
												I recently finished Batman : Arkham Origins. Always been a huge fan of the Arkham series and this game did not disappoint! I played it for around 12.5 hours, completed the story and most of the side quests (aside from Enigma and the escaped inmates)It's definitely a solid game and I personally feel it deserves 7.5/10. It was well worth the 9.98$ I spent (the game and its season pass cost me 4.99$ each), couldn't be happier! Thank Gaben for Steam Sales! That being said, I doubt I would be this cheerful had I paid the full price for the game and the season pass (19.99$ each). As you all know, no game is perfect and there were a few things that bugged me. Of course, there were also some positive points about this very successful game by WB Games Montréal, so let's talk about them. Starting with the good stuff.*Boss fights - each boss fight felt unique and intense. The devs impressed me in this category. These fights were fun and left me wanting for more.*Setting - What can I say? It's always fun to glide around Gotham City in the middle of winter, looking for thugs to beat up and serve some sweet justice.*Story & Dialogue - They did a very good job in this department, plus the cut scenes were really good. I especially enjoyed how well Batman and Alfred worked together. The butler's banter and affection for Bruce adds a little something to the game.*Fast Travel - Nice little addition to the series, after playing the game for hours and hours, you may want to skip gliding across districts and just take the Batwing.*Solving Crimes -  The crimes are one of the highlights of the game. The Bat is the world's greatest detective so it's always a pleasure watching him work.Now to list some of the small complaints I've got....*A longer story - I could not help myself from wanting more! I think I finished the main story in just 8 or 9 hours. Would be great if the story was just a little bit longer.*I badly wanted to wear other suits but I had to finish the main story first! That was not the case in Arkham City as the developers released the cheat codes. Wish they would have done something similar for Origins.*I noticed only policemen, thugs and victims were out on the streets. I wish there were more people that I can see and interact with. I think the reason that they were indoors was because of a curfew but I wanted to see more people in Gotham. Maybe a girl is being mugged and I get to save her. An old couple walking in the park and suddenly there are thugs who want to cause trouble. Batman just so happens to be around and saves the day. Something like that.Again, they're all very minor and I am happy with the game. Thank you to everyone involved in making this game! I highly recommend it! Looking back, I still feel that there was not enough time between Origins and Arkham City to make any revolutionary changes...in other words, not enough innovation but I can't deny that it is a damn good game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 14, 2014
												(I don't recommend this game. I somewhat-recommend it. There is no in between for Steam reviews, but that is exactly how I feel with this title.)My initial thoughts on this game were overwhelmingly negative; I found myself uninstalling it after 8 grueling hours of stressing over when the next game breaking glitch would occur and it felt refreshing to rid myself of this game's torture. However, I attempted a new game recently just because I had a hankering for some Batman: Arkham-style combat and here I am now, having just finished the campaign without a single save-corrupting, fall-through-the-floor, get-stuck-in-a-building-glitch occuring. And, I have to say that now that I've experienced the game the way it was meant to be experienced I can say that this is a deserving entry in the Arkham series, from a creative standpoint. Strictly. From a creative standpoint.Why is it a creative standpoint you ask? Because the developers of Origin are technologically inept and couldn't program better than a monkey with a brain tumor. Okay, that might be a little too much, but seriously, let me tell you about these developers.Warner Brothers Montreau's first game was Batman: Arkham City Armored Edition. It was a special edition Wii U version of the award winning Batman: Arkham City, and it was alright. It was essentially Arkham City with a little gloss and a dash of confetti to spice it up. Then they made a web-based game that I don't know anything about.Then they made Batman: Arkham Origins. This game.Now get this: The developer has worked with this engine before, with the Armored Edition of Arkham City. Now they're using the same map and the same engine ONCE MORE, except this time their making an entirely new game instead of just an enhanced edition.So you'd think they'd be fairly competent with their game's techincal quality right?Nope. Nada. Nuh-uh. Sorry. Zip. Zilch. NO.The game was released with more bugs than a bug petting zoo set on a planet inhabited entirely by humanoid bug creatures. OK, they were rushed by the publisher! Big deal! Ok, sure, maybe they were "rushed" for the release. HOWEVER, get this, in February the developers stated the following: "The team is currently working hard on the upcoming story DLC and there currently are no plans for releasing another patch to address the issues that have been reported on the forums,"and later that the game:"will unfortunately no longer be addressed."They did say they would fix gamebreaking and progression stopping issues somewhere during that article, however those issues still exist, so it doesn't matter.HAHAHAHAHAHAHHAHAHA! YOU'RE NOT GOING TO PATCH YOUR GAME!? HAHAHAHAHAHAHA, OH GOD I'M GOING FULL ON JOKER HERE HAHA HA HA!Another interesting thing: the game hasn't had a patch since April, if you look at the Steam news under the game. So it's true. The game is forgotten. Completely inexplicably forgotten, for no reason other than that the developers just said no.Now that this rant is over, I'll tell you why I think Arkham Origins is a good Batman game.The following pros and cons are in the context of this game being the same game as Arkham City, which it pretty much is, but with a different story. So feel free to add any of the pros and cons for that game into here.Pros+ Combat is improved greatly; there are several new enemy types, each a joy to fight. Combat is also smoother, and the animations seem to flow better.+ Graphics are better. They're not next-gen, in fact they're essentially Arkham City's graphics just enhanced with new visual effects here and there.+ Story is awesome. As much as I disdain some aspects of this game, notably the developers, I applaud the plot here. It draws heavily upon Batman mythos and one of my favorite Batman graphic novels: The Killing Joke. Though I suppose the writers had nothing to do with the programming so huzzah for the writers!+ The game is generally more cinematic, with superior cut scenes when compared to the previous two entries.+ New voice actors for Batman and Joker were well cast and do an excellent job+ Character design is awesome, Copperhead looks genuinely cool, Bane is actually treated as Bane for once (super strong, but also super smart) Deathstroke looks cool.An interesting addition to Origins was the detective segments, which are greatly improved over the previous games' attempts. However, I'm not going to add this as a specific Pro since i believe that it's simply not significant enough, they're essentially pseudo-quicktime events that look cool but nothing more.Cons- The game is buggy. Very. Very buggy.- The developers do not care about their customers.- The game heavily relies on rehashing content from the first two games and rarely adds anything of its own.- The open world here is empty and less interesting. It may seem like there are more things to do in Origins when compared to City, but in actuallity there isn't a lot. Collecting extortion files is boring compared to solving riddles, the side missions are boring and not as well written, the random goon voices you'll hear throughout the city are downright dreadful to listen to, they never say anything cool or funny and you'll hear the same lines OVER and OVER the entire game. I remember smirking and being genuinely interested in what the goons in Arkham City had to say. Here? Nope. Also, I hate to make this single con in an already long-winded review so long, but the opening of Arkham City was seriously cool, wheareas the opening here is very, very lackluster. Sorry, I just needed to say that.I'm not going to add a con for this, since it wouldn't really be fair, but I always note when games have Nvidia's Physx technology. Unless you have an Nvidia graphics card or a NASA processor, you can't enable this without suffering massive FPS drops. In game there's lots of cool cloth simulation and papers/flyers flying about among other things when you have it activated. It's been said elsewhere and I'll say it here, my graphics card is capable of these things but Nvidia, being a greedy company made it to where you simply cannot efficiently use this technology on anything other than Nvidia cards. Games should be played the way the developers meant them to be played, not the way greedy companies meant them to be played (yes, Nvidia pun).In all, I'd give Arkham Origins a 6/10. It's worth a playthrough if you liked the first games, for its story and the improvements made to combat. If you've never played an Arkham title, please go back and play Arkham Asylum or City first.I'd rate the developers of this game a 4/10. The only reason they don't go any lower is because somewhere within that cesspool of "gaming development" there are writers and creative directors who did a remarkable job trying to follow up an award winning series with their own take. And for that, I feel they deserve a commendation. For the rest of them? Please learn how to program before making a AAA-title, and always put technical stability above more content. How can we play the new content if we can't play the game? Oh, you hear that? I think it's the sound of "logic".WARNING: Know this if you buy the game, there are still game breaking bugs present. You MAY run into them, and you MAY lose hours of progress, though some people never even experience one of them, others, like myself ran into TWO in my first 8 hours. It took three new games before I finally was able to beat the game. There are some workarounds out there for the majority of them, as well as backing up your saves.TL;DR: The game is okay and worth it for fans of the series but the developers used mostly rehashed content, then botched the rehashed content somehow producing a truck load of bugs and now refuse to fix it and instead want to make more money with DLC.

content:
Posted: March 21, 2015
												this is a spoilerfree review of the entire gameI have no idea why this arkham game is getting so much more♥♥♥♥♥♥thrown at. Ill review it on its own but let me at least say that compared to the other games it holds up just as well. like seriously I imagined it being a monstrous piece of♥♥♥♥♥♥becuse unlike arkham asylum and arkham city I never see it being talked about let alone glorified which kind of made it look like a mistake that should be forgotten. nevertheless it wasnt.The story is pretty much what you'd expect. You are batman and you are trying to keep the people of gotham safe and put all the bad guys in the jails hospital. The bad guys are almost all very well known classic batvillains. gameplaywise you do 3 things:1 fly around in the city going from one sidequest or quest to another (the city being so big that you will probably use quicktravel at some point.) the mechanics of grappling and flying are very well done. you dont exactly controll where you grapple though which can lead to you going to places you didnt want to go to, but not very often. in this open world you can also get a ton of collectibles. (I miss the way the riddler presented those though)2: melee beat ups. here the classic combo-fighting style the series has become known for shines. and despite different types of enemies it isnt that hard to win a fight most of the time.3: stealth. and here is my problem. I SUCK at stealth. Hitman and dishonored always became a shooter at some point for me. one of the problems I have here though is that the controls are somewhat impresize somtimes. like I just wanna slide in a ventilation shaft and I stylishly throw myself over a railing towards the enemy. or I try to silently and deadly land behind an enemy and smack on the ground in front of him. that being said though you have a lot of gadgets to assist you. so maybe if you dont suck you will have fun here to. I got frustrated enough to ignore one of the bad guys who was only accesable via sidequest, because it was a stealth fight with him. I watched a vid on what happens though and its not very story relevant or interesting.and also I guess 4: boss battles, but those are usually a combination of 2, 3 and a couple gadgets.the looks are good enough but I have to say I am not an FPS junkie meaning I dont cry when the framerate drops beneath 60 FPS because I dont even know what that would look like. to me it really never was an issue. other technical issues are occasinal bugs and glitches. somtimes they even can be gamebreaking. thats basicaly all the negative stuff I have to say.If you liked the other arkham games you will like this one to and if you are new to the series this is as good a game to start with as the others, with the advantage of being a prequel and therefor letting you experience everything chronologically if you start here.

content:
Posted: May 14, 2015
												This game is good & comparable to Arkham City in many ways.  In fact, a lot of assets from AC look like they were used in this game.  The downside is it's not AC & it's hard to say whether it's better or worse than AC in general because there are a lot of issues with this game that keep it from greatness, but it also adds a lot more to the game as well.PROS-Large open City to Explore (roughly 3-4x larger than AC)-More Villains & Boss Fights-Same great combat system-Even more gadgets & upgradesCONS-Bugs & Glitches-Performance Issues (DX10 Fix Needed)-Feels Copy/Pasted from AC-WB has no intentions of fixing what's brokeFEATURESA good example of something good this game adds is the way you unlock certain abilities by completing challenges.  This may seem tedious at first & in the end it actually is, but it does add a bit more depth to how you earn & unlock certain gadgets.  The downside is all the gadgets in this game are all just carbon copies from AC with very few new additions.  The best new addition to your arsenal would be the Grapnel Hook which allows you to silently take out enemies from a distance or crowd control during combat.  Another new addition is the Concussion Grenade but I found it fairly useless.  It's only use is crowd controlling one target & it only stuns for about a second.  It's hot key is also set up in such a way that it's hard to quickfire so I never found myself using it.There are also detective segments that are kind of interactive cut scenes where you rewind/fast forward to find clues hidden in the area.  These aren't a huge addition & don't really make you feel like a detective since it just feeds you everything you need to know.  It would have been more interesting to have actual puzzles or something to make you feel like a detective looking for clues at a crime scene like in L.A. Noire.  How is Batman the "World's Greatest Detective" if he just lets his computer do all the work for him?The campaign in this game is done very well & is probably the only thing in this game that's better than AC.  It's set up around the period where Batman first meets The Joker & the main story is about Black Mask hiring all sorts of assassins to "Kill The Bat" during Christmas Eve, with a good plot twist near the end. It's extremely well done.  The voice actors are all A grade & the guy playing Joker does an excellent job of imitating Mark Hamill's Joker.  Honestly, you probably wouldn't know it isn't MH playing him unless you read the credits.  There is also a lot more to do in this game than in AC.  Well over twice the amount of content, with a city almost 3x (maybe more?) it's size.  This means more collectibles & many more Riddler items you will need to collect in order to beat him.  There is also a fast travel where you call your jet to pick you up & drop you off.  You do need to unlock towers that Riddler has locked down in order for your auto-pilot to find you & you can't unlock them all right away as some require gadgets that you unlock through the story.   The city is huge & full of things to find & there's also random "Crimes in Progress" that happen periodically that will keep you busy well after completing the game.There are also several more enemies & boss fights in this game.  The downside is that all the boss fights are full of fake difficulty.  Pretty much every boss in this game (with a few exceptions) you fight along side his minion cohorts.  Now the other games did this as well, but when they did it they gave you opportunities to take out many minions at once either by controlling bane or a giant mutant, but this one is set up with little to no actual devices for that.  Sometimes the boss may hit a minion, but most of the time he'll focus on you & when he does actually hit a minion by accident little to no damage is taken & it mostly serves as a short stun effect.GLITCHES & ISSUESThis game also has several glitches that WB has no intention of ever fixing & these range from minor failings to major oversights.  One in particular is in the beginning of the game in the first boss battle with Killer Croc.  When it triggers he will constantly flash invisible & most of the sound will stop working properly.  Another glitch involves interrogating certain enemies similar to Riddler henchmen in AC, except they can't be KO'd however this KO invulnerability will sometimes bug out & render the interrogates unable to interact with & requires a reload of a previous save.  Another annoying glitch is the 2x enemy speed that sometimes happens in free flow focus mode.  Enemies are supposed to be slower but sometimes they'll be much faster & nearly impossible to counter.  There's also a glitch that happens during gliding which seems to be an animation bug where you constantly go in/out of a dive.  It's not a huge issue but it should be noted.  Civilian faces are also very messed up looking with their eyebrows stretching beyond their forehead because of the forced expression that is on their faces.  First time I saw this I thought it was a glitch, but nope.  Every civilian seems to have high-arced eyebrows.  Also, they all seem to be men for some reason.  I guess WB didn't want to depict civilian women being attacked by male villains & then being saved by a male hero possibly to avoid SJW propaganda backlash.PERFORMANCEI found myself having to use a 'fix' to put the game in DX10 mode in order to actually play this game.  If you're experiencing any slowdown, long loading, or anything else you may need to do this as well.  This fix is mainly for those of us running older hardware.You'll need to find BMengine.ini in your game files, open it with notepad, CTRL+F "AllowD3D11".Set "AllowD3D11" to FALSE & "AllowD3D10" to TRUE.  This usually fixes several performance issues that people experience with older/lesser graphics cards while playing the game.  If you still experience problems try setting both to FALSE.  This will force the game to run in DX9 mode.The only feature the DX11 mode adds is better graphics & shading so if you don't mind the graphical downgrade & rather have a playable experience on an older machine this fix OVERALLOverall this game is good, but not as good as AC imo.  It's got a lot more to offer content wise but at times it can be too difficult & it's lack of polish when compared to its predecessors shows greatly.  It's still highly recommendable & worth playing.  You may even like it more than AC as a lot of people do.  For me it's great but not quite better than AC due to it's technical issues & lack of polish when it comes to glitches & animations.  If this were a more polished game it would be better than AC, hands down.

Posted: April 10, 2014
												Batman Arkham Origins is a game made simply to cash in on the Arkharm's series success, so I was suprised when I found out that the game itself doesn't feel as cold and calculated as one would expect from a cash grab. Warner Bros. Montereal has hands down made one of my most favorite Batman origin stories to date. What they do here is something Hollywood should take notice of, if they ever decide to reboot Batman entirely. We don't need to see how the man became the bat all we need to see is what happens once he dons the cape and suit. In this regard I feel they peform quite amazingly. Now onto the gameplay, which still feels good even after three games. Some people would start getting tired, but I really do feel that this is Batman and it is the best way to play him. The gameplay overall escpecially the fighting is more refined than ever before. Although I do feel that the Predator sections are not designed as well in the past. Most of the times it feels like they are because what's a Batman game without making people scared ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥? All in all it's a strong game and a great entry in the seires. The sidequests themselves I believe are really good although some lack the same creativity that in shown in Mad Hatter's story line. Deadshot for one is an example of it just coming up to getting a very tricky predator sequence that you have to pass to defeat him. Not as aswesome as the Wonderland you explore in Mad Hatters quest. FOR PEOPLE: Who want more Batman! The game is great and the storyline I dare say is second only to Arkham City.NOT FOR PEOPLE: Who can't see past the cash grab that it is, fine don't play it and you will just be missing out on a really great game.

content:
Posted: July 4, 2015
												If I understand the general consensus correctly, the main criticism of  Arkham Origins  seems to be that it's just "more of the same" when compared to its awesome predecessors  Arkham Asylum  and  Arkham City.  And while I agree that  Origins  suffers from over-familiarity with the series' bag of tricks, I still enjoyed the hell out of it and would recommend it to any fan of the previous two games.It is true that, by now, taking down a roomful of thugs using Arkham's combat or stealth mechanics has become routine (assuming you've played the first two games). But it's also still incredibly fun. And given the series' typical excellence in storytelling and character design, it's always a thrill to return to the Arkhamverse.I'll leave out a specific discussion of the story, since some of the biggest joys in the Arkham games are the inevitable plot twists and surprise guest appearances. Suffice it to say that  Origins  boasts an impressive rogues gallery of familiar and new faces alike. Unlike in the previous two entries, the intensity of the narrative doesn't rise to a fever pitch so much as it maintains a steady (though never quite scalding) burn. For that reason, the ending feels rather abrupt.  Origins  also lacks the previous two games' intriguing (if largely unexplored) awareness of the hypocrisy of Batman's extra-legal crusade against crime. Nevertheless, it's still superior comic-book material; it won't make you think, but it will thoroughly entertain you.Aside from complaints about the over-familiar gameplay,  Origins  was also notorious for having bugs upon its release. Playing it in 2015, I didn't encounter anything game-breaking, even though I ran it on a laptop that I bought a couple years ago. I  did  run across a few glitches -- occasional stuttering or enemies getting trapped in corners -- but these only amounted to minor annoyances, and may have been due to my decidedly less-than-state-of-the-art setup. Overall, I think that the criticism of  Origins  as "more of the same" rings true, but still doesn't detract from it as an enormoursly entertaining experience. While I never got quite the same high from it as I did from  Asylum  or  City,  I was still satisfied throughout. Highly recommended, especially if you're looking for something to tide you over while  Arkham Knight  remains in limbo.

												More of the same.That's really all that can describe this game. If you enjoyed Arkham City tremendously, you'll find Arkham Origins entertaining. The gameplay is the same, the story is very much familiar, and the characters themselves are much the same with a few cameo appearances.Still, the place this game excels is in its storytelling and the environments. Sure, it's more of the same, but you really get a feel for Gotham this time around. From the sewers to the Royal Hotel, you get plenty of sight seeing opportunities.If you're a fan of Batman, or the DC Universe in general, this game should give you a fun few hours.

												If you've played the previous Arkham games, you'll know what to expect. I had a lot of fun kicking♥♥♥♥♥as Batman for the 3rd time in this series, but it has gotten a bit repetitive. Some of the villains have been previously used and the gameplay is pretty much the same. The boss battles are somewhat interesting, but in this particular game they're not as memorable as the previous games. Maybe it all depends on the difficulty setting you play through, but you could generally beat these bosses in 1-2 tries. I'm not saying they should be impossible to get through, but they were slightly above the combat you face from regular enemies. Still, it is interesting to play as a rookie Batman. I give this game a 3.5/5 and I recommend it.
