content:
Posted: June 15, 2015
												TLDR: The Batman Arkham saga continues in this prequel to Arkham Asylum and Arkham City. Arkham Origins had technical problems (bugs) but as far as I’m concerned, it’s still a fun game.  8/10If you’ve played the 2 previous Batman Arkham games you may remember that they were developed by a company called Rocksteady, who did a great job on them. This time around the game development was taken over by Warner Bros, and the quality has diminished, though the general feel of the game is similar to the previous games. Since Arkham Origins is a prequel, Batman is kind of making his debut in Gotham City with no allies other than his trusty butler Alfred. Nobody knows who or what he is and most people don’t even believe he exists. Gotham city is ruled by gangs and corrupt police, and just like the previous Batman games practically everyone you find on the streets is a thug just asking to have his head bashed (including a large number of cops). Your primary nemesis in this game is the crime boss Black Mask (not sure why he wears the mask since people already know his identity) though there’s a lot more going on behind the scenes. Black Mask has put a huge bounty on Batman’s head, and a bunch of world class assassins are here to collect, including some familiar faces: Bane, Deathstroke, Firefly, etc.Just like the first 2 Arkham games, Arkham Origins is a third person half stealth/half beat ’em up action game making extensive use of the grapnel boost, which helps launch Batman into the air so he can soar around with his cape like a hang glider. Most of the bat tools from the previous games appear but the key mapping for some of them has been changed for some reason, and if you play the games back to back like I did, there may be some confusion as to why the developers made certain changes. The flow of combat is very similar to Arkham City though, so if you have decent reflexes you should be able to counter just about any enemy attack, as expected. A couple other noticeable differences from the previous games are the reworked skills system and the reduced number of collectibles. Now the skills that you can unlock at level ups are in a sort of horizontal tree, whereas in the first 2 games you could just pick whatever you wanted. If you’re like me and do a lot of side quests, you may find yourself unable to buy the good skills for a while since they’re locked behind story progress requirements. No critical hits for about half the game this time! As for the fewer/easier Riddler collectibles, this change is welcome to me since I’m not a big fan of searching out 500 collectibles in a game playthrough. Unfortunately to actually face the Riddler you still need to get all of them, which is a challenge even if you are actively trying to do it, armed with an online guide.Pros:+The story is pretty good, as expected from a Batman Arkham game. Some people have said that the game uses “third tier” villains, and I guess I can’t argue that point. But as long as they provide an interesting plot I don’t care. +This time the game encompasses the entire Gotham City, not just a small section of it (although it really isn’t that much bigger than Arkham City). The city map is now large enough that “fast travel” has been added, where you can quickly move around the map via the Batwing jet drop-off.  Again however, the city is filled with thugs to beat up, and since Arkham Origins is kind of an RPG (level ups and skill points) you may want to just glide through the city looking for fights to level up.+With the 8 “master” assassins who took up Black Mask’s bounty hunt, there are a lot of boss fights, each with different ways to take down your foes. My favorite is probably the Firefly boss fight.+There’s a pretty comprehensive multiplayer system, where you can level up and play as either a hero or villain, though there wasn’t as many players online as I’d like. The game is really better as single player.Cons:-This may not affect a lot of people, but for the first week or so, I couldn’t even get the game to start properly. I could get to the “click to start” splash screen but once I clicked, the game would crash out. The WB support was no help, they didn’t even respond to my message for about 2 weeks (and then it was an unhelpful reply). Fortunately, I found the answer online buried in some forums. (I had to force the game into Direct X 9). The last time I played the game, there were no game breaking bugs, so most problems seem to have been addressed by the game developers. I only fell through the floor a couple of times.Overall, like many AAA game titles, there were problems that were probably due to releasing the game too early, but it’s been a while now and the big stuff has been taken care of. If you enjoyed Batman Arkham Asylum and Arkham City, you should enjoy Arkham Origins. It’s just not much in the way of improvement.

content:
Posted: November 9, 2013
												Sadly, Arkham Origins can be easily summarized with a couple of words - conveyor belt cash grab. And it really is sad that WB Montreal didn't have the courage to try anything new of their own but instead take the previous game, tack on a surprisingly short story and do a compulsory check list on previous features which are here once against just because it would've been noticed if they weren't. Game itself delivers a tried and true Arkham series' gameplay, although with a healthy helping of bugs which are thankfully being patched out on regular basis, but has a certain degree of trouble when it comes to breakneck pace of the story, perhaps indicating cut content which could've evened out the pacing a bit. Challenge mode is a worthwhile addition that will have you sinking in a few hours for the experience and the addition of multiplayer works out surprisingly well all things considered, although it's probably going to be forgotten very quickly because it's simply not why you bought the game in the first place, unfortunately.

content:
Posted: December 29, 2013
												Batman Arkham Origins puts you in the shoes of a "rookie" batman,which seems to rely in brute force over outsmarting his opponents like in the other installments of the series.This is not a bad thing, as you play the game, you can see the evolution of batman from just a "myth" to the feared legend he has always been.Gameplay wise, the mechanics of the game have been polished completely, and are now better than ever, however, some of the boss fights, while amazing. tend to become repetitive and lack luster once you are halfway done the bosse's health bar.The series has also recieved a graphic overhaul and looks way better than its brothers do, however, the Physx implementation  is terribly done and leaves a lot of desire, as the papers and strings that use this seem to run at a whole different frame rate and look out of place. Another inclusion of physx is the "dynamic" snow in which Batman and his enemies leave footprints/trail in the snow. However,in some part of the game the use of Physx means you are going to take a HUGE impact in perfromance,even if you have a really beefy computer; and I don't mean just a 10-15 fps drop, no, I mean going from smooth as butter, to as jittery as Jell-O;when I reached that point of the game, I had to turn of Physx to continue playing,because leaving it on would have meant playing at around 15 fps.Story wise, the game is marvelous, as it expands the background of the Dark Knight in almost a comic/graphic novel like fashion. There are many references/homages that comic fans will love to see being put in the game.As an Arkham series game, I see why it might not be as well received as the other games,as it bring almost nothing new to the table.  But if you take it as a standalone Batman game, it might be the best one yet, if it makes any sense.9/10Computer used to run the game:i7 4770kGTX 78016 GB RAMetc,etcResolution:1080pMaxed out game settings,had to turn of physx late in the game for reasons explained above.

content:
Posted: October 25, 2013
												This is a prequel to the Arkham Series dating back to Year One of Batman. Generally, the developers of this game are not Rocksteady. Because of this, most Arkham fans pondered whether it is worth the money to preorder or not. Some, of course, don't have a brain to think and just preorder, crying with joy and bragging like brats. I bought the game after some videos and confirmations of its upcoming gameplay and dlcs. Season Pass is also bought too. This game has been worth the wait. Although, it reminds me of "The Dark Knight Rises" game app on the appstore.The impact sounds are the same and the bridge are from The Dark Knight Rises.The timeline in this game is a "younger" Bruce (Batman) who is more inexperienced than the one in Arkham City. This concludes that the Batman in Origins will be a bit slower in combat and has a brutal combat stance (due to his earlier age when he was more enraged at crime after his father and mother's death).This game offers you a chance to play as deathstroke (If you preorder) and a chance to see Batman in his past. Unfortunately, the game seems to have the same textures and buildings as Arkham City. On the bright side, they tweaked (from what I heard) over 300 things such as removing objects and replacing with snow and such to give a better "Year One" atmosphere.  Moreover, there are more thugs spawns everywhere and new types of enemies such as the "Martial Artists" whom can counter your attacks and strike back at you.Personally, the game has its bugs and the developers have created a multiplayer mode which may inspire Rocksteady, who have hinted on another project which seems to be "bigger and better" as told by Kevin Conroy.For anyone feeling the urge to brutally takedown thugs, beat combo scores, and the fluid combat system that Arkham City has excellently provided, play Arkham Origins.This game may be game of the year but there is GTA V. Unfortunately, GTA V may not be GOTY, I assume, since it did not release on PC which is one of the most used possessions gamers have. Batman Arkham Origins have released games for Wii U, PC, Xbox 360, PS VITA, Nintendo DS, and PS3. Batman Arkham Origins: Blackgate is another game players should look at which has been released for PS VITA and Nintendo DS. There is also an app on the appstore for Batman Arkham Origins which has the same game mechanism and gameplay as the Batman Arkham City one (previous game app). I have not reached the half of the game. All I can say is, there is significant amount of tasks to do and it clearly shows how much Batman needs to do AND done for Gotham City. To the developers, congratulations on the game release. Of course, the bugs need to be fixed, but the amount of comments in the forums practically show that the game is incredible and "epic."

content:
Posted: July 6, 2015
												Arkham Origins got a lot of criticism on release for being overly similar to it's predecessors, Asylum and City. Indeed, it isn't recognised as part of the official Arkham trilogy (which was recently concluded with Knight), and was farmed out to a different developer instead of Rocksteady. The criticism centred around this cash-grab mentality, that Warner Bros. wanted to simply make money off the Arkham IP.However, very little of this criticism was levelled at the game itself. Indeed, Origins is a fantastic game. It's definitely fair to say that Origins borrows heavily from its predecessors, and is short on original ideas. However, given how enjoyable the series' earlier titles were, it is difficult to complain at more of the same. The story is arguably better than Asylum or City, with a younger, darker Batman being exceptionally fun to play.It's unlikely to win the series any new fans, but, if you enjoyed Asylum and City, you'll get a lot out of Arkham Origins.

												I'm not sure why everyone seems to think this is the worst of the batman games.  It's just as great as Arkham City, but with better graphics and more features (the bat cave, fast travel, faster grappling, etc).  The only thing I regret about this, is that I didn't play it before the other two games, considering it's the prequel.  One day I plan on playing all 3 (soon to be 4) in order, and it will be glorious!  This game is not simply a regurgitation of the other batman games, it brings it's own innovative aspects to the batman series.  It's story is both unique and entertaining.All in all, this is my favorite Batman: Arkham game yet and I highly recommend it.  10/10

												Origins is not a dramatically different game compared to City. The combat is largely the same and features most of the same gadgets with a few new ones such as the shock gloves. The city is similar and there are certainly many familiar elements but there are also new places to see and plenty of new location for fights. The boss fights are great, more fluid and fun than City, particularly the Deathstroke fight. The game is not revolutionary but if you are a fan of the previous games then Origins is a very solid addition and well worth playing. It adds a lot of small things and the seemingly large changes like the difference in voice actors end up not being significant changes after all.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 6
												Arkham Origins is the third game in the Arkham series... although serving as a prequel to Arkham Asylum, this game came out in 2013. The voice actors Kevin Conroy (Batman) and Mark Hamill (Joker) do not reprise their role in this game, although the alternative do sound acceptable, it is sad to lose their iconic feel. This is my least favorite of the Arkham Game series for good reason that the plot and the gameplay did not live up to its previous games or next to come game, the plot seemed like something just written so they could make another Arkham game and the map felt like we had been there before... for good reason. I constantly had trouble with the counter attack moves not working, and that really bugged me and prevented the smooth fun combat that the original games had. Although the graphics were still amazing, especially in the cut-scenes, it didn't make up for its boring plot and sad mechanics. This game also lacked the intriguing suspense both Arkham Asylum and Arkham City had therefore really making this game feel like a very slow halt in the series that made me question whether I bought another Arkham game or just gave the studio money. Either way this game is not the worst game out there, it is playable... kinda... and sometimes fun, and I would recommend it if it weren't for one thing, and that is that it is not essential to play if you are playing the Arkham game series, which since you are looking at the third game in the franchise I assume you are. It adds nothing to the game series plot other than an unneeded origin for a certain character, and it is highly unnecessary to spend your money and time on this game when you could spend it on Arkham Knight or just put more time into replaying the previous games.

And if the new one comes out i do not recommend buying it either. The first 2 arkham asylum and arkham city yes i do recommend those games. Arkham origins and any game after it? Not so much.

I played through Batman Arkham City three times and I've faced some tough bosses with Batman before but Deathstroke in this game is different. I've tried to kill him over 300 times and I've never come close. I gave up and quit the game. If a boss is so hard that you can't get past him after 300 tries it's time to admit you suck and it's never going to be fun for you. I have 90 other games in my library to play that I'm good at and are all better than this game including two other Batman titles. In my opinion making Deathstroke such a difficult boss was a game dev mistake.

content:
Posted: September 16, 2016
												After around 44 hours of non-stop gameplay and content, I finally decided to write a review.Batman Arkham Origins is one of the best cinematic batman games ever. Note that I said 'cinematic'. Because the story and plot really makes you feel that you're watching a movie, even quick time events are added mid cinematics for more involvement. Don't hear what others say about the glitches. I rarely even see them, only glitching out while gliding at certain times.Gameplay is as refined as ever, brought over from akrham city. And the boss fights, oh the lovely boss fights. Sure, some of it have rehashed movesets from the previous games, but mostly freaking amazing, far better than that arkham tank game (if you know what i mean). Story is interesting and encourages you to finish it, and there are some very emotional moments that i dont want to spoil. Some skins are made free by completing certain objectives which is really appreciated. I really enjoy the overall game as I play this gritty, violent batman who doesn't even bat an eye to break every bone he sees to get what he wants. In short, if you are looking for a batman game set in winter, has awesome boss fights, amazing story, buy this gameright now during its weekend sale. The DLC is also worth it too, unfortunately there are no sale prices for that.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 14, 2013
												Taking over from Rocksteady for the third game, WB Games Montréal tries to reach the heights of the first two Arkham games with an interestingg origin story of the Dark Knight. But can they live deliver and live up on the expectations? It's around two years after Bruce has put on the mask for the first time, so he still supposed to be a newbie at his outings at night. This Batman, however can act and look like a beginner but his moves tell us otherwise.When it comes to gameplay Origins is almost a clone to Arkham City. The combos, special moves and counters look and feel like the same. There are time when you feel the new team tried to innovate here and there, but those, like countering enemies, aren't decisive enough. On the other hand any game would be delighted to have a combat system like Arkham City, so in the matter of fact the gameplay still works perfectly. It's just that the innovation is missing, which is the game's greatest flaw. There are new gadgets, but even those are sometimes carbon copies of the missing ones, for example the Glue Grenade which has the exact same effect as the Freeze Grenade in Arkham City.One thing you can certainly be hyped for in the game is its story. The game delivers from that perspective putting in front of you a greatly crafted, interesting story which is furthermore amplified by the cast. The Joker, Bane, Black Mask star in the game but others have their important roles as well. It's a tale that is on par with the comic books. And one more word about the cast; even though the Batman's and Joker's voices has been replaced most of the time you won't notice any major difference as Roger Craig Smith and Troy Baker both make hard effort to genuinely impersonate those two epic characters.So, yes 8 assassins are after you on Christmas Eve to kill you even though you aren't as big player in Gotham as you'll become. Interestingly not all of them get the same amount of space. One thing the games does very well are the boss fights. In the first two games there weren't any really challenging and grand boss fights as we had hoped for (except Poison Ivy), but in this game almost every boss has its differently paced fight. There is a different strategy to beating every one of them. This keeps the games varied and you'll always look forward to the next boss. While beating up assassins and progressing in the story there is the moment when you suddenly realize that "this is THE time". The time when those two will meet...for the first time...and you are about to witness it all. It's a thing the creators weren't allowed to screw up. It had to be epic. And it is. The time when Joker reflects on his first meeting with Batman is just unbelievably awesome.Arkham Origins is a really good looking game but there is very little innovation over Arkham City. It's not the best looking game of 2013, but looks great enough to hold up with the competition. Mainly the character models are those that stand out. Batman, Joker, Bane and all of the major characters look detailed. On the audio front it isn't as strong as City. Simply the prominent melodies aren't there that support you as the predator of the night. It's a bit of a disappointment.After you finish the main campaign, which shouldn't take longer than 8 hours, you can do the side-quests Arkham City style. The overall content here is somewhat less than in the second game, but you can easily squeeze out 20 hours by searching every inch of Gotham for data packs and tags on wall. What is very discouraging that WB Montréal didn't have the balls to bring some innovation where they really could have. And those are the side quests, which are again mostly copies of those in Arkham City. There you had to look for phones by the time the counter hit zero, here you have to race to bombs. Before you had to collect question marks, here you have to pick up data packs. The names and locations are changed, but most of the work you have to do remained the same. If this wasn't a Batman game everybody would call it a rip-off. Crime scene investigations are the one that stands out. Those are really new and fun, but it's not groundbreaking. We appreciate the effort though. When you're finished you can fight in the familiar challenge mode or the new multiplayer.Batman: Arkham Origins is a super game that took everything that made Arkham Origins a stellar title and kept all of them. However, they played it very safe introducing only a handful innovation none of which is strong enough to hold out. The side-quests are a real disappointment. When you are like Arkham City you are great, but after playing that game for 40 hours it's not enough just to be like it. Fans will appreciate the story, but everything else (missions, quests, places, etc.) is something we have seen already. And this is why the game will divide fans and players.Rating: 85/100; Replay Value: 3/5; To Beat: 8 hours (main campaign), 20+ hours (with collectibles); Played on: normal.

content:
Posted: April 4, 2014
												So, the third series of Batman: Arkham. It is a prequel, and the story is not that bad. The good things are there is multiplayer now, you can go to the batcave whenever you want, and new batsuits. The combat system is pretty much the same but with new enemies. And new gadjets, and you can talk to Alfred. Also plenty of challenge maps. The BIGGEST issue with this game is all the game breaking bugs. First you got the bug when you go into a building and everything turns black and you can't go anywhere. The next one is the audio messes up sometimes. And sometimes you will glide under the world with the same thing as the first one, everything goes black and you can't do anything. There are other huge bugs and plenty of little bugs like when you start spinning when you glide (but that is a funny bug). Also with the multiplayer (I don't know if anyone else has this problem) most of the time you get a message saying "Steam connection has been dropped" and just brings you back to the menu. And the sad thing is you can't fix these bugs in game. Only the audio one and the multiplayer one (and by fixing the multiplayer you just keep trying to join matches). If you get the forever blackness one you actually have to look up a solution which I did and actually go to your files and type something in the data of the game. For my count, i'm saying no, BUT if you can handle all these bugs and have the solution to the forever blackness bugs, then I guess you can get it. It's pretty fun when it isn't constantly screwing up.

content:
Posted: April 5, 2014
												When Arkham Origins came out, it got a lot of bad press for being derivative and buggy. I hit the buggy parts fairly quickly (a crash-to-desktop involving WBID and a graphical glitch involving DX 11 enhancements) and the derivative part never really escapes Arkham Origins. I mean, it's not all that different from Arkham City, but is that a bad thing? Arkham City was pretty great. Arkham Origins is pretty good. I think it revisits too many of the villains from Asylum and City, and some of the gadgets are inexplicably similar to gadgets in City but not Asylum (despite being a prequel), but it's still a fun game. If you liked Batman: Arkham Asylum and Arkham City, you're going to like Arkham Origins. If you've never played either of those games, start with Arkham Asylum! It does a great job of making you feel like you're Batman within the frame of a 3D Metroidvania with an excellent combat system. And if you're still into it after you get through Asylum and City, then by all means, get Origins. But I wouldn't recommend making Origins your first Arkham game.

content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												A weird case of a game. It is the weakest entry in the Arkham trilogy, but it is nevertheless a good game in itself.Pros* Good story, maybe the best of the Arkham trilogy. The characters and their motivations are adapted to their situation. Beware that it is not Batman's origin story* Non-inventive but entertaining gameplay, slightly faster than its predecessor. Each boss feels different* Graphics are good and the crumbling snow is a welcome additionCons* Gotham City as an environment is very video-gamey* Bugs, some were game-breaking on launch and were fixed, others are still here and annoying* Visible lack of polish compared to the two other gamesDo as I did, and treat it as an expansion pack for Arkham City. Don't pay full-price for it, but WB Montreal showed some love in their youth enthusiasm and thus you should buy it on sale and enjoy it for what it is.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 28, 2014
												Origins was solid although not as broad as the previous two Batman games. The story was fun to follow although brief, and I was definitely done with punching people way before it was completed. The side quests added some variety although it wasn't long before I had to punch someone. The casefile recreations were very cool, mainly because I got to recreate someone punching someone else. There were some standout parts, including being the Joker for a bit, and solving the Riddler's many puzzles. The Mad Hatter mission was both unusual and interesting.  The stalking was still great fun- taking out 7 armed guards without any of them seeing you never got old. You also get to play through many of Batman's first encounters with most of the canon's characters. There were some negatives. Some of the missions didn't work, and the boss battles were fun usually until they add a hundred henchmen to it that you have to punch. It was also tough to 'fly' around the map because the grapnel options were more limited. The area seemed bigger here than in Arkham City, but I had to leg much of it. The final plus to note is the art. The buildings and the character visually of the city were simply amazing. It would have been fun to be able to explore some of these striking skyscrapers, but only mission oriented ones were open. The weather effects were also impressive-the snowy, gusty setting was immersive. This is defintely on par with the other games, but the shortest and weakest. The characters were fun to meet as a younger Batman, the missions were engaging and well connected. If you enjoyed the Asylum and City you will get into this. It was just a little tiring by the end, running the streets of a gorgeous landscape in a game that knows how to pull and pull it's punches.

content:
Posted: December 29, 2013
												Batman Arkham Origins puts you in the shoes of a "rookie" batman,which seems to rely in brute force over outsmarting his opponents like in the other installments of the series.This is not a bad thing, as you play the game, you can see the evolution of batman from just a "myth" to the feared legend he has always been.Gameplay wise, the mechanics of the game have been polished completely, and are now better than ever, however, some of the boss fights, while amazing. tend to become repetitive and lack luster once you are halfway done the bosse's health bar.The series has also recieved a graphic overhaul and looks way better than its brothers do, however, the Physx implementation  is terribly done and leaves a lot of desire, as the papers and strings that use this seem to run at a whole different frame rate and look out of place. Another inclusion of physx is the "dynamic" snow in which Batman and his enemies leave footprints/trail in the snow. However,in some part of the game the use of Physx means you are going to take a HUGE impact in perfromance,even if you have a really beefy computer; and I don't mean just a 10-15 fps drop, no, I mean going from smooth as butter, to as jittery as Jell-O;when I reached that point of the game, I had to turn of Physx to continue playing,because leaving it on would have meant playing at around 15 fps.Story wise, the game is marvelous, as it expands the background of the Dark Knight in almost a comic/graphic novel like fashion. There are many references/homages that comic fans will love to see being put in the game.As an Arkham series game, I see why it might not be as well received as the other games,as it bring almost nothing new to the table.  But if you take it as a standalone Batman game, it might be the best one yet, if it makes any sense.9/10Computer used to run the game:i7 4770kGTX 78016 GB RAMetc,etcResolution:1080pMaxed out game settings,had to turn of physx late in the game for reasons explained above.

content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												This game is getting a lot of hate from everyone, and I can't see why! If you are a batman fan, you must play this game. The story in my opinion is leagues ahead of the other two games. Sure the ending of Arkham City was shocking, but the rest was a long drawn out fetch quest. This game has a consistantly engaging story with character development for many characters like Alfred, Barbara, and Jim which creates much more interesting relationships between Batman and his allies. It is on the same level as the writing of Scott Snyder, Frank Miller, and Jeph Loeb. The new developers kept the combat system the same for the most part, with only minor tweaks. I don't understand everyones dislike of this decision. If they would have changed it, they would have gotten just as much hate. If it ain't broke don't fix it, and that method holds up in this game.They did however, greatly improve the boss fights. You feel like Batman fighting famous DC rougues. They are honestly some of the best boss fights I have played in a long time. With the industry moving away from boss fights, it was very refreshing to have such exceptionally epic battles with the assassin's. The city is a little bland, but it's no different than Arkham City. It's just empty streets filled with thugs to fight. The side quests aren't exceptional, but they are fun and make this game well worth the price. In my personal opinion, this is the best game in the arkham series. It may not have completely reinvented the series, but it improves on the previous iterations. If you are a Batman fan, or never have played the arkaham series before, this is a must-play. Don't believe the hate. The improvements the new developers made (fantastic story and epic boss fights) are massive improvements to the series.

content:
Posted: December 12, 2013
												Origins is not a dramatically different game compared to City. The combat is largely the same and features most of the same gadgets with a few new ones such as the shock gloves. The city is similar and there are certainly many familiar elements but there are also new places to see and plenty of new location for fights. The boss fights are great, more fluid and fun than City, particularly the Deathstroke fight. The game is not revolutionary but if you are a fan of the previous games then Origins is a very solid addition and well worth playing. It adds a lot of small things and the seemingly large changes like the difference in voice actors end up not being significant changes after all.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 18
Product received for free
												Pros:-Most of what was great about Arkham City returns-Some of your new abilities and gadgets are pretty handy-New voices do a good job and aren't just cheap imitations of the Rocksteady games' cast-Not a complete retread of City, though some things return-Fast travel is a godsendCons:-Not a whole lot of new things in this one (similar gadgets, similar sidequests, the map's just Arkham City long before it was Arkham City - with a new section added on, of course)-Textures can be pretty bad, and I don't know why-More glitches than City, such as gun mooks getting trapped in one place during predator encounters, or Batman flipping out in midair while glidingThis game is often called the weakest of the series, and I'll agree. This doesn't make the game bad, though - I still think it's a good game and will be enjoyable for anyone who played the other games, but it doesn't do a whole lot of new things to differentiate it from City. The technical problems are also surprising, since I had stable experience with Asylum and City. However, like I said, most of the good from City is back, which means fun times are still to be had. So, conclusion? Buy it if you think you'll like it, wait for a sale if you're not sure.

content:
Posted: May 24, 2015
												I'd also give it a thumb down if possible since I'm happy with the game and also very disappointed. Single player didn't innovate anything in comparison to Arkham city .. which is fine considering how grate it was. Look at it as a glorified expansion of A.City. Looks a bit different, plays the same. Story is fine, characters old and new both. Sound, voice acting as great as ever, and I'm very pleased to see how well they've optimized it for PC. I have a fairly old system and it runs smooth (certainly not maxed out..but still). And then there's online .... Now KEEP IN MIND that I bought the game almost 2 YEARS AFTER its RELEASE. From the first moment you press quick match you'll be hoping that you don't get disconnected during match making, or the game doesn't crash as soon as it may start. You'll still have a hard. Player controlled gangsters can ♥♥♥♥ Batman and Robin up very easy and very fast. Controls may seem the same, yet they work very differently. I had the fortune to get my first two matches after 30 minutes of trying to find a match that wont disconnect. Once I managed to start the match I'm chosen to be Bats which is cool and all ... if not for the fact that I ad no idea where to go, how to get closer than 5 feet of anyone without getting a a barrel of bullets in my face. They can find you ANYWHERE! It also doesn't help that I'm put as a lvl 2 player against lvl 200+ players. number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 16, 2016
												After around 44 hours of non-stop gameplay and content, I finally decided to write a review.Batman Arkham Origins is one of the best cinematic batman games ever. Note that I said 'cinematic'. Because the story and plot really makes you feel that you're watching a movie, even quick time events are added mid cinematics for more involvement. Don't hear what others say about the glitches. I rarely even see them, only glitching out while gliding at certain times.Gameplay is as refined as ever, brought over from akrham city. And the boss fights, oh the lovely boss fights. Sure, some of it have rehashed movesets from the previous games, but mostly freaking amazing, far better than that arkham tank game (if you know what i mean). Story is interesting and encourages you to finish it, and there are some very emotional moments that i dont want to spoil. Some skins are made free by completing certain objectives which is really appreciated. I really enjoy the overall game as I play this gritty, violent batman who doesn't even bat an eye to break every bone he sees to get what he wants. In short, if you are looking for a batman game set in winter, has awesome boss fights, amazing story, buy this gameright now during its weekend sale. The DLC is also worth it too, unfortunately there are no sale prices for that.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 5, 2015
Competence 101Arkham Origins is an interesting beast. A game that probably no one asked for, a quick fix for the Fall gaming season upon release and a title that is and always will be foreshadowed by "big brother" Rocksteady's Arkham City. It is a case of mapped out goals that are selected just right enough as to not upset what came before. And as a result, it ends up not really having an identity and being a stop-gap before the next big instalment that has now turned out to be Batman: Arkham Knight.The story here isn't particularly bad. It's simply serviceable. It's Christmas Eve and a fledgling vigilante Bat finds himself having to deal with a group of assassin's hired by a certain Roman Sionis (discovering alter egos is part of the fun) who want him rather dead. This motley crew has to kill this particularly grouchy incarnation of the Bat in one night.... Try not to think too much about the logistics of the plan and the hours required to fulfill it. It truly doesn't make sense, but semantics be damned. All this culminates in a twist that fans especially will see coming from MILES away. To add to the main story experience, the Game of the Year (GOTY) edition goes further to include one story DLC that has you revisit the game's locales and challenge map scenarios that are simply battle arenas.Playing Arkham Origins is a clear case of "...if it ain't broke don't fix it". It's more of the same old same old with very slight changes in the combat animations. Having come from completing Arkham City myself (review incoming), I feel that the combat rhythm here is slightly "off" with the Bat's animations being very slightly sluggish between frames. This is especially apparent when you are maintaining high combo strings and he has to move a tad faster between enemies when surrounded. That aside, all other traversal mechanics are present and correct from the previous installment of City, but if you've been used to the routine before there isn't much new to see here save for one particular tricky class of fighter and some new gadgetry (including the Shock Glove and EX Suit that just lovely cop-outs). The detective work has also been tweaked somewhat to provide a bit more narration. Here WB Montreal did a good job.Technically this game performs really well especially after the raft of patches that came post release. Includes some extra DX11 features with regard to ambient occlusion and tessellation that really helps bring out the best the Art team at WB Montreal had to offer for their game. Only really applicable and apparent when you enable ULTRA settings. It certainly looks and runs really great post GOTY. The sound work is not really memorable in that you probably will not end up latching onto a favorite audio track in your head when done. I suppose all the audio work was meant to do was simply set the tone in certain areas while providing some ambiance to the experience albeit with a very limited track selection.So is this title worth getting? Yes. With a caveat... Wait for a sale. Treat this as a quick romp (if you're an old hand at the series) and if you're a new fan? Probably start here then play all of Rocksteady's work back to back with the proviso that Arkham Origins is not a complete necessity but an appetizer to the main event. Be advised that if you are knowledgeable in your DC Comics lore you'll enjoy your Easter Eggs like a certain "Queen Industries" Shipping Container.Parting Shot: "It's Christmas Eve Sir..." ~ Alfred Pennyworth.

content:
Posted: December 22, 2016
												It's an ok game, although only worth buying if you're a big fan of the Batman franchise (which I am not). The map is virtually the same as Arkham City and except for a couple gadgets everything else is pretty much the same. It is fun at first, but the story gets boring/annoying really quick and combat becomes frustrating halfway through the game. On a positive note, like the previous games, it's built using the Unreal engine so it looks fantastic and runs pretty well on various hardware.I don't recommend it 100% and I'd rather rate it "neutral" or "not sure" if I could. Buy it on sale, or else it ain't worth the price.

												Review for Batman: Arkam Origins (Played on a GTX 970 OC, an i7 4790 3,6 and 16 gigs of ram)This game is absolutley amazing and I have no clue why people say it's bad. here's some pros and cons:PROS:- The game has amazing graphics (cutscenes look amazing!!! and gameplay too of course..)and it's very optimized. - The story was really good and I felt really invested in the story and all the characters were great, especially Batman and the Joker. (be the BATMAN!!!) - The combat was amazing. I don't need to say more. . . . . . . . . . Cons:- Ehh, well I didn't have any problems with the game whatsoever but I guess the multiplayer wasn't that good.Conclusion: great game and a must-buy for Batman fans (other gamers as well). 11/10 Ign.

content:
Posted: December 7, 2013
												(SPOLIERS) The game for an entry into the Arkham series is done well. The story is interesting, the combat flows and the gadgets are great to use. But with all of these perks comes a price. Unfortunate for this game is the short story. It is about 25 percent of the game, the rest is divided among item collection and side missions which introduce other batman villans that have not relation to the current story. I mean why all of a sudden come out on christmas? The multiplayer was okay. It did suffer some issues at launch. But it has been supposedly fixed. This also applies to the world elements. Other things that devs have toted about the detective features are there but seem tacked on. For how awesome the above trailer is, the game is not on par with it. play for yourself of course. i would give this game a 7/10.

content:
Posted: April 27, 2015
												Going into the game with the a new developer at the helm of this legendary franchise, I was extremely nervous, as Arkham games captured not only the essence of the Dark Knight himself, but also the dark sinister world in which he casts his shadows. I was expecting the developer will stick to the comfort zone and will follow closely if not completely copy the blueprint of the gameplay and structure perfected by Rocksteady (the developer of the previous two Arkham games) while coming out of the comfort zone with a captivating origin story that drops the first dominoes towards the build up to the next two games in the chronological sense.The good news is they indeed managed to keep the solid gameplay intact, in fact they didn't make any changes to the fight and gadgets, just with different variations of the same gadgets used in Arkham City like Glue Grenade over Freeze Grenade. There was a much greater emphasis on Batman's detective skill-set. As as you found more evidence, the crime scene slowly builds and is illustrated in a hologram. You sometimes had to rewind, pause to a specific spot to find a clue that you might have missed. It was really cool, and perhaps the only new thing this games does that was not done in the previous game. Although, I wish it was much more deeper and instead of just looking at the spot and pressing the 'X' button to scan and tag. Oh well, there is always the next Arkham game right?So I never expected the developer to re-invent the bat wheel for the series, that sort of task is best left to Rocksteady and good thing they didn't as results might have been catastrophic. However, I wished they had done better with the narrative flow of the game as well as the plot. The story felt disjointed and felt like different pieces of awesomeness attached to one another in hopes of making one giant awesomeness instead of melding pieces of narratives that complement each other and make one big awesome narrative like Paul Dini did with the previous two games. I was hoping the Christmas background of the game would add to the atmosphere, but apart from some radio of random christmas songs and some Christmas decorations here and there...it hardly felt like a Christmas Eve, sooner than later it felt just like another long night for Batman. The Another thing that caught my eye was the city itself. The game is supposed to take place in Gotham City, or some part of it. However it hardly feels any different from Arkham City. With virtually no one out in the street instead of hundreds of thugs and random police here and there. This further kills the Christmas vibe, seriously I don't care if it is snowing like crazy, people go out during Christmas Eve, at least some do. At times I felt like I was back to Arkham City, or even worse, considering from the number of thugs out on the streets and rooftops far outnumbering the country's soon-to-be biggest criminally Infested Zone.The story is not at all bad, where Arkham Asylum was a great batman story, Arkham City later became perhaps one of the best (personally the best) Batman story I've witnessed; Arkham Origins comes out short and tends to be a good story. Then again, it is sometimes hard to blame the Warner Brothers Montreal because the legacy left by the first two games were so great that I doubt any developer would succeed leaping over or even matching it.The new voice actors did a solid job and overall the performance of voice actors were on par with the previous games. I thought I would dearly miss the Conroy/Hamill duo of Batman and Joker. I did, but the performance of the actors were amazing, especially Troy Baker's Joker, the way he captured the insanity, the horror and the comedy of Joker only Mark Hamill previously understood.I haven't tried the multiplayer yet, I will post my impressions as soon as  I dive into it. But from what I've heard from people who played it, it is not really worth spending a lot of your time on.So there you have it, its a very good game and a worthy game to add to the Arkhamverse. If the previous two games were masterpieces from a renowned artist. This game comes out as a masterpiece from the artist's best student. The student will only get better as long as he/she comes out of the comfort zone more often.

content:
Posted: November 27, 2013
												Batman is back!Some of the charm of the predecessors has been lost, we've lost Mark Hamill. We've also lost the only man to ever really voice Batman great.  That said, the replacement voice actors aren't too shabby and can grow on you once you move past the change.  The real bummer is the change to the combat.  It's not BAD, per se.  Just not the beautiful rhythm and flow that made the previous Arkham games so amazing, as they got rid of that rhythm in favor of difficulty.  Which at times gets very frustrating.   There are also a few issues with it (Such as double counters sometimes not actually stopping the 2nd attacker from just nailing you as you do the animation), but they've been sorting those out with patches.That said, the story is fun.  It's great to be playing Batman during that early story arc, to have an epic duel with Deathstroke.  It's a good game, but it could have been great.

content:
Posted: January 11, 2014
												Anyone playing the arkham series for the first time would be best served starting here, for those who have played both asylum and city, then you will know to expect an awsome action packed ride.First off, this is the latest game in the series but set before the others, focusing on showing batman at an early stage of his career, still a vigilante in the eyes of both the gotham citizens and the GCPD (gotham city police department)As far as the story telling goes, this game does it better than the previous 2, the extra focus put into cutscenes and detective mode bring the introduction of characters and events to life in a nolan quality way. Being early career we find batman at a pivotal time in his career, the city has just started to take notice of him as a force to be reckoned with and not just a passing fancy, as such the villains that occupy the batman universe and by extension, the DC universe are now set on taking him down before he foils any more plansand slaps more villains behind bars. The GCPD are also on the case to arrest the batman on site giving a good dynamic to certain missions as you progress.This game shines in showing the inner struggle Bruce Wayne/Batman faces in light of what his intentions have wrought upon the city he is protecting, alfred, his butler and dearest friend gets a great showcasing in this game as the moral compass trying to guide Bruce in the right direction before he becomes lost to his own obsession. Roger Craig Smith (who also voiced gaming favorites such as Ezio and Chris Redfield) provides exceptional voice work for batman and really drives emotional scenes home with his work.Gameplay wise the combat is slick and intuative, a great use of gadgets (most of which will be familiar to those who have played previous arkham games) with some fun new additions that really get their spotlight when you play on the harder difficulties. It feels fairly similar to arkham city but dont let that put you off, when it comes to gaming sequels a few brands could learn a thing or two from origins, it perfects what was already great and add's just enough to make it feel fresh and expanded without loosing the core values of the franchise/character for the sake of having a large budget. The main story moves along at a steady and enjoyable pace with plenty of side missions and random events throughout to keep you occupied inbetween. The only low to this game is the multiplayer which i have only dabbled in briefly. it pits teams of 3 against each other in a 'by the numbers' 3rd person team deathmatch. Think gears of war but without the polish. In the same TDM you also have 2 players as Batman and Robin. Anyone who played the superb MGO (Metal Gear Online) in its day will draw instant reference to the sneaking missions. The round ends when one team reaches a kill limit or Batman and Robin have taken out their set number of targets. Im not personaly a fan of tacked on MP mode's and this does nothing to alter my feelings towards the matter.Overall id recommend this game to any who enjoy a great action/adventure, you certainly get your moneys worth in the single player alone and if you have played the previous arkham games im shocked if you dont own it already!8/10 (Multiplayer was not needed)

content:
Posted: October 10, 2014
												There isn't much to say about this game, becasue I am unable to play it any further than Deathstroke boss fight.I can mostly describe technical aspects of the game, isnce this is the only part I got to "enjoy".1) Graphics is mediocre (my laptop w/ GeForce GT630M handles solid 50FPS on medium, 30FPS on high with normal PhysX setting), but excessive and unoptimized use of PhysX may drop your framerates by half.2) Game developers were oriented towards consoles the entire time, so KB+Mouse support is awful: key bindings don't work the way they should, quickfire and finishing moves work only 20% of the time.3) Larger world means poorer planning: player gets stuck all the time while using batclaw for movement or if hanging off the cliff of the building4) AI is ridiculously stupid, which gives you the ability to kill opponents almost in the plain sight under certain conditions5) Even small-scale level design is always flawed: some "how-to-get-to-the-other-side" puzzless may lead you to a halt in your game progression6) Many people, including me, have encountered numerous progression-stopping bugs in boss fights (Flickering Crock, Dissapearing Deathstroke, doors that are not opening and ambient gadgets that do not appear when they should etc.).7) Still present problems with DLC, which were addressed almost a year ago and were supposedly "fixed"8) Non-existent customer support, commuinty support or even any sign of presence of anyone in the community!!!I've decided to check out WBGames forum and i was surprised to see that a moderator, which was responsible for Arkham Origins thread left in april and was not replaced, and moderator for the new Arkham Knight logs in about once a week.9) Most of the updates released up until now are mostly related to multiplayer issues and haven't even scratched the surface of single player bugs. Most of the stuff I've listed here was in game since it's initial release in Oct. 2013. This is probably the best indicator of what you have to expect from Arkham Knight and following games in series.My advice: avoid this abomination even if it is on sale. Stop on Arkham City.

content:
Posted: January 8, 2014
												I have not played the previous two games in this line, so I cannot make a relative comparison to them, but here's a comparison of Batman: Arkham Origins to all the other games I've known before:  1) It has elements of a fighting game, like Mortal Kombat, but is far more dimensional in many ways.  You actually feel like you're participating as a Batman in his various cartoon or action movie incarnations due to the fighting style of the avatar and his animations and the style in which his opponents are portrayed.  You take on groups of thugs constantly like a typical urban vigilante superhero, and the thugs react just like the comic books thugs should.  You gain more experience for being hit less and fighting with more sophisticated combo techniques, allowing you to upgrade faster if you play smarter.  The fighting learning curve is steep and most boss fights with the major supervillans will require retrys - but the game autosaves for you, so you just restart as much as you feel like, jumping right back in without having to press anything.2) It is also similar to games like Metal Gear and Tenchu: Stealth Assassin in the ability of your game Batman avatar to sneak up on people, giving rewards for being like the bat and taking down a whole encounter without even being seen.  You also get unlocks if you pull off archetypal bat-stunts like knocking a guy out from above or below, or by gliding in on your cape and kicking them.3) The cinematics when certain objectives are achieved include the typical hanging a guy upside-down by his leg as a mode of interrogation as an example of how they keep you interested in the 'quest' of the storyline.The storyline itself is early Batman, which I found a more appealing hook than the ideas behind the other two chapters: Arkham City, where they go all dystopia and exile crooks to a walled in area of Gotham seemed a bit jumping the shark for my taste in narrative integrity.  If you like comics and get off on playing a superhero icon such as Batman, you might like this game.  It's pretty true to form.  WB is a bit greedy with their offers of extra content, like costumes that you have to unlock even though you pay for them.  They don't tell you about the unlocking bit either, you find it out later.  That part is lame, but I bought the expansion material for extra playable content.

content:
Posted: May 18, 2015
tl;dr -> I have an old-school (Batman Animated Series), tight Batman costume that I rocked for Halloween 2014. Sometimes I like to take LSD and play this game, living my dream of being the Bat. 11/10 na na na na, na na na na BATMAN!I got this game gifted to me by a very generous friend and was super excited to play it because I thoroughly enjoyed the previous installments (Arkham Asylum and City). I also have been a huge fan of the Assassin's Creed series, which shares overlapping gameplay mechanics with the Arkham series. I absolutely loved my gameplay experience.If you like Batman, gritty/dark themes, being Batman, stealth/stalking, lots of side quests, and plenty of action, then you will love this game.The aesthetics are fantastic - the amount of detail in the world and character models is very, very well-done. Details are so fine that there is a (quite popular in superhero games; ex: the later Spider-man games) "wear-and-tear" mechanic on Batman's outfit. As you progress through the game (specifically, after boss battles), you will notice different "battle scars" adorning Batman's costume. For example, you may see nicks and scratches on his arms, or tears in his cape. I think this simple, but salient feature helps show how much of a toll the events of Origins is taking on the caped crusader. The sounds, music, and voice acting are great and add a lot to the experience of being Batman. I frequently mute gameplay music in favor of my own, however, in Arkham's case, I enjoyed the complete experience until I beat the game (took 18 hours, doing a good number of side missions). The controls are numerous, however, they are fairly easy to learn. I strongly recommend using a controller for this game. The tutorials help immensely, and there are practice/challenge modes that help you hone your skills. During your playthrough, there will always be tooltips (ex: press x during a scene) to assist your progression. The learning curve is minimal to moderate depending on your experience with the Arkham (and even the Assassin's Creed) series - intuitive countering system makes fights pretty easy on normal difficulty. When you play new game + (after completing one playthrough), you will be able to experience a much harder story - the "counter" icon will disappear, and enemies will be more aggressive/skilled. Gameplay involves you moving around the city of Gotham, subduing criminals and completing side/main missions. You will frequently encounter enemies in groups, giving you opportunities to build up a combo chain - the higher your combo when you've cleared the immediate area of enemies, the greater your experience gain. When you level up, you can select abilities to do with Batman's more physical calling (combat-related) or his predatory nature (stealth- and stalking-related). The map is fairly large, and you can unlock radio towers to allow for fast travel. To move around, you will most likely be using Batman's grappling hook extensively (faster than running over rooftops). Combat is very fun because the game is set up to make it reasonably easy for you (at least in the beginning). Whenever you land an actual hit, you build +1 to your score combo. As the multiplier increases, it will eventually allow you to execute special moves (one-hit knock outs) - for example, every 6x you get, you will be granted one special move. There are abilities you can select that make your combo requirement lower (I believe mine is at every 4x). Counter indicators pop up over enemies' heads whenever you can trigger a counter move - you can even do this to multiple enemies. The combat animations are very varied, ensuring that combat does not get stale too quickly. There are also a multitude of different enemy types - complete with their own attack patterns and weaknesses - to keep things fresh and interesting.There are predator instances, where you (should) use stealth to beat your opponents - typically because they are all armed and/or have hostages. To complete these scenarios, you will have to use a lot of hiding and stalking techniques - like swinging to and from ledges, moving through vents and underpassages, etc. Batman has a "detective mode" that allows you to see enemy heat signatures and objects of interest (like switches, mission objects, etc). Later in the game, you will encounter jammers that impair your detective mode, and must be disabled before you can use it again. One of my favorite parts of the game is the "detective" scenarios, where you must rebuild crime scenes. To do this, you will have to scan an area for relevant clues, then usually rewind simulations in order to discover more clues (like a basic version of L.A. Noire's detective mechanics). This component of the Arkham series really adds to the idea and experience of playing as Batman because it isn't just about beating up and stalking bad guys. There are plenty of side missions to complete, and many involve finding x number of items (ex: Riddler packages, Black Mask's weapon caches). Usually, after completing these tedious tasks, you will be allowed to fight/capture the mastermind. A common criticism of this game (the third installment, following Asylum and City) is that it borrows too heavily from its predecessors. While I agree, I still enjoyed this game immensely. If you are interested in this game, then I sincerely hope you will try to begin your experience with a fresh, clean mindset. Yes, you will see, do, and feel things that will remind you of the previous games (if you've played them), but I hope you do not let it subtract from a great playthrough. Something that the Arkham series does very well is slowly adding new elements to keep the game interesting. For example, you will have many predator encounters, but new challenges will be added like jammers on the wall - and, even later - jammers on enemies. Different areas of the game will require further progression to enable access because you unlock more gadgets as you continue the story. This is also a focal point for criticism because people wonder, "shouldn't Batman already have all his gadgets ready to go?" Probably better than the first 2 games (since this is the Origins story), this is explained by Batman having certain gadgets still in development; he also sometimes takes gadgets from enemies and fashions them for his own use. Overall, the game is a fabulous experience and I implore you to get it if you enjoy the Batman series even slightly. It is a nice segue into Arkham Asylum (since Origins is a prequel) and even has some nice easter eggs if you take the time to look for them.ABSOLUTELY RECOMMEND!Cheers,DJSF @DJSF's Rogue Reviews

content:
Posted: March 10, 2014
												Arkham Origins is a slice of greasy pizza after a meal of medium-rare steak and wine. Sure, it's not outright bad, but it leaves the pallet unsatisfied. The combat felt off in Origins and for the longest time I had trouble figuring out why. But during the halfway point, I think I figured it out: The baddie placement. In the previous games, lots of care had been taken in picking which baddies work in what amounts and when special enemies were needed. Here it seems like more of a copy-paste job, carelessly throwing in specials even if their abilities severely hinders the combat. It leads to a lot of frustration and eagerness to get out of combat, something the series hasn't had an issue with until now.In terms of new content, Arkham Origins is kind of bare bones. You have a majority of your old weapons available to you very early and some new ones that, unfortunately, don't mean much in combat. Some of the items feel completely shoehorned in, such as the Sonic Batarang. Not only did it seemingly just appear in my inventory, but there is never any sort of need for it or tactical advantage for using it. So why is it here? The story is fairly muddled. It starts off with Black Mask hiring 8 supervillanous hitmen to take you down on Christmas Eve. Why Christmas Eve? "Who cares" is the answer the game gives. The story actually rehashes some villains, such as Bane, the Riddler, the Penguin, and Deadshot. Unfortunately there isn't much to talk about when it comes to the plot without getting into spoilers. It's not exactly clear why Black Mask hired the assassins in the first place and by the end of the game it's even more confusing. Topping that off, the game ends seemingly out of nowhere, in what I thought was the beginning of the third act. It just sort of stops. There are still a handful of graphical errors and strange Not to mention several game-stopping glitches I encountered in-game despite the titles having been out for 5 months.I don't really think fans of the last two Arkham games will get much out of Arkham Origins, it feels like microwave leftovers. The only people I would recommend this to are die-hard fans of the games or Batman in-general, and even then I would recommend getting it at a low price. Also can I mention that the game DOESN'T HAVE A ♥♥♥♥ING MOUSE SENSITIVY SETTING?

content:
Posted: October 27, 2013
												I am a huge fan of the Arkham games, and even though this game comes from a different developer, I gotta say that this is a great game and a worthy addition to the Arkham franchise.Story:The story is absolutely fantastic.The game takes place about 5 years before Arkham Asylum.You play as a younger, less refined Batman trying to find and stop Black Mask who put a bounty of 50 million dollars on his head, which automatically attracts 8 of the most talented assassins in the DC universe such as Deathstroke, Deadshot and Bane.Even though the title says "Arkham Origins", it doesn't have anything to do with Arkham, and it's definitely not an origin story. In this game, Batman meets his ultimate adversary, The Joker, for the first time, and many other villains and allies as well.Gameplay:Despite the fact that this is not Rocksteady who developed the game, it shouldn't come as a surprise that the the gameplay is exactly the same as in Arkham City, simply because Rocksteady's work is remarkable and irreplaceable, and it should never be changed. There's a few new gadgets, and I have one minor complaint about the new Shock Gloves that I don't like the idea of because it's too overpowered. You are able to clear a room full of guys in matter of seconds with those. Good thing is, you get them pretty late in the game and they need to recharge. Aside from a few new types of enemies and the new gadgets, everything is the same, and that's good. You don't try to fix something if that's not broken.Visuals:The visuals are excellent, and are slightly better than Arkham City's.The game has a lot of bugs though, and some of them are extremely annoying and sometimes they will not let you continue in your mission. For example: I encountered a major frame rate bug near the end of the game, even though my computer was able to run the game on maximum settings smoothly. I eventually managed to fix it.Aside from that, the animations look great and fluid, except for the weird lip movement in dialogue scenes (not cinematic).Multiplayer:The multiplayer can be fun at times, but it's not polished.There are 3 teams, Joker's gang, Bane's gang and Batman and Robin. Both gangs are fighting each other while Batman and Robin need to take both gangs out.It has a lot of potential but it's not well executed.Still, it's always fun to play as Batman and do inverted takedowns on helpless victims.Summary:Definitely a great addition to the Arkham series like I said, WB Games Montreal did a great job with the writing on this game and the new Batman and Joker voices are a great replacement, especially Joker's which is portrayed by the famous Troy Baker.I give this game an 8/10, the things that really bugged me were the multiplayer and the great number of bugs, I wouldn't mind waiting a few more days and get a bug free game instead.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 10, 2014
												Arkham Origins is a slice of greasy pizza after a meal of medium-rare steak and wine. Sure, it's not outright bad, but it leaves the pallet unsatisfied. The combat felt off in Origins and for the longest time I had trouble figuring out why. But during the halfway point, I think I figured it out: The baddie placement. In the previous games, lots of care had been taken in picking which baddies work in what amounts and when special enemies were needed. Here it seems like more of a copy-paste job, carelessly throwing in specials even if their abilities severely hinders the combat. It leads to a lot of frustration and eagerness to get out of combat, something the series hasn't had an issue with until now.In terms of new content, Arkham Origins is kind of bare bones. You have a majority of your old weapons available to you very early and some new ones that, unfortunately, don't mean much in combat. Some of the items feel completely shoehorned in, such as the Sonic Batarang. Not only did it seemingly just appear in my inventory, but there is never any sort of need for it or tactical advantage for using it. So why is it here? The story is fairly muddled. It starts off with Black Mask hiring 8 supervillanous hitmen to take you down on Christmas Eve. Why Christmas Eve? "Who cares" is the answer the game gives. The story actually rehashes some villains, such as Bane, the Riddler, the Penguin, and Deadshot. Unfortunately there isn't much to talk about when it comes to the plot without getting into spoilers. It's not exactly clear why Black Mask hired the assassins in the first place and by the end of the game it's even more confusing. Topping that off, the game ends seemingly out of nowhere, in what I thought was the beginning of the third act. It just sort of stops. There are still a handful of graphical errors and strange Not to mention several game-stopping glitches I encountered in-game despite the titles having been out for 5 months.I don't really think fans of the last two Arkham games will get much out of Arkham Origins, it feels like microwave leftovers. The only people I would recommend this to are die-hard fans of the games or Batman in-general, and even then I would recommend getting it at a low price. Also can I mention that the game DOESN'T HAVE A ♥♥♥♥ING MOUSE SENSITIVY SETTING?

Posted: November 26, 2013
												Short Review:The Good: The Main Story is more gripping and intense than Batman Arkham City. But not much better than Arkham Asylum. The Costume is more realistic giving it that Nolan esque feel to the series. Bane is one of the highlights of the series.The Bad: The combat was made faster which led to some problems like the enemy wouldn't give you much room to do your combo. On most fights it devolves into a counter fest. Effective use of gadgets could fix this. The Ugly: The world looks almost the same. It's not as detailed as Batman Arkham City. The side quests are smaller in scope and some felt rehashed from the previous game. The Riddler datapacks are easier and requires less thought than B:AC.

content:
Posted: May 4, 2014
												I want to endorse this game, I really do. I've enjoyed the Arkham games and I think the stories told here are a bit closer to what I look for in a Batman story, something closer to home and a bit more grounded. However, the game is buggy. I made it through the main story with few problems, but I hit a game breaking bug while playing the Cold, Cold Heart DLC. I was not able to grapple up to an area I need to get to if I was to continue the story. This was after several times having characters I needed to interrogate not allowing me to do so and other odd bugs in the game. I restarted the game several times, and even rebooted Steam, but it made no difference. I deleted the game and decided that the frustration was no longer worth my time. I look forward to playing the next game in the series, but I cannot endorse this entry in the franchise.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 12, 2013
												I'll split this up into two sections because this game has a multiplayer mode as well. I'll focus on the single player first. The main story of the game is not as long as Arkham Asylum and Arkham City. It's actually quite short if you just focus on the main objectives but it's at least enjoyable for what it is. There is a lot to visit when exploring Gotham just like you would experience when exploring Arkham City but what is in the city feels kind of trivial as you travel about. The actual story content is a lot of fun.The gameplay and fighting feel more polished to me than Arkham City. Batman seems to react better and combat feels a lot more fun. You still get upgrades and gadgets as you progress so it always feels like you are making your way forward. Batman definitely feels a lot stronger as you come towards the end of the game. Some of the upgrades however are very situational and you'll only use them a few times, an example of this would be some of the takedowns you unlock. While situations for some of these upgraded moves may be few and far between they are still very awesome when you do get the chance to pull them off.The graphics in this game are amazing, much better than Arkham City. There is some noticeable pop in from time to time but that usually happens with sandbox games of this scale and it's mostly forgivable. If you liked Arkham Asylum and Arkham City's graphics then this game won't disappoint you in that department.The sound lends to the atmosphere that in a brilliant way. You definitely get that Christmas feeling as you explore Gotham and you hear certain music or quips from Alfred. The voice actors do a great job portraying Batman and the various characters. It's not the same ones from the previous games but these voice actors made their characters sound exactly just like they should.Overall if you're a fan of Arkham City and Arkham Asylum you'll definitely enjoy the story. This game is worth it if you can find it at $20 or less.The multiplayer is disappointing in a big way. It's broken. Connections to games are rare. The message you will see the most is Connection to Steam has been dropped. This is a big issue for anyone attempting to play the multiplayer and the developer looks like they have no intention on focusing on fixing it. If you are buying this game for multiplayer then pass on it. It's enjoyable when it works but it fails more than it works.My verdict is if you can find this game on sale for $20 or less then pick it up. You'll get a great enjoyable story out of it which feels like an expansion to Arkham city and that's how I take it as. It's a lot shorter than the previous games but if you can find it at a lower price it is worth its fee. Avoid this game if you want it for the multiplayer though as it's broken since launch and continues to have a ton of problems.

content:
Posted: November 14, 2016
												Broken MessIt has been less than a year since I have gotten Batman Arkham Origins, and with around 30 hours with the game I would have easily said that it was worth it. However in light of many performance and game breaking bugs both reported and personally experienced, I easily say that I would not recommend the game. It is evident that the publishers were not skilled enough in porting the damned thing. I was enjoying the game until around 25 hours or so when I began to notice bugs and glitches, notorious glitches on some of the levels. Whether I would be falling through the floor endlessly in an essential fight forcing you to literally make a new game, or charecter models would glitch and distort, It would always be something game breaking and irreversable causing you to roll back your saves just to ensure the game doesn't crash during something important. It is a glitchy broken mess no matter what settings I play on, whether or not Physx is enabled (which has problems in itself), or even when I switch from a very low end laptop to a mid range gaming desktop, the problems are consistent.Overall - The game is broken and there are no signs that the devs will ever come back to fix this broken mess.4/10It would have been a great game if only I was able to finish it.~LordNeonKnight

content:
Posted: November 29, 2013
												Arkham Origins seems to get a lot of criticism from reviewers, some of this I agree with but not entirely.    While the story is fairly lackluster compared to the previous Arkham games the focus on the relationship between Batman and the Joker is engaging and interesting. Combat is improved to add challenge and variation which for me is the main reason to play. The new map is more varied than that of Arkham City but not by much, the greater sense of scale is very apparent though. The multiplayer is okay, fairly fun when using the heroes or Super-villains but playing as the elites is just a boring 3rd person shooter.    I don't think I would present this as the one-to-buy out of the series, in my opinion it beats Arkham City which I found bored me in parts. The combat is improved compared to Arkham Asylum but the story falls short and stops it from taking the crown of the Arkham franchise.  In conclusion, if you are new to the series buy the first one, if you know and love the series like I do, buy this one, it is a lot of fun!

number of helpful: 4 of 7 people (57%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 5, 2013
												Batman: Arkham Origins takes place before Arkham Asylum and Arkham City, so if you've played those two I recommend this. As the title implies the story revolves Bruce Wayne's early involvement as Batman in Arkham, preparing him to meet criminal overlords he was not expecting to fight.The game play remains the same, allowing you to play as Batman by gliding across the map with his cape and taking down enemies one by one in stealth. You can impair the enemies vision with smoke, take their weapons out of commission or maybe confuse them with your Batarang. You're not forced to take out enemies silently of course since you have the freedom to go "loud" if you prefer that style of fighting.Unlike the previous games, Arkham Origins is packaged with a Multiplayer mode allowing you to play against others as Batman, Robin or other villains from various gangs (that I won't name since it will spoil the main story). Unfortunately I haven't had the chance to play the multiplayer mode since it always crashes during loading a game - so that's one thumbs down on that.If you're a Batman fan, I don't see why you shouldn't  play this game!Peace.
