number of helpful: 4 of 7 people (57%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 2, 2014
												It's tough to give a recommendation for Arkham Origins. It has been plagued by bugs and glitches ever since it was released, and to this day a fair amount of these issues remain. About two weeks ago this game stopped working altogether, which had me trouble shooting my computer for a few days. The problem was caused by a few corrupted INI files that didn't happen to get deleted when uninstalling the game in Steam. The game has been running ever since.However, even with the game working, I still find there is a siginificant amount of lag and stutter, especially when exploring the city; a serious flick in the nuts for people who have spent a lot of money on high-end hardware. It is extremely noticeable and distracting. Other than that I haven't encountered anything too aggravating so far when talking about pure bugs and glitches.As for the game itself, Arkham Origins is actually pretty good. In no way is it as groundbreaking as Arkham Aslyum or Arkham City were, though. Arkham Origins feels more like an expansion on Arkham City than an entirely new game. The combat has not been updated or improved, in fact it feels a little more sluggish than in Arkham City, there are no new noteworthy gadgets and some parts of the map are right out of Arkham City. In terms of story, I think this game actually has the best in the series, although I won't get into it to prevent any spoilers. The voice acting isn't bad, either. While I do miss Kevin Conroy and Mark Hamil, both Roger Craig Smith and Troy Baker are great regardless.The reason why I wouldn't recommend you get this game, is because WB Montreal really doesn't seem to give a f*** about their customers and their game. This company has no plans to fix Arkham Origins, yet has time and money to produce DLC. It is greedyness at its finest and a supreme example of why the game industry is hurting a bit right now. Unless WB Montreal fixes the game, stay away from this one and get Arkham Asylum and/or Arkham City instead, or wait for the recently announced Arkham Knight to be released in October. Although I get my enjoyment from this game, looking back now I wish I had listened to others and didn't fall for this one. It's time to take a stand against the industry and not have them bend us over and f*** us from behind. Out of pure principals, don't purchase anything from developers and publishers like this, as it will only make matters worse and worse. If you do decide to get Arkham Origins anyway, it is still good and worth playing, but I would at least wait for a price drop.

content:
Posted: November 20, 2013
												It’s hard to believe that it has only been four years since Batman: Arkham Asylum. The title that seemingly broke the curse of non-Spider related super-heroics in gaming has cast a shadow over so many games that have come since. Its masterful combination of Nolan’s dark vision of Gotham with the expanded rogues gallery afforded by decades of comics history brought even the most mainstream of Batman’s fans up to speed on everyone from Calendar Man to Victor Zsasz. Its narrow corridors and expansive tool-set created a tight, linear narrative where players nonetheless felt completely in control. Arkham City introduced open world mechanics to the formula that arguably opened up the world too much, taking away from that tightness that made Asylum such a breath of fresh air. Now, with Arkham Origins, new developer WB Montreal has struck a great balance between the levels of Asylum and the open world of City. It doesn’t quite eclipse the original, but Origins is a much more refined sequel than City was, and it’s one that is well worth your time.Read my full review at http://www.geekenstein.com/batman-arkham-origins-review/

content:
Posted: November 9, 2013
												*Notice: I havent tried the multiplayer, so this a singleplayer look only.*So.. This was my first Batman game ive ever played, and it was truly an amazing experience. I dont know why i havent played the Batman series before, all ive heard is that theyre always good, so yeah, i decided to try this since i got it free with my new graphics card. The gameplay and graphics are simply just great, the mechanics are very well made, as well as the animating. The fighting style in this game is some of the best, and its one of the most known fighting styles, it works perfect.The story is good, but im probably missing out on a lot since this is my first Batman game, but i did enjoy it quite a lot. It took me over 10 hours to complete, so im very satisfied with the length, since most games today only seem to last a couple hours, which is sad. But this game is really good, so over 10 hours is just perfect for me.The game also delivered some interesting boss fights and enemies in general, some annoying, but it delivered something different, which i do like. Again, the fighting style and the VERY well made stealth made it so good to play through.Some of the missions were too repetitive though, but it made up for itself in my opinion.Its very well optimized, and i wish that more games ran just as good as this game, because i must say that it runs good compared to a lot of other titles.This game is open world, so it offers a lot of options to what you can do. So more playtime there. Also multiplayer is in there, so you can spend more time on the game than just on the main story.So what would i rate it? Thats a tough one, i want to rate it 10/10 because i really enjoyed it, but some of the repetitive missions, some of the bosses and sometimes just getting lost because of misleading directions frustrated me, so ill rate it 9/10, a close 10/10.Thanks for reading!I hope you will have a look at the Batman series now, if you like me, never tried (until now) the games at all. Definitely worth a try.

content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												When I first heard Rocksteady wasn't doing Arkham Origins I cried like Vader.  NOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOO.  My cries seemed justified at launch, as this game was riddled with game breaking bugs and glitches.However, a series of patches have resolved all my issues and since then I'm loving this newest Batman game the most.  It's essentially Batman Arkham City (BAC) again with a few new gadgets, a revamped crime investigation feature, and a multiplayer mode. Here's the new stuff you can look forward to:Gadgets - Shock gloves replace the electron gun from BAC, and they are amazingly fun to use in combat once you upgrade them.  They'll allow you to punch through armored and shielded guards without the need to cape stun.Glue grenades replace freeze nades.  Same functionality, but now it is glue!Stun grenades temporarily confuse and blind enemies causing them to swing blindly.Improved line launcher can now be used offensively by attaching it to enemies and environmental items causing collisions which disorient and take down enemies.The new crime scene investigation allows deeper exploration in Detective Vision.  You can now scan evidence and scrub the scene by rewinding the events to unlock more clues to scan.   If you enjoyed Arkham City you'll also love Orgins, but don't expect anything too much different.

content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												Amazing game. Maybe too similar to the previous Batman Arkham, but it has improved vastly on very important things, like the combat (more demanding and with 2 new basic enemies), boss fights (the best in the series) and lighting (sick of using the detective mode all time just to tell a door from a wall? Not necessary on this game).Unfortunately, the game is a bit too conservative on both combat and stealth systems, and may feel "more of the same" to fans of the series.It also has a very interesting and original online mode where you can play as Batman, Robin, or thugs in a power war. It's difficult to summarize, but it surely is a very interesting addition.In case you didn't know previous Batman Arkham, just to mention they are some of the best game series this gen, with a fantastic and easy to grasp combat system, all the possible charismatic enemies and characters from the Batman comics, a very nice concept of adventure with fantastic side-quests, and a very good (though not exceptionally deep) combination of combat and stealth gaming.A very honest recommendation, I was going to ignore it for looking "too similar" to the previous games (which I loved) but I'm happy I didn't. Good job from Eidos Montreal.

content:
Posted: April 5, 2015
												Rating 8/10Overview: Action/AdventureThe Good:+ The story takes place over the course of Christmas eve. Batman has a contract on his head and has to take down multiple assassins out to kill him. The story is very well written and more cohesive than arkham city. The pacing is also excellent as the story begins to unfold the game gets more interesting. + Crime scene investigations have been improved by adding a holographic video of the crime taking place while you investigate. It is a small addition to an otherwise mundane activity but it does add a lot in terms of the feeling of solving a mystery. + Combat once again remains mostly the same with a few added enemies for good measure. There are however 2 big differences compared to the other games. The first is that more powerful combat techniques are locked behind main/side quests and challenges, making them much harder to get early on (and in some cases missable) and thus making combat more challenging especially in the early parts of the game. The second is the addition of the electric gloves, another item obtained later in the game. These gloves charge up as you punch enemies and once fully charged you can toggle the option to become nearly unstoppable: punching through any enemy regardless of what they are carrying or doing. It is practically a "win" button if you find combat too frustrating. The difficulty curve for combat goes from hard to frustrating to ridiculously easy. + Every boss battle is unique and fun to play. Granted some of these bosses are more flash than substance but it still feels epic to take one of these bosses down.  + Once again Riddler collectables are scattered across the map for you to find. You can (once again) find riddler informants to 'interrogate' to reveal the location on your mini map. Although I liked collecting these I also found the puzzles associated with them to be simpler than Arkham City. So long as you had the right item, it wasn't very difficult to collect any of these. I was a bit disappointed with the riddler trophies this time around. + Predator/Combat maps are available for those who want to play some post game content. Both combat and predator maps are MUCH easier than the previous two games. + Although the voice actors are not the same they do an excellent job of representing their characters + Great soundtrackThe Average:The games biggest 'fault' is that from a design standpoint it is almost identical to arkham city. The game doesn't do anything particularly new, if you played arkahm city then this game offers little surprise in terms of its gameplay, you've done it all before. Christmas Eve in Gotham means nobody is outside, no people, no cars, no...anything, just criminals looking to terrorize the city. Arkham city was able to get around this by saying this was a section of the city solely for criminals, it just feels weird in this game gliding around a city with nobody in it. Surprisingly the multiplayer is still active, even more surprisingly the multiplayer is actually fun. There are only 2 game modes and 4 maps and only one game mode is still active, it was still a lot of fun to play and it is definitely worth checking out. The problem is the community is slowly fading away and it is getting harder and harder to get a good game going. A lot of achievements are for multiplayer as well. The Bad:- The game crashed on a few occasions and I experienced a few glitches, nothing a restart couldn't fix however the game clearly lacks polish. -Missable upgrades for combat may frustrate players or completionists. ConclusionThe game starts off slow and it wasn't really doing much for me. It wasn't until the story really starts to pick up that things start getting interesting. Locking important upgrades for combat also soured me a bit in the beginning but does make sense given the story and for gameplay reasons. One problem with Arkham City was that you could obtain some of the best combat upgrades early making combat feel very trivial for the rest of the game. The boss battles are excellent but also the gameplay/build up to the boss battles as well. Every boss battle you face feels climatic. You could argue that this game is a cash grab however its a damn good cash grab. If you loved both Batman games by Rocksteady, especially Arkham City then more likely than not you too will like this game, hopefully you are not burned out by the same gameplay.

content:
Posted: December 16, 2016
Product received for free
Originally posted by author:  Overview   Batman: Arkham Origins is a prequel to both Arkham Asylum and City, and is good game, but does not live up to the examples set by either of them. It still perfectly portrays the feeling of being The Bat, however flaws in the gameplay and the somewhat derivative narrative hold it back from being another truly excellent Batman title. In order to convey my full perspective on Arkham Origins, I'll be going over its presentation, gameplay, and story, and then end with my overall final thoughts.   Originally posted by author:  Presentation  When compared to the earlier titles in the series, there has been a small but noticeable change in the presentation. The visual design/feel has a slightly weaker "Batman" atmosphere than the previous two games, however the sheer graphical fidelity is better than ever. The dynamic lighting is beautiful, textures are sufficiently detailed, the models are as intricate as ever, and all visual effects (other than the fire effect) are gorgeous. The snowy weather (as it is Christmas Eve during the game) fits very well into the open world design of Gotham too, however the architecture of the city itself is not as well designed as it was in Arkham City, despite large chunks of the map being redesigns from that entry in the franchise. Next up is the soundscape, which is probably the biggest positive update to the presentation. All audio whether voice, ambiance, sound effects, or music is handled exceedingly well; especially the music, which always fits the situations Batman finds himself in. With regard to the performance though, I have to say everything is a little iffy. Short frame drops are common, bugs (none game breaking) will make an appearance every now and then too, but luckily I never had any crashes. The original release of Arkham Origins was plagued by performance issues, however most short-comings in this department seem to have been fixed by now, so anyone planning on playing the game shouldn't worry too much about the performance. All in all the presentation of Arkham Origins is above average in relation to most modern games, and is on par with previous games in the series.   Originally posted by author:  Gameplay  Considering the gameplay is the most important aspect of any Batman game, I was a bit disappointed to find that nearly every change made in the gameplay was ill-advised. Starting off with the combat, most everything has been kept the same as it was in the other entries in the series so I won't go into detail on how it works, however there are some important to know overhauls to the system. Most noticeably is how huge combos are now infuriatingly easy to strike up, because Batman will literally break the laws of physics and slide across the ground a full 50 feet to punch an enemy if you're in the middle of a streak and a hostile happens to be that far away. While this was (kind of) an element in Asylum and City, it was kept to a believable distance for Batman, but in Origins it gets a bit ridiculous and comes off as lazy game design and a way to make combat easier. The only other change to the combat are some original gadgets, which do improve the gameplay. New items like the glue grenades, remote grapple, and shock gloves all come in handy throughout the game, adding some new elements to the gameplay that I'll allow you to explore yourself should you choose to play Origins. The freshest addition to the gameplay is by far the renovation of the detective system though, which now allows you to reconstruct the events of any crime scene you come across. While a cool gimmick, it does start to get repetitive at around your dozenth or so time of using the mechanic, but overall I'd say it was a good inclusion for the gameplay loop. Moving on, we now reach my biggest qualm with the gameplay, which is without a doubt the questing. While both Asylum and especially City found a way to make each side story/mission interesting to complete, Origins goes for the standard AAA open world treatment, meaning many versions of the same missions are set in different locations of the city, leading to repetitive and predictable quests. While they didn't go too overboard with copy-paste quests, it's upsetting to see this happen to a game that has done better in the past with this element. The return of the Riddlers’ puzzles also can't go without a quick mention, and this time were almost designed well enough to make me try to complete them all, but did eventually become too much of a hassle for me personally. All of this content tallies up to a slightly longer runtime than that of Arkham City's, offering ~18 hours of gameplay for most people who don't play the challenge maps. While I may have seemed a bit harsh as I talked about the gameplay, know that everything I didn't criticize is likely as good as it has always been, with many of the core mechanics still around the make the game fun to play.   Originally posted by author:  Story  Though not the origin story of Batman, Arkham Origins does, in a round-about fashion, tell the story of how the Arkham Project (i.e. Arkham Asylum and Arkham City) came to be. The plot begins on Christmas Eve around 2 years after Bruce Wayne first became The Bat, and marks an important night in the character development of Batman. Black Mask has just staged a prison break at Black Gate, and is instituting a purge of all the members of the police force and Gotham's elected officials that he had in his pocket due to his rich crime empire. Once you, as Batman, interfere with this prison break, it becomes apparent that Black Mask has it out for you, and sends several assassins, from Deadshot to Deathstroke, out to kill you with the promise of a 50 million dollar reward. This even leads to you being at odds with certain corrupt members of the police force, as Gordon has only just become commissioner, and these unsavory cops want to claim the reward for themselves. All of this climaxes at Batman's first encounter with one of his most evil adversaries, and how he deals with him afterwards. Now that the plot analysis is out of the way, let's get to my opinions. While the many villains and assassins are interesting, they are far less emotive than they have been in previous entries in the series. This is made up for by the increased focus on Bruce's relationship with Alfred though, which is handled brilliantly with some top notch writing, which produces some great moments. The same goes for the relationship between Gordon and Batman too, but to a lesser extent. In congregate the writing itself is decent, and maybe actually better than the writing in Asylum, but is still outmatched by the narrative of Arkham City. The ending is a satisfying one as well, and does a commendable job at setting the tone for the chronologically proceeding events in the series. Altogether the story of Arkham Origins is solid enough to stand up on its own two feet, but does have some perceptible faults.   Originally posted by author:  inal Thoughts  For all its flaws, Batman: Arkham Origins is still a game I'd recommend to any fan of the series. I wouldn’t as readily recommend someone plays Origins before the other Arkham games despite being chronologically first though, as it may start any new comers out on the wrong foot with the franchise. In the end, despite borrowing too much from the previous titles in the Arkham series and not innovating enough in its own right, Arkham Origins is just more of the Batman we all know and love, which isn't too bad a thing if you ask me.

number of helpful: 11 of 21 people (52%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: October 28, 2016
												The plot of Batman: Arkham Origins is a refreshing departure from that of its two predecessors in that it resembles a bad Hollywood movie instead of a bad comic book. The game completely dumps its primary plot point early on for a tangential mess of disjointed, QTE-heavy fights and villain-hopping. There's literally a point in the final act where the main villain is imprisoned and Batman just goes and fights some side villains to kill time before his inevitable escape. There isn't a proper reason for Arkham Origins to have so many seemingly random subplots because not a one of them is any good, and none of the villains are at all as compelling as they were in Arkham City, with formerly interesting takes on comic book tropes replaced with super-fancy death battles between martial artists ending with one of them being defeated and saying something edgy like "What are you?" entirely unironically. Between this type of writing and lengthy, misguided attempts at forensic criminology, Arkham Origins is a hot mess of narrative shortcomings and gameplay blunders that amounts to an experience with the equivalent fun factor of Arkham City if it had been marinated in warm vomit instead of being play tested.Truly the cruellest part of Arkham Origins is that it doesn't even have the decency to simply be a bad game. No, this is the evil twin of Arkham City that was accidentally dropped as a child and promptly forgotten, and has spent the subsequent years watching its predecessor flourish in the spotlight of 9/10 ratings from mainstream media outlets and honed its skills for the moment it would release and prove to all that W.B. Games Montréal - a studio renowned for timeless classics like Cartoon Universe and the Wii U port of Arkham City - was as valid a developer as any other, and completely capable of releasing actual games as well. Except while Arkham Origins grasps the very basics of what made the series successful, (it needs combat, stealth and arbitrarily hidden  pickups), the level design, writing and pacing all got lost in translation, winding up with what is essentially a twelve hour trot through a truly diabolical parade of suffering for Arkham fans.Set on Christmas Eve, Arkham Origins depicts a young Batman in a city ravaged by rampant crime and a police force so corrupt that when influential mobster Roman Sionis - called Black Mask after his black mask - puts a $50 million bounty on the head of our brooding vigilante, the Gotham S.W.A.T. team is involved as quickly as the eight assassins privately contracted to do so. These assassins don't cooperate at all with one another, nor do they learn anything from their previous encounters with Batman, exemplified in the Electrocutioner, who is knocked unconscious by Batman in a single punch and then continues to pursue him, apparently believing he has a shot. The Electrocutioner is one of only a couple of these assassins who actually want the money. Bane in particular is established as being interested only in getting revenge on Batman for wronging him in some way. This is mentioned in passing a few times, but it never progresses past being a piece of exposition to squeeze into cool-sounding dialogue about justice. This is the primary motivator for most of the dialogue. In a tense scene between Batman and the Joker, the former demands that the Joker free a hostage now that he has arrived. The Joker responds with "you're just a distraction, compared with what I've got up my sleeve". In the end, of course, all the Joker wants is Batman dead, which he could, logically, have accomplished several times over in this story, but he chooses not to. It's the little things that really annoy me about this story. I can look past an overarching plot that's generally meaningless - this is a superhero game after all, but it's hard to tolerate the way Origins repeatedly sacrifices believability and common sense for cool-sounding dialogue. Combined with controls that feel like more of a suggestion than a command and a myriad of game-breaking bugs that are still mostly alive and kicking after three years, the crappy writing drags the whole thing down, providing such a wealth of things to criticise that I won't even go into a detailed analysis of its gameplay shortcomings. It would be fruitless to do so, seeing as the core product is so fundamentally misguided.My review of Batman: Arkham AsylumMy review of Batman: Arkham City

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 3, 2013
												TLDR; CAVEAT EMPTOR, BUYER BEWARESo, the third outing of Rocksteady Games' Batman: Arkham franchise is upon us. Rather than Rocksteady Games however, new developer Warner Bros. Montreal are at the helm this time, and it shows. Based on an Xbox playthrough, I can safely say WB:M were very wise to make no radical departures from the existing Arkham format, characters and locations feel very familiar, the near legendary combat engine is present in full with only minor adjustments (parry leniency, strike range, shock gloves). Everything feels pretty good, barring the odd input quirk here and there (Silent Takedown? Why not walk the dinosaur instead?). The actual game itself is really good.But there's a problem. There's a laundry list of problems. We are pretty used to half♥♥♥♥♥♥♥PC ports by now, but throw in core system problems including save corruption on consoles next to a staggering list of PC issues (see http://steamcommunity.com/app/209000/discussions/0/792924952554932514/ to get started) and you have a highly questionable release on your hands. While WB:M assure they are "working on it", things are looking chilly. I've been unable to complete the game on PC, only on Xbox, due to ranging issues including startup and exit hard system freezes, and ultimately save file corruption 10 hours into the campaign. Given the sheer number of issues the game is having on various platforms, and the lack of resolution to these problems from the recent fixer patch, I probably won't keep trying.All said and done, I am unable to recommend Arkham Origins in any way shape or form at this time. A potentially great game worthy of the Arkham name has been rendered unplayable by a seemingly untested, thoroughly buggy release. Wait for a later edition (GOTY seems unlikely, hurr hurr hurr), or revisit either of the earlier Arkham titles instead.

												Dispite much of the criticism this game has recieved for bugs and the like, I found it to be enjoyable and rewarding.  It effectively maintained the Arkham reputation for good story and a true-to-comic depiction of the Dark Knight himself.The multiplayer, dispite early problems, is now functional and highly enjoyable: an effective way to ensure continued gameplay after having concluded the story, always a problem in earlier games.If I were to do my utmost to find a problem which seriously affected my enjoyment of the game over a long period of time, it would be the essential sameness of it to the preceeding two titles.  Very little is exciting and new.  However, if you consider it simply as an expansion of Arkham City, it is a great game.

content:
Posted: December 3, 2013
												An incredibly buggy version of Arkham City (the new areas fail to contribute much to the game world) with forgettable characters and a story that went nowhere, perhaps deliberately, to persuade gamers to buy some of what looks to become a Borderlands-2-level of DLC.Nothing gameplay-wise has been improved: same gadgets, same combat and predator system, and, annoyingly, they've changed the perfectly good challenges system present in Arkham City to a sequential one, meaning you have to perform acts in a particular order. Pulled off a very difficult combo but aren't at the right stage of the vigilante challenges? Too bad, you have to do it again at a later stage.WB's appalling complacency and extremely late response to the multitude of often game-breaking bugs on the release of this game also influence my negative review and recommendation.

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 19, 2013
												What could have been a great game is flawed by some poor design choices: 'fast travel' is lazy and boring. I don't want to instantly arrive at destinations via a cut-scene of the Bat-Plane travelling; I want to fly the Bat-Plane myself and explore an open-world map in real-time. You know, like we can in decent games. I'm supposed to be Batman. Also, what's the point in unlocking cool, alternative costumes if I can't wear them until I've completed the campaign! The experience feels limited, too linear and restrictive compared to popular open-world games today. I can't help but imagine how amazing this game would have been if made with the depth and possibility of Saints Row IV. The atmosphere and story are lacking too. Disappointing. I will complete it though, because I am a long-time Batman fan, not because the game deserves my time.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 25, 2013
												Excellent gameplay. Excellent graphics. Good story.However, I still DO NOT recommend this game. The reason? Bugs.It's an excellent game, but only when it works. If you get it to work, you might still run into a bug that prevents you from progressing any further. And even if you are lucky enough to never run into such bugs, you might still get save corruptions. This game uses the same autosave system that were used in Batman Arkham Asylum and Arkham City. It will automatically save your progress, but it doesn't keep a backup. So if something should go wrong while it's saving, your save files are ruined. And that, trust me, is not fun.Just like Batman: AA and Batman: AC, the excellent gameplay was completely overshadowed by the bugs. Do not buy this game.

content:
Posted: November 30, 2014
												This game tells the story of a rich sad goth and his fight against Snow White Black Mask and the Seven Eight Dwarves Mercenaries. Seriously, there are so many villains in this game that it's like listing all the dwarves from The Hobbit. Can he collect all the Chaos Emeralds in time to save Gotham?SPOILER ALERT:Yes he can, but he's  GOTTA GO FASTFive minutes into the overworld, I'd discovered a glitch where Batman got stuck on a pipe and required a restart. Combat is wounded by the fact that countering no longer cancels all attacks. If I wanted to time my attacks and not button-mash, I'd play Dark Souls. I came here to be the night, not learn to fight.Game is prettier than ads for singles in my area, and runs better than my PC after I click on those ads. Maximum spec requirements: Pentium 486, 64KB RAM (should be enough for anybody), gives you constant 120fps max settings.Alfred Moneypenny is not modelled on or voiced by Michael Caine. This ruins the immersion, I do not feel like the night.Deathstroke does not crack wise or make fourth-wall-breaking jokes, like in the comics. Also, his costume is meant to be red (not orange) and they misspelt his name 'Wade' as 'Slade' for some reason. Probably a Japanese translation error, localisation sucks.Also, Batman's web-slinging sucks, he should get lessons from Spiderman lolIf I saw this game walking down an alley next to the Monarch Theater, I'd shoot it's parents.I give this game Commissioner Gordon out of ten.

content:
Posted: January 14, 2014
												The Batman Arkham series has been epic!  I was highly anticipating this game before it came out and hyped myself up for it.  I was a bit let down when they changed game studios for production of the game and rightly so.  The first two games were soo well polished that I would play through them multiple times always finding new easter eggs and still enjoying the content.Playing through this game once was enough and I have been let down.  It isn't a terrible game it just lacks the quality that I came to expect from the first two.  I can only recommend you buy this game on sale for say $29.99 or so... I wouldn't want to have spent any more on that and know that you won't like it as much as the others, if you've played them, but it is worth a play through.Pros:-Very Large World like... 4 times the size of Arkham City-Tons of side quests that could keep you busy to add longevity to the game play-More characters to play as in challenge missions-PvP option-Duna nu na nu na nu na nu na na nu na nu na Bat Cave!Cons:-Story isn't that good-Batman never seems to be in ultimate danger like in other games in the series-No real changes to the combat system which was always a bit bland-World is big.. but sometimes too big and travel between zones is time consuming-Not impressed with the design of the map... I never felt compelled to stop and take a look around at the beauty in the design of gotham-Serious bugs on game day launch including multiple game breakers... should be all fixed now though

number of helpful: 7 of 14 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 20, 2013
												I've been a fan of the Batman: Arkham series since it's inception. I've eagerly awaited each release, bought each DLC, and played countless hours in the first two games. They were nothing short of spectacular.Where the first (Arkham Assylum) established what playing as the Bat should feel like, the second (Arkham City) created a fantastic story complete with some of the best voice acting done in a game to date.This latest installment, Arkham Origins, undoes both the gameplay of the first (by having frequent glitches and crashes) and the story of the second (in that this one feels rushed, uninspired, and pushes the limits of credibility). Origins represents a large step backwards in the series, and a collasal disappointment.Saddest of all, perhaps, is that this game is meant to mark the last performance of Kevin Conroy (voice of Batman since the pivotal animated series in the 90's).I can only hope that Rocksteady -- the developers of the first two -- will retake the reigns for the next installment and bring a return to form which makes us forget about this mistep.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 5, 2016
												AO always manages to polarize the community - some people love it for it's gritty, angry Batman, it's more realistic suit and for referencing past comic tidbits (like Bane being rather cunning and clever). Others don't even want to consider it part of the main trilogy (and if you pay much attention to the Arkham City skyline in Knight you'll notice that Rockteady pretty much deleted WB's work. Adios Diamond District and the bridge.)Story wisel, it's okay. Some of the massive success behind Asylum was that it didn't push the history of the characters on you - it assumed you knew them already. Origins tries hard to introduce some key members of Batman's rogue's gallery but it's a sub par effort. It's esentially the only bit of lore that Rocksteady didn't do themselves. If nothing else it's fun to see Batman be more of a person - there's no cape-and-cowl chill when he's doing the nut, smashing computers and spitting when he growls.Oh - and counters are harder to pull off. I tell myself it's because Bruce is still too "angry and inexperienced" like they kept reminding us.Multiplayer mode isn't worth mentioning. I played it on PS3 and it was just broken. If you've got some friends or people who owe you, you can at least get all the achievements in private matches.All that aside, you've got a decent story, a larger Gotham space to play in that City and the Cold, Cold Heart dlc is quite good. Snag it on special.

content:
Posted: May 1, 2014
												This game seems to be more about the origin of a certain Batman villain more so then Batman himself. Right from the get go you already have most of the gadgets he had in the other Arkham games with a lot of the same fighting moves as well. So it's hard to call it a really good take on the origins of Batman in any sense besides what they say about him in the cutscenes. However that doesn't mean the game is dislikable. I enjoyed it quite a bit. In fact the game contained some of the best boss fights i've had in the series thus far.It was really cool going toe to toe with some of the deadliest assassins in the DC universe such as Slade (Deathstroke), Shiva, Firefly, Deadshot, and others. They were all different from eachother and always intense. Really I feel like I can recommend this game to anyone who enjoyed the other Arkham games. I know the formula hasn't changed much, but it's still fun and has a decent story to go along with it. Even the voice actors who filled in for Conroy and Hamill did a really good job at portraying younger versions of their characters.I have heard a lot of gruff about glitches and currupt saves and the like from various people. However, my experience has been nothing but smooth. No weird game breaking glitches or currupt saves here. Maybe I was just lucky. But i've seen no evidence of such things during my time with this game.There is a multiplayer aspect of the game that I played for an hour or so and then never touched again. Er... I don't know. I felt like it didn't add much. I guess give it a try and see if you like it.If you buy this game it's because you're a fan of the Batman Arkham series and you want more. Or because you're a huge Batman fan. Either way it's worth it at a decent price.Final Verdict (4 out of 5)

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 22, 2013
												It's like Arkham City but worse. Still alright. It's obviously a quick cash-in, It's nowhere near as polished as AC, and the amount of copy/paste is staggering. But it's not bad.I like games about punching people, and they more or less improved the punching people mechanics from Arkham City. The counter window is smaller, and the people punch you more aggressively. Origins has to be played more defensively, with less button mashing and more gadget use. At least on hard, normal is still easy. They tacked on some new enemy types in Origins too, which kind of work.So punching people is the most functional part of the game. There's a lot of dumb bs in the rest of it though.The story of the game makes no sense for the first half but it picks up once the Joker shows up, because the Joker is easy to write. The hyped up assassin plot is barely even relevant to the story: at no point does it feel like there's assassins trying to hunt you down. 4 out of 8 assassins are reused from they previous games because finding new villains is hard and takes work. Half of the assassins get reduced to sidequests, too, so it's actually Batman who's going after the assassins. The sidequests are kind of nonsensical. Deadshot tries to fight you in a tiny confined space in a sneak mission, even though he has a sniper rifle and could just set up camp somewhere and drop you when you glide by. I mean come on.I liked the Bane fight. The developers probably liked it too because they make you repeat it.The new crime-scene reconstruction thing is brainless and tedious. You don't even have to look for clues anymore, they give you a trail of red triangles to follow. Wow!All the AC sidequests have been copy/pasted here. Origins packs watered-down Riddler trophies (now enigma trophies), Bane Canisters (now black mask canisters) and the Zasz mission where you rush after phones (they're bombs this time). The added sidequests are mostly about punching people on the streets, which is something you'll do anyway, so that too is lazy.Many parts of the game feel like pointless filler, as if it was compulsory to pad out the game with reused assets. For some reason you go after the Penguin again and his boat hideout is laid out suspiciously like his museum from AC. You also♥♥♥♥♥♥around in the Steel Mill for a bit, go figure. Batman also gets poisoned again, presumably because they wanted to reuse his "poisoned" walk cycle. Then Batman goes on to have a bunch of lame hallucinations because that is part of the formula.Origins has a neat, dark winter wonderland setting, and gliding around the moody art deco town is all kinds of atmospheric. They did managed to ♥♥♥♥ up the grapnel gun a bit (it doesn't latch on to some buildings for some reason) and the map design is not nearly as tightly structured around gameplay as in AC. There's also no civilians in Gotham apparently, because of excuses. They should have at least put SOME civilians standing around here and there, but no, that's extraneous and all the corners had to be cut.I liked it and will have forgotten all about it by January.

content:
Posted: November 1, 2013
												As someone who would call themselves an expert in Arkham Asylum and Akrham City, the combat is "off" more or less. It's doesn't feel right, and the timings are off. I was doing a first impression live on my twitch stream, and i was suprised to how many times i was hit and how often i dropped my combos. For me, it was ridiculous!When i finally unlocked some Challenge Maps, i noticed that the combat was different yet again, but this time in a better way. My theory is that the combat seems off because it changes from story to challenge depending on your difficulty (I jumped strait into hard obviously).I was dissapointed when they shifted the dynamic away from Black Mask. I too thought that it was cool to see another villain get some attention on such a grand scale. I'm only up to the twist in the game, and while not bad, i was kind of like...dissapointed. It was such an obvious route to take that i had honeslty rolled my eyes when it all happened.The game is not bad by any means! I love it actually! One thing i have to give this game is the boss fights have been incredible! Each one is different and dynamic, and Deathstroke's boss fight has to be my favorite, i don't care who says it's repetative, it was fairly epic.The online is way more solid than i thought it would be. I am really happy with it, but dissapointed that you can't party up with teams of your friends, or at least i havne't found a way too. Winning as the heroes all comes down to the skill of BOTH players, and considering they are random selects, you can't control it. The ONLY times i win as the heroes are times when my partner disconnects. It has some work to be done, but it could be a very solid point in the game, more than it already stands. (Although my stats DO keep erasing).I wouldn't put this game up there as better than Asylum or City, but if you are a fan of the first one, then give this one a shot for sure. You won't be dissapointed, but if you are worried about bugs, then do wait a bit. I go into every PC game knowing it's going to have some issues, and i have the patience to wait them out for the most part.  :batlogo:

content:
Posted: December 24, 2013
												This is a tricky one.  It offers, from what I can tell, a larger world space but suffers from an insane amount of invisible walls.  Even though some can be circumvented by going out of the way a bit.  They did a good job making the city shiny though. The voice-overs aren't bad but not Kevin Conroy or Mark Hammill good.  The character models are as good as the previous games though.  The controls are the same, however the combat is a bit glitchy compared to the Arkham City; which, in my opinion, was the peak of this series.  The gadgets can also be glitchy in some instances and the game kind of lacks the polish that Arkham Asylum or City had.  And  I haven't even bothered with the online mode.  Not sure why developers feel the need to jam such things into single player games like this.  However, I guess Rocksteady is making a prequel to Arkham Asylum... which this game kind of is... and will most likely be of far better quality than this game is.  That all being said, if you really liked the last two games and don't want to wait for the next actual, REAL Arkham game then buy this one... but I would wait until it is $15 or less.  Definitely not worth the asking price or even half the release price.

												I don't know what the problem people have with this game is, but I don't care what those people think.  Batman arkham origins without being made by rocksteady is an amazing game with a great story line.  It's Batman raw, before he was always thinking everything 4 steps ahead, before he knew what he was doing all the time, before he gave a damn about hurting people.  This batman doesn't play about he goes in and kicks♥♥♥♥♥if you want a comparison think of the episode from BTAS back in the 90s when batman didn't have any fear and maneuvered through bullets like he was invincible. content:
Posted: November 29, 2014
												let me start by saying I'm the type that buys and plays a lot of games, but I don't usually beat them.  I did however beat the first two Arkham games and did so with ease and pure enjoyment, but this one for some reason is missing something. The pros -Graphics are nice although not a huge leap forward and the usual pop in associated with Unreal Engine games is here so one minute it's a muddled mess then next details pop in-Start off with a wide variety of gadgets although you could conceivably find this to be a flaw if you're nitpicky about plot and wonder how an origin story can have gadgets that were developed in the future -combat is nice as usual and challenge maps are also fun and offer a pleasant deviation from the main story -A large number of villians to go up against Cons -The combat timing in this one can be inconsistent whereas in City and Asylum is was consistent and flowing although that could be noob talk -The story isnt as engaging and enthralling as city's or Asylum's and I see myself beating this game eventually, but it wont be like the previous two where It is was like a great ride that came to an end it'll be eh, lets give this another try. -The villains are less compelling and lack personallity -The bugs have been fixed for the most part, but there are still some to be found especially in combat -The environment is dull and traveling can be tedious Summary it's more of the same in a lot of ways which is no surprise, but what is a surprise is that sequels usually are bad and the third one gets it back on track but this one, having not been produced by Rockstar, is an obvious step down in writing, atmosphere, quality assurance, and is clearly fan placation until the true sequel Arkham Knight is released. So should you get it? Well, if you loved the first two you may or might not like this especially if you go in with high expectations, but if you want more of the same then get it on sale. If you haven't played the other two then either one would be a better choice to be honest, my favorite being city although Asylum is a classic.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 26, 2013
												TL:DR version: Arkham Origins is a not very innovative, but not a complete messup either. The boss fights are greatly improved, with the story and voice keeping the same high quality. The gameplay has no great improvements besides a few tweaks and the Riddler side missions took a hit. But all in all, the game is fun and deserves your money. 8/10Batman Arkham Origins, the game many have anticipated since the day Arkham City release, is in many senses a flop/masterpiece. The gameplay is somewhat stale, but the bosses are greatly improved; the story is almost on par with Arkham City (and definately better than Arkham Asylum), but it's release was buggy. Therefore, I am going to review each part of the game seperately, then give you the final score (a weighted average with more important elements have greater weights). The scores are from 1-10 with a 1 being garbage, a 5 being average, and a 10 being spectacular.1. The Gameplay - Both the greatest strength and weakness of this new endeavor in the Arkham series is it's gameplay. While WB Games Montreal was smart in not trying to rewrite a broken system, they also did not bring much new to the table in terms of gadgets and fighting mechanics. There are some cool new gadgets like Deathstroke's remote zipline, and these are implemented fairly well into the game. Others however, such as electrocutioner's gloves make the game to easy in some aspects by allowing you to bypass the difficulty of the shielded and armor wearing enemies. The puzzles in the campaign are fun and challenging (a couple stumped me for a little bit) but the riddler side of the game has been slightly downgraded (as of this review the Burneley tower bug has been fixed so 100% is now possible).Gameplay - 7/102. The Boss Fights - The boss fights in Arkham Origins are easily the greatest improvement over Arkham City. With all of them being intuitive, imaginative, and creative, they are a joy to play. Most take something from an Arkham City boss and upgrade it e.g. taking the quick countering of Ra's al Ghul and then adding timing, variations, and a higher level of control for the Deathstroke fight (which is tied with the three part masterpiece of Bane's boss fight for best fight). This part is great, and I hope Rocksteady takes notes for the upcoming Arkham game they have been hinting at. The only dissapointing fight was the Electrocutioner, but it more served as comic relief than an actual flaw.Boss Fights - 10/103. The Story - The story of Arkham Origins has its ups and downs, but for the most part is solid. While I would have liked all eight of the Assassins to have gotten their own boss fight each, they are each implemented well in the story (with the exception of Electrocutioner). The game has its share of twists of turns that attempt to reach the glory of the now infamous ending to Arkham City (which I will not spoil, but if you have not played that game, fix that now, before you even think of playing this game. Arkham Asylum is also fun, but in my opinion is not critical to play before Origins. But you should.), but that in the end cannot due to the incredibly high bar. The story at some points feel slightly disjointed and confusing, but does wrap up quite nicely with a solid, though not incredible ending.Story - 8/104. Visuals - Arkham Origins has some slight improvements in the visuals, but overall not too much too offer in terms of newness. The cutscenes however, are beautiful and incredibly fun to watch, but the ingame graphics are only slightly better than Arkham City (which was as a side note, a beautiful game, don't get me wrong). Batman does move a bit smoother, but in the end it feels somewhat stale and halfhearted.Visuals - 7/105. New Features - This is kind of a grab bag of features that caught my attention, for better or for worse. One of the coolest things they added was an amazing new Crime Scene mode. You can recreate what happened during a crime and then look for clues based on where they were and following their trajectory. Another new feature is the Fast Travel System. I'm sure many liked this system, but for me it took away from the experiance. I love the feeling of flying around the city, looking for and stopping crime, and just feeling like an all around beast. But, since the Fast Travel is optional, there is really no fault in it, just personal preferance on whether it should be used or not.New Features - 7/106. Gotham City - While Gotham itself is not as big is many including myself thought it would be, it still is quite large, albeit that half of the city is a reskinned Arkham City with some new features. The other half however is as much a joy to explore as the Arkham City was in in its namesake of a game, the highlight being the ability to sneak in and take out corrupt GCPD officers in their own building. Perfect? No. Fun? Yes.Gotham City - 7.5/107. Online Play - Online Play is a variation of the regular team deathmatch mode with a twist. There are two teams of three henchman, either Bane's or Joker's, fighting each other, and one team of two, Batman and Robin, trying to stop them both. It's fun for a short while, and though I haven't gotten tired of it yet I have not played very much of it yet and could see one getting tired of it quickly down the road. What we really all want (Rocksteady take notes) is the ability to do a co-op campaign. But that isn't what we got and the multiplayer itself isn't bad. Just don't expect this to be the next big third person shooter.Online Play - 7/108. Voice Acting - Another major strength of the game is the voice acting. Many were scared to have Mark Hamill and Kevin Conroy relinquishing their respecive roles as the Joker and Batman, but fear no more. Troy Baker as a younger Joker nailed it perfectly and while there are slight differences, none are bad, and I am perfectly ok with him taking up the mantle as the Joker. His pauses, his laugh, his switch from soft to screaming in an instant, it's all perfect and I loved it. Roger Craig Smith took over Batman, and while I still stick with Kevin Conroy as the best, Roger does a good job showing what a younger Batman might have sounded like, not perfect, but still admirable and enjoyable. Other characters are voiced by the same actors as those from Arkham City, such as Tara Strong as the loveable but ever annoying (in a good way) Harley Quinn. The voice acting keeps it's high quality and it is always fun to just sit on a roof and listen to some annoying crook rant about the cold or missing Christmas DinnerVoice Acting - 9/109. Side Missions - Side missions have always been a fun part of the Arkham series, looking around to find as many villians as you can, and this holds true, for the most part, here. All of the side missions are fun and interesting in their own way, whether it be gameplay, puzzles, wierdness (see Mad Hatter), or the conversations that go on while do them. The one exception to this rule, and one of the biggest dissapointments of the game so far has been the Riddler puzzles. These have been made much easier, and there are so many of these "datapacks it becomes a chore. The radio towers add a little variety, but in the end the Riddler is a flop.Side Missions - 8/10With all that said, what is the game's final score? Arkham Origins is a hard game to review, because it's hard to pinpoint exactly what is wrong with it. In the end though, it falls short of its lofty expectations without being a bad game by itself. Batman: Arkham Origins earns a 7/10 on release (due to bugs) and an 8/10 with patches, but I am going to blame the bugs on WB pushing the game out the Door and give it a Final Score of 8/10. It isn't perfect, but it is well worth your purchase, though I highly recommend picking up the first two, Arkham Asylum and Arkham City first.Have Fun!-Daniel

content:
Posted: August 14, 2014
												I love Batman games in general I am going to give my review of the game.So first of all let’s start with the game mechanics, They are really good and super responsive I have to say that, but there are times when it feels like its requesting more commands and does extra punches or use baterangs or sometimes even change gadgets unwillingly. The controls are easy to use and very customizable indeed. You can have more than one button that executes the same control and/or ability. Now let’s talk about the A.I thugs and villains. Thy need MAJOR bug fixes some may just keep running straight into the wall and disappear, there was one time where I lost a missions and I restarted and all the thugs I had to knockout just vanished, NOT COOL! I came here for a challenge I'm playing on the hardest difficulty and I'm finding it too easy. I would have to give the mechanics a 7/10.Let’s talk about the music. I really like the music I mean I do. There's just one problem, the soundtrack is just too short only around about three-four hours. Then it can get really annoying and repetitive. I would suggest make a DLC soundtrack like most games do I don't care if it's from the previous Batman Arkham games, I personally think music from Arkham city would be a great addition! Until that happens I give it an 8/10.Onto the story line. The story is absolutely MARVOLOUS! I love it, great acting, great modeling, and the music just fits right in, it really does put you into suspense and makes you want to finish the game just to experience the story. I also love the side missions, how you learn more about Enigma, Anarchy, The Penguins A.K.A Cobble pot, is just fascinating. I give it a 10/10.The upgrade system. This is where it got really disappointing, I thought there would be a bunch more. It's too easy to level up and when I got the last few upgrades I was sad because I couldn't lvl up any higher. I think it would have been better with more customization and at least thirty+ upgrades to unlock. I give this a 6/10.The map. I personally don't think you can get the map wrong and I mean any game shouldn't, this is where it bothers me a lot. There are some times where I am in in area and it shows me somewhere in the middle of the ocean. I have to say there are long periods of time where I have to wait while I use the Batwing for fast travel I had to wait for three minutes one time! I give this a 9/10.Multiplayer. All I have to say is that it sucks! no one is on, you have to wait a good five minutes for a full lobby, but I do have to say the idea was good where two people are randomly selected to be Batman and/or Robin, and the rest gets to choose to be either in Joker's crew or Bane's. I give it a 4/10.The last thing I'm going to talk about are the DLC's, there are some amazing DLC's to get for this game, they are incredible fun and entertaining adds a whole new level of gameplay. I love the challenge maps, skin packs from previous games, different characters to play as all of that. I give it a 10/10.Overall I do think it's a good Batman game to own, but wait till it's on sale next summer because I got it with all the DLC's for 13$ even though normal price is 87$ I did the math. It's not worth all that money. I will give my overall impression the game deserves a 7/10.

content:
Posted: December 28, 2013
												Batman: Arkham Origins is a game that follows the same formula as the past ones. Beat♥♥♥♥♥♥up with a satisfying combat system and have a damn good time. But it ain't without it's flaws. The prerendered cutscenes look bleddy awful when compared to the game on near-max settings, and I've had far more bugs than in Rocksteady's man-dressed-like-a-bat games. For example, in huge swarm-like fights, one or two enemies will often get stuck in walls, leaving you to have to start the fight again. Furthermore, the final boss battle requires you to perform a beatdown on the enemy. This beatdown is completely nonfunctional with a keyboard and mouse, allowing you to punch only twice without plugging in a controller. That being said, the core gameplay is still great and the story is, in my opinion, far more fleshed out than the previous Batfink games. In conclusion, Bluntman: Harlem Oranges is a pretty decent game, which you should buy from your local Torrent retailer.

content:
Posted: April 7, 2016
												I've played all the Arkham games and Origins is  probably my favourite entry in the Arkham series. Set as a precursor to the Arkham series, it tells Batman's beginnings as the Dark Knight and his initial struggles of vigilantism.I often feel a distinct lack of a satisfying boss battle in all the Rocksteady developed Arkham games. Arkham Origins is about Black Mask setting a bounty on Batman's head, it might seem a bit of an overload to cram in 8 villains into this game, that's what I though, but man did Splash Damage pull it off. Its a one-on-one showdown between the Bat and the villains. Each villain plays differently and beautifully. The boss fight with Deathstroke is one of my favourite moments in the Arkham series. Regarding DLC, only the one featuring Mr Freeze is worth a purchase.

In it's current state it is buggy and at some points, completely broken! These issues include random crashes, graphical issues, such as severe screen shaking and flickering images. There are issues with the sound in certain parts, and there are more progression-blocking bugs known that can be looked up online.Do not buy this game for the single player experience before these bugs have been officially fixed, and the game is no longer broken. Releasing a game in this state, when you're such a big company with so many resources is just not okay. To be honest, people would be angry about these kinds of issues in indie games.

content:
Posted: December 27, 2013
												This game had a lot of potential and it's an okay game. But there are a lot of bugs and glitches, especially during the launch. I'm suffering from a major bug where the cutscenes take too long to load, causing it to not be in sync with the game and it even gets cut off at times. It also didn't quite capture the feel of the first two games, which had very beautiful scenery and atmospheres. This game abandoned that and replaced it with very, very gray and dark areas. The first two games had a very smooth combat system, where the game would instantly respond to your inputs, but this game somehow managed to break it, leaving behind very low-accuracy attacks, and counters that sometimes wouldn't even respond (which is especially obvious during the deathstroke fight, which basically is a mashup between counters and quick time events that almost certainly miss, causing a more difficult than it should be fight). The predator system is very different from the last two, pretty much only having one way to clear a room without being detected, unlike the numerous ways to do so before. The game also suffers from having gameplay and story segregated heavily, such as the grapnel boost, which was supposedly in experimental phase during Arkham City, with this being a prequel, it doesn't make that much sense at all. Finally, the story wasn't very engaging either. Hopefully the next installment can be made by Rocksteady again and we can forget this slip as soon as possible.

content:
Posted: February 25, 2014
												AO is a solid game despite the vitriol surrounding it. The story itself stands out as the best in the series, taking a page from the Nolan book both in terms of visuals (the bat suit is clearly a carbon copy of Bale’s in the Dark Knight), and in a preference for (relative) realism over mystical ninjas and shapeshifters. Still, the few game play innovations Arkham Origins manages to make are disappointing—namely the "I-win" shock gloves that sap all thought from combat and break any RP connection you have with old bats, and the remote claw which, while cool in concept, ends up giving the player three free stealth kills in every predator encounter. Since most stealth sections contain eight thugs max, this majorly undercuts the teeth-grinding challenge they ought to pose in the latter half of the game. The world also feels empty. There are Riddler challenges to tackle but nowhere near as many as in Arkham City. Gone too are the citizens of Gotham, relegated to their homes by a dubious Christmas Eve curfew. This in particular robs the game of a potentially fantastic innovation—the interplay between Batman and the common citizen. Wouldn’t you love hurdle over a rooftop only to land next to an awed/terrified couple canoodling on the fire escape? How would they react? How would YOU react? Part of Batman’s mystique is the image he cuts in the non-criminal mind. In the next game I’d love to see that aspect explored.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 14, 2014
												Like so many superheroes, Batman as a real life crime fighter would be ludicrous. In comic books, movies and games, Batman works when the darkness is turned all the way up to 11 and the drama is dialled right up. And it's amid this inky blackness and relentless peril that WB Games Montreal has taken the Bat once again, following in the intimidating footsteps of Rocksteady, and the incredibly lofty bar it set with Batman: Arkham Asylum and Arkham City.Batman: Arkham Origins takes Bruce Wayne back to his roots with a story set prior to the events of the first two games. On paper it sounds like a foolhardy idea to make a prequel, with a whole new voice cast no less, and it begged the question, could WB Montreal match Rocksteady in the execution? In short, the answer is a resounding yes. Batman: Arkham Origins is more of the same in the Arkham City mould, but in the best way imaginable."Boom! Power stance, baby!"Origins' narrative is pretty meaty stuff too, set in the heart of a Gotham City that's tearing itself apart as villains rip through its decaying streets on the search for the Dark Knight, in the vain hope that they'll score Black Mask's $50 million bounty. The game could have quite easily been a romp from A to B, dispatching the assassins out to kill Batman in sequence, but instead there's a strong story laden with twists and turns, and the odd unexpected surprise for the fans.Bats himself is relatively new to a life of fighting crime in Arkham Origins, a myth on the streets of Gotham, largely unknown by Captain Jim Gordon and the GCPD, and written off as a freak; a bizarre sideshow, a menace. Chatter among thugs roaming the gloomy alleyways reveals talk of sightings, conjecture and hearsay about the Bat, with most dismissing his existence as ghost stories and spooky hokum. Until you show up on the scene and prove that you are in fact all too real, that is. This particular version of Batman is also one who's self-involved, determined to go it alone and fuelled by anger. He's younger, more brash, raw and reckless.Like Asylum and City before it, Arkham Origins is about instilling fear in your enemies, although essentially the series' core gameplay mechanics remain untouched, with a few tweaked gadgets like the glue grenade, the odd new one like the concussion detonator, and a couple of fresh moves in Bats' repertoire. Though is has to be said, turning the tables on enemies with the shock gloves is an exceptionally empowering thrill.A game still largely comprised of exploration, free flow combat and predator sections, if you've played Rocksteady's previous two Batman games you'll feel right at home with this one. Arkham Origins doesn't set out to break the mould or reinvent the rules, and yet it still seems like a bold game, and one that proves relentlessly entertaining as you breathlessly freewheel from one set-piece to the next."Get that thing out of my face."Instead of familiarity breeding contempt, Batman: Arkham Origins somehow feels fresh. Even when you bump into a building you're sure you've seen in Arkham City a million times before, it's from a different Gotham years in the past, indistinguishable enough from its future counterpart. Indeed, the city itself is in an entirely different state, with none of the flooding that claimed a chunk Gotham in the previous game, and some taller and more imposing architecture to scale.Arkham City's locked down Gotham was an urban nightmare caked in rust and decay, ruled by feral gangs running amok. Origins' version is a city on a steep downward spiral, but one where there's still a shred of hope buried beneath its seething cauldron of corruption. Knowing that glimmer of hope amounts to nothing doesn't make the atmosphere and tension any less palpable.If anything there are more criminal gangs and crooked cops on the streets, and when you're not punching their faces to burger, you'll be foiling another one of The Riddler's plots, tracking down Anarky, Shiva, Deadshot and a host of other villains that you could ignore altogether if you chose to. There's a whole raft of optional tasks to complete in addition to what is a solid 10-15 hours of story. Collectibles are just the tip of a very big iceberg."Shocking."On top of all of this is an improved and more involving Detective Mode, in which Batman gets to prove his credentials as the great and much-vaunted sleuth that he's supposed to be. You now set about reconstructing a crime, piecing together the components of what transpired, before Bats comes to his own conclusion. It's not exactly LA Noire, but it beats the previous games' efforts.Arkham Origins is not without its frustrations however, and some of the Predator encounters and boss battles can prove trying at certain junctures. Predator areas aren't quite so clearly defined in some cases, and controlling Bats can prove fiddly when there's no obvious place to hide. There's a fight with Deathstroke too where the game attempts to explain that you need to look for an opening to strike and time your counter moves accordingly, but the result is messy and the ultimate outcome – at least in our personal experience – feels arbitrary.On top of a generously proportioned campaign is an entirely separate multiplayer component, assigned to its own disc and outsourced to UK Brink studio Splash Damage. Multiplayer takes nothing away from the fantastic single-player, and has a few neat ideas of its own. Is it a unique enough proposition to stand out? Not really. A rather shoddy Gears of War clone, multiplayer pits two criminal gangs against one another in a straight-up shootout, then throws randomly selected players into the mix who assume control of Batman and Robin. It's playing as the dynamic duo that proves the most fun, filling your Intimidation Meter and swooping down upon unsuspecting enemies.The batarang. Don't leave home without it.Conversely, playing as a bog standard thug is typical tacked-on multiplayer fare with a decent cover system and solid shooter mechanic. It clearly sets out what it aims to do, and Splash Damage has done a fine job in creating a multiplayer mode that slots neatly into the Batman Arkhamverse, but it's hard to imagine it'll have legs amid a slew of better multiplayer options already available and just on the horizon. Multiplayer isn't bad by any stretch of the imagination, but its long-term appeal is questionable.If you want to complete the entire achievement list, you'll have to put some time in with the multiplayer however. That means reaching Prestige level and achieving maximum rank with both the Bane and Joker gang factions, which will take a good few hours and then some. The story campaign is where it's at of course, and this time there's not only New Game Plus to beat, but there's also the 'I Am The Night' mode. Chuck in achievements attached to the Challenge Rooms, and the wealth of content and replay value on offer is simply staggering.A triumphant third outing for the Dark Knight, Batman: Arkham Origins is proof positive that the series is in safe hands with WB Games Montreal. Building upon the strong foundations of the first two Arkham titles, Origins boasts the same marriage of compelling storytelling, uncompromising gameplay, killer combat and faithfulness to the source material. Batman: Arkham Origins is an empowering rollercoaster ride and a more than worthy successor to the cowl and cape. Another dark heroic fantasy that demands to be played.

content:
Posted: May 1, 2014
												This game seems to be more about the origin of a certain Batman villain more so then Batman himself. Right from the get go you already have most of the gadgets he had in the other Arkham games with a lot of the same fighting moves as well. So it's hard to call it a really good take on the origins of Batman in any sense besides what they say about him in the cutscenes. However that doesn't mean the game is dislikable. I enjoyed it quite a bit. In fact the game contained some of the best boss fights i've had in the series thus far.It was really cool going toe to toe with some of the deadliest assassins in the DC universe such as Slade (Deathstroke), Shiva, Firefly, Deadshot, and others. They were all different from eachother and always intense. Really I feel like I can recommend this game to anyone who enjoyed the other Arkham games. I know the formula hasn't changed much, but it's still fun and has a decent story to go along with it. Even the voice actors who filled in for Conroy and Hamill did a really good job at portraying younger versions of their characters.I have heard a lot of gruff about glitches and currupt saves and the like from various people. However, my experience has been nothing but smooth. No weird game breaking glitches or currupt saves here. Maybe I was just lucky. But i've seen no evidence of such things during my time with this game.There is a multiplayer aspect of the game that I played for an hour or so and then never touched again. Er... I don't know. I felt like it didn't add much. I guess give it a try and see if you like it.If you buy this game it's because you're a fan of the Batman Arkham series and you want more. Or because you're a huge Batman fan. Either way it's worth it at a decent price.Final Verdict (4 out of 5)

												To Whom it may concern: i have never played any of the other batman arkham games.This was the first batman game i ever played and i timed it perfectly. This game is a prequel to the other two batman games although it was technically the third game that was made. I am going to break the game down based on gameplay, story, and batman's costume as well as the look of arkham. Gameplay:1. Easy to learn2. Combat is realistic3. Almost all tools that you gain as the game progresses are used at some time 4. (After doing some reasearch) The game play is relatively the same compared to the other games5.The boss fights are very fun, while also being chalenging Story:1. The story is logical and makes scence 2. The characters rolls are well portrayed3. This game explains(mostly) how the other games came to pass4. The story has unexpected twists and turnsCostume/Graphics:1. The batman costume is updated and more armored2. The Villans are also updated with newer looking costumes and voice actors3. Even the lower graphics setting look very good. My computer can only run medium to low graphics on most games but batman arkham origins looks good even on low settings In conclusion this game is a very good option to buy. It has aspects of the other games while it also updates the graphics and apearance of the characters are updated. This game is worth every penny and if you enjoyed the rest of the batman arkham series. Even if you have never played any of the other batman games this would be a very good option.9/10

Posted: December 13, 2015
												This game has its good point and its bad points, but its bad points beat me, here's why.The game failed to update that I'd completed various missions, such as stating that I still needed to collect the second chip in order to find the Penguin when I had in fact already used it to track down the Penguin.Regular goons are much more observant, resulting in very few opportunities to be sneaky batman unless the encounter is specifically designed for it.The ctrl button seems to have a large delay, resulting in it often not activating at all and the insta-kill move against downed enemies is hit and miss.On occasion a boss that had to be killed to progress the game would fall through the floor.Bosses would randomly realise that they could dodge attacks and their ability to dodge would skyrocket effectively negating strategies that worked against them in every reload before and after.The story was good, the graphics were nice, but these issues of gameplay have made it a struggle to play.
