content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												Inherently, everything that is good about this game was in the previous two titles that were made by Rocksteady. This game offers very little new content, with half the assassins ending up being overshadowed side mission that don't do the characters justice.The game itself is still quite good, with most of the core mechanics remaining the same. Movements, expecially grappling and gliding are a little off, and the combat (with the City approach of 'more guys = harder) starts to show it's flaws when surrounded by 20+ enemies.Overall, this game still has a very solid core to it, and should definitely be played. Yes, it is the weakest in the series, but that is because the first two were so strong. Some of the elements of this game are nicely done, just pretend multiplayer doesn't exist though. Writing (although I personally did not like the story) is quite nicely done, and everything about this game still holds it's own.The weakest part of this game is that it is the third in a series, and it is definitely a step backwards. If this was a first up game, we would still highlight the flaws but could see the room for improvment. The sad fact is that there have been two games already that have overall been better. But I do encourage you to play this game, because it is still the same engine and gameplay as the first two - and that is still a damn good thing.

number of helpful: 4 of 8 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 28, 2013
												The game we asked for but not the game we wanted.I write this review as a fan of the Arkham series with a huge preference towards Arkham City.  If you believe that makes me biassed I suppose I would be a fool to disagree.However, on with my thoughts on this game.  I was one of the people who experienced delays with getting their game and the issues I experienced with installing it have been well documented on the forum.  So after finally getting it installed I started playing with the mindset "I really want to like this but I am already hating it", so I was extremely biassed from the outset.  Then the game started and the intro was not really on par with the previous titles.  With Arkham City, the story was broken relatively slowly.  Origins certainly upped the ante and decided upon a bit of a more "up tempo" beginning.  A bit of a video, a quick change, into the action and off to Black Gate Prison we go for the obligatory "prologue"/"training" level.  This is something very common in games now.  The prologue not only trains you (if you're not already familiar with the Arkham controls) but gives you a quick intro to the story.  After that you're in the city of Gotham, going about doing the ususal goon punching.  The story develops at a pace that is a bit start/stop.  After you face the first boss (who I was surprised to face so early) you then hit the city (both figuratively and literally) fullfilling quests that at times feel a little hollow.  There has been many comments about the larger city scape being not much more than a cut and paste affair.  Which is true, there are often quite literally parts which show that WB Montreal had access to the assets from the previous games and were explicitly told to use them.  (I even noticed in the end credits that part of the Rocksteady team that worked on the previous titles were drafted in to help with the game build.)  But then, reusing assets is nothing new and has been happening in the animation world for years.  When the developers announced this and did the usual publicity, the adage that was reinforced was "if it ain't broke don't fix it" and it's fair to say that's almost true.  However I think they also forgot the "if it's fixed, then don't break it" which is how I feel the combat is sometimes - that is broken.  There are times that I find myself swearing at the game because I have felt the combat is not as good as it perhaps should have been.  Teleporting enemies, bats that are a foot longer than they're shown in the modelling, counters not working correctly.  It's tough to get the timing of the combat in this game at times with the game breaking the rhythm that you've learned to play to (and that's after adapting my combat technique from the City one to the Origins one).  Yes, I kind of excused that at first, after all we're playing a less refined Batman earlier in his career but when a game breaks the rhythm and timing that it has established, that's a bit off.Yes, there's reused world space assets, yes there's reused goons, (both of these things are how games in a series are made) and no this game did not innovate as much as the others.  The one area they did innovate gets overlooked and that's the crime scene analysis and detective vision.  There's more reason to use detective vision in this game with all the hidden pieces to find but the new Crime Scene Investigation (or CSI:Gotham) part are marred by the fact that they're not used all that often and they are nothing more than interactive cut-scenes with a large portion of hand-holding.  It's not a case of finding the evidence but looking where you're told to look.  Anyone who's been gaming for a reasonable amount of time is quite adept at finding those elements in games on there own - either by deductive reasoning or by understanding video game mechanics.  The whole hand-holding you through those parts just ruined any innovation they had brought in.  Ok, so that's the "packaging" of the game - what about the story?  Well, ladies and gents, if you're looking for a really meaty story about the origins of Batman then watch those films with Christian Bale.  This game is about the Origins of the Arkham trilogy (which is only a trilogy due to the fact they bought this a third title out).  While it tries very hard to make it's mark on the series, it just come across to me as a "tribute" to the Arkam series rather than a title that deserves to be in the trilogy on it's own merits.  Reused assets aside, there are story elements that are all too annoying to forgive.  (no spoilers but there was one part when I shouted at my computer and turned the game off for all of ten minutes questioning the whole "did you really pull that?")There are contrivances to every story in the world, but the contrivances of this game are, not to be melodramatic (unlike this point in the game), plain unforgivable.  This game tries really hard not to be but just ends up being contrived.  Shoe-horning elements in to fit the canon and making a foul up of it along the way.  The plot twists never shocked me and the contrivances annoyed me.  Which is a shame because, by and large, the performaces of the voice actors wasn't wholly terrible.  You could easily forgive and forget that Troy Baker wasn't Mark Hammill.  While trying to put his own "mark" on his performance of his part (see what I did there?) he did well in aping Mark Hammill's performance.  The performance of Roger Craig Smith was passable when he could remember that he was playing the Arkham Batman and not the Christian Bale Batman.  (It was funny if I noticed this change mid sentence and even funnier when he did a full Bale/Arkham/Bale conversion in one conversation).  The criticisms of others saying "oh, but it's nothing new" either missed the point of buying another game in the same series (which is to get more of what we already knew, so where's the fail?) or completly overlooked what was new and innovative (which didn't always work).  At least this could run in DX11 straight out of the box which left use with a very pretty game.  If you're a fan of the series, you probably already bought it and have made up your mind about it.  If you're not a fan of the series, then consider this Arkham Batman light (all the taste but only half the calories), not a bad contribution if it's the first ever Batman game you played.  Which I suppose is not a bad thing.  If anything could be considered a fail in regards to this game, that is the setting.  Setting a Batman game (or any game for that matter) to a Christmas backdrop and releasing it in October produces two problems.  One, when the game is beaten before christmas and you've played quite a few hours of it, you're sick of Christmas before Advent begins.  Two - it's Batman.  If you're going to send out a lot of people to hunt down a double-hard vigilante who wears a costume resembling a bat then Christmas is not the best time (especially when you release a game in October). The best time (as voiced by my partner) is surely Halloween?  Setting a game at Christmas makes replayability a bit weird.  Afterall who wants to be thinking of Christmas in May?  And replayability of a game is a major selling point to me, personally.  Horror can be done all year round but Christmas Eve defines a very short period of replayability to me. We Batman fans however wanted another Batman game and that's what we got.  Unfortunately, we didn't get the game we expected but it seems foolhardy to be compaining about getting what you asked for.  Rocksteady set the bar so high that it was always going to be tough for this game to be an "instant classic" and while it doesn't quite live up to it's predessors it's definitely a good introduction to the series for newcommers.  I have my own theories about this but it's beyond the scope of this review.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 10, 2016
												Arkham Origins is a mixed bag of the best that the franchise has to offer and the worst that a montreal based company can offer. It's batman thats for sure, and the villians well they are entertaining to fight. The machanics that follow each confrontation have that familiar once you get it its easy feel, and the story or narratvie does a little bit to flesh out this alternate version of the caped crusader however. The question remains is this title nessisary? The previous two and the following arkham knight are a set trilogy, and are confirmed to be apart of the same continuity and story. So making the transition between each title feels seamless. Less like a new installment and more like a continuation. Unfortunatley Arkham Origins while on many levels being very much a "origins" story feels a little disconnected. It feels like it should be apart of its own trilogy. The new gameplay mechanics , and side quests feel a little bit tacked on as such. In that sort of Assasins creed collectables kind of way. Overall though its as I had stated before still very much a batman game just doesn't quite feel like an arkham game. Like for example in Arkham City after you find enough riddler trophies not only are you given an alternate task to save hostages, but your also given an opportunity to catch the riddler or in this game Enigma. In this game all that effort really just amounts to getting an acheivement or a trophy. Which I mean its kind of nice but it lacks the closure or menace of completeing, or not completeing a case file. Like when you hunt down hush in Arkham City , and he reveals his identity before vanishing while leaving you trapped inside his lair. You have to accept you couldn't catch him, and your left wondering whats next.I definetly wouldn't give this game a ten maybe a 7.5, and that would be the reason why. These side quests don't feel fleshed out they feel tached on and repetitive. Taking into account the limitations of the hardware other glaring issues i.e where are the gotham citizens? are forgivable.I'd still reccomend playing this game just play it before Arkham Asylum. Not just for story purposes , but because If you play this game after Arkham city you will likley find it a little disappointing.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 16, 2013
												Batman Arkham Origins is basically an expansion pack to Arkham City. In that way, if you enjoyed that, you'll enjoy this, provided you aren't already burnt out on the whole thing.Combat is a bit arcade-y which is kind of nice for people who seek to score high. Additional multipliers for not being hit, varying your attacks, I can see the draw to the challenge modes that further this goal. The shock gauntlets kind of cheese the difficulty by being able to override shields and foes that typically have to be stunned, so it feels like a bit of depth is lost once you have those. Perhaps alieviated when played on a higher difficulty. I just played on normal.The stealth sections or room clears didn't gel with me. Particularly because I guess I was not great at them. Clearly them silently seems to require extensive patience since any stealth take down typically results in the enemies finding the body and them all being near each other until you wait for them to spread out again. Plus it's easy enough to just to knock out who you want and then retreat to the rafters and repeat.Story is forgettable. Joker is bad. Other villians. Yes. Cool.No real interesting variations to the boss fights. Just lots of enemy hoards or sneaking around. For the most part.People who seek collectables and enjoy filling bars will find plenty to do. Clearing optional villian based objectives or performing combat challenges. I'd enjoyed clearing the map and the Most Wanted but Enigma Trophies are too numerous and same-y for me to drop the time required to gather those up. I can see the draw, though.7/10. It's Batman.

content:
Posted: September 30, 2014
												Batman: Arkham Origins is the 3rd installment in the Arkham series and is the prequel to the previous 2 games. It takes place in Old and New Gotham on the night of Christmas Eve, and wouldn't ya know, someone wants to kill Batman. He has been targeted for assassination by multiple assassins, including, but not limited to, Killer Croc, Bane, and Deathstroke. Some people would like to say that this game is the worst in the franchise, but is this correct? Well, it definitely has its moments. In fact, I believe it is much more influential and memorable than Arkham Asylum, the first in the series of these games.Now, do I recommend this game? Oh yes. This game was enough fun for me to return to it multiple times, and it has much more to do even after completing the game, like challenge maps where you can actually play as Deathstroke.The gameplay is pretty much the same as the last 2 games in this series. Nothing fancy here, just some new gadgets, which I will not spoil.Alfred has a much larger role in this game, acting as your go-to guy for info, and your... Well... Advice guy. The story took a big turn for me, and I wasn't expecting it to go where it did.This game truly did not deserve the bad reputations that it got, and in my opinion, is the second best in the series.

content:
Posted: June 14, 2014
												In this game you play as muti-billionaire Tony Stark as he decides to live up to his dead parents legacy by beating up anyone on the streets of New Jersey, and maybe stopping some crime bosses along the way. And Heath Ledger makes an appearance as a gay cowboy as well.In this game you are given tons of gadgets to play with, all of which are incredibly contrived and don't actually make you feel like Bat Iron Man at all. You fight a multitude of bosses, all of which are really boring, especially when you fight Solid Snake Slade. That battle consists of pressing counter for an hour and nothing else, eventually Solid Snake Slade gives up and you have him arrested.When you are beating up random citizens of Gotham, the combat feels fine. Although the fighting style of Bat Iron Man is akin to a very nimble amature boxer and would get him beat up in the real world. GG Bat Iron Man, you dead.The game has some very interesting plot twists, you think you are fighting one big bad guy, then it throws you through a loop when you have to go beat the♥♥♥♥♥♥out of Booker DeWitt, I mean, Heath Ledger the Gay Cowboy.All in All I think Bat Iron Man Tony Stark EA Origin is a game with a contrived plot that feels needlessly long and jumps around worse than this review. 0/10, since there were no female characters and I felt like the game was oppressing me.

number of helpful: 7 of 14 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 20, 2013
												I've been a fan of the Batman: Arkham series since it's inception. I've eagerly awaited each release, bought each DLC, and played countless hours in the first two games. They were nothing short of spectacular.Where the first (Arkham Assylum) established what playing as the Bat should feel like, the second (Arkham City) created a fantastic story complete with some of the best voice acting done in a game to date.This latest installment, Arkham Origins, undoes both the gameplay of the first (by having frequent glitches and crashes) and the story of the second (in that this one feels rushed, uninspired, and pushes the limits of credibility). Origins represents a large step backwards in the series, and a collasal disappointment.Saddest of all, perhaps, is that this game is meant to mark the last performance of Kevin Conroy (voice of Batman since the pivotal animated series in the 90's).I can only hope that Rocksteady -- the developers of the first two -- will retake the reigns for the next installment and bring a return to form which makes us forget about this mistep.

content:
Posted: November 30, 2014
												This game tells the story of a rich sad goth and his fight against Snow White Black Mask and the Seven Eight Dwarves Mercenaries. Seriously, there are so many villains in this game that it's like listing all the dwarves from The Hobbit. Can he collect all the Chaos Emeralds in time to save Gotham?SPOILER ALERT:Yes he can, but he's  GOTTA GO FASTFive minutes into the overworld, I'd discovered a glitch where Batman got stuck on a pipe and required a restart. Combat is wounded by the fact that countering no longer cancels all attacks. If I wanted to time my attacks and not button-mash, I'd play Dark Souls. I came here to be the night, not learn to fight.Game is prettier than ads for singles in my area, and runs better than my PC after I click on those ads. Maximum spec requirements: Pentium 486, 64KB RAM (should be enough for anybody), gives you constant 120fps max settings.Alfred Moneypenny is not modelled on or voiced by Michael Caine. This ruins the immersion, I do not feel like the night.Deathstroke does not crack wise or make fourth-wall-breaking jokes, like in the comics. Also, his costume is meant to be red (not orange) and they misspelt his name 'Wade' as 'Slade' for some reason. Probably a Japanese translation error, localisation sucks.Also, Batman's web-slinging sucks, he should get lessons from Spiderman lolIf I saw this game walking down an alley next to the Monarch Theater, I'd shoot it's parents.I give this game Commissioner Gordon out of ten.

content:
Posted: February 24, 2015
												Warning: Spoilers AheadIf you want to know what I think of the game without spoilers, just know that: It's a great entry point for people starting the series, and still an enjoyable romp for veterans of the series despite the overall uninspired level design and combat. The story and performance of the characters is what sells this entry, and in my opinion is a must play/watch for any Batman fan.This game gets lots of flack, and only some of it is deserved. I agree with people who say the game itself is uninspired, borrowing practically every element of their game from Rocksteady's preceding games. I also agree that when it first released, it was a buggy mess. Thankfully most major issues are all fixed now, and I didn't run into anything game breaking (a far cry from when I played it at launch on the 360).Now, despite Origins' lack of innovation, I still think it's well put together. The actual design of the game, which admittedly lifts much of Arkham City's design, is very well done, and despite some reviews I've seen that say they added nothing of their own, there are TONS of added easter eggs and content that reward Bat-fans. Furthermore, Origins adds one cool new thing that is original and adds a much needed kick into Arkham's aging combat system; the shock gloves. The shock gloves alleviate some of the tedium of combat that veterans of the Arkham series are likely getting a bit tired of, if only because they mastered it two games ago. It is essentially a temporary super powerup, allowing Batman to do even more damage to enemies and therefore ending fights even quicker. They are also incorporated into a few puzzles, but aren't actually that clever despite looking pretty cool.Speaking of puzzles, one thing Origins does better than any of the other Arkham games are the crime-scene reconstructions. They have multiple steps, and are a lot of fun to figure out. Yes, it may be scifi mumbo jumbo, but it's engaging nonetheless.Most importantly, I feel that Origin's story is overlooked completely by most critics. The story of Origins is objectively the best in the series. It isn't overly convoluted, and doesn't contain any out-of-character moments like the Titan-Joker fight in Asylum. While I truly appreciate the comic-book style storytelling in the first two games, and I certainly don't think Batman needs his origin retold ever again, the Arkham games nonetheless are not good entry points to casual Bat-fans. Despite it being common knowledge amongst many comic-readers, most gamers had no idea who Oracle was in Asylum, and the fact that there were many people online legitimately trying to figure out who Azrael was supposed to be in City only cements that most players are casual Batfans. Despite my personal appreciation of Rocksteady's willingness to jump into the deep end of Batman lore, I can't help but think that it hurts various storytelling elements and opportunities.Origins, on the other hand, tells a concise Batman story, where motivations, plot twists, and themes all come together and really impress on a more universal level.It should also be noted that while I don't think Roger Craig Smith did a bad job as Batman, he certainly doesn't have the range nor depth of Conroy. Troy Baker as the Joker, on the other hand, is in some ways even better than Hamil. Don't get me wrong, I LOVE Hamil's Joker, but unfortunately for Hamil he was never really given an opportunity to cut loose with the character until much later in his career of voicing him, and his vocal chords at that point simply couldn't take that kind of strain. Baker is in his prime, and takes Hamil's version of the Joker (indeed, it is still Hamil's Joker, and I know Baker wouldn't deny it) to new levels of gritty realism and black humor that Hamil's Joker never got to really experience but a handful of times. It could be argued that Arkham Origins' plot is centrally about Batman and Joker's relationship's Origin. There is a brilliant section in the game that takes the classic Bruce Timm/Paul Dini story Mad Love, and somehow makes it even better by taking Joker's manipulation of Harley to another level completely. After being asked to describe fate by Harley, Joker begins rattling off his origin in typical dramatic fashion. The thing that's brilliant to me is that it's unclear if Joker even realizes that he's manipulating Harely; his romantic description of fate and everything it entails is [from the player's perspective] clearly concerning his relationship with Batman, but to Harley, it sounds like Joker is spilling out his feelings for her. This whole section plays out from a rather dramatic and abstract thought-plane from the Joker's perspective, with the player controlling Joker, maneuvering him through this surreal landscape while he describes how important fate is to him. It's all done so well, and Baker's performance really shines.Another point that shines in the game overall are the new boss encounters. The assassins out to kill Batman are all capable, and in my opinion the real standout is the fight with a female Copperhead. While similar to the R'as fight from City, Copperhead's hard-to-read, snake-like movements make for an intense fight. Certainly, the boss fights overall in Origins are more varied than Asylum by far, and even City in my opinion, although nothing tops the Mr. Freeze fight from City.Speaking of Mr. Freeze, the one extra DLC story mission is concerning Freeze's origins within the Arkhamverse. It starts out in Wayne Manor, and the player gets to control Bruce for a long while, which I always enjoy. It tells more or less the same story as the classic animated series tale, but modernizes it in a few key ways. For one, Batman reconstructs the fateful moment concerning Freeze's tragic origin, and this reconstruction is by far more engaging than the Animated Series original version where Batman simply sneaks into a security room and watches some easily-accessed, surprisingly well edited security tapes. Beyond that, though, there really isn't a substantial departure from the original tale, and like other elements of Origins, simply seems uninspired. It's done well enough, and it's worth playing through just to hear Marice LaMarche's performance as Mr. Freeze.So overall, despite its uninspired gameplay and in certain cases storytelling, Arkham Origins is still quite well made, and certainly worth a playthrough for fans and non-fans of Batman alike. Just because it's uninspired doesn't mean it's bad, and now that it has been patched for a non-glitchy experience, there's no reason not to give it a play. The music is well done, if again, uninspired (it's mostly Gothic renditions of Christmas themes, since the game takes place during Christmas Eve). The voice acting is overall quite great, as well as the digital acting. The story is well put together and stands out as the most accessible and arguably well-written entry in the Arkham series. So play it if you get a chance, I don't think you'll be disappointed.

content:
Posted: November 29, 2014
												let me start by saying I'm the type that buys and plays a lot of games, but I don't usually beat them.  I did however beat the first two Arkham games and did so with ease and pure enjoyment, but this one for some reason is missing something. The pros -Graphics are nice although not a huge leap forward and the usual pop in associated with Unreal Engine games is here so one minute it's a muddled mess then next details pop in-Start off with a wide variety of gadgets although you could conceivably find this to be a flaw if you're nitpicky about plot and wonder how an origin story can have gadgets that were developed in the future -combat is nice as usual and challenge maps are also fun and offer a pleasant deviation from the main story -A large number of villians to go up against Cons -The combat timing in this one can be inconsistent whereas in City and Asylum is was consistent and flowing although that could be noob talk -The story isnt as engaging and enthralling as city's or Asylum's and I see myself beating this game eventually, but it wont be like the previous two where It is was like a great ride that came to an end it'll be eh, lets give this another try. -The villains are less compelling and lack personallity -The bugs have been fixed for the most part, but there are still some to be found especially in combat -The environment is dull and traveling can be tedious Summary it's more of the same in a lot of ways which is no surprise, but what is a surprise is that sequels usually are bad and the third one gets it back on track but this one, having not been produced by Rockstar, is an obvious step down in writing, atmosphere, quality assurance, and is clearly fan placation until the true sequel Arkham Knight is released. So should you get it? Well, if you loved the first two you may or might not like this especially if you go in with high expectations, but if you want more of the same then get it on sale. If you haven't played the other two then either one would be a better choice to be honest, my favorite being city although Asylum is a classic.

Posted: June 23, 2014
												Although not as good as City, Origins is still a pretty good game in it's own right, and it's gameplay style will be very familiar to players of the previous two games. Origins definitely had a huge lot to live up to when it was brought out, as many people felt that City was unbeatable and that the Warner Bros studio would mess up. In my opinion, the gameplay and freedom was much better in this game, as it has a larger world to explore than City. The story, however, wasn't nearly what it should've been, and felt rushed and unfinished in places. As Origins is a prequel to the first games, it could easily be skipped without missing much, but to players who want an extra dose of Arkham before the new game releases next year, it's a worthwile purchase without a doubt.

content:
Posted: April 21, 2014
												Buggy and a pathetic port of a console game. They didn't even try to pretend that this was going to be played on a PC. The menu describing the controls actually shows the XBox controls, not computer controls. (i.e. Use X for this, Y for that, no mention of keyboard at all). This is a massive problem because in the first few minutes, you WILL get stuck because the game doesn't tell you to let go of the batclaw by pressing Left Control. Furthermore, the game glitches out massively and frequently. For example, it is very common to complete an interrogation mission, but the interrogation option doesn't actually appear/work. Your only choice at that point is to exit the game, re-load, and do it all over again. Also, the game will freeze and crash at one point during a cutscene after a mission. It hasn't been patched, and a google search shows that you have to manually modify the config file to fix it. The graphics are nice, but with such broken gameplay, its a total waste. Do yourself a favor and get Arkham City instead, its basically the same gameplay, but its not broken.

Especially when doing the worst nightmare challenges which are really easy to miss since you cannot do them inside challenge mode. Otherwise, Arkham Origins  could have been a great Batman game; the story was there including some great voice acting by Roger Graig Smith (who is does a great Batman) and Troy Baker who doesn't sound like himself at all as the Joker. So I find myself unable to recommend this game at full price. Wait for any Steam sale or price reduction.

content:
Posted: December 2, 2013
												While Arkham Origins (AO) didn't really revolutionize the Batman gaming franchise it did provide one good thing and that was more Batman. In my mind this game was more of an extended expansion pack of Arkham City with many of the same features with a couple new ones sprinkled in here and there. While some may have been hoping for an all new Batman experience I was content to continue on being the same old badass I had been in the previous games. As with the other games the story is well done and kept me interested. Although I do wish that some of the newer characters that were introduced were explained a bit more. As their stories were a bit lackluster. Overall though I think the story was fun.As for the mechanics there isn't much new here if you've played any of the previous games. The same great free flow combat system is in place with a few new gadgets to play with. Overall though, combat is largely the same. I did enjoy the remake of the detective mode and all of the cool features that now come with that. It made me feel like more of an actual detective than I was in previous games. Finally, for the online portions. I have not put that many hours into the online area yet, although from the short time I've spent there I'm not sure I will. While some what intriguing and posing a particularly interesting gameplay mechanic of having a 3 team match. The fact that that is the only game mode available makes it a lot less interesting. Combine lack of players in with that too and you have a fairly lackluster multiplayer. Overall, the ideas are interesting, but the execution is poor.In closing, I really enjoyed the game. If you liked the previous Batman games, you'll probably like this one too.

content:
Posted: December 2, 2013
												As a fan of Rocksteady's previous Arkham games, I too was skeptical - as many others were - of Arkham Origins being handed over to another studio (WB Montreal). However, at least for the most part, they've done a damn fine job. Arkham Origins thankfully stands up as a great third entry into the Batman Arkham franchise.Gameplay remains largely unchanged from Arkham City, but why fix what isn't broken? The excellent Freeflow combat system is back and as good as ever, though enemy attacks are a LOT harder to dodge - this gets very frustrating in larger fights. I'm not sure if this was intentional, but frankly I find it annoying. That being said, I think that's literally my only gripe with the game.The "predator" sequences, wherein you sneak around a room, slowly picking off enemies one by one, is as awesome as ever. You still feel like the Dark Knight himself throughout the entire game. And there's a lot of game here - it'll take you over 20 hours to do everything in the game, and then there's New Game Plus and the new permadeath mode: I Am The Night. Odd that a game like this has a permadeath mode, but I guess if you really want a challenge, go for it.The story in Arkham Origins is my favourite in the series, by far. There's a lot of great twists and turns you definitely won't see coming, but it also has a few predictable moments. I really don't want to spoil anything, but every scene that involves The Joker is solid gold. Speaking of Joker, Mark Hamill stepped down from the role after Arkham City, but Troy Baker certainly does a fantastic job of filling the spot, even if he does sound like he's trying to be Hamill.Batman also sounds way too much like Chris Redfield from the Resident Evil series, but that's because they now share the same voice actor (Roger Craig Smith). It's a real shame Kevin Conroy isn't voicing Bats here.Overall, Arkham Origins is a great Batman game, and well worth playing for the incredible story alone. I've just finished off everything in the main game, and now I'm going straight for the challenge maps and New Game Plus.

content:
Posted: December 19, 2013
												Origins was nearly guaranteed to be a best selling game judging by the two prior games in the series. It's important to remember, however, that the game is made by a different developer, and worst of all: It shows. While Arkham Origins' storyline and characters are amazing, including the new "younger" cast of voices for some characters, the mechanics themselves are querky. For once you are limited to grappeling to certain areas only while soaring through the skies of Gotham, and random glitchy occurences will also have you performing flips in the air, going through objects, or best of all punching someone twenty feet away as the game teleports you to the nearest enemy regardless of distance during your combos. Putting aside these imperfections, however, the storyline is progressively exciting with great twists for any fan of the lore. Surprise appearances by various personalities are also a treat, but nothing beats watching Batman's struggles as he learns to mature over the course of this game with the help of Alfred as he realizes he cannot be the sole savior of a city when its filled with villians he could never have imagined.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 3, 2014
												Though it is an unneeded game in the franchise and many will be put off by its visual departure and lack of inventiveness, it is still a good game.Pros-Visually great! I personally like Batman's younger less blocky look. I was always a bit put off with how derpy Bruce looked in the past games. So this was a welcome change in my book.-Atmosphere. Arkham City made me feel cold while i was playing it. It gave me the sensation that i was snug and cozy in my batsuit while all the unlucky thugs were miserabley cold. Arkham Origins makes me feel that if it wasn't for my batsuite I would be suffering from hypothermia. The added christmas vibe gives this the best apmosphere in all of the games in my opinion.-Story. I have to confess I haven't beat the story yet but I honestly don't see it being any better or worse than the previous titles. It is a perfect excuse to suit up as Bats and beat up on a portion of the Rogue's gallery. Will update this after I have completed it.Cons-Multiplayer. A very creative idea and when a match gets going (after waiting anywhere from 5-20 minutes) it CAN be alot of fun. But like many mp games these days it was an after thought and this game is very evident. It's nice to see a different mp idea surface but it needed more time to stew.-Tech. Once again we have an Arkham PC release with poorly used DX11 and Physx tech in it. I found, like Arkham City, when gliding around Gotham and DX11 is enabled the game starts spurting and stuttering so much that it pulled me out of the experience. Thankfully you can disable dx11 features to make the game a much smoother experience. Though still not 100% free of the stutter (thank you unreal engine). I disabled mine from the ini file which seemed to do a better job than simply disabling it from the in game options. And honstely, you're not missing much with these features turned off. If you are a gamer, like me, who prefers fluidity over graphical fidelity then do yourself a favor and TURN DX11 OFF.-COD syndrome. No advancement. Nothing new to see here other than story and some new visuals. If you are expecting a change like we saw in Arkham Asylimg to Arkham City then you will be dissapointed. However don't let that stop you from enjoying a game that is still really good despite it not stepping outside of the box a bit. Here's to hoping the next game doesn't follow suit.Despite some bumps and bruises throughout this game it is still a fantastic title. Especially to Bat fans and those who are jonesing for a bit more Arkham in their gaming library. Give it a whirl!

Posted: January 3, 2014
												Naysayers abound for this game and I have no idea why!  This game by far made me feel like Batman than the other two by a wide margin.  Batman in a prison and Batman in a bigger prison  is neat but actually going through Gotham City and interacting with police on the streets was a much awaited experience.  Whoever said the boss battles in Origins are dull must love generic, because in my opinion on Arkham Asylum and Arkham City boss battles was lackluster at best.  The only boss battle I enjoyed at any length was the Mr. Freeze battle where you had to use your wits to defeat him.  In Origins almost every boss battle was clearly thought out and AMAZING (Especially Deadpool).  The weather effects and the music are fantastic.  Some people have said they added snow to hide the draw distance, but I think it looks impressive regardless (Especially if you have a good PC)  Some people have also said the story was nonsensical.  I'm not sure what aspects of the story are so nonsensical but I enjoyed it greatly.  Yes, you meet Joker yet again, but the depth of the characters is really on full display here.Now the negatives:-The Riddler ending - DO NOT WASTE YOUR TIME!  Look it up on You tube and I promise you won't want to see the ending either.  They should have given him a lesser role if they wanted to have that ending. (Aka, not wasting a couple of hours going to every crevice of the city.)-The bridge.  Even with the quick travel system that bridge was exhausting to go through.  And you WILL go back and forth.-The city is alive only when you have events do to. I think this is mostly on the fact of the dev being handed this instead of having two games prior to work within their own merits (small grace, if they do another Arkham this aspect won't be so forgiving)-Upgrades.  They are boring.  Plain and simple boring.  The fact they are connected to different systems in the game is more frustrating than anything else.  I don't know why they chose to go in this direction but it's frustrating.-Audio tapes.  Why can't they take notes from System Shock, Deadspace, and a litany of other games where you can listen WHILE you play.  They might be great tapes but I wouldn't know, sitting on a single non-moving screen seeing the tape play is just plain boring.  No transcripts, either.That being said, I think it's the best of the three.  I hope they fix the problems and really make the next Batman (hopefully give them a couple years to get it perfect, don't annualize it!) what it deserves to be.

content:
Posted: February 6, 2014
												What is the definition of a blockbuster game? Well, some would say that either of the games from the Arkham series are exactly that. What Arkham Origins is, however...is not much different from what the other two games were. So much of the story was in the shadows until now, when Origins was made to be a prequel to the other two monumental games. What Arkham Origins isn't however…an overhyped or underwhelming game, in fact...it has much more content than what Arkham Asylum had. I personally always wanted to see what all happened before the first game, because there was quite a bit of backstory between Batman and the villains that lead up to the first game. Here is my experience and thoughts of Batman: Arkham Origins.Gameplay: What some people complain about is that the game is more or less the same than Arkham City. This would seem like it is a little bit of a problem, but Arkham City is an amazing game. Having the same concept for the gameplay is more good than bad. Combat is what Arkham has always been, a beat-em-up system with combos similar to how Devil May Cry is. Every new mechanic added to the game, while not making it counterproductive to what the premise of the game or story is.Sound: Everything seems to be up to par with using the old sounds, with all the new sounds being clean and precise. Not much has been changed or improved, but how can you improve on something that was already perfect? There were little problems with sound cutting out or not triggering, but it was more of with one cutscene that you will see whenever you use the fast travel points that are in the city.Graphics: Arkham Origins is a demanding game, like how Asylum and City were when they came out. I am currently using a GTX 760, and it was running the temp close to 80 C yet still able to run on max at 60+ FPS in 1920x1080. What the game gives is a masterpiece molded together into a beautiful but dark game. PhysX is used to more of an effect than most other games with smaller objects like dollar bills, toilet paper thrown around and even steam that reacts to your movements.Story: Everything that was culminated in the Arkham story is all shown at it's start, with quite a few of the villains that were talked about in the story were actually battled for the first time. It does feel like the general story that Batman does have, but it's a timeless classic and does deserve to be told in the ways that it is done nowadays. Batman has a massive $50 million bounty put onto his head by an unknown person, with every villain and mercenary gunning for your head. It gives you a sense of doubt that you can handle everything that is thrown at you, with many story elements around every corner.Multiplayer: This part of the game I have yet to be able to get into due to poor Steam integration and lack of dedicated servers. In the year 2014, there are and will be games that are going to use Peer-2-Peer as a main source for online server hosting. Though this does make me sad, because from what I have seen in videos of people being able to play the multiplayer with others, it does also make me hope that others will attempt to play it more.Overall, it's an amazing game and well worth buying if you plan on playing the other games. Playing this one first before Asylum and City is a great way to be introduced to the story and characters since it is in fact the beginning of the Batman in the Arkham storyline. The few bugs and glitches that I did encounter were somewhat annoying, but nothing major happened throughout the several hours I spent playing through this game. Definitely worth the money that I spent on the game, and will be willing to play the game again, as it does have quite a bit of extra content both during the story and after it is over.

content:
Posted: January 21, 2014
												I just responded to a friend's positive recommendation of this game with the following and realized that I never "unrecommended" it officially, so here's my lazy copy and paste:Personally, it was by far the weakest of the three games and was definitively generic as opposed to the stellar work of Rocksteady's creations. It was despicably mediocre and clunky and lazy in design. As much as I like Troy Baker and it may have been the voice direction and not his fault, but Joker was not the Joker. He wasn't scary or funny or remarkable in any way. He was a deranged bad guy like any of the others: boring.Pros:- Batman's replacement voice actor- license and established Rocksteady IP- letting us see how Joker sees things- the new detective casesOther than that, it was a♥♥♥♥♥♥poor Arkham City reboot. I have replayed the first 2 games at least 3 times each and will probably go back for more in the future. I hurried to finish Origins so that I wouldn't have to play it again. I was SUPREMELY disappointed and will only purchase another Arkham game if Rocksteady does it.

content:
Posted: May 1, 2014
												First, the bad: The game has some minor bugs I ran into. Nothing game breaking though. The main bug I ran into was that the interrogate mechanic just stopped working on me three different times and I had to reload the last checkpoint to fix it. The game constantly tells you to ctrl+right click to knockout dudes that are on the ground but it almost never does anything when you press it. Also there's one side mission where you get trapped in a dream world and the camera angles are all wonky and it's extremely difficult to get through with the mouse and keyboard. Luckily I have a gamepad but not everyone does. Also there is an entire set of collectibles called "Gotham intel" listed in the menu that I somehow made it through the entire game through without even finding out what these are. Would have been nice if the game bothered to explain any of that stuff.The good: Batman is a badass. A rich jerk badass. It's fun zipping around the city, gliding into packs of criminals/cops/criminal cops and just beating the everloving snot out of them all with your ridiculous gadgets. There's lots of side quests to do, major villians to stop, minor villians to stop, crimes to solve, and dumb hidden trophies ("datapacks" in this one) to collect. The multiplayer: Didn't play it, don't care. The single player is the reason to get this game.

content:
Posted: May 1, 2014
												This game seems to be more about the origin of a certain Batman villain more so then Batman himself. Right from the get go you already have most of the gadgets he had in the other Arkham games with a lot of the same fighting moves as well. So it's hard to call it a really good take on the origins of Batman in any sense besides what they say about him in the cutscenes. However that doesn't mean the game is dislikable. I enjoyed it quite a bit. In fact the game contained some of the best boss fights i've had in the series thus far.It was really cool going toe to toe with some of the deadliest assassins in the DC universe such as Slade (Deathstroke), Shiva, Firefly, Deadshot, and others. They were all different from eachother and always intense. Really I feel like I can recommend this game to anyone who enjoyed the other Arkham games. I know the formula hasn't changed much, but it's still fun and has a decent story to go along with it. Even the voice actors who filled in for Conroy and Hamill did a really good job at portraying younger versions of their characters.I have heard a lot of gruff about glitches and currupt saves and the like from various people. However, my experience has been nothing but smooth. No weird game breaking glitches or currupt saves here. Maybe I was just lucky. But i've seen no evidence of such things during my time with this game.There is a multiplayer aspect of the game that I played for an hour or so and then never touched again. Er... I don't know. I felt like it didn't add much. I guess give it a try and see if you like it.If you buy this game it's because you're a fan of the Batman Arkham series and you want more. Or because you're a huge Batman fan. Either way it's worth it at a decent price.Final Verdict (4 out of 5)

content:
Posted: September 30, 2014
												Batman: Arkham Origins is the 3rd installment in the Arkham series and is the prequel to the previous 2 games. It takes place in Old and New Gotham on the night of Christmas Eve, and wouldn't ya know, someone wants to kill Batman. He has been targeted for assassination by multiple assassins, including, but not limited to, Killer Croc, Bane, and Deathstroke. Some people would like to say that this game is the worst in the franchise, but is this correct? Well, it definitely has its moments. In fact, I believe it is much more influential and memorable than Arkham Asylum, the first in the series of these games.Now, do I recommend this game? Oh yes. This game was enough fun for me to return to it multiple times, and it has much more to do even after completing the game, like challenge maps where you can actually play as Deathstroke.The gameplay is pretty much the same as the last 2 games in this series. Nothing fancy here, just some new gadgets, which I will not spoil.Alfred has a much larger role in this game, acting as your go-to guy for info, and your... Well... Advice guy. The story took a big turn for me, and I wasn't expecting it to go where it did.This game truly did not deserve the bad reputations that it got, and in my opinion, is the second best in the series.

content:
Posted: June 14, 2014
												In this game you play as muti-billionaire Tony Stark as he decides to live up to his dead parents legacy by beating up anyone on the streets of New Jersey, and maybe stopping some crime bosses along the way. And Heath Ledger makes an appearance as a gay cowboy as well.In this game you are given tons of gadgets to play with, all of which are incredibly contrived and don't actually make you feel like Bat Iron Man at all. You fight a multitude of bosses, all of which are really boring, especially when you fight Solid Snake Slade. That battle consists of pressing counter for an hour and nothing else, eventually Solid Snake Slade gives up and you have him arrested.When you are beating up random citizens of Gotham, the combat feels fine. Although the fighting style of Bat Iron Man is akin to a very nimble amature boxer and would get him beat up in the real world. GG Bat Iron Man, you dead.The game has some very interesting plot twists, you think you are fighting one big bad guy, then it throws you through a loop when you have to go beat the♥♥♥♥♥♥out of Booker DeWitt, I mean, Heath Ledger the Gay Cowboy.All in All I think Bat Iron Man Tony Stark EA Origin is a game with a contrived plot that feels needlessly long and jumps around worse than this review. 0/10, since there were no female characters and I felt like the game was oppressing me.

content:
Posted: April 8, 2016
												To Whom it may concern: i have never played any of the other batman arkham games.This was the first batman game i ever played and i timed it perfectly. This game is a prequel to the other two batman games although it was technically the third game that was made. I am going to break the game down based on gameplay, story, and batman's costume as well as the look of arkham. Gameplay:1. Easy to learn2. Combat is realistic3. Almost all tools that you gain as the game progresses are used at some time 4. (After doing some reasearch) The game play is relatively the same compared to the other games5.The boss fights are very fun, while also being chalenging Story:1. The story is logical and makes scence 2. The characters rolls are well portrayed3. This game explains(mostly) how the other games came to pass4. The story has unexpected twists and turnsCostume/Graphics:1. The batman costume is updated and more armored2. The Villans are also updated with newer looking costumes and voice actors3. Even the lower graphics setting look very good. My computer can only run medium to low graphics on most games but batman arkham origins looks good even on low settings In conclusion this game is a very good option to buy. It has aspects of the other games while it also updates the graphics and apearance of the characters are updated. This game is worth every penny and if you enjoyed the rest of the batman arkham series. Even if you have never played any of the other batman games this would be a very good option.9/10

content:
Posted: June 23, 2014
												Although not as good as City, Origins is still a pretty good game in it's own right, and it's gameplay style will be very familiar to players of the previous two games. Origins definitely had a huge lot to live up to when it was brought out, as many people felt that City was unbeatable and that the Warner Bros studio would mess up. In my opinion, the gameplay and freedom was much better in this game, as it has a larger world to explore than City. The story, however, wasn't nearly what it should've been, and felt rushed and unfinished in places. As Origins is a prequel to the first games, it could easily be skipped without missing much, but to players who want an extra dose of Arkham before the new game releases next year, it's a worthwile purchase without a doubt.

content:
Posted: May 2, 2014
												Arkham Origins is a bit controverse for the third game in a row to be such an downfall.In Arkham Assylum you are chasing threw an dark psychotrip and got kind of an straight storyline to follow threw the depths of hell. It plays well and works really god, no mayor bugs even if you think so at first, because you can see all these Riddler-Trophys which you can't get. Turns out that you get these Gadgets that help you getting them later. Clever.Arkham City is even darker when you get thrown into an whole City that was turned into an jail. You actually start as Catwoman and turn the good to bad and bad to good while kicking and punshing the f*****g ♥♥♥♥ out of the real big guys in an combat-system that rocks you socks off. The fight against Mr. Freeze is an nice example for an clever battle where you can not win by just hitting a button like an woodpicker.Than there was Arkham Origins... well..The Storyline is still great. You gotta give the credit that they had cool storylines in all the games and manged to stay as close as possible to the original comics as they could.The game plays before the other two games in timeline (did Star Wars start this? and why is everyone making an copycat out of it?)  and shows some old Supercrimes like Black Mask (when I think about it, they made the time-twist to bring the joker back)The fightsystem changed a bit again. It changed barely enough to make you vomit when there are more than 5 enemies at a time. While always able to stop in attacking enemy in AC - you get your♥♥♥♥♥kicked in AO all of the time. It doesn't help that from time to time the input on keyboard and/ormouse seem to be partly ignored and instead of going to the left upper corner of the room, you slam into the wall on your left as hard as you can.This brings me to the worst Part of this game: BUGSI played this game over and over and over.. and if there would be any statistics about starts and/or crashes you could see how many times I only played for about five minutes. I got the game about first day it came out and really thought it might be getting better soon. Now I installed "Cold Cold Heart" and mine broke. I am actually writing this Review now, because the game just stopped... no clue why.When I got the game I had the problem with the riddler-tower where the window closes and you can't escape the room, because the way you are suposed to go is blocked by an bug. Thanks to the genius who found and glitch (and also made it public - thanks again) me and many others glitched our way through that and other minor problems.A good thing is that they changed the detective-mode so that you are no longer in an godmode kind of version. Now it is sometimes better to turn the Mode of to see more (for example, sometimes you can not see enemys in an slightly wider range around you and they magicaly apear when you turn detective-mode of) That is good, but why the hack does Batman not see his own Batsignal which you use to mark points on the map? Looking up into the air: batsignal... detective-mode on to avoid bad guys with big guns: Where am i going? the green "!" on your navigation helps a lot...  but only until you realise that you just passed your marked spot for the second time.It is sad that they changed the combat and that the bugs drive you insanse. I would have loved to give it an good ranking for the great story and the cool new invention where you can go through the crime by timeshifting and see how things happened in special places, but that doesn't help when the game crushes.6/10(get Arkham City instead if you didn't before)

content:
Posted: April 25, 2014
As a big fan of the previous two Arkham releases this was pretty disappointing gameplay-wise.tl;drThere were many bugs such as combos cancelling even after hitting counter (especially on the new martial artists enemy) and some fights not starting until you reload the checkpoint.Including the technical stuff I've got my own personal gripes about this game;For one, the sounds you hear when you beat on baddies don't feel as awesome. They may sound more "realistic" (I think that's what they were going for) I guess but they just don't have that cool feeling of hitting someone and knowing when you've knocked 'em out cold.A number of the gadgets are basically just rip-offs of the gadgets from the previous games (glue grenade hah).Despite a bigger map and more enemies standing everywhere Gotham feels shallow.Some areas pull jerk moves by making you only go a certain, specific path to a destination when it seems like you could get there a more obvious way. (tl;dr rant)  Here's an example: a place you had to go inside of was protected. The front door was heavily armed and the game kept suggesting me to find an alternate route. However I decided "well we'll just see about that" and kicked every one of their arses to the ground. So I remove the guards from the front door ONLY TO FIND THAT I CAN'T GO THROUGH IT. It wasn't locked either, or better yet it didn't really SAY anything about the door at least when I went to detective mode anyway. In detective mode I saw that the door wasn't even highlighted thus highly suggesting that I was never even supposed to go in the front door in the first place. And when I walk up to it Batman just starts repeating "I need to find another way in" or something like that everytime I go up to it. So, I take out every guard protecting the door to my objective only to realize that I wasn't even supposed to be here because the script says "no you were supposed to go to the alternate route." That heavy scripting in this sandbox-y game ticked me off the most good golly god. /rant The plot was at least interesting, however I feel that the assassins didn't have enough screentime (especially Slade). Most of the bossfights were at least pretty cool and fun to play too as they felt more like I was actually being challenged (mostly).All-in-all, unrecommended, because I'm too much jerky for what I expect. It's at least very playable until the end for the story though for the actual gameplay, I gave it a chance, despite hearing its negative words said about it, and overall unfortunately I was pretty bummed. Technical problems, fan-ranting, etc.I didn't really try the multiplayer since I didn't care much for that.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 19, 2013
												More of the same...but that's not necessarily a bad thing.If you're looking for new gameplay, new tactics and a new experience, this isn't the game for you. Arkham Origins (AO) plays very much like Arkham City (AC) and Arkham Asylum (AA).  There are a few new gadgets, different villians and a fast-travel system, but the combat is very much like the other games.One new interesting feature is the ability to re-construct a crime-scene. It's not ground-breaking, but it does add some fresh air to the gameplay. As with the other games, you are tasked with stopping the bad guys while taking names and cracking heads. Along the way, you'll also run into numerous collecibles scattered around the snowy city.  Getting around is a bit easier as the city is now divided in several districts, each with a Batwing Drop point.  If you enjoyed AA and AC, you will enjoy this. But as it's more of the same, hold out for a sale.  As of December 19th 2013, the lowest price I've seen for this is about $23.

content:
Posted: July 11, 2015
												This game is amazing for those who like Batman games. It has a great story, one which is different from the other 3 Batman games but similar to each other in combat and voice actors. It has a story where Batman doesn't even know the Joker up until the near end. Some parts of it can be difficult, but it took me 6.6 hours to finish the whole game. I enjoyed every minute of this game and I will surely start a new game or even play the online mode. Once, I got stuck in my room because the lock got broken(not stating why :P) and I was stuck in my room for an hour. I didn't even care since I was playing this game the whole time. The only part of the game that was really scary was the last boss fight against Bane when he was Hulk 2.0. That part itself was so scary and the music was just making it worse. Everytime Bane saw me and ran towards me with his huge body, I literally couldn't think of doing anything. Took me 20-30 mins to man up and beat him thought. The other boss fights weren't as scary or difficult, but I hated the parts that were like: defuse 4 bombs, rescue hostages, defeat Firefly. Those parts were just annoying, but not bad.10/10 Would totally get stuck in a room again to play this game.

content:
Posted: May 25, 2014
												For reference, this review is primarily concerning the DLC, Cold Cold Heart (as well as some of the Season Pass content).  My review for the original game is at http://gamersglance.com/2013/11/11/batman-arkham-origins-review/.  In my review for Arkham Origins, I noted a number of game-breaking bugs.  I am sorry to say that WB Montreal patched only a few of these, and actually made the Burnley Tower issue worse by making some of the buildings surrounding it physically intangible (as in, you literally fly straight through them).  They coupled their poor attitude towards releasing a very broken game with an announcement some months later that they would no longer be patching the main game and were focused on DLC.  I remember thinking, "So your plan is to build DLC on top of a broken game?  What could POSSIBLY go wrong?"Oy vey.As you might have guessed from the DLC title, the storyline DLC Cold Cold Heart (which is a lame lame title) is the origin story of Mister Freeze.  Minor spoilers ahead, but here's the short list of what I liked.-Getting to navigate Wayne Manor is cool and those levels aren't poorly designed.  Plus Alfred regualrly smarms the goons who are holding him hostage.-Thermal batarangs look pretty kickass and are actually used in a neat way.Yep, that list was short.  Here's the bad stuff.-The story is completely predicatable for anyone who is even remotely familiar with Mr. Freeze, even if your only familiarity comes from his appearance in Arkham City.-The main story arc takes place in an artifically limited version of Gotham (two disctricts) and features new buildings and girders which happen to be installed over outdoor stealth sections.  For reference, this story also takes place EXACTLY one week after Arkham Origins... so in the week between Christmas and New Year's, which as we all know is the high point of activitiy for construction crews, Gotham City construction workers managed to put up (or at best, relabel) a new skyscraper for GothCorp, AND install girders that support no structural purpose over bad guy hangouts.  This is what happens when the DLC is concepted and sketched out AFTER Gotham City is designed and modeled.-The first two guards you encounter (the ones with the codes) use the same model and skin.  This is especially sloppy considering there are other, uninteractable guards with different models later in the level.-Whoever made the decision to zoom in during the initial dialogue sequence between Alfred and Bruce should be fired.  Both Alfred and Bruce's lips appear to come a good inch away from their faces while speaking, something which is not noticible in later dialogue sequences because they are further zoomed out.  It genuinely looks like a goofy Garry's Mod face.-The DLC is noticibly padded in multiple places - first, with Anarky's "riots" (yes this is the same Anarky you appreheneded a week before in the main game).  By "riots," I mean five or six Anarky guys standing around chatting.  Then breaking up the parts of the Cryo Drill, which are very large but apparently fit well within his utility belt pouches, because why not?  There are another couple of instances, but I'm too bored to point them out.Oh word, remember the part at the beginning of the review where I mentioned bugs?-Don't land too near any frozen guard, or you will be caught in an infinite loop of hovering and attempting to land.-Don't attempt to leave the game before completing a mission objective (especially clearing a room) unless you like having to start the DLC over from scratch - this causes the DLC to clear the room of baddies, and if you were required to interrogate any of them in order to progress, well eff you.-Grappeling is just as buggy and weird as in the main game - you're going to say to yourself "Why can't I grappel there?" A LOT.  I particularly liked it when I grappel to a point just below an armed guard to perform a ledge takedown, only to have Batman hop the ledge and stand in front of the bad guy.  Nice stealth, bro.-Especially on stairs, performing a stealth or ground takedown is buggy, will cause the body to glitch partially through the stairs, and occassionally bounce up wildly into the ceiling.-You will still randomly drop combos, especially when most of the enemies are down but not unconscious.  I know someone will say this so let me go ahead and ask the question - "But y don't u use ground takdown!!1!"  Uh, because the animation is so long that by the time you are finished performing it, anyone else who was on the ground is up and already hitting you or about to.-Using alternate suits in the main game can and will crash the game under random conditions.  This was particularly a problem with the Brightest Day suit.The worst part of this, though, (read the latest patch note comments for reference) is that people are actively swearing off Batman video games because of how broken this game is.  A lot of them don't realize that this is the only Arkham game WB Montreal ever made, and the two previous (and upcoming Arkham Knight) were made by Rocksteady.  I mean, if I were Rocksteady, I would actually draft a press release concerning their disappointment with Arkham Origins, and clarifying that they didn't make it.  If Arkham Kinght underperforms because of this glitchy mess, that would be a real shame.At the end of the day, I got the Season Pass on sale at Amazon for $8.  And I still feel like I got ripped off.  Don't buy either the DLC or the main game unless you don't have enough frustration in your life.  I wouldn't even recommend this to diehard Batman fans.

content:
Posted: January 21, 2014
												I just responded to a friend's positive recommendation of this game with the following and realized that I never "unrecommended" it officially, so here's my lazy copy and paste:Personally, it was by far the weakest of the three games and was definitively generic as opposed to the stellar work of Rocksteady's creations. It was despicably mediocre and clunky and lazy in design. As much as I like Troy Baker and it may have been the voice direction and not his fault, but Joker was not the Joker. He wasn't scary or funny or remarkable in any way. He was a deranged bad guy like any of the others: boring.Pros:- Batman's replacement voice actor- license and established Rocksteady IP- letting us see how Joker sees things- the new detective casesOther than that, it was a♥♥♥♥♥♥poor Arkham City reboot. I have replayed the first 2 games at least 3 times each and will probably go back for more in the future. I hurried to finish Origins so that I wouldn't have to play it again. I was SUPREMELY disappointed and will only purchase another Arkham game if Rocksteady does it.

content:
Posted: May 1, 2014
												First, the bad: The game has some minor bugs I ran into. Nothing game breaking though. The main bug I ran into was that the interrogate mechanic just stopped working on me three different times and I had to reload the last checkpoint to fix it. The game constantly tells you to ctrl+right click to knockout dudes that are on the ground but it almost never does anything when you press it. Also there's one side mission where you get trapped in a dream world and the camera angles are all wonky and it's extremely difficult to get through with the mouse and keyboard. Luckily I have a gamepad but not everyone does. Also there is an entire set of collectibles called "Gotham intel" listed in the menu that I somehow made it through the entire game through without even finding out what these are. Would have been nice if the game bothered to explain any of that stuff.The good: Batman is a badass. A rich jerk badass. It's fun zipping around the city, gliding into packs of criminals/cops/criminal cops and just beating the everloving snot out of them all with your ridiculous gadgets. There's lots of side quests to do, major villians to stop, minor villians to stop, crimes to solve, and dumb hidden trophies ("datapacks" in this one) to collect. The multiplayer: Didn't play it, don't care. The single player is the reason to get this game.

The relationship with Joker is masterfully explored and this is a worthy addition in this flawed but awesome franchise!Batman: Arkham Origins Impressions:I was not hyped for this game. I believed Arkham City was an outstanding game, but still overhyped. This game is basically the same game that Arkham City was with a diffrent story line. Are there some tweeks? Yes, for sure, but in the end, the bad press Origins recieves is not earned, the diffrent voice cast does not dissappoint either.The game is not only NOT as bad as they say... it is a very good game, that ought to be played by everyone who loved the previous games, and/or likes Batman.I deffinetly recommend this.(Knowing what Initiation DLC would be before buying it - simple maps forced into a non-existing story line - it did not dissappoint either)Batman Arkham Origins - Cold, Cold Heart: 9/10 - Strongly Recommended for fans of Arkham OriginsCold, Cold Heart Impressions:Arkham games have earned their bad rep with DLC, so it is always refreshing to see such an impressive post game add on with pre-rendered cut scenes, in-engine cut-scenes, new locations, new enemy types and two suits (one for Bruce and one for Bats) and a change of light for the open city sections of South Gotham. I think there should be industry standards, what is called DLC, what is an Expansion and in this case a mini-Expansion.Clocking in at barely 3 hours, it does not deserve to be called "Expansion", but it includes more, than all other Season Pass content together for this game! So it also does not deserve to be called merely a DLC...On the downside, the pre-rendered cut scenes seem not to be full HD, and the Anarky tags are a pain... but otherwise this is all that makes the Arkham Games so beloved compressed into very entertaining 3 hours...

content:
Posted: February 7, 2014
												I'll start off by saying, This game gets -far- too much flak. Is it as good as City or Asylum? No. Is it a step down for the series? Yes. Is it a step back? No. It's not, but it's not a step forward either. The game is essentially Arkham City all over again, the same combat mechanics, and a few gadgets that can make things insanely simple. Notably, the Remote Claw, which allows you to hang thugs up from the rafters, at range. Did it have a horribly glitchy release? Definitely. And there's no excuse for that, patches or not. The bugs should've been ironed out. I myself, was lucky enough to not encounter any on my first playthrough. The mechanics are much the same as City, though it's a common complaint that thugs can hit you, even if you're countering someone else. As I would politely put it, "Well... yeah?" It's not a new thing. It happens in City. You try countering someone, and expecting it to stop the path of a giant hammer in City, see what happens. Takedowns are a different story in both games, but it leads me to my greatest issue with Origins. The Dark Knight System. As you play the game, you will be continually graded on your performace, complete with marks, and awarded EXP accordingly. However, the Dark Knight System seems to reward grandstanding more than efficentcy. The Combat -is- somewhat harder, enemies are faster, and will corner you, and attempt to dogpile you with a flurry of hits, if you don't think tactically. Origins is the first Arkham Game where i've actively started using Gadgets in combat, from a few quick batarangs to a glue grenade or my standard Batclaw. The new Batman voice seems.. fitting, though it's jarring to not have Conroy at the helm. This younger Batman is meant to be more aggressive, and he definitely sounds it. On the other end of the spectrum, Joker is -close- to hamill's voice, but it's different enough to seem -very- off. Joker always seems like he's rehearsed his lines, and while it's true for the voice actor, it's something Hamill never dealt with. Joker's voice and actions, always seemed to be completely in tune.The boss battles are an improvement over City, a couple of them can be nightmarishly hard on Hard New Game +, for example, Copperhead. A common complaint is that the boss Deathstroke is too difficult. After careful examination of the fight, i've managed to deduce why people claim this. They're too busy looking for a Win button. Deathstroke is -insanely- simple, on any and every difficulty. I got the achievement for beating him without a scratch on Hard New Game +, and i'd of gotten it on hard, if I hadn't been having a conversation while I played.The game is harder, slightly. The story however... for me, is a disappointment. It felt as though they were -afraid- to change anything up, and after a particular point in the game, to do with a bank, I was left annoyed at the story. The Deathstroke DLC is quite fun, Deathstroke himself handles well, and hits hard. It's fun to play, and makes me wish for a Deathstroke game.This game isn't City, or Asylum. It's the worst of the franchise. But when a franchise is -this- good overall, even the least of it, is pretty damn good. If you beat City, and wished it was longer, or just wanted another story with the same general mechanics, this is for you. It's not big on innovation, but not all games need to be. We'll get that from Rocksteady. If you're not a fan, i'd either go back to Asylum and City, or wait for Rocksteady to release their next.

												I do recommend this game but I think overall it's pretty meh. I did have fun playing it but it's more of the same compared to the last game. I think I mostly like it because of the combat but I did feel it was more frustrating than last time. The moves were not as telegraphed and it was definitely harder to counter this time around. I would say that the gadgets♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥me off because they were the same as the previous game even though this was supposed to be a prequel. It doesn't make any sense that he was creating the gadgets in the last game when he could have just summoned them. The inconsistency can agitate you, it would have been nice to have more original gadgets.For me I got into it because the story was good and I liked the idea of playing a prequel. The combat was enough for me to keep playing the game. I figure pick this up when it's on sale and you'll have an OK time. I didn't play any of the online modes so I cannot speak about that. I also didn't experience any bugs that ruined my experience.

Yes, I'm looking at you Bane and Riddler!So by all means, buy it and enjoy it, because it is actually pretty good. Just be mindful of a few things if you've played the other two Arkham games.

												There's something about this game that isn't as good as the previous, still has good combat and story, It's simple enough, if you enjoyed the other two Arkham games you're going enjoy Batman: Arkham Origins. Combat system is much more refined, with new moves, better mechanics, with every punch feeling more satisfying than before. The main storyline is fantastic and shows us the beginning of Batman's career and how he deals with meeting many of his enemies for the first time. Overall, Batman: Arkham Origins was full of glitches and bugs and simply was not polished like the previous Arkham games.As a huge Arkham fan I can honestly tell you that now all of those bugs and glitches are fixed and that you should get this game.8/10

												Очень переживал за данный проект, так как за разработку взялась другая команда и как выяснилось зря! Разработчикам все таки удалось грамотно использовать базу, созданную когда-то Rocksteady и при этом добавить что-то свое! Да, в игре практически ничего изменилось со времен Arkham City, что в приницпе было ожидаемо, т.к. игра является приквелом к серии, но это не делает игру хуже предыдущих! Сюжет как всегда на высоте! Очень рад был увидеть отсылку на свой любимый комикс "Killing Joke", а также развитие сюжета, сделанное по мотивам события вселенной Бэтмена "Knightfall" (одно из самых важных). Очень понравился Альфред, а также был в восторге от режима детектива! Вердикт: однозначный "Must have!" И все критики, которые ставят игре 7.5 и просто хотели новых фишек от ПРИКВЕЛА - глупцы! Пусть засунут свое мнение куда подальше! Да... она не побила рекорд Arkham Asylum, но оценку отлично она отработала полностью! (9,5/10)
